<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This tale grew in the telling, until it became a history of the Great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">War of the Ring and included many glimpses of the yet more ancient history<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that preceded it. It was begun soon after The Hobbit was written and before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its publication in 1937; but I did not go on with this sequel, for I wished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first to complete and set in order the mythology and legends of the Elder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Days, which had then been taking shape for some years. I desired to do this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for my own satisfaction, and I had little hope that other people would be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">interested in this work, especially since it was primarily linguistic in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inspiration and was begun in order to provide the necessary background of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'history' for Elvish tongues.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When those whose advice and opinion I sought corrected little hope to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no hope, I went back to the sequel, encouraged by requests from readers for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more information concerning hobbits and their adventures. But the story was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drawn irresistibly towards the older world, and became an account, as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were, of its end and passing away before its beginning and middle had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">told. The process had begun in the writing of The Hobbit, in which there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were already some references to the older matter: Elrond, Gondolin, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">High-elves, and the ores, as well as glimpses that had arisen unbidden of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things higher or deeper or darker than its surface: Durin, Moria, Gandalf,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Necromancer, the Ring. The discovery of the significance of these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimpses and of their relation to the ancient histories revealed the Third<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Age and its culmination in the War of the Ring.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Those who had asked for more information about hobbits eventually got<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, but they had to wait a long time; for the composition of The Lord of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rings went on at intervals during the years 1936 to 1949, a period in which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I had many duties that I did not neglect, and many other interests as a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">learner and teacher that often absorbed me. The delay was, of course, also<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">increased by the outbreak of war in 1939, by the end of which year the tale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had not yet reached the end of Book One. In spite of the darkness of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">next five years I found that the story could not now be wholly abandoned,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I plodded on, mostly by night, till I stood by Balin's tomb in Moria.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There I halted for a long while. It was almost a year later when I went on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and so came to Lothlurien and the Great River late in 1941. In the next year<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I wrote the first drafts of the matter that now stands as Book Three, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the beginnings of chapters I and III of Book Five; and there as the beacons<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flared in Anurien and Thjoden came to Harrowdale I stopped. Foresight had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">failed and there was no time for thought.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was during 1944 that, leaving the loose ends and perplexities of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">war which it was my task to conduct, or at least to report, 1 forced myself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to tackle the journey of Frodo to Mordor. These chapters, eventually to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become Book Four, were written and sent out as a serial to my son,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Christopher, then in South Africa with the RAF. Nonetheless it took another<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">five years before the tale was brought to its present end; in that time I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">changed my house, my chair, and my college, and the days though less dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were no less laborious. Then when the â€™endâ€™ had at last been reached the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whole story had to be revised, and indeed largely re-written backwards. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it had to be typed, and re-typed: by me; the cost of professional typing by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ten-fingered was beyond my means.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Lord of the Rings has been read by many people since it finally<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared in print; and I should like to say something here with reference to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the many opinions or guesses that I have received or have read concerning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the motives and meaning of the tale. The prime motive was the desire of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tale-teller to try his hand at a really long story that would hold the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">attention of readers, amuse them, delight them, and at times maybe excite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them or deeply move them. As a guide I had only my own feelings for what is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appealing or moving, and for many the guide was inevitably often at fault.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Some who have read the book, or at any rate have reviewed it, have found it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boring, absurd, or contemptible; and I have no cause to complain, since I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have similar opinions of their works, or of the kinds of writing that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evidently prefer. But even from the points of view of many who have enjoyed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my story there is much that fails to please. It is perhaps not possible in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long tale to please everybody at all points, nor to displease everybody at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the same points; for I find from the letters that I have received that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passages or chapters that are to some a blemish are all by others specially<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">approved. The most critical reader of all, myself, now finds many defects,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">minor and major, but being fortunately under no obligation either to review<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the book or to write it again, he will pass over these in silence, except<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one that has been noted by others: the book is too short.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As for any inner meaning or 'message', it has in the intention of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">author none. It is neither allegorical nor topical. As the story grew it put<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down roots (into the past) and threw out unexpected branches: but its main<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">theme was settled from the outset by the inevitable choice of the Ring as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the link between it and The Hobbit. The crucial chapter, "The Shadow of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Past', is one of the oldest parts of the tale. It was written long before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the foreshadow of 1939 had yet become a threat of inevitable disaster, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from that point the story would have developed along essentially the same<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lines, if that disaster had been averted. Its sources are things long before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in mind, or in some cases already written, and little or nothing in it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">modified by the war that began in 1939 or its sequels.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The real war does not resemble the legendary war in its process or its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conclusion. If it had inspired or directed the development of the legend,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then certainly the Ring would have been seized and used against Sauron; he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would not have been annihilated but enslaved, and Barad-dyr would not have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been destroyed but occupied. Saruman, failing to get possession of the Ring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would m the confusion and treacheries of the time have found in Mordor the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">missing links in his own researches into Ring-lore, and before long he would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have made a Great Ring of his own with which to challenge the self-styled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ruler of Middle-earth. In that conflict both sides would have held hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in hatred and contempt: they would not long have survived even as slaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Other arrangements could be devised according to the tastes or views of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those who like allegory or topical reference. But I cordially dislike<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">allegory in all its manifestations, and always have done so since I grew old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and wary enough to detect its presence. I much prefer history, true or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feigned, with its varied applicability to the thought and experience of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">readers. I think that many confuse 'applicability' with 'allegory'; but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one resides in the freedom of the reader, and the other in the purposed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">domination of the author.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">An author cannot of course remain wholly unaffected by his experience,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the ways in which a story-germ uses the soil of experience are extremely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">complex, and attempts to define the process are at best guesses from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evidence that is inadequate and ambiguous. It is also false, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">naturally attractive, when the lives of an author and critic have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">overlapped, to suppose that the movements of thought or the events of times<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">common to both were necessarily the most powerful influences. One has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">personally to come under the shadow of war to feel fully its oppression; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as the years go by it seems now often forgotten that to be caught in youth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by 1914 was no less hideous an experience than to be involved in 1939 and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the following years. By 1918 all but one of my close friends were dead. Or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to take a less grievous matter: it has been supposed by some that The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Scouring of the Shireâ€™ reflects the situation in England at the time when I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was finishing my tale. It does not. It is an essential part of the plot,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foreseen from the outset, though in the event modified by the character of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Saruman as developed in the story without, need I say, any allegorical<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">significance or contemporary political reference whatsoever. It has indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some basis in experience, though slender (for the economic situation was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">entirely different), and much further back. The country in which I lived in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">childhood was being shabbily destroyed before I was ten, in days when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">motor-cars were rare objects (I had never seen one) and men were still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">building suburban railways. Recently I saw in a paper a picture of the last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">decrepitude of the once thriving corn-mill beside its pool that long ago<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to me so important. I never liked the looks of the Young miller, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his father, the Old miller, had a black beard, and he was not named<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sandy man.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Lord of the Rings is now issued in a new edition, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">opportunity has been taken of revising it. A number of errors and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inconsistencies that still remained in the text have been corrected, and an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">attempt has been made to provide information on a few points which attentive<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">readers have raised. I have considered all their comments and enquiries, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if some seem to have been passed over that may be because I have failed to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">keep my notes in order; but many enquiries could only be answered by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">additional appendices, or indeed by the production of an accessory volume<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">containing much of the material that I did not include in the original<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">edition, in particular more detailed linguistic information. In the meantime<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this edition offers this Foreword, an addition to the Prologue, some notes,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and an index of the names of persons and places. This index is in intention<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">complete in items but not in references, since for the present purpose it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has been necessary to reduce its bulk. A complete index, making full use of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the material prepared for me by Mrs. N. Smith, belongs rather to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accessory volume.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">* PROLOGUE *<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">1. Concerning Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This book is largely concerned with Hobbits, and from its pages a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reader may discover much of their character and a little of their history.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Further information will also be found in the selection from the Red Book of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Westmarch that has already been published, under the title of The Hobbit.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That story was derived from the earlier chapters of the Red Book, composed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by Bilbo himself, the first Hobbit to become famous in the world at large,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and called by him There and Back Again, since they told of his journey into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the East and his return: an adventure which later involved all the Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the great events of that Age that are here related.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Many, however, may wish to know more about this remarkable people<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the outset, while some may not possess the earlier book. For such readers a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">few notes on the more important points are here collected from Hobbit-lore,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the first adventure is briefly recalled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits are an unobtrusive but very ancient people, more numerous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">formerly than they are today; for they love peace and quiet and good tilled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">earth: a well-ordered and well-farmed countryside was their favourite haunt.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They do not and did not understand or like machines more complicated than a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forge -bellows, a water-mill, or a hand-loom, though they were skilful with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tools. Even in ancient days they were, as a rule, shy of 'the Big Folk', as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they call us, and now they avoid us with dismay and are becoming hard to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find. They are quick of hearing and sharp-eyed, and though they are inclined<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be fat and do not hurry unnecessarily, they are nonetheless nimble and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deft in their movements. They possessed from the first the art of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disappearing swiftly and silently, when large folk whom they do not wish to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meet come blundering by; and this an they have developed until to Men it may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seem magical. But Hobbits have never, in fact, studied magic of any kind,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and their elusiveness is due solely to a professional skill that heredity<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and practice, and a close friendship with the earth, have rendered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inimitable by bigger and clumsier races.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For they are a little people, smaller than Dwarves: less tout and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stocky, that is, even when they are not actually much shorter. Their height<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is variable, ranging between two and four feet of our measure. They seldom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now reach three feet; but they hive dwindled, they say, and in ancient days<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were taller. According to the Red Book, Bandobras Took (Bullroarer),<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">son of Isengrim the Second, was four foot five and able to ride a horse. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was surpassed in all Hobbit records only by two famous characters of old;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but that curious matter is dealt with in this book.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As for the Hobbits of the Shire, with whom these tales are concerned,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the days of their peace and prosperity they were a merry folk. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dressed in bright colours, being notably fond of yellow and green; but they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seldom wore shoes, since their feet had tough leathery soles and were clad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a thick curling hair, much like the hair of their heads, which was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">commonly brown. Thus, the only craft little practised among them was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoe-making; but they had long and skilful fingers and could make many other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">useful and comely things. Their faces were as a rule good-natured rather<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than beautiful, broad, bright-eyed, red-cheeked, with mouths apt to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laughter, and to eating and drinking. And laugh they did, and eat, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drink, often and heartily, being fond of simple jests at all times, and of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">six meals a day (when they could get them). They were hospitable and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delighted in parties, and in presents, which they gave away freely and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eagerly accepted.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is plain indeed that in spite of later estrangement Hobbits are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">relatives of ours: far nearer to us than Elves, or even than Dwarves. Of old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they spoke the languages of Men, after their own fashion, and liked and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disliked much the same things as Men did. But what exactly our relationship<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is can no longer be discovered. The beginning of Hobbits lies far back in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Elder Days that are now lost and forgotten. Only the Elves still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">preserve any records of that vanished time, and their traditions are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">concerned almost entirely with their own history, in which Men appear seldom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Hobbits are not mentioned at all. Yet it is clear that Hobbits had, in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fact, lived quietly in Middle-earth for many long years before other folk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became even aware of them. And the world being after all full of strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creatures beyond count, these little people seemed of very little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">importance. But in the days of Bilbo, and of Frodo his heir, they suddenly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became, by no wish of their own, both important and renowned, and troubled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the counsels of the Wise and the Great.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Those days, the Third Age of Middle -earth, are now long past, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shape of all lands has been changed; but the regions in which Hobbits then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lived were doubtless the same as those in which they still linger: the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">North-West of the Old World, east of the Sea. Of their original home the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits in Bilbo's time preserved no knowledge. A love of learning (other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than genealogical lore) was far from general among them, but there remained<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still a few in the older families who studied their own books, and even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gathered reports of old times and distant lands from Elves, Dwarves, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Men. Their own records began only after the settlement of the Shire, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their most ancient legends hardly looked further back than their Wandering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Days. It is clear, nonetheless, from these legends, and from the evidence of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their peculiar words and customs, that like many other folk Hobbits had in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the distant past moved westward. Their earliest tales seem to glimpse a time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they dwelt in the upper vales of Anduin, between the eaves of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Greenwood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Great and the Misty Mountains. Why they later undertook the hard and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perilous crossing of the mountains into Eriador is no longer certain. Their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own accounts speak of the multiplying of Men in the land, and of a shadow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that fell on the forest, so that it became darkened and its new name was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mirkwood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before the crossing of the mountains the Hobbits had already become<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">divided into three somewhat different breeds: Harfoots, Stoors, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fallohides. The Harfoots were browner of skin, smaller, and shorter, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were beardless and bootless; their hands and feet were neat and nimble;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they preferred highlands and hillsides. The Stoors were broader, heavier<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in build; their feet and hands were larger, and they preferred flat lands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and riversides. The Fallohides were fairer of skin and also of hair, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were taller and slimmer than the others; they were lovers of trees and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of woodlands.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Harfoots had much to do with Dwarves in ancient times, and long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lived in the foothills of the mountains. They moved westward early, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roamed over Eriador as far as Weathertop while the others were still in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wilderland. They were the most normal and representative variety of Hobbit,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and far the most numerous. They were the most inclined to settle in one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">place, and longest preserved their ancestral habit of living in tunnels and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">holes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Stoors lingered long by the banks of the Great River Anduin, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were less shy of Men. They came west after the Harfoots and followed the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course of the Loudwater southwards; and there many of them long dwelt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between Tharbad and the borders of Dunland before they moved north again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Fallohides, the least numerous, were a northerly branch. They were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more friendly with Elves than the other Hobbits were, and had more skill in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">language and song than in handicrafts; and of old they preferred hunting to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tilling. They crossed the mountains north of Rivendell and came down the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River Hoarwell. In Eriador they soon mingled with the other kinds that had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">preceded them, but being somewhat bolder and more adventurous, they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">often found as leaders or chieftains among clans of Harfoots or Stoors. Even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Bilbo's time the strong Fallohidish strain could still be noted among the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greater families, such as the Tooks and the Masters of Buckland.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the westlands of Eriador, between the Misty Mountains and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains of Lune, the Hobbits found both Men and Elves. Indeed, a remnant<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still dwelt there of the DÂ®nedain, the kings of Men that came over the Sea<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of Westernesse; but they were dwindling fast and the lands of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">North Kingdom were falling far and wide into waste. There was room and to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spare for incomers, and ere long the Hobbits began to settle in ordered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">communities. Most of their earlier settlements had long disappeared and been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgotten in Bilbo's time; but one of the first to become important still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">endured, though reduced in size; this was at Bree and in the Chetwood that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lay round about, some forty miles east of the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was in these early days, doubtless, that the Hobbits learned their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letters and began to write after the manner of the DÂ®nedain, who had in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their turn long before learned the art from the Elves. And in those days<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also they forgot whatever languages they had used before, and spoke ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after the Common Speech, the Westron as it was named, that was current<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through all the lands of the kings from Arnor to Gondor, and about all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coasts of the Sea from B elf alas to Lune. Yet they kept a few words of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own, as well as their own names of months and days, and a great store of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">personal names out of the past.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">About this time legend among the Hobbits first becomes history with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reckoning of years. For it was in the one thousand six hundred and first<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year of the Third Age that the Fallohide brothers, Marcho and Blanco, set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out from Bree; and having obtained permission from the high king at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fornostl, they crossed the brown river Baranduin with a great following of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits. They passed over the Bridge of Stonebows, that had been built in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the days of the power of the North Kingdom, and they took ail the land<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond to dwell in, between the river and the Far Downs. All that was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">demanded of them was that they should keep the Great Bridge in repair, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all other bridges and roads, speed the king's messengers, and acknowledge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his lordship.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Thus began the Shire-reckoning, for the year of the crossing of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandywine (as the Hobbits turned the name) became Year One of the Shire,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and all later dates were reckoned from it. 2 At once the western Hobbits fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in love with their new land, and they remained there, and soon passed once<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more out of the history of Men and of Elves. While there was still a king<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were in name his subjects, but they were, in fact, ruled by their own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chieftains and meddled not at all with events in the world outside. To the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last battle at Fornost with the Witch-lord of Angmar they sent some bowmen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the aid of the king, or so they maintained, though no tales of Men record<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. But in that war the North Kingdom ended; and then the Hobbits took the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land for their own, and they chose from their own chiefs a Thain to hold the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">authority of the king that was gone. There for a thousand years they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little troubled by wars, and they prospered and multiplied after the Dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Plague (S.R. 37) until the disaster of the Long Winter and the famine that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed it. Many thousands then perished, but the Days of Dearth (1158-60)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were at the time of this tale long past and the Hobbits had again become<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accustomed to plenty. The land was rich and kindly, and though it had long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been deserted when they entered it, it had before been well tilled, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there the king had once had many farms, cornlands, vineyards, and woods.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Forty leagues it stretched from the Far Downs to the Brandywine Bridge,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and fifty from the northern moors to the marshes in the south. The Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">named it the Shire, as the region of the authority of their Thain, and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">district of well-ordered business; and there in that pleasant comer of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">world they plied their well-ordered business of living, and they heeded less<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and less the world outside where dark things moved, until they came to think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that peace and plenty were the rule in Middle-earth and the right of all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sensible folk. They forgot or ignored what little they had ever known of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Guardians, and of the labours of those that made possible the long peace of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire. They were, in fact, sheltered, but they had ceased to remember<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At no time had Hobbits of any kind been warlike, and they had never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fought among themselves. In olden days they had, of course, been often<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">obliged to fight to maintain themselves in a hard world; but in Bilbo's time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that was very ancient history. The last battle, before this story opens, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed the only one that had ever been fought within the borders of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire, was beyond living memory: the Battle of Greenfields, S.R. 1147, in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which Bandobras Took routed an invasion of Ores. Even the weathers had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">milder, and the wolves that had once come ravening out of the North in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bitter white winters were now only a grandfather's tale. So, though there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was still some store of weapons in the Shire, these were used mostly as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trophies, hanging above hearths or on walls, or gathered into the museum at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Michel Delving. The Mathom-house it was called; for anything that Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had no immediate use for, but were unwilling to throw away, they called a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mathom. Their dwellings were apt to become rather crowded with mathoms,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many of the presents that passed from hand to hand were of that son.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nonetheless, ease and peace had left this people still curiously tough.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They were, if it came to it, difficult to daunt or to kill; and they were,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps, so unwearyingly fond of good things not least because they could,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when put to it, do without them, and could survive rough handling by grief,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foe, or weather in a way that astonished those who did not know them well<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and looked no further than their bellies and their well-fed faces. Though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slow to quarrel, and for sport killing nothing that lived, they were doughty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at bay, and at need could still handle arms. They shot well with the bow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for they were keen-eyed and sure at the mark. Not only with bows and arrows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">If any Hobbit stooped for a stone, it was well to get quickly under cover,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as all trespassing beasts knew very well.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All Hobbits had originally lived in holes in the ground, or so they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">believed, and in such dwellings they still felt most at home; but in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course of time they had been obliged to adopt other forms of abode. Actually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Shire in Bilbo's days it was, as a rule, only the richest and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">poorest Hobbits that maintained the old custom. The poorest went on living<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in burrows of the most primitive kind, mere holes indeed, with only one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">window or none; while the well-to-do still constructed more luxurious<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">versions of the simple diggings of old. But suitable sites for these large<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and ramifying tunnels (or smicils as they called them) were not everywhere to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be found; and in the flats and the low-lying districts the Hobbits, as they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">multiplied, began to build above ground. Indeed, even in the hilly regions<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the older villages, such as Hobbiton or Tuckborough, or in the chief<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">township of the Shire, Michel Delving on the White Downs, there were now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many houses of wood, brick, or stone. These were specially favoured by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">millers, smiths, ropers, and Cartwrights, and others of that sort; for even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they had holes to live in. Hobbits had long been accustomed to build<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sheds and workshops.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The habit of building farmhouses and barns was said to have begun among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the inhabitants of the Marish down by the Brandywine. The Hobbits of that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quarter, the Eastfarthing, were rather large and heavy-legged, and they wore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf-boots in muddy weather. But they were well known to be Stoors in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large part of their blood, as indeed was shown by the down that many grew on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their chins. No Harfoot or Fallohide had any trace of a beard. Indeed, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk of the Marish, and of Buckland, east of the River, which they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afterwards occupied, came for the most part later into the Shire up from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">south-away; and they still had many peculiar names and strange words not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found elsewhere in the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is probable that the craft of building, as many other crafts beside,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was derived from the DÂ®nedain. But the Hobbits may have learned it direct<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the Elves, the teachers of Men in their youth. For the Elves of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">High Kindred had not yet forsaken Middle-earth, and they dwelt still at that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time at the Grey Havens away to the west, and in other places within reach<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Shire. Three Elf-towers of immemorial age were still to be seen on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Tower Hills beyond the western marches. They shone far off in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moonlight. The tallest was furthest away, standing alone upon a green mound.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Hobbits of the Westfarthing said that one could see the Sea from the lop<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of that tower; but no Hobbit had ever been known to climb it. Indeed, few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits had ever seen or sailed upon the Sea, and fewer still had ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">returned to report it. Most Hobbits regarded even rivers and small boats<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with deep misgivings, and not many of them could swim. And as the days of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire lengthened they spoke less and less with the Elves, and grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afraid of them, and distrustful of those that had dealings with them; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Sea became a word of fear among them, and a token of death, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turned their faces away from the hills in the west.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The craft of building may have come from Elves or Men, but the Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used it in their own fashion. They did not go in for towers. Their houses<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were usually long, low, and comfortable. The oldest kind were, indeed, no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more than built imitations of smials, thatched with dry grass or straw, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roofed with turves, and having walls somewhat bulged. That stage, however,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">belonged to the early days of the Shire, and hobbit -building had long since<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been altered, improved by devices, learned from Dwarves, or discovered by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves. A preference for round windows, and even round doors, was the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chief remaining peculiarity of hobbit-architecture.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The houses and the holes of Shire-hobbits were often large, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inhabited by large families. (Bilbo and Frodo Baggins were as bachelors very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">exceptional, as they were also in many other ways, such as their friendship<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the Elves.) Sometimes, as in the case of the Tooks of Great Smials, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Brandybucks of Brandy Hall, many generations of relatives lived in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(comparative) peace together in one ancestral and many -tunnelled mansion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All Hobbits were, in any case, clannish and reckoned up their relationships<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with great care. They drew long and elaborate family -trees with innumerable<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches. In dealing with Hobbits it is important to remember who is related<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to whom, and in what degree. It would be impossible in this book to set out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a family -tree that included even the more important members of the more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">important families at the time which these tales tell of. The genealogical<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees at the end of the Red Book of Westmarch are a small book in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves, and all but Hobbits would find them exceedingly dull. Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delighted in such things, if they were accurate: they liked to have books<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">filled with things that they already knew, set out fair and square with no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">contradictions.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">2. Concerning Pipe-weed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There is another astonishing thing about Hobbits of old that must be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mentioned, an astonishing habit: they imbibed or inhaled, through pipes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clay or wood, the smoke of the burning leaves of a herb, which they called<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pipe-weed or leaf, a variety probably of Nicotiana. A great deal of mystery<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">surrounds the origin of this peculiar custom, or 'art' as the Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">preferred to call it. All that could be discovered about it in antiquity was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">put together by Meriadoc Brandybuck (later Master of Buckland), and since he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the tobacco of the Southfarthing play a part in the history that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">follows, his remarks in the introduction to his Herblore of the Shire may be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quoted.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™This,' he says, 'is the one art that we can certainly claim to be our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own invention. When Hobbits first began to smoke is not known, all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">legends and family histories take it for granted; for ages folk in the Shire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smoked various herbs, some fouler, some sweeter. But all accounts agree that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tobold Hornblower of Longbottom in the Southfarthing first grew the true<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pipe-weed in his gardens in the days of Isengrim the Second, about the year<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">1070 of Shire-reckoning. The best home-grown still comes from that district,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">especially the varieties now known as Longbottom Leaf, Old Toby, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Southern Star.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How Old Toby came by the plant is not recorded, for to his dying day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he would not tell. He knew much about herbs, but he was no traveller. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said that in his youth he went often to Bree, though he certainly never went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">further from the Shire than that. It is thus quite possible that he learned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of this plant in Bree, where now, at any rate, it grows well on the south<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slopes of the hill. The Bree-hobbits claim to have been the first actual<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smokers of the pipe-weed. They claim, of course, to have done everything<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before the people of the Shire, whom they refer to as "colonists"; but in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this case their claim is, I think, likely to be true. And certainly it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Bree that the art of smoking the genuine weed spread in the recent<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">centuries among Dwarves and such other folk, Rangers, Wizards, or wanderers,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as still passed to and fro through that ancient road-meeting. The home and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">centre of the an is thus to be found in the old inn of Bree, The Prancing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pony, that has been kept by the family of Butterbur from time beyond record.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All the same, observations that I have made on my own many journeys<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">south have convinced me that the weed itself is not native to our parts of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the world, but came northward from the lower Anduin, whither it was, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suspect, originally brought over Sea by the Men of Westernesse. It grows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">abundantly in Gondor, and there is richer and larger than in the North,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where it is never found wild, and flourishes only in warm sheltered places<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like Longbottom. The Men of Gondor call it sweet galenas, and esteem it only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the fragrance of its flowers. From that land it must have been carried<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up the Greenway during the long centuries between the coming of Elendil and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">our own day. But even the DÂ®nedain of Gondor allow us this credit: Hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first put it into pipes. Not even the Wizards first thought of that before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we did. Though one Wizard that I knew took up the art long ago, and became<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as skilful in it as in all other things that he put his mind to.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">3. Of the Ordering of the Shire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Shire was divided into four quarters, the Farthings already<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">referred to. North, South, East, and West; and these again each into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">number of folklands, which still bore the names of some of the old leading<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">families, although by the time of this history these names were no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found only in their proper folklands. Nearly all Tooks still lived in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tookland, but that was not true of many other families, such as the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bagginses or the Boffins. Outside the Farthings were the East and West<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Marches: the Buckland (see beginning of Chapter V, Book I); and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Westmarch added to the Shire in S.R. 1462.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Shire at this time had hardly any 'government'. Families for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">most part managed their own affairs. Growing food and eating it occupied<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">most of their time. In other matters they were, as a rule, generous and not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greedy, but contented and moderate, so that estates, farms, workshops, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small trades tended to remain unchanged for generations.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There remained, of course, the ancient tradition concerning the high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">king at Fornost, or Norbury as they called it, away north of the Shire. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
