<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there had been no king for nearly a thousand years, and even the ruins of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Kings' Norbury were covered with grass. Yet the Hobbits still said of wild<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk and wicked things (such as trolls) that they had not heard of the king.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For they attributed to the king of old all their essential laws; and usually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they kept the laws of free will, because they were The Rules (as they said),<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">both ancient and just.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is true that the Took family had long been pre-eminent; for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">office of Thain had passed to them (from the Oldbucks) some centuries<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before, and the chief Took had borne that title ever since. The Thain was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the master of the Shire-moot, and captain of the Shire-muster and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbitry-in-arms, but as muster and moot were only held in times of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">emergency, which no longer occurred, the Thainship had ceased to be more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than a nominal dignity. The Took family was still, indeed, accorded a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">special respect, for it remained both numerous and exceedingly wealthy, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was liable to produce in every generation strong characters of peculiar<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">habits and even adventurous temperament. The latter qualities, however, were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now rather tolerated (in the rich) than generally approved. The custom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">endured, nonetheless, of referring to the head of the family as The Took,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and of adding to his name, if required, a number: such as Isengrim the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Second, for instance.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The only real official in the Shire at this date was the Mayor of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Michel Delving (or of the Shire), who was elected every seven years at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Free Fair on the White Downs at the Lithe, that is at Midsummer. As mayor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost his only duty was to preside at banquets, given on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire-holidays, which occurred at frequent intervals. But the offices of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Postmaster and First Shirriff were attached to the mayoralty, so that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">managed both the Messenger Service and the Watch. These were the only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire-services, and the Messengers were the most numerous, and much the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">busier of the two. By no means all Hobbits were lettered, but those who were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wrote constantly to all their friends (and a selection of their relations)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who lived further off than an afternoon's walk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Shirriffs was the name that the Hobbits gave to their police, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the nearest equivalent that they possessed. They had, of course, no uniforms<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(such things being quite unknown), only a feather in their caps; and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were in practice rather haywards than policemen, more concerned with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strayings of beasts than of people. There were in all the Shire only twelve<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of them, three in each Farthing, for Inside Work. A rather larger body,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">varying at need, was employed to 'beat the boundsâ€™, and to see that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Outsiders of any kind, great or small, did not make themselves a nuisance.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the time when this story begins the Bounders, as they were called,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had been greatly increased. There were many reports and complaints of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strange persons and creatures prowling about the borders, or over them: the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first sign that all was not quite as it should be, and always had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">except in tales and legends of long ago. Few heeded the sign, and not even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo yet had any notion of what it portended. Sixty years had passed since<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he set out on his memorable journey, and he was old even for Hobbits, who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached a hundred as often as not; but much evidently still remained of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">considerable wealth that he had brought back. How much or how little he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">revealed to no one, not even to Frodo his favourite 'nephew'. And he still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kept secret the ring that he bad found.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">4. Of the Finding of the Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As is told in The Hobbit , there came one day to Bilbo's door the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wizard, Gandalf the Grey, and thirteen dwarves with him: none other, indeed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than Thorin Oakenshield, descendant of kings, and his twelve companions in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">exile. With them he set out, to his own lasting astonishment, on a morning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of April, it being then the year 1341 Shire-reckoning, on a quest of great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treasure, the dwarf-hoards of the Kings under the Mountain, beneath Erebor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Dale, far off in the East. The quest was successful, and the Dragon that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guarded the hoard was destroyed. Yet, though before all was won the Battle<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Five Armies was fought, and Thorin was slain, and many deeds of renown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were done, the matter would scarcely have concerned later history, or earned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more than a note in the long annals of the Third Age, but for an 'accident'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by the way. The party was assailed by Ores in a high pass of the Misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains as they went towards Wilderland; and so it happened that Bilbo was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lost for a while in the black ore-mines deep under the mountains, and there,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as he groped in vain in the dark, he put his hand on a ring, lying on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">floor of a tunnel. Ele put it in his pocket. It seemed then like mere luck.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Trying to find his way out. Bilbo went on down to the roots of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains, until he could go no further. At the bottom of the tunnel lay a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold lake far from the light, and on an island of rock in the water lived<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gollum. He was a loathsome little creature: he paddled a small boat with his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large flat feet, peering with pale luminous eyes and catching blind fish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with his long fingers, and eating them raw. He ate any living thing, even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ore, if he could catch it and strangle it without a struggle. He possessed a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secret treasure that had come to him long ages ago, when he still lived in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the light: a ring of gold that made its wearer invisible. It was the one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing he loved, his 'precious', and he talked to it, even when it was not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with him. For he kept it hidden safe in a hole on his island, except when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was hunting or spying on the ores of the mines.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maybe he would have attacked Bilbo at once, if the ring had been on him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they met; but it was not, and the hobbit held in his hand an Elvish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knife, which served him as a sword. So to gain time Gollum challenged Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Riddle-game, saying that if he asked a riddle which Bilbo could not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guess, then he would kill him and eat him; but if Bilbo defeated him, then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he would do as Bilbo wished: he would lead him to a way out of the tunnels.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Since he was lost in the dark without hope, and could neither go on nor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back. Bilbo accepted the challenge; and they asked one another many riddles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the end Bilbo won the game, more by luck (as it seemed) than by wits; for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was stumped at last for a riddle to ask, and cried out, as his hand came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon the ring he lad picked up and forgotten: What haw I got in my pocket?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This Gollum failed to answer, though he demanded three guesses.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Authorities, it is true, differ whether this last question was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mere 'question' and not a 'riddle' according to the strict rules of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Game; but all agree that, after accepting it and trying to guess the answer,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gollum was bound by his promise. And Bilbo pressed him to keep his word;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the thought came to him that this slimy creature might prove false, even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though such promises were held sacred, and of old all but the wickedest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things feared to break them. But after ages alone in the dark Gollum's heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was black, and treachery was in it. He slipped away, and returned to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">island, of which Bilbo knew nothing, not far off in the dark water. There,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he thought, lay his ring. He was hungry now, and angry, and once his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'precious' was with him he would not fear any weapon at all.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the ring was not on the island; he had lost it, it was gone. His<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">screech sent a shiver down Bilbo's back, though he did not yet understand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what had happened. But Gollum had at last leaped to a guess, too late. What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has it got in its pocketses? he cried. The light in his eyes was like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green flame as he sped back to murder the hobbit and recover his 'precious'.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Just in time Bilbo saw his peril, and he fled blindly up the passage away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the water; and once more he was saved by his luck. For just as he ran<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he put his hand in his pocket, and the ring slipped quietly on to his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finger. So it was that Gollum passed him without seeing him, and went to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guard the way out, lest the 'thief should escape. Warily Bilbo followed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, as he went along, cursing, and talking to himself about his 'precious';<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from which talk at last even Bilbo guessed the truth, and hope came to him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the darkness: he himself had found the marvellous ring and a chance of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">escape from the ores and from Gollum.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length they came to a halt before an unseen opening that led to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lower gates of the mines, on the eastward side of the mountains. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gollum crouched at bay, smelling and listening; and Bilbo was tempted to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slay him with his sword. But pity stayed him, and though he kept the ring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in which his only hope lay, he would not use it to help him kill the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wretched creature at a disadvantage. In the end, gathering his courage, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaped over Gollum in the dark, and fled away down the passage, pursued by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his enemy's cries of hate and despair: Thief thief! Baggins! We hates it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for ever!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now it is a curious fact that this is not the story as Bilbo first told<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it to his companions. To them his account was that Gollum had promised to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">give him a present, if he won the game; but when Gollum went to fetch it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from his island he found the treasure was gone: a magic ring, which had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">given to him long ago on his birthday. Bilbo guessed that this was the very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring that he had found, and as he had won the game, it was already his by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right. But being in a tight place, he said nothing about it, and made Gollum<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">show him the way out, as a reward instead of a present. This account Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set down in his memoirs, and he seems never to have altered it himself, not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even after the Council of Elrond. Evidently it still appeared in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">original Red Book, as it did in several of the copies and abstracts. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many copies contain the true account (as an alternative), derived no doubt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from notes by Frodo or Samwise, both of whom learned the truth, though they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seem to have been unwilling to delete anything actually written by the old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit himself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf, however, disbelieved Bilbo's first story, as soon as he heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, and he continued to be very curious about the ring. Eventually he got<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the true tale out of Bilbo after much questioning, which for a while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strained their friendship; but the wizard seemed to think the truth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">important. Though he did not say so to Bilbo, he also thought it important,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and disturbing, to find that the good hobbit had not told the truth from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first: quite contrary to his habit. The idea of a 'present' was not mere<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbitlike invention, all the same. It was suggested to Bilbo, as he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">confessed, by Gollum's talk that he overheard; for Gollum did, in fact, call<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ring his 'birthday present', many times. That also Gandalf thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strange and suspicious; but he did not discover the truth in this point for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many more years, as will be seen in this book.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of Bilbo's later adventures little more need be said here. With the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help of the ring he escaped from the ore-guards at the gate and rejoined his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companions. He used the ring many times on his quest, chiefly for the help<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his friends; but he kept it secret from them as long as he could. After<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his return to his home he never spoke of it again to anyone, save Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Frodo; and no one else in the Shire knew of its existence, or so he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">believed. Only to Frodo did he show the account of his Journey that he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">writing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His sword, Sting, Bilbo hung over his fireplace, and his coat of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">marvellous mail, the gift of the Dwarves from the Dragon -hoard, he lent to a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">museum, to the Michel Delving Mathom-house in fact. But he kept in a drawer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at Bag End the old cloak and hood that he had worn on his travels; and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring, secured by a fine chain, remained in his pocket.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He returned to his home at Bag End on June the 22nd in his fifty-second<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year (S.R. 1342), and nothing very notable occurred in the Shire until Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins began the preparations for the celebration of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hundred-and-eleventh birthday (S.R. 1401). At this point this History<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">begins.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">NOTE ON THE SHIRE RECORDS<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the end of the Third Age the part played by the Hobbits in the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">events that led to the inclusion of the Shire in the Reunited Kingdom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">awakened among them a more widespread interest in their own history; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many of their traditions, up to that time still mainly oral, were collected<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Written down. The greater families were also concerned with events in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Kingdom at large, and many of their members studied its ancient<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">histories and legends. By the end of the first century of the Fourth Age<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were already to be found in the Shire several libraries that contained<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many historical books and records.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The largest of these collections were probably at Undertowers, at Great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Smials, and at Brandy Hall. This account of the end of the Third Age is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drawn mainly from the Red Book of Westmarch. That most important source<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the history of the War of the Ring was so called because it was long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">preserved at Undertowers, the home of the Fairbairns, Wardens of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Westmarch. 1 It was in origin Bilbo's private diary, which he took with him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Rivendell. Frodo brought it back to the Shire, together with many loose<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves of notes, and during S.R. 1420-1 he nearly filled its pages with his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">account of the War. But annexed to it and preserved with it, probably m a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">single red case, were the three large volumes, bound in red leather, that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo gave to him as a parting gift. To these four volumes there was added<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Westmarch a fifth containing commentaries, genealogies, and various other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">matter concerning the hobbit members of the Fellowship.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The original Red Book has not been preserved, but many copies were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made, especially of the first volume, for the use of the descendants of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">children of Master Samwise. The most important copy, however, has a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different history. It was kept at Great Smials, but it was written in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Condor, probably at the request of the great-grandson of Peregrin, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">completed in S.R. 1592 (F.A. 172). Its southern scribe appended this note:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Findegil, King's Writer, finished this work in IV 172. It is an exact copy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in all details of the Thain's Book m Minas Tirith. That book was a copy,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made at the request of King Elessar, of the Red Book of the Periannath, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was brought to him by the Thain Peregrin when he retired to Gondor in IV 64.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Thainâ€™s Book was thus the first copy made of the Red Book and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">contained much that was later omitted or lost. In Minas Tirith it received<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much annotation, and many corrections, especially of names, words, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quotations in the Elvish languages; and there was added to it an abbreviated<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">version of those parts of The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen which lie outside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the account of the War. The full tale is stated to have been written by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barahir, grandson of the Steward Faramir, some time after the passing of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">King. But the chief importance of Findegilâ€™s copy is that it alone contains<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the whole of Bilbo's â€™Translations from the Elvish'. These three volumes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were found to be a work of great skill and learning in which, between 1403<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and 1418, he had used all the sources available to him in Rivendell, both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">living and written. But since they were little used by Frodo, being almost<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">entirely concerned with the Elder Days, no more is said of them here.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Since Meriadoc and Peregrin became the heads of their great families,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and at the same time kept up their connexions with Rohan and Gondor, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">libraries at Bucklebury and Tuckborough contained much that did not appear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Red Book. In Brandy Hall there were many works dealing with Eriador<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the history of Rohan. Some of these were composed or begun by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Meriadoc<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself, though in the Shire he was chiefly remembered for his Herhlore of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire, and for his Reckoning of Years m which he discussed the relation<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the calendars of the Shire and Bree to those of Rivendell, Gondor, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rohan. He also wrote a short treatise on Old Words and Names in the Shire,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">having special interest in discovering the kinship with the language of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rohirrim of such 'shire-words' as mathom and old elements in place names.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At Great Smials the books were of less interest to Shire-folk, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more important for larger history. None of them was written by Peregrin, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he and his successors collected many manuscripts written by scribes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gondor: mainly copies or summaries of histories or legends relating to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elendil and his heirs. Only here in the Shire were to be found extensive<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">materials for the history of NÂ®menor and the arising of Sauron. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">probably at Great Smials that The Tale of Years 1 was put together, with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">assistance of material collected by Meriadoc. Though the dates given are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">often conjectural, especially for the Second Age, they deserve attention. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is probable that Meriadoc obtained assistance and information from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell, which he visited more than once. There, though Elrond had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">departed, his sons long remained, together with some of the High-elven folk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is said that Celeborn went to dwell there after the departure of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galadriel; but there is no record of the day when at last he sought the Grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Havens, and with him went the last living memory of the Elder Days in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Middle-earth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">* BOOK I *<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 1 . A Long-expected Party<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When Mr. Bilbo Baggins of Bag End announced that he would shortly be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">celebrating his eleventy -first birthday with a party of special<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">magnificence, there was much talk and excitement in Hobbiton.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo was very rich and very peculiar, and had been the wonder of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire for sixty years, ever since his remarkable disappearance and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpected return. The riches he had brought back from his travels had now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become a local legend, and it was popularly believed, whatever the old folk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might say, that the Hill at Bag End was full of tunnels stuffed with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treasure. And if that was not enough for fame, there was also his prolonged<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vigour to marvel at. Time wore on, but it seemed to have little effect on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Baggins. At ninety he was much the same as at fifty. At ninety-nine they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to call him we//-preserved, but unchanged would have been nearer the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mark. There were some that shook their heads and thought this was too much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of a good thing; it seemed unfair that anyone should possess (apparently)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perpetual youth as well as (reputedly) inexhaustible wealth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It will have to be paid for,' they said. 'It isn't natural, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trouble will come of it!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But so far trouble had not come; and as Mr. Baggins was generous with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his money, most people were willing to forgive him his oddities and his good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fortune. He remained on visiting terms with his relatives (except, of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course, the Sackville-Bagginses), and he had many devoted admirers among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits of poor and unimportant families. But he had no close friends, until<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some of his younger cousins began to grow up.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The eldest of these, and Bilbo's favourite, was young Frodo Baggins.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When Bilbo was ninety-nine, he adopted Frodo as his heir, and brought him to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">live at Bag End; and the hopes of the Sackville-Bagginses were finally<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dashed. Bilbo and Frodo happened to have the same birthday, September<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">22nd.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You had better come and live here, Frodo my lad,' said Bilbo one day; 'and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then we can celebrate our birthday-parties comfortably together.' At that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time Frodo was still in his tweens, as the hobbits called the irresponsible<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twenties between childhood and coming of age at thirty-three.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Twelve more years passed. Each year the Bagginses had given very lively<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">combined birthday-parties at Bag End; but now it was understood that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something quite exceptional was being planned for that autumn. Bilbo was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going to be eleventy-one, 111, a rather curious number and a very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">respectable age for a hobbit (the Old Took himself had only reached 130);<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Frodo was going to be thirty-three, 33) an important number: the date of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his 'coming of age'.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tongues began to wag in Flobbiton and By water; and rumour of the coming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">event travelled all over the Shire. The history and character of Mr. Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins became once again the chief topic of conversation; and the older<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk suddenly found their reminiscences in welcome demand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">No one had a more attentive audience than old Ham Gamgee, commonly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">known as the Gaffer. He held forth at The Ivy Bush , a small inn on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bywater road; and he spoke with some authority, for he had tended the garden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at Bag End for forty years, and had helped old Holman in the same job before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that. Now that he was himself growing old and stiff in the joints, the job<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was mainly carried on by his youngest son, Sam Gamgee. Both father and son<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were on very friendly terms with Bilbo and Frodo. They lived on the Hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">itself, in Number 3 Bagshot Row just below Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™A very nice well-spoken gentlehobbit is Mr. Bilbo, as I've always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said,' the Gaffer declared. With perfect truth: for Bilbo was very polite to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, calling him 'Master Hamfast', and consulting him constantly upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">growing of vegetables - in the matter of 'roots', especially potatoes, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gaffer was recognized as the leading authority by all in the neighbourhood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(including himself).<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But what about this Frodo that lives with him?' asked Old Noakes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By water. 'Baggins is his name, but he's more than half a Brandybuck, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say. It beats me why any Baggins of Hobbiton should go looking for a wife<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away there in Buckland, where folks are so queer.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And no wonder they're queer,' put in Daddy Twofoot (the Gaffer's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">next-door neighbour), 'if they live on the wrong side of the Brandywine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River, and right agin the Old Forest. That's a dark bad place, if half the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tales be true.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You're right, Dad!' said the Gaffer. 'Not that the Brandybucks of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Buck-land live in the Old Forest; but they're a queer breed, seemingly. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fool about with boats on that big river - and that isnâ€™t natural. Small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonder that trouble came of it, I say. But be that as it may, Mr. Frodo is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as nice a young hobbit as you could wish to meet. Very much like Mr. Bilbo,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and in more than looks. After all his father was a Baggins. A decent<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">respectable hobbit was Mr. Drogo Baggins; there was never much to tell of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, till he was drownded.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Drownded?' said several voices. They had heard this and other darker<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rumours before, of course; but hobbits have a passion for family history,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they were ready to hear it again. 'Well, so they say,' said the Gaffer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You see: Mr. Drogo, he married poor Miss Primula Brandybuck. She was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Bilbo's first cousin on the mother's side (her mother being the youngest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Old Took's daughters); and Mr. Drogo was his second cousin. So Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo is his first and second cousin, once removed either way, as the saying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is, if you follow me. And Mr. Drogo was staying at Brandy Flail with his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">father-in-law, old Master Gorbadoc, as he often did after his marriage (him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">being partial to his vittles, and old Gorbadoc keeping a mighty generous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table); and he went out boating on the Brandywine River; and he and his wife<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were drownded, and poor Mr. Frodo only a child and all. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I've heard they went on the water after dinner in the moonlight,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Noakes; 'and it was Drogo's weight as sunk the boat.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And / heard she pushed him in, and he pulled her in after him,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sandy man, the Hobbiton miller.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You shouldn't listen to all you hear, Sandyman,' said the Gaffer, who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did not much like the miller. 'There isn't no call to go talking of pushing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and pulling. Boats are quite tricky enough for those that sit still without<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking further for the cause of trouble. Anyway: there was this Mr. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left an orphan and stranded, as you might say, among those queer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bucklanders, being brought up anyhow in Brandy Hall. A regular warren, by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all accounts. Old Master Gorbadoc never had fewer than a couple of hundred<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">relations in the place. Mr. Bilbo never did a kinder deed than when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brought the lad back to live among decent folk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I reckon it was a nasty shock for those Sackville-Bagginses. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought they were going to get Bag End, that time when he went off and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought to be dead. And then he comes back and orders them off; and he goes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on living and living, and never looking a day older, bless him! And suddenly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he produces an heir, and has all the papers made out proper. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sackville-Bagginses wonâ€™t never see the inside of Bag End now, or it is to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be hoped not.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There's a tidy bit of money tucked away up there, I hear tell,' said a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stranger, a visitor on business from Michel Delving in the Westfarthing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All the top of your hill is full of tunnels packed with chests of gold and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver, and jools, by what I've heard. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then you've heard more than I can speak to,' answered the Gaffer. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know nothing about jools. Mr. Bilbo is free with his money, and there seems<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no lack of it; but I know of no tunnel -making. I saw Mr. Bilbo when he came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back, a matter of sixty years ago, when I was a lad. I'd not long come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prentice to old Holman (him being my dad's cousin), but he had me up at Bag<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">End helping him to keep folks from trampling and trapessing all over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">garden while the sale was on. And in the middle of it all Mr. Bilbo comes up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Hill with a pony and some mighty big bags and a couple of chests. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't doubt they were mostly full of treasure he had picked up in foreign<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">parts, where there be mountains of gold, they say; but there wasn't enough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to fill tunnels. But my lad Sam will know more about that. He's in and out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Bag End. Crazy about stories of the old days he is, and he listens to all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Bilbo's tales. Mr. Bilbo has learned him his letters - meaning no harm,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mark you, and I hope no harm will come of it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Elves and Dragons' Isays to him. 'Cabbages and potatoes are better<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for me and you. Don 't go getting mixed up in the business of your betters,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or you'll land in trouble too big for you, ' I says to him. And I might say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it to others,' he added with a look at the stranger and the miller.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the Gaffer did not convince his audience. The legend of Bilbo's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wealth was now too firmly fixed in the minds of the younger generation of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah, but he has likely enough been adding to what he brought at first,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">argued the miller, voicing common opinion. 'He's often away from home. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look at the outlandish folk that visit him: dwarves coming at night, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that old wandering conjuror, Gandalf, and all. You can say what you like,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gaffer, but Bag End's a queer place, and its folk are queerer.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And you can say what you like, about what you know no more of than you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do of boating, Mr. Sandyman,' retorted the Gaffer, disliking the miller even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more than usual. If that's being queer, then we could do with a bit more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">queerness in these parts. There's some not far away that wouldn't offer a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pint of beer to a friend, if they lived in a hole with golden walls. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they do things proper at Bag End. Our Sam says that everyone's going to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">invited to the party, and thereâ€™s going to be presents, mark you, presents<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for all - this very month as is.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That very month was September, and as fine as you could ask. A day or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">two later a rumour (probably started by the knowledgeable Sam) was spread<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about that there were going to be fireworks - fireworks, what is more, such<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as had not been seen in the Shire for nigh on a century, not indeed since<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Old Took died.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Days passed and The Day drew nearer. An odd-looking waggon laden with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">odd-looking packages rolled into Hobbiton one evening and toiled up the Hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Bag End. The startled hobbits peered out of lamplit doors to gape at it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was driven by outlandish folk, singing strange songs: dwarves with long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beards and deep hoods. A few of them remained at Bag End. At the end of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">second week in September a cart came in through Bywater from the direction<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Brandywine Bridge in broad daylight. An old man was driving it all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone. He wore a tall pointed blue hat, a long grey cloak, and a silver<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scarf. He had a long white beard and bushy eyebrows that stuck out beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the brim of his hat. Small hobbit-children ran after the cart all through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbiton and right up the hill. It had a cargo of fireworks, as they rightly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed. At Bilbo's front door the old man began to unload: there were great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bundles of fireworks of all sorts and shapes, each labelled with a large red<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">G and the elf-rune, .<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That was Gandalf s mark, of course, and the old man was Gandalf the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wizard, whose fame in the Shire was due mainly to his skill with fires,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smokes, and lights. His real business was far more difficult and dangerous,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the Shire-folk knew nothing about it. To them he was just one of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'attractions' at the Party. Hence the excitement of the hobbit-children. 'G<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for Grand!' they shouted, and the old man smiled. They knew him by sight,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though he only appeared in Hobbiton occasionally and never stopped long; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither they nor any but the oldest of their elders had seen one of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">firework displays - they now belonged to the legendary past.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When the old man, helped by Bilbo and some dwarves, had finished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unloading. Bilbo gave a few pennies away; but not a single squib or cracker<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was forthcoming, to the disappointment of the onlookers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Run away now!' said Gandalf. 'You will get plenty when the time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comes.' Then he disappeared inside with Bilbo, and the door was shut. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">young hobbits stared at the door in vain for a while, and then made off,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feeling that the day of the party would never come.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Inside Bag End, Bilbo and Gandalf were sitting at the open window of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small room looking out west on to the garden. The late afternoon was bright<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and peaceful. The flowers glowed red and golden: snap-dragons and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun-flowers, and nasturtiums trailing all over the turf walls and peeping in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at the round windows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How bright your garden looks!' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Bilbo. I am very fond indeed of it, and of all the dear old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire; but I think I need a holiday.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You mean to go on with your plan then?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do. I made up my mind months ago, and I haven't changed it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well. It is no good saying any more. Stick to your plan - your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whole plan, mind - and I hope it will turn out for the best, for you, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for all of us.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope so. Anyway I mean to enjoy myself on Thursday, and have my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little joke.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who will laugh, I wonder?' said Gandalf, shaking his head.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We shall see,' said Bilbo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The next day more carts rolled up the Hill, and still more carts. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might have been some grumbling about 'dealing locally', but that very week<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">orders began to pour out of Bag End for every kind of provision, commodity,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or luxury that could be obtained in Hobbiton or Bywater or anywhere in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neighbourhood. People became enthusiastic; and they began to tick off the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days on the calendar; and they watched eagerly for the postman, hoping for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">invitations.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before long the invitations began pouring out, and the Hobbiton<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">post-office was blocked, and the Bywater post-office was snowed under, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voluntary assistant postmen were called for. There was a constant stream of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them going up the Hill, carrying hundreds of polite variations on Thank you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I shall certainly come.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A notice appeared on the gate at Bag End: NO ADMITTANCE EXCEPT<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ON PARTY<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">BUSINESS. Even those who had, or pretended to have Party Business were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seldom allowed inside. Bilbo was busy: writing invitations, ticking off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">answers, packing up presents, and making some private preparations of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own. From the time of Gandalf s arrival he remained hidden from view.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One morning the hobbits woke to find the large field, south of Bilbo's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">front door, covered with ropes and poles for tents and pavilions. A special<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">entrance was cut into the bank leading to the road, and wide steps and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large white gate were built there. The three hobbit-families of Bagshot Row,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">adjoining the field, were intensely interested and generally envied. Old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gaffer Gamgee stopped even pretending to work in his garden.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The tents began to go up. There was a specially large pavilion, so big<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that the tree that grew in the field was right inside it, and stood proudly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near one end, at the head of the chief table. Lanterns were hung on all its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches. More promising still (to the hobbitsâ€™ mind): an enormous open-air<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kitchen was erected in the north corner of the field. A draught of cooks,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from every inn and eating-house for miles around, arrived to supplement the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
