<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well. Old Gaffer Gamgee got two sacks of potatoes, a new spade, a woollen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waistcoat, and a bottle of ointment for creaking joints. Old Rory<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandybuck, in return for much hospitality, got a dozen bottles of Old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Winyards: a strong red wine from the Southfarthing, and now quite mature, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it had been laid down by Bilbo's father. Rory quite forgave Bilbo, and voted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him a capital fellow after the first bottle.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was plenty of everything left for Frodo. And, of course, all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chief treasures, as well as the books, pictures, and more than enough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">furniture, were left in his possession. There was, however, no sign nor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mention of money or jewellery: not a penny -piece or a glass bead was given<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo had a very trying time that afternoon. A false rumour that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whole household was being distributed free spread like wildfire; and before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long the place was packed with people who had no business there, but could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not be kept out. Fabels got torn off and mixed, and quarrels broke out. Some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">people tried to do swaps and deals in the hall; and others tried to make off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with minor items not addressed to them, or with anything that seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unwanted or unwatched. The road to the gate was blocked with barrows and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">handcarts.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the middle of the commotion the Sackville-Bagginses arrived. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had retired for a while and left his friend Merry Brandybuck to keep an eye<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on things. When Otho loudly demanded to see Frodo, Merry bowed politely.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He is indisposed,' he said. 'He is resting.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hiding, you mean,' said Fobelia. 'Anyway we want to see him and we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mean to see him. Just go and tell him so!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry left them a long while in the hall, and they had time to discover<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their parting gift of spoons. It did not improve their tempers. Eventually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were shown into the study. Frodo was sitting at a table with a lot of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">papers in front of him. He looked indisposed - to see Sackville-Bagginses at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any rate; and he stood up, fidgeting with something in his pocket. But he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke quite politely.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Sackville-Bagginses were rather offensive. They began by offering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him bad bargain-prices (as between friends) for various valuable and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unlabelled things. When Frodo replied that only the things specially<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">directed by Bilbo were being given away, they said the whole affair was very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fishy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Only one thing is clear to me,' said Otho, 'and that is that you are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doing exceedingly well out of it. I insist on seeing the will.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Otho would have been Bilbo's heir, but for the adoption of Frodo. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">read the will carefully and snorted. It was, unfortunately, very clear and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">correct (according to the legal customs of hobbits, which demand among other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things seven signatures of witnesses in red ink).<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Foiled again!' he said to his wife. 'And after waiting sixty years.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Spoons? Fiddlesticks!' He snapped his fingers under Frodo's nose and slumped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off. But Lobelia was not so easily got rid of. A little later Frodo came out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the study to see how things were going on and found her still about the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">place, investigating nooks and comers and tapping the floors. He escorted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her firmly off the premises, after he had relieved her of several small (but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rather valuable) articles that had somehow fallen inside her umbrella. Her<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">face looked as if she was in the throes of thinking out a really crushing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">parting remark; but all she found to say, turning round on the step, was:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You'll live to regret it, young fellow! Why didn't you go too? You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't belong here; you're no Baggins - you - you're a Brandybuck!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Did you hear that, Merry? That was an insult, if you like,' said Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as he shut the door on her.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was a compliment,' said Merry Brandybuck, 'and so, of course, not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">true.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then they went round the hole, and evicted three young hobbits (two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boffins and a Bolger) who were knocking holes in the walls of one of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cellars. Frodo also had a tussle with young Sancho Proudfoot (old Odo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Proudfoot's grandson), who had begun an excavation in the larger pantry,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where he thought there was an echo. The legend of Bilbo's gold excited both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">curiosity and hope; for legendary gold (mysteriously obtained, if not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">positively ill-gotten), is, as every one knows, any one's for the finding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">-unless the search is interrupted.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he had overcome Sancho and pushed him out, Frodo collapsed on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chair in the hall. It's time to close the shop, Merry,' he said. 'Lock the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">door, and donâ€™t open it to anyone today, not even if they bring a battering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ram.â€™ Then he went to revive himself with a belated cup of tea.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He had hardly sat down, when there came a soft knock at the front-door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lobelia again most likely,' he thought. 'She must have thought of something<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">really nasty, and have come back again to say it. It can wait.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He went on with his tea. The knock was repeated, much louder, but he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">took no notice. Suddenly the wizard's head appeared at the window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If you don't let me in, Frodo, I shall blow your door right down your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hole and out through the hill,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My dear Gandalf! Half a minute!' cried Frodo, running out of the room<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the door. 'Come in! Come in! I thought it was Lobelia.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then I forgive you. But I saw her some time ago, driving a pony-trap<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards Bywater with a face that would have curdled new milk.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'She had already nearly curdled me. Honestly, I nearly tried on Bilbo's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring. I longed to disappear.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't do that!' said Gandalf, sitting down. 'Do be careful of that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring, Frodo ! In fact, it is partly about that that I have come to say a last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">word.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, what about it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you know already?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Only what Bilbo told me. I have heard his story: how he found it, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">how he used it: on his journey, I mean.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Which story, I wonder,' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh, not what he told the dwarves and put in his book,' said Frodo. 'He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">told me the true story soon after I came to live here. He said you had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pestered him till he told you, so I had better know too. "No secrets between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us, Frodo," he said; "but they are not to go any further. It's mine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anyway.'"<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That's interesting,' said Gandalf. 'Well, what did you think of it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If you mean, inventing all that about a "present", well, I thought the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">true story much more likely, and I couldn't see the point of altering it at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all. It was very unlike Bilbo to do so, anyway; and I thought it rather<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">odd.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So did I. But odd things may happen to people that have such treasures<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">- if they use them. Let it be a warning to you to be very careful with it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It may have other powers than just making you vanish when you wish to.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't understand,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Neither do I,' answered the wizard. 'I have merely begun to wonder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the ring, especially since last night. No need to worry. But if you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take my advice you will use it very seldom, or not at all. At least I beg<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you not to use it in any way that will cause talk or rouse suspicion. I say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again: keep it safe, and keep it secret!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are very mysterious! What are you afraid of?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am not certain, so I will say no more. I may be able to tell you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something when I come back. I am going off at once: so this is good-bye for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the present.' He got up.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'At once!' cried Frodo. 'Why, I thought you were staying on for at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least a week. I was looking forward to your help.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I did mean to - but I have had to change my mind. I may be away for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good while; but I'll come and see you again, as soon as I can. Expect me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when you see me! I shall slip in quietly. I shan't often be visiting the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire openly again. I find that I have become rather unpopular. They say I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">am a nuisance and a disturber of the peace. Some people are actually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accusing me of spiriting Bilbo away, or worse. If you want to know, there is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">supposed to be a plot between you and me to get hold of his wealth.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Some people!' exclaimed Frodo. 'You mean Otho and Lobelia. How<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">abominable! I would give them Bag End and everything else, if I could get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo back and go off tramping in the country with him. I love the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But I begin to wish, somehow, that I had gone too. I wonder if I shall ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see him again.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So do I,' said Gandalf. 'And I wonder many other things. Good-bye now!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Take care of yourself! Lookout for me, especially at unlikely times !<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Good-bye!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo saw him to the door. He gave a final wave of his hand, and walked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off at a surprising pace; but Frodo thought the old wizard looked unusually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bent, almost as if he was carrying a great weight. The evening was closing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in, and his cloaked figure quickly vanished into the twilight. Frodo did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see him again for a long time.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 2 . The Shadow of the Past<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The talk did not die down in nine or even ninety -nine days. The second<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disappearance of Mr. Bilbo Baggins was discussed in Hobbiton, and indeed all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the Shire, for a year and a day, and was remembered much longer than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that. It became a fireside -story for young hobbits; and eventually Mad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins, who used to vanish with a bang and a flash and reappear with bags<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of jewels and gold, became a favourite character of legend and lived on long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after all the true events were forgotten.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But in the meantime, the general opinion in the neighbourhood was that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo, who had always been rather cracked, had at last gone quite mad, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had run off into the Blue. There he had undoubtedly fallen into a pool or a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">river and come to a tragic, but hardly an untimely, end. The blame was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mostly laid on Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If only that dratted wizard will leave young Frodo alone, perhaps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he'll settle down and grow some hobbit-sense,' they said. And to all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appearance the wizard did leave Frodo alone, and he did settle down, but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">growth of hobbit-sense was not very noticeable. Indeed, he at once began to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">carry on Bilbo's reputation for oddity. He refused to go into mourning; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the next year he gave a party in honour of Bilbo's hundred-and-twelfth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">birthday, which he called Hundred-weight Feast. But that was short of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mark, for twenty guests were invited and there were several meals at which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it snowed food and rained drink, as hobbits say.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Some people were rather shocked; but Frodo kept up the custom of giving<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo's Birthday Party year after year until they got used to it. He said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he did not think Bilbo was dead. When they asked: 'Where is he then?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he shrugged his shoulders.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He lived alone, as Bilbo had done; but he had a good many friends,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">especially among the younger hobbits (mostly descendants of the Old Took)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who had as children been fond of Bilbo and often in and out of Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Folco Boffin and Fredegar Bolger were two of these; but his closest friends<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were Peregrin Took (usually called Pippin), and Merry Brandybuck (his real<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name was Meriadoc, but that was seldom remembered). Frodo went tramping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the Shire with them; but more often he wandered by himself, and to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">amazement of sensible folk he was sometimes seen far from home walking in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hills and woods under the starlight. Merry and Pippin suspected that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">visited the Elves at times, as Bilbo had done.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As time went on, people began to notice that Frodo also showed signs of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good â€™preservation': outwardly he retained the appearance of a robust and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">energetic hobbit just out of his tweens. â€™Some folk have all the luck,â€™ they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said; but it was not until Frodo approached the usually more sober age of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fifty that they began to think it queer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo himself, after the first shock, found that being his own master<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the Mr. Baggins of Bag End was rather pleasant. For some years he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quite happy and did not worry much about the future. But half unknown to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself the regret that he had not gone with Bilbo was steadily growing. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dreams. He began to say to himself: 'Perhaps I shall cross the River myself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one day.' To which the other half of his mind always replied: 'Not yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So it went on, until his forties were running out, and his fiftieth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">birthday was drawing near: fifty was a number that he felt was somehow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">significant (or ominous); it was at any rate at that age that adventure had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly befallen Bilbo. Frodo began to feel restless, and the old paths<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed too well-trodden. He looked at maps, and wondered what lay beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their edges: maps made in the Shire showed mostly white spaces beyond its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borders. He took to wandering further afield and more often by himself; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry and his other friends watched him anxiously. Often he was seen walking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and talking with the strange wayfarers that began at this time to appear in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There were rumours of strange things happening in the world outside;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and as Gandalf had not at that time appeared or sent any message for several<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years, Frodo gathered all the news he could. Elves, who seldom walked in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire, could now be seen passing westward through the woods in the evening,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passing and not returning; but they were leaving Middle-earth and were no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer concerned with its troubles. There were, however, dwarves on the road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in unusual numbers. The ancient East -West Road ran through the Shire to its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end at the Grey Havens, and dwarves had always used it on their way to their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mines in the Blue Mountains. They were the hobbits' chief source of news<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from distant parts - if they wanted any: as a rule dwarves said little and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits asked no more. But now Frodo often met strange dwarves of far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">countries, seeking refuge in the West. They were troubled, and some spoke in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whispers of the Enemy and of the Land of Mordor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That name the hobbits only knew in legends of the dark past, like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow in the background of their memories; but it was ominous and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disquieting. It seemed that the evil power in Mirkwood had been driven out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by the White Council only to reappear in greater strength in the old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strongholds of Mordor. The Dark Tower had been rebuilt, it was said. From<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there the power was spreading far and wide, and away far east and south<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were wars and growing fear. Ores were multiplying again in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains. Trolls were abroad, no longer dull-witted, but cunning and armed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with dreadful weapons. And there were murmured hints of creatures more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terrible than all these, but they had no name.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Little of all this, of course, reached the ears of ordinary hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But even the deafest and most stay-at-home began to hear queer tales; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those whose business took them to the borders saw strange things. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conversation in The Green Dragon at Bywater, one evening in the spring of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo's fiftieth year, showed that even in the comfortable heart of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire rumours had been heard, though most hobbits still laughed at them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam Gamgee was sitting in one corner near the fire, and opposite him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was Ted Sandyman, the miller's son; and there were various other rustic<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits listening to their talk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Queer things you do hear these days, to be sure,' said Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah,' said Ted, 'you do, if you listen. But I can hear fireside-tales<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and children's stories at home, if I want to.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No doubt you can,' retorted Sam, 'and I daresay there's more truth in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some of them than you reckon. Who invented the stories anyway? Take<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dragons<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No thank 'ee,' said Ted, 'I won't. I heard tell of them when I was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">youngster, but there's no call to believe in them now. There's only one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dragon in By water, and that's Green,' he said, getting a general laugh.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right,' said Sam, laughing with the rest. 'But what about these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tree-men, these giants, as you might call them? They do say that one bigger<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than a tree was seen up away beyond the North Moors not long back.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who's theyT<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My cousin Hal for one. He works for Mr. Boffin at Overhill and goes up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Northfarthing for the hunting. He saw one.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Says he did, perhaps. Your Hal's always saying he's seen things; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">maybe he sees things that ain't there.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But this one was as big as an elm tree, and walking - walking seven<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yards to a stride, if it was an inch.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then I bet it wasn't an inch. What he saw was an elm tree, as like as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But this one was walking, I tell you; and there ain't no elm tree on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the North Moors.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then Hal can't have seen one,' said Ted. There was some laughing and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clapping: the audience seemed to think that Ted had scored a point.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All the same,' said Sam, 'you can't deny that others besides our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Halfast have seen queer folk crossing the Shire - crossing it, mind you:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there are more that are turned back at the borders. The Bounders have never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been so busy before.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I've heard tell that Elves are moving west. They do say they are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going to the harbours, out away beyond the White Towers.' Sam waved his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vaguely: neither he nor any of them knew how far it was to the Sea, past the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old towers beyond the western borders of the Shire. But it was an old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tradition that away over there stood the Grey Havens, from which at times<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">elven-ships set sail, never to return.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They are sailing, sailing, sailing over the Sea, they are going into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the West and leaving us,' said Sam, half chanting the words, shaking his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">head sadly and solemnly. But Ted laughed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, that isn't anything new, if you believe the old tales. And I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't see what it matters to me or you. Let them sail! But I warrant you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">haven't seen them doing it; nor any one else in the Shire.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well I don't know,' said Sam thoughtfully. He believed he had once<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seen an Elf in the woods, and still hoped to see more one day. Of all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">legends that he had heard in his early years such fragments of tales and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">half-remembered stories about the Elves as the hobbits knew, had always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moved him most deeply. 'There are some, even in these parts, as know the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fair Folk and get news of them,' he said. 'There's Mr. Baggins now, that I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">work for. He told me that they were sailing and he knows a bit about Elves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And old Mr. Bilbo knew more: many's the talk I had with him when I was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little lad.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh, they're both cracked,' said Ted. 'Leastways old Bilbo was cracked,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Frodo's cracking. If that's where you get your news from, you'll never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">want for moonshine. Well, friends, I'm off home. Your good health!' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drained his mug and went out noisily.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam sat silent and said no more. He had a good deal to think about. For<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one thing, there was a lot to do up in the Bag End garden, and he would have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a busy day tomorrow, if the weather cleared. The grass was growing fast. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam had more on his mind than gardening. After a while he sighed, and got up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and went out.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was early April and the sky was now clearing after heavy rain. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun was down, and a cool pale evening was quietly fading into night. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walked home under the early stars through Hobbiton and up the Hill,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whistling softly and thoughtfully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was just at this time that Gandalf reappeared after his long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">absence. For three years after the Party he had been away. Then he paid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo a brief visit, and after taking a good look at him he went off again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">During the next year or two he had turned up fairly often, coming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpectedly after dusk, and going off without warning before sunrise. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would not discuss his own business and journeys, and seemed chiefly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">interested in small news about Frodo's health and doings.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then suddenly his visits had ceased. It was over nine years since Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had seen or heard of him, and he had begun to think that the wizard would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never return and had given up all interest in hobbits. But that evening, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam was walking home and twilight was fading, there came the once familiar<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tap on the study window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo welcomed his old friend with surprise and great delight. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked hard at one another.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Ah well eh?' said Gandalf. 'You look the same as ever, Frodo!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So do you,' Frodo replied; but secretly he thought that Gandalf looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">older and more careworn. He pressed him for news of himself and of the wide<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">world, and soon they were deep in talk, and they stayed up far into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Next morning after a late breakfast, the wizard was sitting with Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by the open window of the study. A bright fire was on the hearth, but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun was warm, and the wind was in the South. Everything looked fresh, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the new green of Spring was shimmering in the fields and on the tips of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees' fingers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf was thinking of a spring, nearly eighty years before, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo had run out of Bag End without a handkerchief. His hair was perhaps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whiter than it had been then, and his beard and eyebrows were perhaps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer, and his face more lined with care and wisdom; but his eyes were as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright as ever, and he smoked and blew smoke -rings with the same vigour and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He was smoking now in silence, for Frodo was sitting still, deep in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought. Even in the light of morning he felt the dark shadow of the tidings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that Gandalf had brought. At last he broke the silence.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Last night you began to tell me strange things about my ring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf,' he said. 'And then you stopped, because you said that such matters<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were best left until daylight. Don't you think you had better finish now?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You say the ring is dangerous, far more dangerous than I guess. In what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'In many ways,' answered the wizard. It is far more powerful than I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever dared to think at first, so powerful that in the end it would utterly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">overcome anyone of mortal race who possessed it. It would possess him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'In Eregion long ago many Elven-rings were made, magic rings as you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">call them, and they were, of course, of various kinds: some more potent and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some less. The lesser rings were only essays in the craft before it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">full-grown, and to the Elven-smiths they were but trifles - yet still to my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mind dangerous for mortals. But the Great Rings, the Rings of Power, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were perilous.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A mortal, Frodo, who keeps one of the Great Rings, does not die, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he does not grow or obtain more life, he merely continues, until at last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">every minute is a weariness. And if he often uses the Ring to make himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">invisible, he fades: he becomes in the end invisible permanently, and walks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the twilight under the eye of the dark power that rules the Rings. Yes,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sooner or later - later, if he is strong or well-meaning to begin with, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither strength nor good purpose will last - sooner or later the dark power<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will devour him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How terrifying!' said Frodo. There was another long silence. The sound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Sam Gamgee cutting the lawn came in from the garden.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How long have you known this?' asked Frodo at length. 'And how much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did Bilbo know?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bilbo knew no more than he told you, I am sure,' said Gandalf. 'He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would certainly never have passed on to you anything that he thought would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be a danger, even though I promised to look after you. He thought the ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was very beautiful, and very useful at need; and if anything was wrong or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">queer, it was himself. He said that it was "growing on his mind", and he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">always worrying about it; but he did not suspect that the ring itself was to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blame. Though he had found out that the thing needed looking after; it did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not seem always of the same size or weight; it shrank or expanded in an odd<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way, and might suddenly slip off a finger where it had been tight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, he warned me of that in his last letter,' said Frodo, 'so I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">always kept it on its chain.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very wise,' said Gandalf. 'But as for his long life, Bilbo never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">connected it with the ring at all. He took all the credit for that to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself, and he was very proud of it. Though he was getting restless and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uneasy. Thin and stretched he said. A sign that the ring was getting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">control.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How long have you known all this?' asked Frodo again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Known?' said Gandalf. 'I have known much that only the Wise know,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo. But if you mean "known about this ring", well, I still do not know,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one might say. There is a last test to make. But I no longer doubt my guess.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'When did I first begin to guess?' he mused, searching back in memory.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let me see - it was in the year that the White Council drove the dark power<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Mirkwood, just before the Battle of Five Armies, that Bilbo found his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring. A shadow fell on my heart then, though I did not know yet what I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feared. I wondered often how Gollum came by a Great Ring, as plainly it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">- that at least was clear from the first. Then I heard Bilbo's strange story<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of how he had "won" it, and I could not believe it. When I at last got the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">truth out of him, I saw at once that he had been trying to put his claim to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ring beyond doubt. Much like Gollum with his "birthday present". The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lies were too much alike for my comfort. Clearly the ring had an unwholesome<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">power that set to work on its keeper at once. That was the first real<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warning I had that all was not well. I told Bilbo often that such rings were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">better left unused; but he resented it, and soon got angry. There was little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">else that I could do. I could not take it from him without doing greater<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">harm; and I had no right to do so anyway. I could only watch and wait. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might perhaps have consulted Saruman the White, but something always held<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who is he?' asked Frodo. I have never heard of him before.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe not,' answered Gandalf. 'Hobbits are, or were, no concern of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his. Yet he is great among the Wise. He is the chief of my order and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">head of the Council. His knowledge is deep, but his pride has grown with it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he takes ill any meddling. The lore of the Elven-rings, great and small,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is his province. He has long studied it, seeking the lost secrets of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">making; but when the Rings were debated in the Council, all that he would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reveal to us of his ring-lore told against my fears. So my doubt slept - but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uneasily. Still I watched and I waited.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And all seemed well with Bilbo. And the years passed. Yes, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed, and they seemed not to touch him. He showed no signs of age. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow fell on me again. But I said to myself: "After all he comes of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long-lived family on his mother's side. There is time yet. Wait!"<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I waited. Until that night when he left this house. He said and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did things then that filled me with a fear that no words of Saruman could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">allay. I knew at last that something dark and deadly was at work. And I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spent most of the years since then in finding out the truth of it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There wasn't any permanent harm done, was there?' asked Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anxiously. 'He would get all right in time, wouldn't he? Be able to rest in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peace, I mean?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He felt better at once,' said Gandalf. 'But there is only one Power in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this world that knows all about the Rings and their effects; and as far as I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know there is no Power in the world that knows all about hobbits. Among the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wise I am the only one that goes in for hobbit-lore: an obscure branch of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knowledge, but full of surprises. Soft as butter they can be, and yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sometimes as tough as old tree-roots. I think it likely that some would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">resist the Rings far longer than most of the Wise would believe. I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think you need worry about Bilbo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course, he possessed the ring for many years, and used it, so it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might take a long while for the influence to wear off - before it was safe<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for him to see it again, for instance. Otherwise, he might live on for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years, quite happily: just stop as he was when he parted with it. For he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave it up in the end of his own accord: an important point. No, I was not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troubled about dear Bilbo any more, once he had let the thing go. It is for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you that I feel responsible.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ever since Bilbo left I have been deeply concerned about you, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about all these charming, absurd, helpless hobbits. It would be a grievous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blow to the world, if the Dark Power overcame the Shire; if all your kind,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jolly, stupid Bolgers, Hornblowers, Boffins, Bracegirdles, and the rest, not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to mention the ridiculous Bagginses, became enslaved.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo shuddered. 'But why should we be?' he asked. 'And why should he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">want such slaves?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'To tell you the truth,' replied Gandalf, 'I believe that hitherto -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hitherto, mark you - he has entirely overlooked the existence of hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You should be thankful. But your safety has passed. He does not need you -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he has many more useful servants - but he won't forget you again. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits as miserable slaves would please him far more than hobbits happy and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">free. There is such a thing as malice and revenge.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Revenge?' said Frodo. 'Revenge for what? I still don't understand what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all this has to do with Bilbo and myself, and our ring.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It has everything to do with it,' said Gandalf. 'You do not know the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">real peril yet; but you shall. I was not sure of it myself when I was last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here; but the time has come to speak. Give me the ring for a moment.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo took it from his breeches-pocket, where it was clasped to a chain<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that hung from his belt. He unfastened it and handed it slowly to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard. It felt suddenly very heavy, as if either it or Frodo himself was in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some way reluctant for Gandalf to touch it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf held it up. It looked to be made of pure and solid gold. 'Can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you see any markings on it?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' said Frodo. 'There are none. It is quite plain, and it never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shows a scratch or sign of wear.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well then, look!' To Frodo's astonishment and distress the wizard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">threw it suddenly into the middle of a glowing corner of the fire. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave a cry and groped for the tongs; but Gandalf held him back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Wait!' he said in a commanding voice, giving Frodo a quick look from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under his bristling brows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">No apparent change came over the ring. After a while Gandalf got up,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">closed the shutters outside the window, and drew the curtains. The room<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became dark and silent, though the clack of Sam's shears, now nearer to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windows, could still be heard faintly from the garden. For a moment the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard stood looking at the fire; then he stooped and removed the ring to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hearth with the tongs, and at once picked it up. Frodo gasped.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is quite cool,' said Gandalf. 'Take it!' Frodo received it on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shrinking palm: it seemed to have become thicker and heavier than ever.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hold it up!' said Gandalf. 'And look closely!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Frodo did so, he now saw fine lines, finer than the finest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pen-strokes, running along the ring, outside and inside: lines of fire that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to form the letters of a flowing script. They shone piercingly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright, and yet remote, as if out of a great depth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I cannot read the fiery letters,' said Frodo in a quavering voice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' said Gandalf, 'but I can. The letters are Elvish, of an ancient<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mode, but the language is that of Mordor, which I will not utter here. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this in the Common Tongue is what is said, close enough:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
