<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is only two lines of a verse long known in Elven-lore:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Three Rings for the Elven-kings under the sky,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Seven for the Dwarf-lords in their halls of stone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nine for Mortal Men doomed to die,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One for the Dark Lord on his dark throne<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One Ring to rule them all. One Ring to find them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the Land of Mordor where the Shadows lie. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He paused, and then said slowly in a deep voice: 'This is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Master -ring, the One Ring to rule them all. This is the One Ring that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lost many ages ago, to the great weakening of his power. He greatly desires<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it - but he must not get it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo sat silent and motionless. Fear seemed to stretch out a vast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hand, like a dark cloud rising in the East and looming up to engulf him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'This ring!' he stammered. 'How, how on earth did it come to me?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah!' said Gandalf. 'That is a very long story. The beginnings lie back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Black Years, which only the lore-masters now remember. If I were to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tell you all that tale, we should still be sitting here when Spring had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed into Winter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But last night I told you of Sauron the Great, the Dark Lord. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rumours that you have heard are true: he has indeed arisen again and left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his hold in Mirkwood and returned to his ancient fastness in the Dark Tower<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Mordor. That name even you hobbits have heard of, like a shadow on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borders of old stories. Always after a defeat and a respite, the Shadow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">takes another shape and grows again.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wish it need not have happened in my time,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So do I,' said Gandalf, 'and so do all who live to see such times. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is not for them to decide. All we have to decide is what to do with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time that is given, us. And already, Frodo, our time is beginning to look<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">black. The Enemy is fast becoming very strong. His plans are far from ripe,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I think, but they are ripening. We shall be hard put to it. We should be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very hard put to it, even if it were not for this dreadful chance.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Enemy still lacks one thing to give him strength and knowledge to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beat down all resistance, break the last defences, and cover all the lands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a second darkness. He lacks the One Ring.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Three, fairest of all, the Elf-lords hid from him, and his hand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never touched them or sullied them. Seven the Dwarf-kings possessed, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three he has recovered, and the others the dragons have consumed. Nine he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave to Mortal Men, proud and great, and so ensnared them. Long ago they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fell under the dominion of the One, and they became Ringwraiths, shadows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under his great Shadow, his most terrible servants. Long ago. It is many a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year since the Nine walked abroad. Yet who knows? As the Shadow grows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">once<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more, they too may walk again. But come! We will not speak of such things<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even in the morning of the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So it is now: the Nine he has gathered to himself; the Seven also, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">else they are destroyed. The Three are hidden still. But that no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troubles him. He only needs the One; for he made that Ring himself, it is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his, and he let a great part of his own former power pass into it, so that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he could rule all the others. If he recovers it, then he will command them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all again, wherever they be, even the Three, and all that has been wrought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with them will be laid bare, and he will be stronger than ever.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And this is the dreadful chance, Frodo. He believed that the One had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perished; that the Elves had destroyed it, as should have been done. But he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knows now that it has not perished, that it has been found. So he is seeking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, seeking it, and all his thought is bent on it. It is his great hope and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">our great fear.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why, why wasn't it destroyed?' cried Frodo. 'And how did the Enemy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever come to lose it, if he was so strong, and it was so precious to him?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He clutched the Ring in his hand, as if he saw already dark fingers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stretching out to seize it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was taken from him,' said Gandalf. 'The strength of the Elves to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">resist him was greater long ago; and not all Men were estranged from them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Men of Westernesse came to their aid. That is a chapter of ancient<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">history which it might be good to recall; for there was sorrow then too, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gathering dark, but great valour, and great deeds that were not wholly vain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One day, perhaps, I will tell you all the tale, or you shall hear it told in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">full by one who knows it best.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But for the moment, since most of all you need to know how this thing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came to you, and that will be tale enough, this is all that I will say. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was Gil-galad, Elven-king and Elendil of Westernesse who overthrew Sauron,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though they themselves perished in the deed; and Isildur Elendil's son cut<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Ring from Sauron's hand and took it for his own. Then Sauron was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanquished and his spirit fled and was hidden for long years, until his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow took shape again in Mirkwood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But the Ring was lost. It fell into the Great River, Anduin, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished. For Isildur was marching north along the east banks of the River,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and near the Gladden Fields he was waylaid by the Ores of the Mountains, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost all his folk were slain. He leaped into the waters, but the Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slipped from his finger as he swam, and then the Ores saw him and killed him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with arrows.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf paused. 'And there in the dark pools amid the Gladden Fields,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said, 'the Ring passed out of knowledge and legend; and even so much of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its history is known now only to a few, and the Council of the Wise could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">discover no more. But at last I can carry on the story, I think.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Fong after, but still very long ago, there lived by the banks of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Great River on the edge of Wilderland a clever -handed and quiet-footed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little people. I guess they were of hobbit -kind; akin to the fathers of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fathers of the Stoors, for they loved the River, and often swam in it, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made little boats of reeds. There was among them a family of high repute,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for it was large and wealthier than most, and it was ruled by a grandmother<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the folk, stern and wise in old lore, such as they had. The most<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inquisitive and curious-minded of that family was called Smjagol. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">interested in roots and beginnings; he dived into deep pools; he burrowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under trees and growing plants; he tunnelled into green mounds; and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ceased to look up at the hill-tops, or the leaves on trees, or the flowers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">opening in the air: his head and his eyes were downward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He had a friend called Djagol, of similar sort, sharper -eyed but not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">so quick and strong. On a time they took a boat and went down to the Gladden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fields, where there were great beds of iris and flowering reeds. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Smjagol got out and went nosing about the banks but Deal sat in the boat and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fished. Suddenly a great fish took his hook, and before he knew where he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was, he was dragged out and down into the water, to the bottom. Then he let<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go of his line, for he thought he saw something shining in the river-bed;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and holding his breath he grabbed at it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then up he came spluttering, with weeds in his hair and a handful of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mud; and he swam to the bank. And behold! when he washed the mud away,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in his hand lay a beautiful golden ring; and it shone and glittered in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun, so that his heart was glad. But Smjagol had been watching him from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind a tree, and as Deal gloated over the ring, Smjagol came softly up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"'Give us that, Deal, my love," said Smjagol, over his friend's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulder.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'"Why?" said Deal.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Because it's my birthday, my love, and I wants it," said Smjagol.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'"I don't care," said Deal. "I have given you a present already, more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than I could afford. I found this, and I'm going to keep it."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Oh, are you indeed, my love," said Smjagol; and he caught Deal by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the throat and strangled him, because the gold looked so bright and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beautiful. Then he put the ring on his finger.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No one ever found out what had become of Deal; he was murdered far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from home, and his body was cunningly hidden. But Smjagol returned alone;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he found that none of his family could see him, when he was wearing the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring. He was very pleased with his discovery and he concealed it; and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used it to find out secrets, and he put his knowledge to crooked and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">malicious uses. He became sharp-eyed and keen-eared for all that was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hurtful. The ring had given him power according to his stature. It is not to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be wondered at that he became very unpopular and was shunned (when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">visible)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by all his relations. They kicked him, and he bit their feet. He took to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thieving, and going about muttering to himself, and gurgling in his throat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So they called him Gollum, and cursed him, and told him to go far away; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his grandmother, desiring peace, expelled him from the family and turned him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of her hole.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He wandered in loneliness, weeping a little for the hardness of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">world, and he journeyed up the River, till he came to a stream that flowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down from the mountains, and he went that way. He caught fish in deep pools<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with invisible fingers and ate them raw. One day it was very hot, and as he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was bending over a pool, he felt a burning on the back of his head) and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dazzling light from the water pained his wet eyes. He wondered at it, for he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had almost forgotten about the Sun. Then for the last time he looked up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shook his fist at her.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But as he lowered his eyes, he saw far above the tops of the Misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains, out of which the stream came. And he thought suddenly: "It would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be cool and shady under those mountains. The Sun could not watch me there.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The roots of those mountains must be roots indeed; there must be great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secrets buried there which have not been discovered since the beginning."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™So he journeyed by night up into the highlands, and he found a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cave out of which the dark stream ran; and he wormed his way like a maggot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the heart of the hills, and vanished out of all knowledge. The Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went into the shadows with him, and even the maker, when his power had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">begun<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to grow again, could learn nothing of it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gollum!' cried Frodo. 'Gollum? Do you mean that this is the very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gollum-creature that Bilbo met? How loathsome!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think it is a sad story,' said the wizard, 'and it might have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">happened to others, even to some hobbits that I have known.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I can't believe that Gollum was connected with hobbits, however<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distantly,' said Frodo with some heat. 'What an abominable notion!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is true all the same,' replied Gandalf. 'About their origins, at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any rate, I know more than hobbits do themselves. And even Bilbo's story<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suggests the kinship. There was a great deal in the background of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">minds and memories that was very similar. They understood one another<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remarkably well, very much better than a hobbit would understand, say, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dwarf, or an Ore, or even an Elf. Think of the riddles they both knew, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one thing.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Frodo. 'Though other folks besides hobbits ask riddles, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of much the same sort. And hobbits don't cheat. Gollum meant to cheat all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the time. He was just trying to put poor Bilbo off his guard. And I daresay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it amused his wickedness to start a game which might end in providing him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with an easy victim, but if he lost would not hurt him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Only too true, I fear,' said Gandalf. 'But there was something else in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, I think, which you don't see yet. Even Gollum was not wholly ruined. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had proved tougher than even one of the Wise would have guessed -as a hobbit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might. There was a little corner of his mind that was still his own, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light came through it, as through a chink in the dark: light out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">past. It was actually pleasant, I think, to hear a kindly voice again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bringing up memories of wind, and trees, and sun on the grass, and such<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgotten things.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But that, of course, would only make the evil part of him angrier in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the end - unless it could be conquered. Unless it could be cured.' Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sighed. 'Alas! there is little hope of that for him. Yet not no hope. No,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not though he possessed the Ring so long, almost as far back as he can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remember. For it was long since he had worn it much: in the black darkness<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it was seldom needed. Certainly he had never "faded". He is thin and tough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still. But the thing was eating up his mind, of course, and the torment had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become almost unbearable.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All the "great secrets" under the mountains had turned out to be just<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">empty night: there was nothing more to find out, nothing worth doing, only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nasty furtive eating and resentful remembering. He was altogether wretched.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He hated the dark, and he hated light more: he hated everything, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring most of all.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you mean?' said Frodo. 'Surely the Ring was his precious and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the only thing he cared for? But if he hated it, why didn't he get rid of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, or go away and leave it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You ought to begin to understand, Frodo, after all you have heard,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Gandalf. 'He hated it and loved it, as he hated and loved himself. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not get rid of it. He had no will left in the matter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A Ring of Power looks after itself, Frodo. It may slip off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treacherously, but its keeper never abandons it. At most he plays with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">idea of handing it on to someone else's care - and that only at an early<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stage, when it first begins to grip. But as far as I know Bilbo alone in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">history has ever gone beyond playing, and really done it. He needed all my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help, too. And even so he would never have just forsaken it, or cast it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside. It was not Gollum, Frodo, but the Ring itself that decided things.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Ring left him. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What, just in time to meet Bilbo?' said Frodo. 'Wouldn't an Ore have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suited it better?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is no laughing matter,' said Gandalf. 'Not for you. It was the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strangest event in the whole history of the Ring so far: Bilbo's arrival<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">just at that time, and putting his hand on it, blindly, in the dark.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There was more than one power at work, Frodo. The Ring was trying to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get back to its master. It had slipped from Isildur's hand and betrayed him;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then when a chance came it caught poor Deal, and he was murdered; and after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that Gollum, and it had devoured him. It could make no further use of him:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was too small and mean; and as long as it stayed with him he would never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leave his deep pool again. So now, when its master was awake once more and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sending out his dark thought from Mirkwood, it abandoned Gollum. Only to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">picked up by the most unlikely person imaginable: Bilbo from the Shire!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Behind that there was something else at work, beyond any design of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring-maker. I can put it no plainer than by saying that Bilbo was meant to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find the Ring, and not by its maker. In which case you also were meant to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have it. And that maybe an encouraging thought.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is not,' said Frodo. "Though I am not sure that I understand you.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But how have you learned all this about the Ring, and about Gollum? Do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">really know it all, or are you just guessing still?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf looked at Frodo, and his eyes glinted. I knew much and I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">learned much,' he answered. 'But I am not going to give an account of all my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doings to you. The history of Elendil and Isildur and the One Ring is known<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to all the Wise. Your ring is shown to be that One Ring by the fire- writing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone, apart from any other evidence.' 'And when did you discover that?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asked Frodo, interrupting. 'Just now in this room, of course,' answered the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard sharply. 'But I expected to find it. I have come back from dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journeys and long search to make that final test. It is the last proof, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all is now only too clear. Making out Gollum's part, and fitting it into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gap in the history, required some thought. I may have started with guesses<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about Gollum, but I am not guessing now. I know. I have seen him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You have seen Gollum?' exclaimed Frodo in amazement.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes. The obvious thing to do, of course, if one could. I tried long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ago; but I have managed it at last.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then what happened after Bilbo escaped from him? Do you know that?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not so clearly. What I have told you is what Gollum was willing to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tell - though not, of course, in the way I have reported it. Gollum is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">liar, and you have to sift his words. For instance, he called the Ring his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"birthday present", and he stuck to that. He said it came from his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grandmother, who had lots of beautiful things of that kind. A ridiculous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">story. I have no doubt that Smjagol's grandmother was a matriarch, a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">person in her way, but to talk of her possessing many Elven-rings was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">absurd, and as for giving them away, it was a lie. But a lie with a grain of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">truth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The murder of Deal haunted Gollum, and he had made up a defence,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">repeating it to his "precious" over and over again, as he gnawed bones in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dark, until he almost believed it. It was his birthday. Deal ought to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have given the ring to him. It had previously turned up just so as to be a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">present. It was his birthday present, and so on, and on.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I endured him as long as I could, but the truth was desperately<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">important, and in the end I had to be harsh. I put the fear of fire on him,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and wrung the true story out of him, bit by bit, together with much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snivelling and snarling. He thought he was misunderstood and ill-used. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when he had at last told me his history, as far as the end of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riddle-game and Bilbo's escape, he would not say any more, except in dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hints. Some other fear was on him greater than mine. He muttered that he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going to gel his own back. People would see if he would stand being kicked,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and driven into a hole and then robbed. Gollum had good friends now, good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends and very strong. They would help him. Baggins would pay for it. That<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was his chief thought. He hated Bilbo and cursed his name. What is more, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew where he came from.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But how did he find that out?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, as for the name, Bilbo very foolishly told Gollum himself; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after that it would not be difficult to discover his country, once Gollum<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came out. Oh yes, he came out. His longing for the Ring proved stronger than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his fear of the Ores, or even of the light. After a year or two he left the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains. You see, though still bound by desire of it, the Ring was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer devouring him; he began to revive a little. He felt old, terribly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old, yet less timid, and he was mortally hungry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Light, light of Sun and Moon, he still feared and hated, and he always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will, I think; but he was cunning. He found he could hide from daylight and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moonshine, and make his way swiftly and softly by dead of night with his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale cold eyes, and catch small frightened or unwary things. He grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stronger and bolder with new food and new air. He found his way into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mirkwood, as one would expect.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Is that where you found him?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I saw him there,' answered Gandalf, 'but before that he had wandered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far, following Bilbo's trail. It was difficult to learn anything from him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for certain, for his talk was constantly interrupted by curses and threats.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"What had it got in its pocketses?" he said. "It wouldn't say, no precious.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Little cheat. Not a fair question. It cheated first, it did. It broke the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rules. We ought to have squeezed it, yes precious. And we will, precious!"<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™That is a sample of his talk. I don't suppose you want any more. I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weary days of it. But from hints dropped among the snarls I even gathered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that his padding feet had taken him at last to Esgaroth, and even to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">streets of Dale, listening secretly and peering. Well, the news of the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">events went far and wide in Wilderland, and many had heard Bilbo's name and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew where he came from. We had made no secret of our return journey to his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">home in the West. Gollum's sharp ears would soon learn what he wanted.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then why didn't he track Bilbo further?' asked Frodo. 'Why didn't he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come to the Shire?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah,' said Gandalf, 'now we come to it. I think Gollum tried to. He set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out and came back westward, as far as the Great River. But then he turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside. He was not daunted by the distance, I am sure. No, something else<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drew him away. So my friends think, those that hunted him for me.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Wood -elves tracked him first, an easy task for them, for his trail<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was still fresh then. Through Mirkwood and back again it led them, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they never caught him. The wood was full of the rumour of him, dreadful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tales even among beasts and birds. The Woodmen said that there was some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">new<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terror abroad, a ghost that drank blood. It climbed trees to find nests; it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crept into holes to find the young; it slipped through windows to find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cradles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But at the western edge of Mirkwood the trail turned away. It wandered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off southwards and passed out of the Wood-elves' ken, and was lost. And then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I made a great mistake. Yes, Frodo, and not the first; though I fear it may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prove the worst. I let the matter be. I let him go; for I had much else to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think of at that time, and I still trusted the lore of Saruman.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, that was years ago. I have paid for it since with many dark and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dangerous days. The trail was long cold when I took it up again, after Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left here. And my search would have been in vain, but for the help that I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had from a friend: Aragorn, the greatest traveller and huntsman of this age<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the world. Together we sought for Gollum down the whole length of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wilderland, without hope, and without success. But at last, when I had given<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up the chase and turned to other parts, Gollum was found. My friend returned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the great perils bringing the miserable creature with him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What he had been doing he would not say. He only wept and called us<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cruel, with many a gollum in his throat; and when we pressed him he whined<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and cringed, and rubbed his long hands, licking his fingers as if they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pained him, as if he remembered some old torture. But I am afraid there is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no possible doubt: he had made his slow, sneaking way, step by step, mile by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mile, south, down at last to the Land of Mordor.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A heavy silence fell in the room. Frodo could hear his heart beating.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Even outside everything seemed still. No sound of Sam's shears could now be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Yes, to Mordor,' said Gandalf. 'Alas! Mordor draws all wicked things,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the Dark Power was bending all its will to gather them there. The Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Enemy would leave its mark, too, leave him open to the summons. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all folk were whispering then of the new Shadow in the South, and its hatred<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the West. There were his fine new friends, who would help him in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">revenge !<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Wretched fool! In that land he would learn much, too much for his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comfort. And sooner or later as he lurked and pried on the borders he would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be caught, and taken - for examination. That was the way of it, I fear. When<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was found he had already been there long, and was on his way back. On<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some errand of mischief. But that does not matter much now. His worst<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mischief was done.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, alas! through him the Enemy has learned that the One has been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found again. He knows where Isildur fell. He knows where Gollum found his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring. He knows that it is a Great Ring, for it gave long life. He knows that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it is not one of the Three, for they have never been lost, and they endure<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no evil. He knows that it is not one of the Seven, or the Nine, for they are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accounted for. He knows that it is the One. And he has at last heard, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think, of hobbits and the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Shire - he may be seeking for it now, if he has not already found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out where it lies. Indeed, Frodo, I fear that he may even think that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long -unnoticed name of Baggins has become important.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But this is terrible!' cried Frodo. 'Far worse than the worst that I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">imagined from your hints and warnings. O Gandalf, best of friends, what am I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to do? For now I am really afraid. What am I to do? What a pity that Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did not stab that vile creature, when he had a chance!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Pity? It was Pity that stayed his hand. Pity, and Mercy: not to strike<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without need. And he has been well rewarded, Frodo. Be sure that he took so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little hurt from the evil, and escaped in the end, because he began his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ownership of the Ring so. With Pity.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sorry,' said Frodo. 'But I am frightened; and I do not feel any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pity for Gollum.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You have not seen him,' Gandalf broke in.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, and I don't want to,' said Frodo. I can't understand you. Do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mean to say that you, and the Elves, have let him live on after all those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horrible deeds? Now at any rate he is as bad as an Ore, and just an enemy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He deserves death.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have not much hope that Gollum can be cured before he dies, but there is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chance of it. And he is bound up with the fate of the Ring. My heart tells<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me that he has some part to play yet, for good or ill, before the end; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when that comes, the pity of Bilbo may rule the fate of many - yours not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least. In any case we did not kill him: he is very old and very wretched.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Wood-elves have him in prison, but they treat him with such kindness as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they can find in their wise hearts.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All the same,' said Frodo, 'even if Bilbo could not kill Gollum, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish he had not kept the Ring. I wish he had never found it, and that I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not got it! Why did you let me keep it? Why didn't you make me throw it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away, or, or destroy it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let you? Make you?' said the wizard. 'Haven't you been listening to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all that I have said? You are not thinking of what you are saying. But as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for throwing it away, that was obviously wrong. These Rings have a way of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">being found. In evil hands it might have done great evil. Worst of all, it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might have fallen into the hands of the Enemy. Indeed it certainly would;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for this is the One, and he is exerting all his power to find it or draw it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to himself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course, my dear Frodo, it was dangerous for you; and that has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troubled me deeply. But there was so much at stake that I had to take some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">risk - though even when I was far away there has never been a day when the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire has not been guarded by watchful eyes. As long as you never used it, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did not think that the Ring would have any lasting effect on you, not for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil, not at any rate for a very long time. And you must remember that nine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years ago, when I last saw you, I still knew little for certain.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But why not destroy it, as you say should have been done long ago?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cried Frodo again. If you had warned me, or even sent me a message, I would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have done away with it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Would you? How would you do that? Have you ever tried?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No. But I suppose one could hammer it or melt it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Try!' said Gandalf. Try now!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo drew the Ring out of his pocket again and looked at it. It now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared plain and smooth, without mark or device that he could see. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gold looked very fair and pure, and Frodo thought how rich and beautiful was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its colour, how perfect was its roundness. It was an admirable thing and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">altogether precious. When he took it out he had intended to fling it from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him into the very hottest part of the fire. But he found now that he could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not do so, not without a great struggle. He weighed the Ring in his hand,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hesitating, and forcing himself to remember all that Gandalf had told him;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then with an effort of will he made a movement, as if to cast it away -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but he found that he had put it back in his pocket.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf laughed grimly. 'You see? Already you too, Frodo, cannot easily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">let it go, nor will to damage it. And I could not "make" you - except by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">force, which would break your mind. But as for breaking the Ring, force is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">useless. Even if you took it and struck it with a heavy sledge-hammer, it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would make no dint in it. It cannot be unmade by your hands, or by mine.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Your small fire, of course, would not melt even ordinary gold. This<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring has already passed through it unscathed, and even unheated. But there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is no smith's forge in this Shire that could change it at all. Not even the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anvils and furnaces of the Dwarves could do that. It has been said that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dragon-fire could melt and consume the Rings of Power, but there is not now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any dragon left on earth in which the old fire is hot enough; nor was there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever any dragon, not even Ancalagon the Black, who could have harmed the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring, the Ruling Ring, for that was made by Sauron himself. There is only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one way: to find the Cracks of Doom in the depths of Orodruin, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fire-mountain, and cast the Ring in there, if you really wish to destroy it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to put it beyond the grasp of the Enemy for ever.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do really wish to destroy it!' cried Frodo. 'Or, well, to have it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">destroyed. I am not made for perilous quests. I wish I had never seen the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring ! Why did it come to me? Why was I chosen?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Such questions cannot be answered,' said Gandalf. 'You may be sure<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that it was not for any merit that others do not possess: not for power or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wisdom, at any rate. But you have been chosen, and you must therefore use<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">such strength and heart and wits as you have.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I have so little of any of these things! You are wise and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">powerful. Will you not take the Ring?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No!' cried Gandalf, springing to his feet. 'With that power I should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have power too great and terrible. And over me the Ring would gain a power<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still greater and more deadly.' His eyes flashed and his face was lit as by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a fire within. 'Do not tempt me! For I do not wish to become like the Dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lord himself. Yet the way of the Ring to my heart is by pity, pity for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weakness and the desire of strength to do good. Do not tempt me! I dare not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take it, not even to keep it safe, unused. The wish to wield it would be too<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great, for my strength. I shall have such need of it. Great perils lie<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He went to the window and drew aside the curtains and the shutters.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sunlight streamed back again into the room. Sam passed along the path<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">outside whistling. 'And now,' said the wizard, turning back to Frodo, 'the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">decision lies with you. But I will always help you.' He laid his hand on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo's shoulder. 'I will help you bear this burden, as long as It is yours<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to bear. But we must do something, soon. The Enemy is moving.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a long silence. Gandalf sat down again and puffed at his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pipe, as if lost in thought. His eyes seemed closed, but under the lids he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was watching Frodo intently. Frodo gazed fixedly at the red embers on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hearth, until they filled all his vision, and he seemed to be looking down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into profound wells of fire. He was thinking of the fabled Cracks of Doom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the terror of the Fiery Mountain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well!' said Gandalf at last. 'What are you thinking about? Have you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">decided what to do?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No!' answered Frodo, coming back to himself out of darkness, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finding to his surprise that it was not dark, and that out of the window he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could see the sunlit garden. 'Or perhaps, yes. As far as I understand what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you have said, I suppose I must keep the Ring and guard it, at least for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">present, whatever it may do to me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Whatever it may do, it will be slow, slow to evil, if you keep it with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that purpose,' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope so,' said Frodo. 'But I hope that you may find some other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">better keeper soon. But in the meanwhile it seems that I am a danger, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">danger to all that live near me. I cannot keep the Ring and stay here. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ought to leave Bag End, leave the Shire, leave everything and go away.â€™ He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sighed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
