<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I should like to save the Shire, if I could - though there have been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">times when I thought the inhabitants too stupid and dull for words, and have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt that an earthquake or an invasion of dragons might be good for them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But I don't feel like that now. I feel that as long as the Shire lies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind, safe and comfortable, I shall find wandering more bearable: I shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know that somewhere there is a firm foothold, even if my feet cannot stand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course, I have sometimes thought of going away, but I imagined that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as a kind of holiday, a series of adventures like Bilbo's or better, ending<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in peace. But this would mean exile, a flight from danger into danger,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drawing it after me. And I suppose I must go alone, if I am to do that and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">save the Shire. But I feel very small, and very uprooted, and well -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desperate. The Enemy is so strong and terrible.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He did not tell Gandalf, but as he was speaking a great desire to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">follow Bilbo flamed up in his heart - to follow Bilbo, and even perhaps to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find him again. It was so strong that it overcame his fear: he could almost<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have run out there and then down the road without his hat, as Bilbo had done<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on a similar morning long ago.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My dear Frodo!' exclaimed Gandalf. 'Hobbits really are amazing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creatures, as I have said before. You can learn all that there is to know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about their ways in a month, and yet after a hundred years they can still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">surprise you at a pinch. I hardly expected to get such an answer, not even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from you. But Bilbo made no mistake in choosing his heir, though he little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought how important it would prove. I am afraid you are right. The Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will not be able to stay hidden in the Shire much longer; and for your own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sake, as well as for others, you will have to go, and leave the name of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins behind you. That name will not be safe to have, outside the Shire or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Wild. I will give you a travelling name now. When you go, go as Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Underhill.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I don't think you need go alone. Not if you know of anyone you can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust, and who would be willing to go by your side - and that you would be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willing to take into unknown perils. But if you look for a companion, be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">careful in choosing! And be careful of what you say, even to your closest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends! The enemy has many spies and many ways of hearing.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly he stopped as if listening. Frodo became aware that all was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very quiet, inside and outside. Gandalf crept to one side of the window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then with a dart he sprang to the sill, and thrust a long arm out and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">downwards. There was a squawk, and up came Sam Gamgee's curly head<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hauled by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one ear.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, well, bless my beard!' said Gandalf. 'Sam Gamgee is it? Now what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may you be doing?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lor bless you, Mr. Gandalf, sir!' said Sam. 'Nothing! Leastways I was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">just trimming the grass-border under the window, if you follow me.' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">picked up his shears and exhibited them as evidence.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't,' said Gandalf grimly. It is some time since I last heard the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sound of your shears. How long have you been eavesdropping?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Eavesdropping, sir? I don't follow you, begging your pardon. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ain't no eaves at Bag End, and that's a fact.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't be a fool! What have you heard, and why did you listen?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf s eyes flashed and his brows stuck out like bristles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Mr. Frodo, sir!' cried Sam quaking. 'Don't let him hurt me, sir! Don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">let him turn me into anything unnatural! My old dad would take on so. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meant no harm, on my honour, sir!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He won't hurt you,' said Frodo, hardly able to keep from laughing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">although he was himself startled and rather puzzled. 'He knows, as well as I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do, that you mean no harm. But just you up and answer his questions straight<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, sir,' said Sam dithering a little. 'I heard a deal that I didn't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rightly understand, about an enemy, and rings, and Mr. Bilbo, sir, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dragons, and a fiery mountain, and - and Elves, sir. I listened because I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">couldn't help myself, if you know what I mean. Lor bless me, sir, but I do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">love tales of that sort. And I believe them too, whatever Ted may say.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves, sir! I would dearly love to see them. Couldn't you take me to see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves, sir, when you go?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly Gandalf laughed. 'Come inside!' he shouted, and putting out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">both his arms he lifted the astonished Sam, shears, grass-clippings and all,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right through the window and stood him on the floor. 'Take you to see Elves,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eh?' he said, eyeing Sam closely, but with a smile flickering on his face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So you heard that Mr. Frodo is going away?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I did, sir. And that's why I choked: which you heard seemingly. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tried not to, sir, but it burst out of me: I was so upset.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It can't be helped, Sam,' said Frodo sadly. He had suddenly realized<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that flying from the Shire would mean more painful partings than merely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saying farewell to the familiar comforts of Bag End. 'I shall have to go.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But' - and here he looked hard at Sam - 'if you really care about me, you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will keep that dead secret. See? If you don't, if you even breathe a word of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what you've heard here, then I hope Gandalf will turn you into a spotted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">toad and fill the garden full of grass-snakes.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam fell on his knees, trembling. 'Get up, Sam!' said Gandalf. I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought of something better than that. Something to shut your mouth, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">punish you properly for listening. You shall go away with Mr. Frodo!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Me, sir!' cried Sam, springing up like a dog invited for a walk. 'Me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go and see Elves and all! Hooray!' he shouted, and then burst into tears.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 3 . Three is Company<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You ought to go quietly, and you ought to go soon,' said Gandalf. Two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or three weeks had passed, and still Frodo made no sign of getting ready to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go-<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I know. But it is difficult to do both,' he objected. If I just vanish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like Bilbo, the tale will be all over the Shire in no time.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course you mustn't vanish!' said Gandalf. 'That wouldn't do at all!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I said soon, not instantly. If you can think of any way of slipping out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire without its being generally known, it will be worth a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delay. But you must not delay too long.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What about the autumn, on or after Our Birthday?' asked Frodo. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think I could probably make some arrangements by then.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To tell the truth, he was very reluctant to start, now that it had come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the point. Bag End seemed a more desirable residence than it had for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years, and he wanted to savour as much as he could of his last summer in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire. When autumn came, he knew that part at least of his heart would think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more kindly of journeying, as it always did at that season. He had indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">privately made up his mind to leave on his fiftieth birthday: Bilbo's one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hundred and twenty-eighth. It seemed somehow the proper day on which to set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out and follow him. Following Bilbo was uppermost in his mind, and the one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing that made the thought of leaving bearable. He thought as little as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">possible about the Ring, and where it might lead him in the end. But he did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not tell all his thoughts to Gandalf. What the wizard guessed was always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">difficult to tell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He looked at Frodo and smiled. 'Very well,' he said. 'I think that will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do - but it must not be any later. I am getting very anxious. In the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mean-while, do take care, and don't let out any hint of where you are going!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And see that Sam Gamgee does not talk. If he does, I really shall turn him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into a toad.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As for where I am going,' said Frodo, 'it would be difficult to give<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that away, for I have no clear idea myself, yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't be absurd!' said Gandalf. 'I am not warning you against leaving<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">an address at the post-office! But you are leaving the Shire - and that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should not be known, until you are far away. And you must go, or at least<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set out, either North, South, West or East - and the direction should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">certainly not be known.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have been so taken up with the thoughts of leaving Bag End, and of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saying farewell, that I have never even considered the direction,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo. 'For where am I to go? And by what shall I steer? What is to be my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quest? Bilbo went to find a treasure, there and back again; but I go to lose<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one, and not return, as far as I can see.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But you cannot see very far,' said Gandalf. 'Neither can I. It may be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your task to find the Cracks of Doom; but that quest may be for others: I do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not know. At any rate you are not ready for that long road yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No indeed!' said Frodo. 'But in the meantime what course am I to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lake?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Towards danger; but not too rashly, nor too straight,' answered the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard. 'If you want my advice, make for Rivendell. That journey should not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prove too perilous, though the Road is less easy than it was, and it will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grow worse as the year fails.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Rivendell!' said Frodo. 'Very good: I will go east, and I will make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for Rivendell. I will take Sam to visit the Elves; he will be delighted.' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke lightly; but his heart was moved suddenly with a desire to see the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house of Elrond Halfelven, and breathe the air of that deep valley where<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many of the Fair Folk still dwelt in peace.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One summer's evening an astonishing piece of news reached the Ivy Bush<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Green Dragon. Giants and other portents on the borders of the Shire were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgotten for more important matters: Mr. Frodo was selling Bag End, indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had already sold it - to the Sackville-Bagginses!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'For a nice bit, loo,' said some. 'At a bargain price,' said others,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and that's more likely when Mistress Fobelia's the buyer.' (Otho had died<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some years before, at the ripe but disappointed age of 102.)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Just why Mr. Frodo was selling his beautiful hole was even more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">debatable than the price. A few held the theory - supported by the nods and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hints of Mr. Baggins himself - that Frodo's money was running out: he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going to leave Hobbiton and live in a quiet way on the proceeds of the sale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down in Buckland among his Brandybuck relations. 'As far from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sackville-Bagginses as may be,' some added. But so firmly fixed had the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">notion of the immeasurable wealth of the Bagginses of Bag End become that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">most found this hard to believe, harder than any other reason or unreason<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that their fancy could suggest: to most it suggested a dark and yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unrevealed plot by Gandalf. Though he kept himself very quiet and did not go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about by day, it was well known that he was 'hiding up in the Bag End'. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">however a removal might fit in with the designs of his wizardry, there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no doubt about the fact: Frodo Baggins was going back to Buckland.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, I shall be moving this autumn,' he said. 'Merry Brandybuck is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking out for a nice little hole for me, or perhaps a small house.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As a matter of fact with Merry's help he had already chosen and bought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a little house at Crickhollow in the country beyond Bucklebury. To all but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam he pretended he was going to settle down there permanently. The decision<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to set out eastwards had suggested the idea to him; for Buckland was on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastern borders of the Shire, and as he had lived there in childhood his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going back would at least seem credible.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf stayed in the Shire for over two months. Then one evening, at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the end of June, soon after Frodo's plan had been finally arranged, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly announced that he was going off again next morning. 'Only for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">short while, I hope,' he said. 'But I am going down beyond the southern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borders to get some news, if I can. I have been idle longer than I should.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He spoke lightly, but it seemed to Frodo that he looked rather worried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Has anything happened?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well no; but I have heard something that has made me anxious and needs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking into. If I think it necessary after all for you to get off at once,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I shall come back immediately, or at least send word. In the meanwhile stick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to your plan; but be more careful than ever, especially of the Ring. Fet me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">impress on you once more: don't use it!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He went off at dawn. 'I may be back any day,' he said. 'At the very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">latest I shall come back for the farewell party. I think after all you may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">need my company on the Road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first Frodo was a good deal disturbed, and wondered often what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf could have heard; but his uneasiness wore off, and in the fine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weather he forgot his troubles for a while. The Shire had seldom seen so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fair a summer, or so rich an autumn: the trees were laden with apples, honey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was dripping in the combs, and the corn was tall and full.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Autumn was well under way before Frodo began to worry about Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. September was passing and there was still no news of him. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Birthday, and the removal, drew nearer, and still he did not come, or send<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">word. Bag End began to be busy. Some of Frodo's friends came to stay and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help him with the packing: there was Fredegar Bolger and Folco Boffin, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of course his special friends Pippin Took and Merry Brandybuck. Between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they turned the whole place upside-down.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On September 20th two covered carts went off laden to Buckland,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conveying the furniture and goods that Frodo had not sold to his new home,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by way of the Brandywine Bridge. The next day Frodo became really anxious,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and kept a constant look-out for Gandalf. Thursday, his birthday morning,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dawned as fair and clear as it had long ago for Bilbo's great party. Still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf did not appear. In the evening Frodo gave his farewell feast: it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quite small, just a dinner for himself and his four helpers; but he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troubled and fell in no mood for it. The thought that he would so soon have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to part with his young friends weighed on his heart. He wondered how he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would break it to them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The four younger hobbits were, however, in high spirits, and the party<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">soon became very cheerful in spite of Gandalf s absence. The dining-room was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bare except for a table and chairs, but the food was good, and there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good wine: Frodo's wine had not been included in the sale to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sackville-Bagginses.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Whatever happens to the rest of my stuff, when the S.-B.s get their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">claws on it, at any rate I have found a good home for this!' said Frodo, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he drained his glass. It was the last drop of Old Winyards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had sung many songs, and talked of many things they had done<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">together, they toasted Bilbo's birthday, and they drank his health and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo's together according to Frodo's custom. Then they went out for a sniff<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of air, and glimpse of the stars, and then they went to bed. Frodo's party<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was over, and Gandalf had not come.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The next morning they were busy packing another cart with the remainder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the luggage. Merry took charge of this, and drove off with Fatty (that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fredegar Bolger). 'Someone must get there and warm the house before you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arrive,' said Merry. 'Well, see you later - the day after tomorrow, if you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't go to sleep on the way!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Folco went home after lunch, but Pippin remained behind. Frodo was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">restless and anxious, listening in vain for a sound of Gandalf. He decided<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to wait until nightfall. After that, if Gandalf wanted him urgently, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would go to Crickhollow, and might even get there first. For Frodo was going<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on foot. His plan - for pleasure and a last look at the Shire as much as any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other reason - was to walk from Hobbiton to Bucklebury Ferry, taking it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fairly easy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I shall get myself a bit into training, too,' he said, looking at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself in a dusty mirror in the half-empty hall. He had not done any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strenuous walking for a long time, and the reflection looked rather flabby,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he thought.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After lunch, the Sackville-Bagginses, Lobelia and her sandy-haired son,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lotho, turned up, much to Frodo's annoyance. 'Ours at last!' said Lobelia,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as she stepped inside. It was not polite; nor strictly true, for the sale of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bag End did not take effect until midnight. But Lobelia can perhaps be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgiven: she had been obliged to wait about seventy-seven years longer for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bag End than she once hoped, and she was now a hundred years old.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Anyway,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">she had come to see that nothing she had paid for had been carried off; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">she wanted the keys. It took a long while to satisfy her, as she had brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a complete inventory with her and went right through it. In the end she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">departed with Lotho and the spare key and the promise that the other key<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would be left at the Gamgees' in Bagshot Row. She snorted, and showed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">plainly that she thought the Gamgees capable of plundering the hole during<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the night. Frodo did not offer her any tea.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He took his own tea with Pippin and Sam Gamgee in the kitchen. It had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been officially announced that Sam was coming to Buckland 'to do for Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo and look after his bit of garden'; an arrangement that was approved by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Gaffer, though it did not console him for the prospect of having Lobelia<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as a neighbour.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Our last meal at Bag End!' said Frodo, pushing back his chair. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left the washing up for Lobelia. Pippin and Sam strapped up their three<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">packs and piled them in the porch. Pippin went out for a last stroll in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">garden. Sam disappeared.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun went down. Bag End seemed sad and gloomy and dishevelled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wandered round the familiar rooms, and saw the light of the sunset fade on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the walls, and shadows creep out of the corners. It grew slowly dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indoors. He went out and walked down to the gate at the bottom of the path,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then on a short way down the Hill Road. He half expected to see Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come striding up through the dusk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sky was clear and the stars were growing bright. 'It's going to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a fine night,' he said aloud. 'That's good for a beginning. I feel like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walking. I can't bear any more hanging about. I am going to start, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf must follow me.' He turned to go back, and then slopped, for he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard voices, just round the corner by the end of Bagshot Row. One voice was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">certainly the old Gaffer's; the other was strange, and somehow unpleasant.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He could not make out what it said, but he heard the Gaffer's answers, which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were rather shrill. The old man seemed put out.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, Mr. Baggins has gone away. Went this morning, and my Sam went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him: anyway all his stuff went. Yes, sold out and gone, I tell'ee. Why?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Why's none of my business, or yours. Where to? That ain't no secret. He's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moved to Bucklebury or some such place, away down yonder. Yes it is - a tidy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way. I've never been so far myself; they're queer folks in Buckland. No, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can't give no message. Good night to you!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Footsteps went away down the Hill. Frodo wondered vaguely why the fact<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they did not come on up the Hill seemed a great relief. 'I am sick of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">questions and curiosity about my doings, I suppose,' he thought. 'What an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inquisitive lot they all are!' He had half a mind to go and ask the Gaffer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who the inquirer was; but he thought better (or worse) of it, and turned and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walked quickly back to Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin was sitting on his pack in the porch. Sam was not there. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stepped inside the dark door. 'Sam!' he called. 'Sam! Time!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Coming, sir!' came the answer from far within, followed soon by Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself, wiping his mouth. He had been saying farewell to the beer -barrel in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cellar.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All aboard, Sam?' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, sir. I'll last for a bit now, sir.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo shut and locked the round door, and gave the key to Sam. 'Run<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down with this to your home, Sam!' he said. 'Then cut along the Row and meet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us as quick as you can at the gate in the lane beyond the meadows. We are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not going through the village tonight. Too many ears pricking and eyes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prying.' Sam ran off at full speed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, now we're off at last!' said Frodo. They shouldered their packs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and took up their sticks, and walked round the corner to the west side of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bag End. 'Good-bye!' said Frodo, looking at the dark blank windows. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waved<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his hand, and then turned and (following Bilbo, if he had known it) hurried<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after Peregrin down the garden-path. They jumped over the low place in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hedge at the bottom and took to the fields, passing into the darkness like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rustle in the grasses.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the bottom of the Hill on its western side they came to the gate<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">opening on to a narrow lane. There they halted and adjusted the straps of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their packs. Presently Sam appeared, trotting quickly and breathing hard;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his heavy pack was hoisted high on his shoulders, and he had put on his head<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a tall shapeless fell bag, which he called a hat. In the gloom he looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very much like a dwarf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sure you have given me all the heaviest stuff,' said Frodo. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pity snails, and all that carry their homes on their backs.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I could take a lot more yet, sir. My packet is quite light,' said Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stoutly and untruthfully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, you don't, Sam!' said Pippin. 'It is good for him. He's got<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing except what he ordered us to pack. He's been slack lately, and he'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feel the weight less when he's walked off some of his own.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Be kind to a poor old hobbit!' laughed Frodo. 'I shall be as thin as a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willow-wand, I'm sure, before I get to Buckland. But I was talking nonsense.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I suspect you have taken more than your share, Sam, and I shall look into it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at our next packing.' He picked up his stick again. 'Well, we all like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walking in the dark,' he said, 'so let's put some miles behind us before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bed.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For a short way they followed the lane westwards. Then leaving it they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turned left and took quietly to the fields again. They went in single file<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">along hedgerows and the borders of coppices, and night fell dark about them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In their dark cloaks they were as invisible as if they all had magic rings.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Since they were all hobbits, and were trying to be silent, they made no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">noise that even hobbits would hear. Even the wild things in the fields and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods hardly noticed their passing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After some time they crossed the Water, west of Hobbiton, by a narrow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">plank -bridge. The stream was there no more than a winding black ribbon,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bordered with leaning alder -trees. A mile or two further south they hastily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crossed the great road from the Brandywine Bridge; they were now in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tookland and bending south-eastwards they made for the Green Hill Country.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they began to climb its first slopes they looked back and saw the lamps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Hobbiton far off twinkling in the gentle valley of the Water. Soon it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disappeared in the folds of the darkened land, and was followed by By water<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beside its grey pool. When the light of the last farm was far behind,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peeping among the trees, Frodo turned and waved a hand in farewell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder if I shall ever look down into that valley again,' he said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quietly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had walked for about three hours they rested. The night was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clear, cool, and starry, but smoke-like wisps of mist were creeping up the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill-sides from the streams and deep meadows. Thin-clad birches, swaying in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a light wind above their heads, made a black net against the pale sky. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ate a very frugal supper (for hobbits), and then went on again. Soon they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">struck a narrow road, that went rolling up and down, fading grey into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">darkness ahead: the road to Woodhall, and Stock, and the Bucklebury Ferry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It climbed away from the main road in the Water -valley, and wound over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">skirts of the Green Hills towards Woody-End, a wild corner of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Eastfarthing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a while they plunged into a deeply cloven track between tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees that rustled their dry leaves in the night. It was very dark. At first<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they talked, or hummed a tune softly together, being now far away from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inquisitive ears. Then they marched on in silence, and Pippin began to lag<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind. At last, as they began to climb a steep slope, he stopped and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yawned.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am so sleepy,' he said, 'that soon I shall fall down on the road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Are you going to sleep on your legs? It is nearly midnight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I thought you liked walking in the dark,' said Frodo. 'But there is no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great hurry. Merry expects us some time the day after tomorrow; but that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves us nearly two days more. We'll halt at the first likely spot.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The wind's in the West,' said Sam. 'If we get to the other side of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this hill, we shall find a spot that is sheltered and snug enough, sir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There is a dry fir-wood just ahead, if I remember rightly.' Sam knew the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land well within twenty miles of Hobbiton, but that was the limit of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">geography.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Just over the top of the hill they came on the patch of fir-wood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Leaving the road they went into the deep resin-scented darkness of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees, and gathered dead sticks and cones to make a fire. Soon they had a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merry crackle of flame at the foot of a large fir-tree and they sat round it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for a while, until they began to nod. Then, each in an angle of the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree's roots, they curled up in their cloaks and blankets, and were soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fast asleep. They set no watch; even Frodo feared no danger yet, for they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were still in the heart of the Shire. A few creatures came and looked at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them when the fire had died away. A fox passing through the wood on business<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his own stopped several minutes and sniffed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hobbits!' he thought. 'Well, what next? I have heard of strange doings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in this land, but I have seldom heard of a hobbit sleeping out of doors<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under a tree. Three of them! There's something mighty queer behind this.' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was quite right, but he never found out any more about it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The morning came, pale and clammy. Frodo woke up first, and found that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a tree-root had made a hole in his back, and that his neck was stiff.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Walking for pleasure! Why didn't I drive?' he thought, as he usually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did at the beginning of an expedition. 'And all my beautiful feather beds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are sold to the Sackville-Bagginses! These tree-roots would do them good.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He stretched. 'Wake up, hobbits!' he cried. It's a beautiful morning.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What's beautiful about it?' said Pippin, peering over the edge of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blanket with one eye. 'Sam! Gel breakfast ready for half-past nine! Have you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">got the bath-water hot?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam jumped up, looking rather bleary. 'No, sir, I haven't, sir!' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo stripped the blankets from Pippin and rolled him over, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walked off to the edge of the wood. Away eastward the sun was rising red out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the mists that lay thick on the world. Touched with gold and red the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">autumn trees seemed to be sailing rootless in a shadowy sea. A little below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him to the left the road ran down steeply into a hollow and disappeared.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he returned Sam and Pippin had got a good fire going. 'Water!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shouted Pippin. 'Where's the water?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't keep water in my pockets,' said Frodo. 'We thought you had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone to find some,' said Pippin, busy setting out the food, and cups. 'You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had better go now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You can come too,' said Frodo, 'and bring all the water-bottles.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a stream at the foot of the hill. They filled their bottles and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the small camping kettle at a little fall where the water fell a few feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over an outcrop of grey stone. It was icy cold; and they spluttered and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">puffed as they bathed their faces and hands.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When their breakfast was over, and their packs all trussed up again, it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was after ten o'clock, and the day was beginning to turn fine and hot. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went down the slope, and across the stream where it dived under the road,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and up the next slope, and up and down another shoulder of the hills; and by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that time their cloaks, blankets, water, food, and other gear already seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a heavy burden.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The day's march promised to be warm and tiring work. After some miles,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">however, the road ceased to roll up and down: it climbed to the top of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steep bank in a weary zig-zagging sort of way, and then prepared to go down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the last time. In front of them they saw the lower lands dotted with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small clumps of trees that melted away in the distance to a brown woodland<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">haze. They were looking across the Woody End towards the Brandywine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The road wound away before them like a piece of string.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™The road goes on for ever,' said Pippin; 'but I can't without a rest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is high time for lunch.' He sat down on the bank at the side of the road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and looked away east into the haze, beyond which lay the River, and the end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Shire in which he had spent all his life. Sam stood by him. His round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eyes were wide open - for he was looking across lands he had never seen to a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">new horizon.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do Elves live in those woods?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not that I ever heard,' said Pippin. Frodo was silent. He too was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gazing eastward along the road, as if he had never seen it before. Suddenly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he spoke, aloud but as if to himself, saying slowly:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Road goes ever on and on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Down from the door where it began.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now far ahead the Road has gone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And I must follow, if I can,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pursuing it with weary feet,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Until it joins some larger way,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Where many paths and errands meet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And whither then? I cannot say.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That sounds like a bit of old Bilbo's rhyming,' said Pippin. 'Or is it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one of your imitations? It does not sound altogether encouraging.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know,' said Frodo. It came to me then, as if I was making it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up; but I may have heard it long ago. Certainly it reminds me very much of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo in the last years, before he went away. He used often to say there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only one Road; that it was like a great river: its springs were at every<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doorstep, and every path was its tributary. "It's a dangerous business,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo, going out of your door," he used to say. "You step into the Road, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if you don't keep your feet, there is no knowing where you might be swept<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off to. Do you realize that this is the very path that goes through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mirkwood, and that if you let it, it might take you to the Lonely Mountain<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or even further and to worse places?" He used to say that on the path<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">outside the front door at Bag End, especially after he had been out for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long walk.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, the Road wonâ€™t sweep me anywhere for an hour at least,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin, unslinging his pack. The others followed his example, putting their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">packs against the bank and their legs out into the road. After a rest they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had a good lunch, and then more rest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun was beginning to get low and the light of afternoon was on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land as they went down the hill. So far they had not met a soul on the road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This way was not much used, being hardly fit for carts, and there was little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">traffic to the Woody End. They had been jogging along again for an hour or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more when Sam stopped a moment as if listening. They were now on level<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground, and the road after much winding lay straight ahead through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass-land sprinkled with tall trees, outliers of the approaching woods.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I can hear a pony or a horse coming along the road behind,' said Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They looked back, but the turn of the road prevented them from seeing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far. 'I wonder if that is Gandalf coming after us,' said Frodo; but even as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said it, he had a feeling that it was not so, and a sudden desire to hide<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the view of the rider came over him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It may not matter much,' he said apologetically, 'but I would rather<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not be seen on the road - by anyone. I am sick of my doings being noticed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and discussed. And if it is Gandalf,' he added as an afterthought, 'we can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
