</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't you leave him! they said to me. Leave him! I said. I never mean to. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">am going with him, if he climbs to the Moon, and if any of those Black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rulers try to stop him, they'll have Sam Gamgee to reckon with, I said. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laughed.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who are they, and what are you talking about?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Elves, sir. We had some talk last night; and they seemed to know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you were going away, so I didn't see the use of denying it. Wonderful folk,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves, sir! Wonderful!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They are,' said Frodo. 'Do you like them still, now you have had a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">closer view?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They seem a bit above my likes and dislikes, so to speak,' answered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam slowly. 'It don't seem to matter what I think about them. They are quite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different from what I expected - so old and young, and so gay and sad, as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked at Sam rather startled, half expecting to see some outward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sign of the odd change that seemed to have come over him. It did not sound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like the voice of the old Sam Gamgee that he thought he knew. But it looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like the old Sam Gamgee sitting there, except that his face was unusually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thoughtful.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you feel any need to leave the Shire now - now that your wish to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see them has come true already?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, sir. I don't know how to say it, but after last night I feel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different. I seem to see ahead, in a kind of way. I know we are going to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take a very long road, into darkness; but I know I can't turn back. It isn't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to see Elves now, nor dragons, nor mountains, that I want - 1 don't rightly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know what I want: but I have something to do before the end, and it lies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ahead, not in the Shire. I must see it through, sir, if you understand me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't altogether. But I understand that Gandalf chose me a good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companion. I am content. We will go together.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo finished his breakfast in silence. Then standing up he looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the land ahead, and called to Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All ready to start?' he said as Pippin ran up. 'We must be getting off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at once. We slept late; and there are a good many miles to go.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You slept late, you mean,' said Pippin. 'I was up long before; and we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are only waiting for you to finish eating and thinking.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have finished both now. And I am going to make for Bucklebury Ferry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as quickly as possible. I am not going out of the way, back to the road we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left last night: I am going to cut straight across country from here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then you are going to fly,' said Pippin. 'You won't cut straight on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foot anywhere in this country.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We can cut straighter than the road anyway,' answered Frodo. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ferry is east from Woodhall; but the hard road curves away to the left -you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can see a bend of it away north over there. It goes round the north end of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Marish so as to strike the causeway from the Bridge above Stock. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is miles out of the way. We could save a quarter of the distance if we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made a line for the Ferry from where we stand.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Short cuts make long delays, ' argued Pippin. 'The country is rough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round here, and there are bogs and all kinds of difficulties down in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Marish -I know the land in these parts. And if you are worrying about Black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders, I can't see that it is any worse meeting them on a road than in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wood or a field.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is less easy to find people in the woods and fields,' answered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo. 'And if you are supposed to be on the road, there is some chance that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you will be looked for on the road and not off it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right!' said Pippin. 'I will follow you into every bog and ditch.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But it is hard! I had counted on passing the Golden Perch at Stock before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sundown. The best beer in the Eastfarthing, or used to be: it is a long time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since I tasted it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That settles it!' said Frodo. 'Short cuts make delays, but inns make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer ones. At all costs we must keep you away from the Golden Perch. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">want to get to Bucklebury before dark. What do you say, Sam?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will go along with you, Mr. Frodo,' said Sam (in spite of private<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">misgiving and a deep regret for the best beer in the Eastfarthing).<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then if we are going to toil through bog and briar, let's go now!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was already nearly as hot as it had been the day before; but clouds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were beginning to come up from the West. It looked likely to turn to rain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits scrambled down a steep green bank and plunged into the thick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees below. Their course had been chosen to leave Woodhall to their left,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and to cut slanting through the woods that clustered along the eastern side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the hills, until they reached the flats beyond. Then they could make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">straight for the Ferry over country that was open, except for a few ditches<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and fences. Frodo reckoned they had eighteen miles to go in a straight line.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He soon found that the thicket was closer and more tangled than it had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared. There were no paths in the undergrowth, and they did not get on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very fast. When they had struggled to the bottom of the bank, they found a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream running down from the hills behind in a deeply dug bed with steep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slippery sides overhung with brambles. Most inconveniently it cut across the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">line they had chosen. They could not jump over it, nor indeed get across it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at all without getting wet, scratched, and muddy. They halted, wondering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what to do. 'First check!' said Pippin, smiling grimly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam Gamgee looked back. Through an opening in the trees he caught a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimpse of the top of the green bank from which they had climbed down.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look!' he said, clutching Frodo by the arm. They all looked, and on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the edge high above them they saw against the sky a horse standing. Beside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it stooped a black figure.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They at once gave up any idea of going back. Frodo led the way, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">plunged quickly into the thick bushes beside the stream. 'Whew!' he said to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin. 'We were both right! The short cut has gone crooked already; but we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">got under cover only just in time. You've got sharp ears, Sam: can you hear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything coming?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They stood still, almost holding their breath as they listened; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was no sound of pursuit. 'I don't fancy he would try bringing his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horse down that bank,' said Sam. 'But I guess he knows we came down it. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had better be going on.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Going on was not altogether easy. They had packs to carry, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bushes and brambles were reluctant to let them through. They were cut off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the wind by the ridge behind, and the air was still and stuffy. When<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they forced their way at last into more open ground, they were hot and tired<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and very scratched, and they were also no longer certain of the direction in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which they were going. The banks of the stream sank, as it reached the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">levels and became broader and shallower, wandering off towards the Marish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the River.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Why, this is the Stock-brook!' said Pippin. 'If we are going to try<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and get back on to our course, we must cross at once and bear right.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They waded the stream, and hurried over a wide open space, rush-grown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and treeless, on the further side. Beyond that they came again to a belt of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees: tall oaks, for the most part, with here and there an elm tree or an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ash. The ground was fairly level, and there was little undergrowth; but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees were loo close for them to see far ahead. The leaves blew upwards in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sudden gusts of wind, and spots of rain began to fall from the overcast sky.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then the wind died away and the rain came streaming down. They trudged<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">along<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as fast as they could, over patches of grass, and through thick drifts of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old leaves; and all about them the rain pattered and trickled. They did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talk, but kept glancing back, and from side to side.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After half an hour Pippin said: 'I hope we have not turned too much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the south, and are not walking longwise through this wood! It is not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a very broad belt â€”I should have said no more than a mile at the widest -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and we ought to have been through it by now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is no good our starting to go in zig-zags,' said Frodo. 'That won't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mend matters. Let us keep on as we are going! I am not sure that I want to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come out into the open yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went on for perhaps another couple of miles. Then the sun gleamed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of ragged clouds again and the rain lessened. It was now past mid-day,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they felt it was high time for lunch. They halted under an elm tree: its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves though fast turning yellow were still thick, and the ground at its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feel was fairly dry and sheltered. When they came to make their meal, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found that the Elves had filled their bottles with a clear drink, pale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">golden in colour: it had the scent of a honey made of many flowers, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonderfully refreshing. Very soon they were laughing, and snapping their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fingers at rain, and at Black Riders. The last few miles, they felt, would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">soon be behind them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo propped his back against the tree-trunk, and closed his eyes. Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Pippin sat near, and they began to hum, and then to sing softly:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ho! Ho! Ho! to the bottle I go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To heal my heart and drown my woe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rain may fall and wind may blow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And many miles be still to go,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But under a tall tree I will lie,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And let the clouds go sailing by.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ho! Ho! Ho! they began again louder. They stopped short suddenly. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprang to his feet. A long-drawn wail came down the wind, like the cry of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some evil and lonely creature. It rose and fell, and ended on a high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">piercing note. Even as they sat and stood, as if suddenly frozen, it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">answered by another cry, fainter and further off, but no less chilling to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the blood. There was then a silence, broken only by the sound of the wind in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the leaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what do you think that was?' Pippin asked at last, trying to speak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lightly, but quavering a little. 'If it was a bird, it was one that I never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard in the Shire before.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was not bird or beast,' said Frodo. 'It was a call, or a signal â€”<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were words in that cry, though I could not catch them. But no hobbit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has such a voice.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">No more was said about it. They were all thinking of the Riders, but no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one spoke of them. They were now reluctant either to stay or go on; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sooner or later they had got to get across the open country to the Ferry,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and it was best to go sooner and in daylight. In a few moments they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shouldered their packs again and were off.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before long the wood came to a sudden end. Wide grass-lands stretched<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before them. They now saw that they had, in fact, turned too much to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">south. Away over the flats they could glimpse the low hill of Bucklebury<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">across the River, but it was now to their left. Creeping cautiously out from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the edge of the trees, they set off across the open as quickly as they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first they felt afraid, away from the shelter of the wood. Far back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind them stood the high place where they had breakfasted. Frodo half<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expected to see the small distant figure of a horseman on the ridge dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against the sky; but there was no sign of one. The sun escaping from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">breaking clouds, as it sank towards the hills they had left, was now shining<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brightly again. Their fear left them, though they still felt uneasy. But the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land became steadily more tame and well-ordered. Soon they came into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well-tended fields and meadows: there were hedges and gates and dikes for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drainage. Everything seemed quiet and peaceful, just an ordinary corner of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire. Their spirits rose with every step. The line of the River grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearer; and the Black Riders began to seem like phantoms of the woods now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left far behind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They passed along the edge of a huge turnip-field, and came to a stout<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gate. Beyond it a rutted lane ran between low well-laid hedges towards a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distant clump of trees. Pippin stopped.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I know these fields and this gate!' he said. 'This is Bamfurlong, old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Farmer Maggot's land. That's his farm away there in the trees.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'One trouble after another!' said Frodo, looking nearly as much alarmed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as if Pippin had declared the lane was the slot leading to a dragon's den.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others looked at him in surprise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What's wrong with old Maggot?' asked Pippin. 'He's a good friend to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the Brandy bucks. Of course he's a terror to trespassers, and keeps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ferocious dogs - but after all, folk down here are near the border and have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be more on their guard.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I know,' said Frodo. 'But all the same,' he added with a shamefaced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laugh, 'I am terrified of him and his dogs. I have avoided his farm for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years and years. He caught me several times trespassing after mushrooms,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when I was a youngster at Brandy Hall. On the last occasion he beat me, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then took me and showed me to his dogs. "See, lads," he said, "next time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this young varmint sets foot on my land, you can eat him. Now see him off!"<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They chased me all the way to the Ferry. I have never got over the fright -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though I daresay the beasts knew their business and would not really have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">touched me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin laughed. 'Well, it's time you made it up. Especially if you are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming back to live in Buckland. Old Maggot is really a stout fellow - if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you leave his mushrooms alone. Fet's get into the lane and then we shan't be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trespassing. If we meet him, I'll do the talking. He is a friend of Merry's,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I used to come here with him a good deal at one time.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went along the lane, until they saw the thatched roofs of a large<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house and farm-buildings peeping out among the trees ahead. The Maggots,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Puddifoots of Stock, and most of the inhabitants of the Marish, were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house-dwellers; and this farm was stoutly built of brick and had a high wall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all round it. There was a wide wooden gate opening out of the wall into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lane.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly as they drew nearer a terrific baying and barking broke out,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a loud voice was heard shouting: â€™Grip! Fang! Wolf! Come on, lads!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo and Sam stopped dead, but Pippin walked on a few paces. The gate<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">opened and three huge dogs came pelting out into the lane, and dashed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the travellers, barking fiercely. They took no notice of Pippin; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam shrank against the wall, while two wolvish-looking dogs sniffed at him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suspiciously, and snarled if he moved. The largest and most ferocious of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three halted in front of Frodo, bristling and growling.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Through the gate there now appeared a broad thick -set hobbit with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round red face. 'Hallo! Hallo! And who may you be, and what may you be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wanting?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good afternoon, Mr. Maggot!' said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The farmer looked at him closely. 'Well, if it isn't Master Pippin -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Peregrin Took, I should say!' he cried, changing from a scowl to a grin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's a long time since I saw you round here. It's lucky for you that I know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you. I was just going out to set my dogs on any strangers. There are some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">funny things going on today. Of course, we do get queer folk wandering in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these parts at times. Too near the River,' he said, shaking his head. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this fellow was the most outlandish I have ever set eyes on. He won't cross<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my land without leave a second time, not if I can stop it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What fellow do you mean?' asked Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then you haven't seen him?' said the farmer. 'He went up the lane<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the causeway not a long while back. He was a funny customer and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asking funny questions. But perhaps you'll come along inside, and we'll pass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the news more comfortable. I've a drop of good ale on tap, if you and your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends are willing, Mr. Took.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It seemed plain that the farmer would tell them more, if allowed to do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it in his own time and fashion, so they all accepted the invitation. 'What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the dogs?' asked Frodo anxiously.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The farmer laughed. 'They won't harm you - not unless I tell 'em to.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Here, Grip! Fang! Heel!' he cried. 'Heel, Wolf!' To the relief of Frodo and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam, the dogs walked away and let them go free.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin introduced the other two to the farmer. 'Mr. Frodo Baggins,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said. 'You may not remember him, but he used to live at Brandy Hall.' At the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name Baggins the farmer started, and gave Frodo a sharp glance. For a moment<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo thought that the memory of stolen mushrooms had been aroused, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dogs would be told to see him off. But Farmer Maggot took him by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arm.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, if that isn't queerer than ever?' he exclaimed. 'Mr. Baggins is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it? Come inside! We must have a talk.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went into the farmer's kitchen, and sat by the wide fire-place.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mrs. Maggot brought out beer in a huge jug, and filled four large mugs. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a good brew, and Pippin found himself more than compensated for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">missing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Golden Perch. Sam sipped his beer suspiciously. He had a natural<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mistrust of the inhabitants of other parts of the Shire; and also he was not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disposed to be quick friends with anyone who had beaten his master, however<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long ago.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a few remarks about the weather and the agricultural prospects<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(which were no worse than usual), Farmer Maggot put down his mug and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at them all in turn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now, Mr. Peregrin,' he said, 'where might you be coming from, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where might you be going to? Were you coming to visit' me? For, if so, you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had gone past my gate without my seeing you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, no,' answered Pippin. 'To tell you the truth, since you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed it, we got into the lane from the other end: we had come over your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fields. But that was quite by accident. We lost our way in the woods, back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near Woodhall, trying to take a short cut to the Ferry.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If you were in a hurry, the road would have served you better,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the farmer. 'But I wasn't worrying about that. You have leave to walk over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my land, if you have a mind, Mr. Peregrin. And you, Mr. Baggins - though I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">daresay you still like mushrooms.' He laughed. 'Ah yes, I recognized the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name. I recollect the time when young Frodo Baggins was one of the worst<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">young rascals of Buckland. But it wasn't mushrooms I was thinking of. I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">just heard the name Baggins before you turned up. What do you think that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">funny customer asked me?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They waited anxiously for him to go on. 'Well,' the farmer continued,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">approaching his point with slow relish, 'he came riding on a big black horse<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in at the gate, which happened to be open, and right up to my door. All<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">black he was himself, too, and cloaked and hooded up, as if he did not want<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be known. "Now what in the Shire can he want?" I thought to myself. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't see many of the Big Folk over the border; and anyway I had never heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of any like this black fellow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Good-day to you!" I says, going out to him. "This lane donâ€™t lead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anywhere, and wherever you may be going, your quickest way will be back to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the road." I didn't like the looks of him; and when Grip came out, he took<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one sniff and let out a yelp as if he had been slung: he put down his tail<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and bolted off howling. The black fellow sat quite still.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "I come from yonder," he said, slow and stiff-like, pointing back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">west, over my fields, if you please. "Have you seen Baggins? " he asked in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">queer voice, and bent down towards me. I could not see any face, for his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hood fell down so low; and I felt a sort of shiver down my back. But I did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not see why he should come riding over my land so bold.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Be off!" I said. "There are no Bagginses here. You're in the wrong<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">part of the Shire. You had better go back west to Hobbiton - but you can go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by road this time."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Baggins has left," he answered in a whisper. "He is coming. He is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not far away. I wish to find him. If he passes will you tell me? I will come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back with gold."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "No you won't," I said. "You'll go back where you belong, double<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quick. I give you one minute before I call all my dogs."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He gave a sort of hiss. It might have been laughing, and it might not.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then he spurred his great horse right at me, and I jumped out of the way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only just in time. I called the dogs, but he swung off, and rode through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gate and up the lane towards the causeway like a bolt of thunder. What do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you think of that?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo sat for a moment looking at the fire, but his only thought was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">how on earth would they reach the Ferry. 'I don't know what to think,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said at last.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then I'll tell you what to think,' said Maggot. 'You should never have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone mixing yourself up with Hobbiton folk, Mr. Frodo. Folk are queer up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there.' Sam stirred in his chair, and looked at the farmer with an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unfriendly eye. 'But you were always a reckless lad. When I heard you had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left the Brandybucks and gone off to that old Mr. Bilbo, I said that you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were going to find trouble. Mark my words, this all comes of those strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doings of Mr. Bilbo's. His money was got in some strange fashion in foreign<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">parts, they say. Maybe there is some that want to know what has become of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the gold and jewels that he buried in the hill of Hobbiton, as I hear?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo said nothing: the shrewd guesses of the farmer were rather<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disconcerting.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, Mr. Frodo,' Maggot went on, 'I'm glad that you've had the sense<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to come back to Buckland. My advice is: stay there! And don't get mixed up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with these outlandish folk. You'll have friends in these parts. If any of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these black fellows come after you again, I'll deal with them. I'll say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you're dead, or have left the Shire, or anything you like. And that might be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">true enough; for as like as not it is old Mr. Bilbo they want news of.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe you're right,' said Frodo, avoiding the farmer's eye and staring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at the fire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maggot looked at him thoughtfully. 'Well, I see you have ideas of your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own,' he said. 'It is as plain as my nose that no accident brought you and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that rider here on the same afternoon; and maybe my news was no great news<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to you, after all. I am not asking you to tell me anything you have a mind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to keep to yourself; but I see you are in some kind of trouble. Perhaps you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are thinking it won't be too easy to get to the Ferry without being caught?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I was thinking so,' said Frodo. But we have got to try and get there;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and it won't be done by sitting and thinking. Sol am afraid we must be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going. Thank you very much indeed for your kindness! I've been in terror of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you and your dogs for over thirty years, Farmer Maggot, though you may laugh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to hear it. It's a pity: for I've missed a good friend. And now I'm sorry to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leave so soon. But I'll come back, perhaps, one day - if I get a chance.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You'll be welcome when you come,' said Maggot. 'But now I've a notion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It's near sundown already, and we are going to have our supper; for we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mostly go to bed soon after the Sun. If you and Mr. Peregrin and all could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stay and have a bite with us, we would be pleased!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And so should we!' said Frodo. 'But we must be going at once, I'm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afraid. Even now it will be dark before we can reach the Ferry.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah! but wait a minute! I was going to say: after a bit of supper, I'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gel out a small waggon, and I'll drive you all to the Ferry. That will save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you a good step, and it might also save you trouble of another sort.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo now accepted the invitation gratefully, to the relief of Pippin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Sam. The sun was already behind the western hills, and the light was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">failing. Two of Maggot's sons and his three daughters came in, and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">generous supper was laid on the large table. The kitchen was lit with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">candles and the fire was mended. Mrs. Maggot hustled in and out. One or two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other hobbits belonging to the farm-household came in. In a short while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fourteen sat down to eat. There was beer in plenty, and a mighty dish of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mushrooms and bacon, besides much other solid farmhouse fare. The dogs lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by the fire and gnawed rinds and cracked bones.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had finished, the farmer and his sons went out with a lantern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and got the waggon ready. It was dark in the yard, when the guests came out.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They threw their packs on board and climbed in. The farmer sat in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">driving-seat, and whipped up his two stout ponies. His wife stood in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light of the open door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You be careful of yourself. Maggot!' she called. 'Don't go arguing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with any foreigners, and come straight back!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will!' said he, and drove out of the gate. There was now no breath<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of wind stirring; the night was still and quiet, and a chill was in the air.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went without lights and took it slowly. After a mile or two the lane<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came to an end, crossing a deep dike, and climbing a short slope up on to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the high-banked causeway.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maggot got down and took a good look either way, north and south, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing could be seen in the darkness, and there was not a sound in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still air. Thin strands of river -mist were hanging above the dikes, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crawling over the fields.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's going to be thick,' said Maggot; 'but I'll not light my lantern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">till I turn for home. We'll hear anything on the road long before we meet it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tonight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was five miles or more from Maggot's lane to the Ferry. The hobbits<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wrapped themselves up, but their ears were strained for any sound above the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creak of the wheels and the slow clop of the ponies' hoofs. The waggon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed slower than a snail to Frodo. Beside him Pippin was nodding towards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep; but Sam was staring forwards into the rising fog.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They reached the entrance to the Ferry lane at last. It was marked by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">two tall white posts that suddenly loomed up on their right. Farmer Maggot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drew in his ponies and the waggon creaked to a halt. They were just<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning lo scramble out, when suddenly they heard what they had all been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dreading: hoofs on the road ahead. The sound was coming towards them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maggot jumped down and stood holding the ponies' heads, and peering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward into the gloom. Clip-clop, clip-clop came the approaching rider. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fall of the hoofs sounded loud in the still, foggy air.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You'd better be hidden, Mr. Frodo,â€™ said Sam anxiously. 'You get down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the waggon and cover up with blankets, and we'll send this rider to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rightabouts!' He climbed out and went to the farmer's side. Black Riders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would have to ride over him to get near the waggon.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Clop-clop, clop-clop. The rider was nearly on them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hallo there!' called Farmer Maggot. The advancing hoofs stopped short.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They thought they could dimly guess a dark cloaked shape in the mist, a yard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or two ahead. 'Now then!' said the farmer, throwing the reins to Sam and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">striding forward. 'Don't you come a step nearer! What do you want, and where<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are you going?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I want Mr. Baggins. Have you seen him?' said a muffled voice - but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice was the voice of Merry Brandybuck. A dark lantern was uncovered, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its light fell on the astonished face of the farmer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Mr. Merry!' he cried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, of course! Who did you think it was?' said Merry coming forward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he came out of the mist and their fears subsided, he seemed suddenly to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">diminish to ordinary hobbit-size. He was riding a pony, and a scarf was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swathed round his neck and over his chin to keep out the fog.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo sprang out of the waggon to greet him. 'So there you are at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last!' said Merry. 'I was beginning to wonder if you would turn up at all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">today, and I was just going back to supper. When it grew foggy I came across<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and rode up towards Stock to see if you had fallen in any ditches. But I'm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blest if I know which way you have come. Where did you find them, Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maggot? In your duck-pond?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I caught 'em trespassing,' said the farmer, 'and nearly set my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dogs on 'em; but they'll tell you all the story, I've no doubt. Now, if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you'll excuse me, Mr. Merry and Mr. Frodo and all, I'd best be turning for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">home. Mrs. Maggot will be worriting with the night getting thick.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He backed the waggon into the lane and turned it. 'Well, good night to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you all,' he said. 'It's been a queer day, and no mistake. But all's well as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ends well; though perhaps we should not say that until we reach our own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors. I'll not deny that I'll be glad now when I do.' He lit his lanterns,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and got up. Suddenly he produced a large basket from under the seat. 'I was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearly forgetting,' he said. 'Mrs. Maggot put this up for Mr. Baggins, with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her compliments.' He handed it down and moved off, followed by a chorus of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thanks and good-nights.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They watched the pale rings of light round his lanterns as they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwindled into the foggy night. Suddenly Frodo laughed: from the covered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">basket he held, the scent of mushrooms was rising.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 5 . A Conspiracy Unmasked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now we had better get home ourselves,' said Merry. There's something<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">funny about all this, I see; but it must wait till we get in.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They turned down the Ferry lane, which was straight and well-kept and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">edged with large white- washed stones. In a hundred yards or so it brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them to the river -bank, where there was a broad wooden landing-stage. A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large flat ferry-boat was moored beside it. The white bollards near the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water's edge glimmered in the light of two lamps on high posts. Behind them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the mists in the flat fields were now above the hedges; but the water before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them was dark, with only a few curling wisps like steam among the reeds by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the bank. There seemed to be less fog on the further side.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry led the pony over a gangway on to the ferry, and the others<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed. Merry then pushed slowly off with a long pole. The Brandywine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowed slow and broad before them. On the other side the bank was steep, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up it a winding path climbed from the further landing. Lamps were twinkling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there. Behind loomed up the Buck Hill; and out of it, through stray shrouds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of mist, shone many round windows, yellow and red. They were the windows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandy Hall, the ancient home of the Brandy bucks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Long ago Gorhendad Oldbuck, head of the Oldbuck family, one of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">oldest in the Marish or indeed in the Shire, had crossed the river, which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was the original boundary of the land eastwards. He built (and excavated)<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandy Hall, changed his name to Brandybuck, and settled down to become<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">master of what was virtually a small independent country. His family grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and grew, and after his days continued to grow, until Brandy Hall occupied<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the whole of the low hill, and had three large front-doors, many side-doors,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and about a hundred windows. The Brandybucks and their numerous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dependants<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then began to burrow, and later to build, all round about. That was the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">origin of Buckland, a thickly inhabited strip between the river and the Old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Forest, a sort of colony from the Shire. Its chief village was Bucklebury,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clustering in the banks and slopes behind Brandy Hall.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The people in the Marish were friendly with the Bucklanders, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">authority of the Master of the Hall (as the head of the Brandybuck family<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was called) was still acknowledged by the farmers between Stock and Rushey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But most of the folk of the old Shire regarded the Bucklanders as peculiar,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">half foreigners as it were. Though, as a matter of fact, they were not very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different from the other hobbits of the Four Farthings. Except in one point:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were fond of boats, and some of them could swim.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their land was originally unprotected from the East; but on that side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they had built a hedge: the High Hay. It had been planted many generations<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ago, and was now thick and tail, for it was constantly tended. It ran all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
