<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the way from Brandywine Bridge, in a big loop curving away from the river,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Haysend (where the Withywindle flowed out of the Forest into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandywine): well over twenty miles from end to end. But, of course, it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not a complete protection. The Forest drew close to the hedge in many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places. The Bucklanders kept their doors locked after dark, and that also<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was not usual in the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The ferry-boat moved slowly across the water. The Buckland shore drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearer. Sam was the only member of the party who had not been over the river<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before. He had a strange feeling as the slow gurgling stream slipped by: his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old life lay behind in the mists, dark adventure lay in front. He scratched<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his head, and for a moment had a passing wish that Mr. Frodo could have gone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on living quietly at Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The four hobbits stepped off the ferry. Merry was tying it up, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin was already leading the pony up the path, when Sam (who had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking back, as if to take farewell of the Shire) said in a hoarse whisper:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look back, Mr. Frodo! Do you see anything?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the far stage, under the distant lamps, they could just make out a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">figure: it looked like a dark black bundle left behind. But as they looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it seemed to move and sway this way and that, as if searching the ground. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then crawled, or went crouching, back into the gloom beyond the lamps.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What in the Shire is that?' exclaimed Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Something that is following us,' said Frodo. 'But don't ask any more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now! Let's get away at once!' They hurried up the path to the top of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bank, but when they looked back the far shore was shrouded in mist, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing could be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Thank goodness you don't keep any boats on the west -bank!' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Can horses cross the river?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They can go twenty miles north to Brandywine Bridge - or they might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swim,' answered Merry. 'Though I never heard of any horse swimming the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandywine. But what have horses to do with it?' I'll tell you later. Let's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get indoors and then we can talk.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right! You and Pippin know your way; so I'll just ride on and tell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fatty Bolger that you are coming. We'll see about supper and things.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We had our supper early with Farmer Maggot,' said Frodo; 'but we could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do with another.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You shall have it! Give me that basket!' said Merry, and rode ahead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the darkness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was some distance from the Brandywine to Frodo's new house at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Crickhollow. They passed Buck Hill and Brandy Hall on their left, and on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">outskirts of Bucklebury struck the main road of Buckland that ran south from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Bridge. Half a mile northward along this they came to a lane opening on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their right. This they followed for a couple of miles as it climbed up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down into the country.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last they came to a narrow gate in a thick hedge. Nothing could be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seen of the house in the dark: it stood back from the lane in the middle of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a wide circle of lawn surrounded by a belt of low trees inside the outer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hedge. Frodo had chosen it, because it stood in an out-of-the-way corner of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the country, and there were no other dwellings close by. You could get in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and out without being noticed. It had been built a long while before by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandybucks, for the use of guests, or members of the family that wished to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">escape from the crowded life of Brandy Hall for a time. It was an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old-fashioned countrified house, as much like a hobbit-hole as possible: it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was long and low, with no upper storey; and it had a roof of turf, round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windows, and a large round door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they walked lip the green path from the gate no light was visible;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the windows were dark and shuttered. Frodo knocked on the door, and Fatty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bolger opened it. A friendly light streamed out. They slipped in quickly and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shut themselves and the light inside. They were in a wide hall with doors on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">either side; in front of them a passage ran back down the middle of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, what do you think of it?' asked Merry coming up the passage. 'We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have done our best in a short time to make it look like home. After all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fatty and I only got here with the last cart-load yesterday.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked round. It did look like home. Many of his own favourite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things - or Bilbo's things (they reminded him sharply of him in their new<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">selling) - were arranged as nearly as possible as they had been at Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was a pleasant, comfortable, welcoming place; and he found himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wishing that he was really coming here to settle down in quiet retirement.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It seemed unfair to have put his friends to all this trouble; and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wondered again how he was going to break the news to them that he must leave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them so soon, indeed at once. Yet that would have to be done that very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night, before they all went to bed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's delightful!' he said with an effort. 'I hardly feel that I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moved at all.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The travellers hung up their cloaks, and piled their packs on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">floor. Merry led them down the passage and threw open a door at the far end.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Firelight came out, and a puff of steam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A bath!' cried Pippin. 'O blessed Meriadoc!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Which order shall we go in?' said Frodo. 'Eldest first, or quickest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first? You'll be last either way, Master Peregrin.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Trust me to arrange things better than that!' said Merry. 'We can't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">begin life at Crickhollow with a quarrel over baths. In that room there are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three tubs, and a copper full of boiling water. There are also towels, mats<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and soap. Get inside, and be quick!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry and Fatty went into the kitchen on the other side of the passage,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and busied themselves with the final preparations for a late supper.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Snatches of competing songs came from the bathroom mixed with the sound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">splashing and wallowing. The voice of Pippin was suddenly lifted up above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the others in one of Bilbo's favourite bath-songs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sing hey! for the bath at close of day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that washes the weary mud away!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A loon is he that will not sing:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O! Water Hot is a noble thing!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O! Sweet is the sound of falling rain,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the brook that leaps from hill to plain;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but better than rain or rippling streams<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is Water Hot that smokes and steams.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O! Water cold we may pour at need<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down a thirsty throat and be glad indeed;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but better is Beer, if drink we lack,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Water Hot poured down the back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O! Water is fair that leaps on high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a fountain white beneath the sky;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but never did fountain sound so sweet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as splashing Hot Water with my feet!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a terrific splash, and a shout of Whoa! from Frodo. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared that a lot of Pippin's bath had imitated a fountain and leaped on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry went to the door: 'What about supper and beer in the throat?' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called. Frodo came out drying his hair.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There's so much water in the air that I'm coming into the kitchen to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finish,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lawks!' said Merry, looking in. The stone floor was swimming. 'You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ought to mop all that up before you get anything to eat. Peregrin,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hurry up, or we shan't wait for you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had supper in the kitchen on a table near the fire. 'I suppose you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three won't want mushrooms again?' said Fredegar without much hope.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes we shall!' cried Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They're mine!' said Frodo. 'Given to me by Mrs. Maggot, a queen among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">farmers' wives. Take your greedy hands away, and I'll serve them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits have a passion for mushrooms, surpassing even the greediest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">likings of Big People. A fact which partly explains young Frodo's long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expeditions to the renowned fields of the Marish, and the wrath of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">injured Maggot. On this occasion there was plenty for all, even according to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit standards. There were also many other things to follow, and when they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had finished even Fatty Bolger heaved a sigh of content. They pushed back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the table, and drew chairs round the fire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We'll clear up later,' said Merry. 'Now tell me all about it! I guess<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that you have been having adventures, which was not quite fair without me. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">want a full account; and most of all I want to know what was the matter with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old Maggot, and why he spoke to me like that. He sounded almost as if he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scared, if that is possible.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have all been scared,' said Pippin after a pause, in which Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stared at the fire and did not speak. 'You would have been, too, if you had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been chased for two days by Black Riders.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what are they?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Black figures riding on black horses,' answered Pippin. 'If Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">won't talk, I will tell you the whole tale from the beginning.' He then gave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a full account of their journey from the time when they left Hobbiton. Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave various supporting nods and exclamations. Frodo remained silent.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I should think you were making it all up,' said Merry, 'if I had not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seen that black shape on the landing-stage - and heard the queer sound in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Maggot's voice. What do you make of it all, Frodo?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Cousin Frodo has been very close,' said Pippin. 'But the time has come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for him to open out. So far we have been given nothing more to go on than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Farmer Maggot's guess that it has something to do with old Bilbo's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treasure.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That was only a guess,' said Frodo hastily. 'Maggot does not know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Old Maggot is a shrewd fellow,' said Merry. 'A lot goes on behind his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round face that does not come out in his talk. I've heard that he used to go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the Old Forest at one time, and he has the reputation of knowing a good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many strange things. But you can at least tell us, Frodo, whether you think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his guess good or bad.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think, ' answered Frodo slowly, 'that it was a good guess, as far as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it goes. There is a connexion with Bilbo's old adventures, and the Riders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are looking, or perhaps one ought to say searching, for him or for me. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also fear, if you want to know, that it is no joke at all; and that I am not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">safe here or anywhere else.' He looked round at the windows and walls, as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was afraid they would suddenly give way. The others looked at him in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silence, and exchanged meaning glances among themselves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's coming out in a minute,' whispered Pippin to Merry. Merry nodded.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well!' said Frodo at last, sitting up and straightening his back, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if he had made a decision. 'I can't keep it dark any longer. I have got<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something to tell you all. But I don't know quite how to begin.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think I could help you,' said Merry quietly, 'by telling you some of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it myself.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you mean?' said Frodo, looking at him anxiously. 'Just this,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my dear old Frodo: you are miserable, because you don't know how to say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good-bye. You meant to leave the Shire, of course. But danger has come on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you sooner than you expected, and now you are making up your mind to go at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">once. And you don't want to. We are very sorry for you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo opened his mouth and shut it again. His look of surprise was so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comical that they laughed. 'Dear old Frodo!' said Pippin. 'Did you really<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think you had thrown dust in all our eyes? You have not been nearly careful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or clever enough for that! You have obviously been planning to go and saying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">farewell to all your haunts all this year since April. We have constantly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard you muttering: "Shall I ever look down into that valley again, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonder", and things like that. And pretending that you had come to the end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of your money, and actually selling your beloved Bag End to those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sackville-Bagginses! And all those close talks with Gandalf.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good heavens!' said Frodo. 'I thought I had been both careful and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clever. I don't know what Gandalf would say. Is all the Shire discussing my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">departure then?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh no!' said Merry. 'Don't worry about that! The secret won't keep for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long, of course; but at present it is, I think, only known to us<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conspirators. After all, you must remember that we know you well, and are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">often with you. We can usually guess what you are thinking. I knew Bilbo,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">too. To tell you the truth, I had been watching you rather closely ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since he left. I thought you would go after him sooner or later; indeed I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expected you to go sooner, and lately we have been very anxious. We have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been terrified that you might give us the slip, and go off suddenly, all on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your own like he did. Ever since this spring we have kept our eyes open, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">done a good deal of planning on our own account. You are not going to escape<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">so easily!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I must go,' said Frodo. 'It cannot be helped, dear friends. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wretched for us all, but it is no use your trying to keep me. Since you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed so much, please help me and do not hinder me!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You do not understand!' said Pippin. 'You must go - and therefore we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must, too. Merry and I are coming with you. Sam is an excellent fellow, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would jump down a dragon's throat to save you, if he did not trip over his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own feet; but you will need more than one companion in your dangerous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">adventure.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My dear and most beloved hobbits!' said Frodo deeply moved. 'But I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not allow it. I decided that long ago, too. You speak of danger, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you do not understand. This is no treasure-hunt, no there-and -back journey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I am flying from deadly peril into deadly peril.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course we understand,' said Merry firmly. 'That is why we have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">decided to come. We know the Ring is no laughing -matter; but we are going to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do our best to help you against the Enemy.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Ring!' said Frodo, now completely amazed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, the Ring,' said Merry. 'My dear old hobbit, you don't allow for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the inquisitiveness of friends. I have known about the existence of the Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for years - before Bilbo went away, in fact; but since he obviously regarded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it as secret, I kept the knowledge in my head, until we formed our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conspiracy. I did not know Bilbo, of course, as well as I know you; I was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">too young, and he was also more careful - but he was not careful enough. If<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you want to know how I first found out, I will tell you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Go on!' said Frodo faintly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was the Sackville-Bagginses that were his downfall, as you might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expect. One day, a year before the Party, I happened to be walking along the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road, when I saw Bilbo ahead. Suddenly in the distance the S.-B.s appeared,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming towards us. Bilbo slowed down, and then hey presto! he vanished. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was so startled that I hardly had the wits to hide myself in a more ordinary<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fashion; but I got through the hedge and walked along the field inside. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was peeping through into the road, after the S.-B.s had passed, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking straight at Bilbo when he suddenly reappeared. I caught a glint of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gold as he put something back in his trouser -pocket.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'After that I kept my eyes open. In fact, I confess that I spied. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you must admit that it was very intriguing, and I was only in my teens. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must be the only one in the Shire, besides you Frodo, that has ever seen the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old fellow's secret book.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You have read his book!' cried Frodo. 'Good heavens above! Is nothing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">safe?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not too safe, I should say,' said Merry. 'But I have only had one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rapid glance, and that was difficult to get. He never left the book about. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonder what became of it. I should like another look. Have you got it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No. It was not at Bag End. He must have taken it away.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, as I was saying,' Merry proceeded, 'I kept my knowledge to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">myself, till this Spring when things got serious. Then we formed our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conspiracy; and as we were serious, too, and meant business, we have not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been too scrupulous. You are not a very easy nut to crack, and Gandalf is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worse. But if you want to be introduced to our chief investigator, I can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">produce him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where is he?' said Frodo, looking round, as if he expected a masked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sinister figure to come out of a cupboard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Step forward, Sam!' said Merry; and Sam stood up with a face scarlet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up to the ears. 'Here's our collector of information ! And he collected a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lot, I can tell you, before he was finally caught. After which, I may say,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he seemed to regard himself as on parole, and dried up.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Sam!' cried Frodo, feeling that amazement could go no further, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quite unable to decide whether he felt angry, amused, relieved, or merely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foolish.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, sir!' said Sam. 'Begging your pardon, sir! But I meant no wrong<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to you, Mr. Frodo, nor to Mr. Gandalf for that matter. He has some sense,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mind you; and when you said go alone, he said no! lake someone as you can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But it does not seem that I can trust anyone,' said Frodo. Sam looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at him unhappily. 'It all depends on what you want,' put in Merry. 'You can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust us to stick to you through thick and thin - to the bitter end. And you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can trust us to keep any secret of yours - closer than you keep it yourself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But you cannot trust us to let you face trouble alone, and go off without a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">word. We are your friends, Frodo. Anyway: there it is. We know most of what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf has told you. We know a good deal about the Ring. We are horribly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afraid - but we are coming with you; or following you like hounds.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And after all, sir,' added Sam, 'you did ought to take the Elves'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">advice. Gildor said you should take them as was willing, and you can't deny<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't deny it,' said Frodo, looking at Sam, who was now grinning. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't deny it, but I'll never believe you are sleeping again, whether you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snore or not. I shall kick you hard to make sure.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are a set of deceitful scoundrels!' he said, turning to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">others. 'But bless you!' he laughed, getting up and waving his arms, 'I give<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in. I will take Gildor's advice. If the danger were not so dark, I should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dance for joy. Even so, I cannot help feeling happy; happier than I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt for a long time. I had dreaded this evening.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good! That's settled. Three cheers for Captain Frodo and company!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they shouted; and they danced round him. Merry and Pippin began a song,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which they had apparently got ready for the occasion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was made on the model of the dwarf-song that started Bilbo on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">adventure long ago, and went to the same tune:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Farewell we call to hearth and hall!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though wind may blow and rain may fall,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We must away ere break of day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Far over wood and mountain tall.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To Rivendell, where Elves yet dwell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In glades beneath the misty fell,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Through moor and waste we ride in haste,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And whither then we cannot tell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With foes ahead, behind us dread,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beneath the sky shall be our bed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Until at last our toil be passed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Our journey done, our errand sped.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We must away! We must away!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We ride before the break of day!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very good!' said Frodo. 'But in that case there are a lot of things to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do before we go to bed - under a roof, for tonight at any rate.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh! That was poetry!' said Pippin. 'Do you really mean to start before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the break of day?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know,' answered Frodo. 'I fear those Black Riders, and I am<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sure it is unsafe to stay in one place long, especially in a place to which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it is known I was going. Also Gildor advised me not to wait. But I should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very much like to see Gandalf. I could see that even Gildor was disturbed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when he heard that Gandalf had never appeared. It really depends on two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things. Flow soon could the Riders get to Bucklebury? And how soon could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get off? It will take a good deal of preparation.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The answer to the second question,' said Merry, 'is that we could get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off in an hour. I have prepared practically everything. There are six ponies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a stable across the fields; stores and tackle are all packed, except for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a few extra clothes, and the perishable food.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It seems to have been a very efficient conspiracy,' said Frodo. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what about the Black Riders? Would it be safe to wait one day for Gandalf?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That all depends on what you think the Riders would do, if they found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you here,' answered Merry. 'They could have reached here by now, of course,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if they were not stopped at the North-gate, where the Hedge runs down to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">river -bank, just this side of the Bridge. The gate-guards would not let them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through by night, though they might break through. Even in the daylight they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would try to keep them out, I think, at any rate until they got a message<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through to the Master of the Hall - for they would not like the look of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders, and would certainly be frightened by them. But, of course, Buckland<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cannot resist a determined attack for long. And it is possible that in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">morning even a Black Rider that rode up and asked for Mr. Baggins would be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">let through. It is pretty generally known that you are coming back to live<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at Crickhollow.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo sat for a while in thought. 'I have made up my mind,' he said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finally. 'I am starting tomorrow, as soon as it is light. But I am not going<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by road: it would be safer to wait here than that. If I go through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">North-gate my departure from Buckland will be known at once, instead of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">being secret for several days at least, as it might be. And what is more,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Bridge and the East Road near the borders will certainly be watched,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whether any Rider gets into Buckland or not. We don't know how many there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are; but there are at least two, and possibly more. The only thing to do is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to go off in a quite unexpected direction.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But that can only mean going into the Old Forest!' said Fredegar<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horrified. 'You can't be thinking of doing that. It is quite as dangerous as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Black Riders.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not quite,' said Merry. It sounds very desperate, but I believe Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is right. It is the only way of getting off without being followed at once.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With luck we might gel a considerable start.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But you won't have any luck in the Old Forest,' objected Fredegar. 'No<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one ever has luck in there. You'll gel lost. People don't go in there.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh yes they do!' said Merry. 'The Brandybucks go in - occasionally<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when the fit takes them. We have a private entrance. Frodo went in once,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long ago. I have been in several times: usually in daylight, of course, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the trees are sleepy and fairly quiet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, do as you think best!' said Fredegar. 'I am more afraid of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Forest than of anything I know about: the stories about it are a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nightmare; but my vote hardly counts, as I am not going on the journey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Still, I am very glad someone is stopping behind, who can tell Gandalf what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you have done, when he turns up, as I am sure he will before long.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fond as he was of Frodo, Fatty Bolger had no desire to leave the Shire,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nor to see what lay outside it. His family came from the Eastfarthing, from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Budgeford in Bridgefields in fact, but he had never been over the Brandywine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bridge. His task, according to the original plans of the conspirators, was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to stay behind and deal with inquisitive folk, and to keep up as long as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">possible the pretence that Mr. Baggins was still living at Crickhollow. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had even brought along some old clothes of Frodo's to help him in playing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the part. They little thought how dangerous that part might prove.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Excellent!' said Frodo, when he understood the plan. â€™We could not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have left any message behind for Gandalf otherwise. I don't know whether<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these Riders can read or not, of course, but I should not have dared to risk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a written message, in case they got in and searched the house. But if Fatty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is willing to hold the fort, and I can be sure of Gandalf knowing the way we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have gone, that decides me. I am going into the Old Forest first thing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tomorrow.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, that's that,' said Pippin. 'On the whole I would rather have our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">job than Fatty's - waiting here till Black Riders come.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You wait till you are well inside the Forest,' said Fredegar. 'You'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish you were back here with me before this time tomorrow.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's no good arguing about it any more,' said Merry. 'We have still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">got to tidy up and put the finishing touches to the packing, before we get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to bed. I shall call you all before the break of day.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When at last he had got to bed, Frodo could not sleep for some time.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His legs ached. He. was glad that he was riding in the morning. Eventually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he fell into a vague dream, in which he seemed to be looking out of a high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">window over a dark sea of tangled trees. Down below among the roots there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was the sound of creatures crawling and snuffling. He felt sure they would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smell him out sooner or later.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then he heard a noise in the distance. At first he thought it was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great wind coming over the leaves of the forest. Then he knew that it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not leaves, but the sound of the Sea far-off; a sound he had never heard in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waking life, though it had often troubled his dreams. Suddenly he found he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was out in the open. There were no trees after all. He was on a dark heath,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there was a strange salt smell in the air. Looking up he saw before him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a tall white tower, standing alone on a high ridge. A great desire came over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him to climb the tower and see the Sea. He started to struggle up the ridge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the tower: but suddenly a light came in the sky, and there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">noise of thunder.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 6. The Old Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo woke suddenly. It was still dark in the room. Merry was standing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there with a candle in one hand, and banging on the door with the other.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right! What is it?' said Frodo, still shaken and bewildered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is it!' cried Merry. 'It is time to get up. It is half past four<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and very foggy. Come on! Sam is already getting breakfast ready. Even Pippin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is up. I am just going to saddle the ponies, and fetch the one that is to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the baggage-carrier. Wake that sluggard Fatty! At least he must get up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see us off.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Soon after six o'clock the five hobbits were ready to start. Fatty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bolger was still yawning. They stole quietly out of the house. Merry went in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">front leading a laden pony, and took his way along a path that went through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a spinney behind the house, and then cut across several fields. The leaves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of trees were glistening, and every twig was dripping; the grass was grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with cold dew. Everything was still, and far-away noises seemed near and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clear: fowls chattering in a yard, someone closing a door of a distant<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In their shed they found the ponies; sturdy little beasts of the kind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">loved by hobbits, not speedy, but good for a long day's work. They mounted,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and soon they were riding off into the mist, which seemed to open<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reluctantly before them and close forbiddingly behind them. After riding for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about an hour, slowly and without talking, they saw the Fledge looming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly ahead. It was tall and netted over with silver cobwebs. 'How are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you going to get through this?' asked Fredegar. 'Follow me!' said Merry,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and you will see.' He turned to the left along the Hedge, and soon they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came to a point where it bent inwards, running along the lip of a hollow. A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cutting had been made, at some distance from the Hedge, and went sloping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gently down into the ground. It had walls of brick at the sides, which rose<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steadily, until suddenly they arched over and formed a tunnel that dived<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep under the Hedge and came out in the hollow on the other side.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Here Fatty Bolger halted. 'Good-bye, Frodo!' he said. 'I wish you were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not going into the Forest. I only hope you will not need rescuing before the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">day is out. But good luck to you - today and every day!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If there are no worse things ahead than the Old Forest, I shall be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lucky,' said Frodo. 'Tell Gandalf to hurry along the East Road: we shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">soon be back on it and going as fast as we can.â€™ â€™Good-bye!' they cried, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rode down the slope and disappeared from Fredegar's sight into the tunnel.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was dark and damp. At the far end it was closed by a gate of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thick-set iron bars. Merry got down and unlocked the gate, and when they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all passed through he pushed it to again. It shut with a clang, and the lock<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clicked. The sound was ominous.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™There!â€™ said Merry. 'You have left the Shire, and are now outside, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the edge of the Old Forest.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Are the stories about it true?' asked Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know what stories you mean,' Merry answered. 'If you mean the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old bogey-stories Fatty's nurses used to tell him, about goblins and wolves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and things of that sort, I should say no. At any rate I don't believe them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the Forest is queer. Everything in it is very much more alive, more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aware of what is going on, so to speak, than things are in the Shire. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the trees do not like strangers. They watch you. They are usually content<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merely to watch you, as long as daylight lasts, and don't do much.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Occasionally the most unfriendly ones may drop a branch, or stick a root<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out, or grasp at you with a long trailer. But at night things can be most<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alarming, or so I am told. I have only once or twice been in here after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark, and then only near the hedge. I thought all the trees were whispering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to each other, passing news and plots along in an unintelligible language;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the branches swayed and groped without any wind. They do say the trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do actually move, and can surround strangers and hem them in. In fact long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ago they attacked the Hedge: they came and planted themselves right by it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and leaned over it. But the hobbits came and cut down hundreds of trees, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made a great bonfire in the Forest, and burned all the ground in a long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strip east of the Hedge. After that the trees gave up the attack, but they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became very unfriendly. There is still a wide bare space not far inside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the bonfire was made.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Is it only the trees that are dangerous?' asked Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are various queer things living deep in the Forest, and on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far side,' said Merry, 'or at least I have heard so; but I have never seen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any of them. But something makes paths. Whenever one comes inside one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">open tracks; but they seem to shift and change from time to time in a queer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fashion. Not far from this tunnel there is, or was for a long time, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning of quite a broad path leading to the Bonfire Glade, and then on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more or less in our direction, east and a little north. That is the path I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">am going to try and find.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits now left the tunnel-gate and rode across the wide hollow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the far side was a faint path leading up on to the floor of the Forest, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hundred yards and more beyond the Hedge; but it vanished as soon as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brought them under the trees. Looking back they could see the dark line of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Hedge through the stems of trees that were already thick about them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Looking ahead they could see only tree-trunks of innumerable sizes and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shapes: straight or bent, twisted, leaning, squat or slender, smooth or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gnarled and branched; and all the stems were green or grey with moss and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slimy, shaggy growths.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry alone seemed fairly cheerful. 'You had better lead on and find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
