<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that path,' Frodo said to him. 'Don't let us lose one another, or forget<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which way the Hedge lies!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They picked a way among the trees, and their ponies plodded along,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">carefully avoiding the many writhing and interlacing roots. There was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">undergrowth. The ground was rising steadily, and as they went forward it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed that the trees became taller, darker, and thicker. There was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sound, except an occasional drip of moisture falling through the still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves. For the moment there was no whispering or movement among the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches; but they all got an uncomfortable feeling that they were being<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watched with disapproval, deepening to dislike and even enmity. The feeling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steadily grew, until they found themselves looking up quickly, or glancing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back over their shoulders, as if they expected a sudden blow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was not as yet any sign of a path, and the trees seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">constantly to bar their way. Pippin suddenly felt that he could not bear it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any longer, and without warning let out a shout. 'Oi! Oi !' he cried. 'I am<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not going to do anything. Just let me pass through, will you!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others halted startled; but the cry fell as if muffled by a heavy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">curtain. There was no echo or answer though the wood seemed to become<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crowded and more watchful than before.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I should not shout, if I were you,' said Merry. It does more harm than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo began to wonder if it were possible to find a way through, and if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had been right to make the others come into this abominable wood. Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was looking from side to side, and seemed already uncertain which way to go.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin noticed it. 'It has not taken you long to lose us,' he said. But at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that moment Merry gave a whistle of relief and pointed ahead.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, well!' he said. 'These trees do shift. There is the Bonfire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glade in front of us (or I hope so), but the path to it seems to have moved<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The light grew clearer as they went forward. Suddenly they came out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the trees and found themselves in a wide circular space. There was sky above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them, blue and clear to their surprise, for down under the Forest -roof they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had not been able to see the rising morning and the lifting of the mist. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun was not, however, high enough yet to shine down into the clearing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though its light was on the tree-tops. The leaves were all thicker and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greener about the edges of the glade, enclosing it with an almost solid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wall. No tree grew there, only rough grass and many tall plants: stalky and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">faded hemlocks and wood-parsley, fire-weed seeding into fluffy ashes, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rampant nettles and thistles. A dreary place: but it seemed a charming and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cheerful garden after the close Forest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits felt encouraged, and looked up hopefully at the broadening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">daylight in the sky. At the far side of the glade there was a break in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wall of trees, and a clear path beyond it. They could see it running on into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the wood, wide in places and open above, though every now and again the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees drew in and overshadowed it with their dark boughs. Up this path they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rode. They were still climbing gently, but they now went much quicker, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with better heart; for it seemed to them that the Forest had relented, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was going to let them pass unhindered after all.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But after a while the air began to get hot and stuffy. The trees drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">close again on either side, and they could no longer see far ahead. Now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stronger than ever they felt again the ill will of the wood pressing on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. So silent was it that the fall of their ponies' hoofs, rustling on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dead leaves and occasionally stumbling on hidden roots, seemed to thud in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their ears. Frodo tried to sing a song to encourage them, but his voice sank<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to a murmur.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O! Wanderers in the shadowed land<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">despair not! For though dark they stand,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all woods there be must end at last,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and see the open sun go past:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the setting sun, the rising sun,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the day's end, or the day begun.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For east or west all woods must fail...<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fail - even as he said the word his voice faded into silence. The air<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed heavy and the making of words wearisome. Just behind them a large<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branch fell from an old overhanging tree with a crash into the path. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees seemed to close in before them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They do not like all that about ending and failing,' said Merry. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should not sing any more at present. Wait till we do get to the edge, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then we'll turn and give them a rousing chorus!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He spoke cheerfully, and if he felt any great anxiety, he did not show<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. The others did not answer. They were depressed. A heavy weight was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">settling steadily on Frodo's heart, and he regretted now with every step<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward that he had ever thought of challenging the menace of the trees. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was, indeed, just about to stop and propose going back (if that was still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">possible), when things took a new turn. The path stopped climbing, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became for a while nearly level. The dark trees drew aside, and ahead they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could see the path going almost straight forward. Before them, but some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distance off, there stood a green hill-top, treeless, rising like a bald<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">head out of the encircling wood. The path seemed to be making directly for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They now hurried forward again, delighted with the thought of climbing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out for a while above the roof of the Forest. The path dipped, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again began to climb upwards, leading them at last to the foot of the steep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hillside. There it left the trees and faded into the turf. The wood stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all round the hill like thick hair that ended sharply in a circle round a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shaven crown.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits led their ponies up, winding round and round until they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached the top. There they stood and gazed about them. The air was gleaming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sunlit, but hazy; and they could not see to any great distance. Near at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hand the mist was now almost gone; though here and there it lay in hollows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the wood, and to the south of them, out of a deep fold cutting right<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">across the Forest, the fog still rose like steam or wisps of white smoke.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That,' said Merry, pointing with his hand, 'that is the line of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Withywindle. It comes down out of the Downs and flows south-west through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">midst of the Forest to join the Brandywine below Haysend. We don't want to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go that way! The Withywindle valley is said to be the queerest part of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whole wood - the centre from which all the queerness comes, as it were.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others looked in the direction that Merry pointed out, but they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could see little but mists over the damp and deep-cut valley; and beyond it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the southern half of the Forest faded from view.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun on the hill-lop was now getting hot. It must have been about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eleven o'clock; but the autumn haze still prevented them from seeing much in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other directions. In the west they could not make out either the line of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hedge or the valley of the Brandywine beyond it. Northward, where they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked most hopefully, they could see nothing that might be the line of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great East Road, for which they were making. They were on an island in a sea<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of trees, and the horizon was veiled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the south-eastern side the ground fell very steeply, as if the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slopes of the hill were continued far down under the trees, like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">island-shores that really are the sides of a mountain rising out of deep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waters. They sat on the green edge and looked out over the woods below them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while they ate their mid-day meal. As the sun rose and passed noon they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimpsed far off in the east the grey-green lines of the Downs that lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond the Old Forest on that side. That cheered them greatly; for it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good to see a sight of anything beyond the wood's borders, though they did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not mean to go that way, if they could help it: the Barrow-downs had as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sinister a reputation in hobbit-legend as the Forest itself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length they made up their minds to go on again. The path that had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brought them to the hill reappeared on the northward side; but they had not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed it far before they became aware that it was bending steadily to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right. Soon it began to descend rapidly and they guessed that it must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">actually be heading towards the Withy windle valley: not at all the direction<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they wished lo take. After some discussion they decided to leave this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">misleading path and strike northward; for although they had not been able to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see it from the hill-top, the Road must lie that way, and it could not be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many miles off. Also northward, and to the left of the path, the land seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lo be drier and more open, climbing up to slopes where the trees were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thinner, and pines and firs replaced the oaks and ashes and other strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and nameless trees of the denser wood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first their choice seemed to be good: they got along at a fair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speed, though whenever they got a glimpse of the sun in an open glade they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed unaccountably to have veered eastwards. But after a time the trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to close in again, just where they had appeared from a distance to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thinner and less tangled. Then deep folds in the ground were discovered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpectedly, like the ruts of great giant-wheels or wide moats and sunken<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roads long disused and choked with brambles. These lay usually right across<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their line of march, and could only be crossed by scrambling down and out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again, which was troublesome and difficult with their ponies. Each time they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbed down they found the hollow filled with thick bushes and matted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">undergrowth, which somehow would not yield to the left, but only gave way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they turned to the right; and they had to go some distance along the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bottom before they could find a way up the further bank. Each time they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clambered out, the trees seemed deeper and darker; and always to the left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and upwards it was most difficult to find a way, and they were forced to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right and downwards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After an hour or two they had lost all clear sense of direction, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they knew well enough that they had long ceased to go northward at all. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were being headed off, and were simply following a course chosen for them -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastwards and southwards, into the heart of the Forest and not out of it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The afternoon was wearing away when they scrambled and stumbled into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fold that was wider and deeper than any they had yet met. It was so sleep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and overhung that it proved impossible to climb out of it again, either<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forwards or backwards, without leaving their ponies and their baggage<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind. All they could do was to follow the fold - downwards. The ground<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew soft, and in places boggy; springs appeared in the banks, and soon they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found themselves following a brook that trickled and babbled through a weedy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bed. Then the ground began to fall rapidly, and the brook growing strong and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">noisy, flowed and leaped swiftly downhill. They were in a deep dim-lit gully<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over-arched by trees high above them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After stumbling along for some way along the stream, they came quite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly out of the gloom. As if through a gate they saw the sunlight before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. Coming to the opening they found that they had made their way down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through a cleft in a high sleep bank, almost a cliff. At its feet was a wide<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">space of grass and reeds; and in the distance could be glimpsed another bank<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost as steep. A golden afternoon of late sunshine lay warm and drowsy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon the hidden land between. In the midst of it there wound lazily a dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">river of brown water, bordered with ancient willows, arched over with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willows, blocked with fallen willows, and flecked with thousands of faded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willow-leaves. The air was thick with them, fluttering yellow from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches; for there was a warm and gentle breeze blowing softly in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">valley, and the reeds were rustling, and the willow-boughs were creaking.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, now I have at least some notion of where we are!' said Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have come almost in the opposite direction to which we intended. This is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the River Withy windle! I will go on and explore.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He passed out into the sunshine and disappeared into the long grasses.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a while he reappeared, and reported that there was fairly solid ground<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between the cliff-foot and the river; in some places firm turf went down to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the water's edge. 'What's more,' he said, 'there seems to be something like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a footpath winding along on this side of the river. If we turn left and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">follow it, we shall be bound to come out on the east side of the Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eventually.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I dare say!' said Pippin. 'That is, if the track goes on so far, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">does not simply lead us into a bog and leave us there. Who made the track,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do you suppose, and why? I am sure it was not for our benefit. I am getting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very suspicious of this Forest and everything in it, and I begin to believe<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the stories about it. And have you any idea how far eastward we should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have to go?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' said Merry, 'I haven't. I don't know in the least how far down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Withywindle we are, or who could possibly come here often enough to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a path along it. But there is no other way out that I can see or think of.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There being nothing else for it, they filed out, and Merry led them to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the path that he had discovered. Everywhere the reeds and grasses were lush<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and tall, in places far above their heads; but once found, the path was easy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to follow, as it turned and twisted, picking out the sounder ground among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the bogs and pools. Here and there it passed over other rills, running down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gullies into the Withywindle out of the higher forest-lands, and at these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">points there were tree-trunks or bundles of brushwood laid carefully across.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits began to feel very hot. There were armies of flies of all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kinds buzzing round their ears, and the afternoon sun was burning on their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">backs. At last they came suddenly into a thin shade; great grey branches<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached across the path. Each step forward became more reluctant than the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last. Sleepiness seemed to be creeping out of the ground and up their legs,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and falling softly out of the air upon their heads and eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo felt his chin go down and his head nod. Just in front of him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin fell forward on to his knees. Frodo halted. 'It's no good,' he heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry saying. 'Can't go another step without rest. Must have nap. It's cool<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the willows. Less flies!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo did not like the sound of this. 'Come on!' he cried. 'We can't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have a nap yet. We must get clear of the Forest first.' But the others were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">too far gone to care. Beside them Sam stood yawning and blinking stupidly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly Frodo himself felt sleep overwhelming him. His head swam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There now seemed hardly a sound in the air. The flies had stopped buzzing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Only a gentle noise on the edge of hearing, a soft fluttering as of a song<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">half whispered, seemed to stir in the boughs above. He lifted his heavy eyes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and saw leaning over him a huge willow-tree, old and hoary. Enormous it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked, its sprawling branches going up like reaching arms with many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long-fingered hands, its knotted and twisted trunk gaping in wide fissures<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that creaked faintly as the boughs moved. The leaves fluttering against the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright sky dazzled him, and he toppled over, lying where he fell upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry and Pippin dragged themselves forward and lay down with their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">backs to the willow-trunk. Behind them the great cracks gaped wide to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">receive them as the tree swayed and creaked. They looked up at the grey and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yellow leaves, moving softly against the light, and singing. They shut their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eyes, and then it seemed that they could almost hear words, cool words,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saying something about water and sleep. They gave themselves up to the spell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and fell fast asleep at the foot of the great grey willow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo lay for a while fighting with the sleep that was overpowering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him; then with an effort he struggled to his feel again. He felt a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">compelling desire for cool water. 'Wait for me, Sam,' he stammered. 'Must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bathe feet a minute.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Half in a dream he wandered forward to the riverward side of the tree,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where great winding roots grew out into the stream, like gnarled dragonets<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">straining down to drink. He straddled one of these, and paddled his hot feel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the cool brown water; and there he too suddenly fell asleep with his back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against the tree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam sat down and scratched his head, and yawned like a cavern. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worried. The afternoon was getting late, and he thought this sudden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleepiness uncanny. 'There's more behind this than sun and warm air,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">muttered to himself. 'I don't like this great big tree. I don't trust it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hark at it singing about sleep now! This won't do at all!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He pulled himself to his feet, and staggered off to see what had become<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the ponies. He found that two had wandered on a good way along the path;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he had just caught them and brought them back towards the others, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he heard two noises; one loud, and the other soft but very clear. One was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the splash of something heavy falling into the water; the other was a noise<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like the snick of a lock when a door quietly closes fast.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He rushed back to the bank. Frodo was in the water close to the edge,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a great tree-root seemed to be over him and holding him down, but he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not struggling. Sam gripped him by the jacket, and dragged him from under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the root; and then with difficulty hauled him on to the bank. Almost at once<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he woke, and coughed and spluttered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you know, Sam,' he said at length, 'the beastly tree threw me in! I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt it. The big root just twisted round and tipped me in!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You were dreaming I expect, Mr. Frodo,' said Sam. 'You shouldn't sit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in such a place, if you feel sleepy.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What about the others?' Frodo asked. 'I wonder what sort of dreams<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they are having.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went round to the other side of the tree, and then Sam understood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the click that he had heard. Pippin had vanished. The crack by which he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laid himself had closed together, so that not a chink could be seen. Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was trapped: another crack had closed about his waist; his legs lay outside,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the rest of him was inside a dark opening, the edges of which gripped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a pair of pincers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo and Sam beat first upon the tree-trunk where Pippin had lain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They then struggled frantically to pull open the jaws of the crack that held<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">poor Merry. It was quite useless.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What a foul thing to happen!' cried Frodo wildly. 'Why did we ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come into this dreadful Forest? I wish we were all back at Crickhollow!' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kicked the tree with all his strength, heedless of his own feet. A hardly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perceptible shiver ran through the stem and up into the branches; the leaves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rustled and whispered, but with a sound now of faint and far-off laughter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I suppose we haven't got an axe among our luggage, Mr. Frodo?' asked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I brought a little hatchet for chopping firewood,' said Frodo. 'That<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wouldn't be much use.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Wait a minute!' cried Sam, struck by an idea suggested by firewood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We might do something with fire!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We might,' said Frodo doubtfully. 'We might succeed in roasting Pippin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alive inside.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We might try to hurt or frighten this tree to begin with,' said Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fiercely. 'If it don't let them go, I'll have it down, if I have to gnaw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it.' He ran to the ponies and before long came back with two tinder-boxes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a hatchet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Quickly they gathered dry grass and leaves, and bits of bark; and made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a pile of broken twigs and chopped sticks. These they heaped against the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trunk on the far side of the tree from the prisoners. As soon as Sam had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">struck a spark into the tinder, it kindled the dry grass and a flurry of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flame and smoke went up. The twigs crackled. Little fingers of fire licked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against the dry scored rind of the ancient tree and scorched it. A tremor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ran through the whole willow. The leaves seemed to hiss above their heads<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a sound of pain and anger. A loud scream came from Merry, and from far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inside the tree they heard Pippin give a muffled yell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Put it out! Put it out!' cried Merry. 'He'll squeeze me in two, if you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't. He says so!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who? What?' shouted Frodo, rushing round to the other side of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Put it out! Put it out!' begged Merry. The branches of the willow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to sway violently. There was a sound as of a wind rising and spreading<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">outwards to the branches of all the other trees round about, as though they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had dropped a stone into the quiet slumber of the river -valley and set up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ripples of anger that ran out over the whole Forest. Sam kicked at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little fire and stamped out the sparks. But Frodo, without any clear idea of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">why he did so, or what he hoped for, ran along the path crying help! help!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help! It seemed to him that he could hardly hear the sound of his own shrill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice: it was blown away from him by the willow-wind and drowned in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clamour of leaves, as soon as the words left his mouth. He felt desperate:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lost and witless.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly he slopped. There was an answer, or so he thought; but it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to come from behind him, away down the path further back in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Forest. He turned round and listened, and soon there could be no doubt:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">someone was singing a song; a deep glad voice was singing carelessly and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">happily, but it was singing nonsense:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring a dong! hop along! fal lal the willow!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom Bom, jolly Tom, Tom Bombadillo!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Half hopeful and half afraid of some new danger, Frodo and Sam now both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stood still. Suddenly out of a long string of nonsense-words (or so they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed) the voice rose up loud and clear and burst into this song:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey! Come merry dot ! derry dol! My darling!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Light goes the weather-wind and the feathered starling.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Down along under Hill, shining in the sunlight,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Waiting on the doorstep for the cold starlight,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There my pretty lady is. River-woman's daughter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slender as the willow-wand, clearer than the water.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Tom Bombadil water-lilies bringing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Comes hopping home again. Can you hear him singing?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey! Come merry dol! deny dol! and merry-o,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry, Goldberry, merry yellow berry-o!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Poor old Willow-man, you tuck your roots away!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's in a hurry now. Evening will follow day.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's going home again water-lilies bringing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey! Come derry dol! Can you hear me singing?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo and Sam stood as if enchanted. The wind puffed out. The leaves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hung silently again on stiff branches. There was another burst of song, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then suddenly, hopping and dancing along the path, there appeared above the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reeds an old battered hat with a tall crown and a long blue feather stuck in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the band. With another hop and a bound there came into view a man, or so it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed. At any rate he was too large and heavy for a hobbit, if not quite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tall enough for one of the Big People, though he made noise enough for one,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slumping along with great yellow boots on his thick legs, and charging<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through grass and rushes like a cow going down to drink. He had a blue coat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a long brown beard; his eyes were blue and bright, and his face was red<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as a ripe apple, but creased into a hundred wrinkles of laughter. In his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hands he carried on a large leaf as on a tray a small pile of white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water-lilies.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Help!' cried Frodo and Sam running towards him with their hands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stretched out.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Whoa! Whoa! steady there!â€™ cried the old man, holding up one hand, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they stopped short, as if they had been struck stiff. 'Now, my little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fellows, where be you a-going to, puffing like a bellows? What's the matter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here then? Do you know who I am? I'm Tom Bombadil. Tell me what's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trouble! Tom's in a hurry now. Don't you crush my lilies!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My friends are caught in the willow-tree,' cried Frodo breathlessly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Master Merry's being squeezed in a crack!' cried Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What?' shouted Tom Bombadil, leaping up in the air. 'Old Man Willow?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Naught worse than that, eh? That can soon be mended. I know the tune for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him. Old grey Willow-man! I'll freeze his marrow cold, if he don't behave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself. I'll sing his roots off. I'll sing a wind up and blow leaf and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branch away. Old Man Willow!' Setting down his lilies carefully on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass, he ran to the tree. There he saw Merry's feet still sticking out -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the rest had already been drawn further inside. Tom put his mouth to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crack and began singing into it in a low voice. They could not catch the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">words, but evidently Merry was aroused. His legs began to kick. Tom sprang<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away, and breaking off a hanging branch smote the side of the willow with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. 'You let them out again, Old Man Willow!' he said. 'What be you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a-thinking of? You should not be waking. Eat earth! Dig deep! Drink water!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Go to sleep! Bombadil is talking!' He then seized Merry's feet and drew him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the suddenly widening crack.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a tearing creak and the other crack split open, and out of it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin sprang, as if he had been kicked. Then with a loud snap both cracks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">closed fast again. A shudder ran through the tree from root to tip, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">complete silence fell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Thank you!' said the hobbits, one after the other.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom Bombadil burst out laughing. 'Well, my little fellows!' said he,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stooping so that he peered into their faces. 'You shall come home with me!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The table is all laden with yellow cream, honeycomb, and white bread and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">butter. Goldberry is waiting. Time enough for questions around the supper<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table. You follow after me as quick as you are able!' With that he picked up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his lilies, and then with a beckoning wave of his hand went hopping and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dancing along the path eastward, still singing loudly and nonsensically.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Too surprised and too relieved to talk, the hobbits followed after him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as fast as they could. But that was not fast enough. Tom soon disappeared in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">front of them, and the noise of his singing got fainter and further away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly his voice came floating back to them in a loud halloo!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's going on ahead candles for to kindle.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Down west sinks the Sun: soon you will be groping.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When the night-shadows fall, then the door will open,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Out of the window-panes light will twinkle yellow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fear no alder black! Heed no hoary willow!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fear neither root nor bough! Tom goes on before you.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey now! merry dot! We'll be waiting for you!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After that the hobbits heard no more. Almost at once the sun seemed to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sink into the trees behind them. They thought of the slanting light of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evening glittering on the Brandywine River, and the windows of Bucklebury<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning to gleam with hundreds of lights. Great shadows fell across them;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trunks and branches of trees hung dark and threatening over the path. White<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mists began to rise and curl on the surface of the river and stray about the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roots of the trees upon its borders. Out of the very ground at their feet a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadowy steam arose and mingled with the swiftly falling dusk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It became difficult to follow the path, and they were very tired. Their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">legs seemed leaden. Strange furtive noises ran among the bushes and reeds on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">either side of them; and if they looked up to the pale sky, they caught<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sight of queer gnarled and knobbly faces that gloomed dark against the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twilight, and leered down at them from the high bank and the edges of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wood. They began to feel that all this country was unreal, and that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were stumbling through an ominous dream that led to no awakening.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Just as they felt their feet slowing down to a standstill, they noticed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that the ground was gently rising. The water began to murmur. In the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">darkness they caught the white glimmer of foam, where the river flowed over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a short fall. Then suddenly the trees came to an end and the mists were left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind. They stepped out from the Forest, and found a wide sweep of grass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">welling up before them. The river, now small and swift, was leaping merrily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down to meet them, glinting here and there in the light of the stars, which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were already shining in the sky.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The grass under their feet was smooth and short, as if it had been mown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or shaven. The eaves of the Forest behind were clipped, and trim as a hedge.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The path was now plain before them, well -tended and bordered with stone. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wound up on to the top of a grassy knoll, now grey under the pale starry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night; and there, still high above them on a further slope, they saw the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twinkling lights of a house. Down again the path went, and then up again, up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a long smooth hillside of turf, towards the light. Suddenly a wide yellow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beam flowed out brightly from a door that was opened. There was Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bombadilâ€™s house before them, up, down, under hill. Behind it a steep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulder of the land lay grey and bare, and beyond that the dark shapes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Barrow-downs stalked away into the eastern night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They all hurried forward, hobbits and ponies. Already half their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weariness and all their fears had fallen from them. Hey! Come merry dol!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rolled out the song to greet them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey! Come derry dol! Hop along, my hearties!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits! Ponies all! We are fond of parties.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now let the fun begin! Let us sing together!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then another clear voice, as young and as ancient as Spring, like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">song of a glad water flowing down into the night from a bright morning in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hills, came falling like silver to meet them:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now let the song begin! Let us sing together<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of sun, stars, moon and mist, rain and cloudy weather,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Light on the budding leaf, dew on the feather,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wind on the open hill, bells on the heather,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Reeds by the shady pool, lilies on the water:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Tom Bombadil and the River-daughter!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And with that song the hobbits stood upon the threshold, and a golden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light was all about them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 7 . In the House of Tom Bombadil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The four hobbits stepped over the wide stone threshold, and stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still, blinking. They were in a long low room, filled with the light of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lamps swinging from the beams of the roof; and on the table of dark polished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wood stood many candles, tall and yellow, burning brightly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In a chair, at the far side of the room facing the outer door, sat a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woman. Her long yellow hair rippled down her shoulders; her gown was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green as young reeds, shot with silver like beads of dew; and her belt was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of gold, shaped like a chain of flag-lilies set with the pale-blue eyes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forget-me-nots. About her feel in wide vessels of green and brown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">earthenware, white water-lilies were floating, so that she seemed to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enthroned in the midst of a pool.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Enter, good guests!' she said, and as she spoke they knew that it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her clear voice they had heard singing. They came a few timid steps further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the room, and began to bow low, feeling strangely surprised and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">awkward, like folk that, knocking at a cottage door to beg for a drink of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water, have been answered by a fair young elf-queen clad in living flowers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But before they could say anything, she sprang lightly up and over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lily -bowls, and ran laughing towards them; and as she ran her gown rustled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">softly like the wind in the flowering borders of a river.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Come dear folk!' she said, taking Frodo by the hand. Faugh and be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merry! I am Goldberry, daughter of the River.' Then lightly she passed them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and closing the door she turned her back to it, with her white arms spread<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out across it. 'Let us shut out the night!' she said. 'For you are still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afraid, perhaps, of mist and tree-shadows and deep water, and untame things.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fear nothing! For tonight you are under the roof of Tom Bombadil.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits looked at her in wonder; and she looked at each of them and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
