<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smiled. 'Fair lady Goldberry!' said Frodo at last, feeling his heart moved<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a joy that he did not understand. He stood as he had at times stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enchanted by fair el ven- voices; but the spell that was now laid upon him was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different: less keen and lofty was the delight, but deeper and nearer to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mortal heart; marvellous and yet not strange. 'Fair lady Goldberry!' he said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. 'Now the joy that was hidden in the songs we heard is made plain to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O slender as a willow-wand! O clearer than clear water !<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O reed by the living pool! Fair River-daughter!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O spring-time and summer-time, and spring again after!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O wind on the waterfall, and the leaves' laughter!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly he stopped and stammered, overcome with surprise to hear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself saying such things. But Goldberry laughed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome!' she said. 'I had not heard that folk of the Shire were so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sweet -tongued. But I see you are an elf-friend; the light in your eyes and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ring in your voice tells it. This is a merry meeting! Sit now, and wait<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the Master of the house! He will not be long. He is tending your tired<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beasts.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits sat down gladly in low rush-seated chairs, while Goldberry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">busied herself about the table; and their eyes followed her, for the slender<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grace of her movement filled them with quiet delight. From somewhere behind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the house came the sound of singing. Every now and again they caught, among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many a derry dol and a merry dol and a ring a ding dillo the repeated words:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bright blue his jacket is, and his boots are yellow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Fair lady!' said Frodo again after a while. 'Tell me, if my asking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">does not seem foolish, who is Tom Bombadil?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He is,' said Goldberry, staying her swift movements and smiling.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked at her questioningly. 'He is, as you have seen him,' she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said in answer to his look. 'He is the Master of wood, water, and hill.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then all this strange land belongs to him?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No indeed!' she answered, and her smile faded. 'That would indeed be a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">burden,' she added in a low voice, as if to herself. 'The trees and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grasses and all things growing or living in the land belong each to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves. Tom Bombadil is the Master. No one has ever caught old Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walking in the forest, wading in the water, leaping on the hill-tops under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light and shadow. He has no fear. Tom Bombadil is master.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A door opened and in came Tom Bombadil. He had now no hat and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brown hair was crowned with autumn leaves. He laughed, and going to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry, took her hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here's my pretty lady!' he said, bowing to the hobbits. 'Here's my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry clothed all in silver -green with flowers in her girdle! Is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table laden? I see yellow cream and honeycomb, and white bread, and butter;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">milk, cheese, and green herbs and ripe berries gathered. Is that enough for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us? Is the supper ready?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is,' said Goldberry; 'but the guests perhaps are not?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom clapped his hands and cried: 'Tom, Tom! your guests are tired, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you had near forgotten! Come now, my merry friends, and Tom will refresh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you! You shall clean grimy hands, and wash your weary faces; cast off your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">muddy cloaks and comb out your tangles!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He opened the door, and they followed him down a short passage and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round a sharp turn. They came to a low room with a sloping roof (a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">penthouse, it seemed, built on to the north end of the house). Its walls<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were of clean stone, but they were mostly covered with green hanging mats<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and yellow curtains. The floor was flagged, and strewn with fresh green<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rushes. There were four deep mattresses, each piled with white blankets,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laid on the floor along one side. Against the opposite wall was a long bench<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laden with wide earthenware basins, and beside it stood brown ewers filled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with water, some cold, some steaming hot. There were soft green slippers set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ready beside each bed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before long, washed and refreshed, the hobbits were seated at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table, two on each side, while at either end sat Goldberry and the Master.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was a long and merry meal. Though the hobbits ate, as only famished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits can eat, there was no lack. The drink in their drinking -bowls seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be clear cold water, yet it went to their hearts like wine and set free<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their voices. The guests became suddenly aware that they were singing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merrily, as if it was easier and more natural than talking.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last Tom and Goldberry rose and cleared the table swiftly. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guests were commanded to sit quiet, and were set in chairs, each with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">footstool to his tired feet. There was a fire in the wide hearth before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them, and it was burning with a sweet smell, as if it were built of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">apple-wood. When everything was set in order, all the lights in the room<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were put out, except one lamp and a pair of candles at each end of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chimney-shelf. Then Goldberry came and stood before them, holding a candle;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and she wished them each a good night and deep sleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Have peace now,' she said, 'until the morning! Heed no nightly noises!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For nothing passes door and window here save moonlight and starlight and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind off the hill-top. Good night!' She passed out of the room with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimmer and a rustle. The sound of her footsteps was like a stream falling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gently away downhill over cool stones in the quiet of night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom sat on a while beside them in silence, while each of them tried to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">muster the courage to ask one of the many questions he had meant to ask at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">supper. Sleep gathered on their eyelids. At last Frodo spoke:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Did you hear me calling, Master, or was it just chance that brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you at that moment?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom stirred like a man shaken out of a pleasant dream. 'Eh, what?' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he. 'Did I hear you calling? Nay, I did not hear: I was busy singing. Just<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chance brought me then, if chance you call it. It was no plan of mine,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though I was waiting for you. We heard news of you, and learned that you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were wandering. We guessed you'd come ere long down to the water: all paths<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lead that way, down to Withywindle. Old grey Willow-man, he's a mighty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">singer; and it's hard for little folk to escape his cunning mazes. But Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had an errand there, that he dared not hinder.' Tom nodded as if sleep was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">taking him again; but he went on in a soft singing voice:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I had an errand there: gathering water-lilies,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green leaves and lilies white to please my pretty lady,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the last ere the year's end to keep them from the winter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to flower by her pretty feet tilt the snows are melted.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Each year at summer's end I go to find them for her,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a wide pool, deep and clear, far down Withywindle;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there they open first in spring and there they linger latest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By that pool long ago I found the River-daughter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fair young Goldberry sitting in the rushes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sweet was her singing then, and her heart was beating!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He opened his eyes and looked at them with a sudden glint of blue:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And that proved well for you â€” for now I shall no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go down deep again along the forest-water,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not while the year is old. Nor shall I be passing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Man Willow's house this side of spring-time,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not till the merry spring, when the River-daughter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dances down the withy-path to bathe in the water.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He fell silent again; but Frodo could not help asking one more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">question: the one he most desired to have answered. 'Tell us, Master,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said, 'about the Willow-man. What is he? I have never heard of him before.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, don't!' said Merry and Pippin together, sitting suddenly upright.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not now! Not until the morning!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That is right!' said the old man. 'Now is the time for resting. Some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things are ill to hear when the world's in shadow. Sleep till the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">morning -light, rest on the pillow ! Heed no nightly noise! Fear no grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willow!' And with that he took down the lamp and blew it out, and grasping a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">candle in either hand he led them out of the room.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their mattresses and pillows were soft as down, and the blankets were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of white wool. They had hardly laid themselves on the deep beds and drawn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the light covers over them before they were asleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the dead night, Frodo lay in a dream without light. Then he saw the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">young moon rising; under its thin light there loomed before him a black wall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of rock, pierced by a dark arch like a great gate. It seemed to Frodo that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was lifted up, and passing over he saw that the rock-wall was a circle of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills, and that within it was a plain, and in the midst of the plain stood a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pinnacle of stone, like a vast tower but not made by hands. On its top stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the figure of a man. The moon as it rose seemed to hang for a moment above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his head and glistened in his white hair as the wind stirred it. Up from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark plain below came the crying of fell voices, and the howling of many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wolves. Suddenly a shadow, like the shape of great wings, passed across the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moon. The figure lifted his arms and a light flashed from the staff that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wielded. A mighty eagle swept down and bore him away. The voices wailed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the wolves yammered. There was a noise like a strong wind blowing, and on it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was borne the sound of hoofs, galloping, galloping, galloping from the East.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Black Riders!' thought Frodo as he wakened, with the sound of the hoofs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still echoing in his mind. He wondered if he would ever again have the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">courage to leave the safety of these stone walls. He lay motionless, still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">listening; but all was now silent, and at last he turned and fell asleep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again or wandered into some other unremembered dream.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At his side Pippin lay dreaming pleasantly; but a change came over his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dreams and he turned and groaned. Suddenly he woke, or thought he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waked,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and yet still heard in the darkness the sound that had disturbed his dream:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tip-tap, squeak : the noise was like branches fretting in the wind,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twig-fingers scraping wall and window: creak, creak, creak. He wondered if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were willow-trees close to the house; and then suddenly he had a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dreadful feeling that he was not in an ordinary house at all, but inside the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">willow and listening to that horrible dry creaking voice laughing at him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. He sat up, and felt the soft pillows yield to his hands, and he lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down again relieved. He seemed to hear the echo of words in his ears: â€™Fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing! Have peace until the morning! Heed no nightly noises!' Then he went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to sleep again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was the sound of water that Merry heard falling into his quiet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep: water streaming down gently, and then spreading, spreading<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">irresistibly all round the house into a dark shoreless pool. It gurgled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the walls, and was rising slowly but surely. 'I shall be drowned!' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought. It will find its way in, and then I shall drown.' He felt that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was lying in a soft slimy bog, and springing up he set his fool on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">corner of a cold hard flagstone. Then he remembered where he was and lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down again. He seemed to hear or remember hearing: 'Nothing passes doors or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windows save moonlight and starlight and the wind off the hill-top.' A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little breath of sweet air moved the curtain. He breathed deep and fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asleep again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As far as he could remember, Sam slept through the night in deep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">content, if logs are contented.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They woke up, all four at once, in the morning light. Tom was moving<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the room whistling like a starling. When he heard them stir he clapped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his hands, and cried: 'Hey! Come merry dol! derry dol! My hearties!' He drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back the yellow curtains, and the hobbits saw that these had covered the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windows, at either end of the room, one looking east and the other looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">west.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They leapt up refreshed. Frodo ran to the eastern window, and found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself looking into a kitchen-garden grey with dew. He had half expected to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see turf right up to the walls, turf all pocked with hoof-prints. Actually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his view was screened by a tall line of beans on poles; but above and far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond them the grey top of the hill loomed up against the sunrise. It was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale morning: in the East, behind long clouds like lines of soiled wool<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stained red at the edges, lay glimmering deeps of yellow. The sky spoke of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rain to come; but the light was broadening quickly, and the red flowers on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the beans began to glow against the wet green leaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin looked out of the western window, down into a pool of mist. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Forest was hidden under a fog. It was like looking down on to a sloping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloud-roof from above. There was a fold or channel where the mist was broken<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into many plumes and billows; the valley of the Withywindle. The stream ran<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down the hill on the left and vanished into the white shadows. Near at hand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a flower-garden and a clipped hedge silver -netted, and beyond that grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shaven grass pale with dew-drops. There was no willow-tree to be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good morning, merry friends!' cried Tom, opening the eastern window<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wide. A cool air flowed in; it had a rainy smell. 'Sun won't show her face<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much today. I'm thinking. I have been walking wide, leaping on the hilltops,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since the grey dawn began, nosing wind and weather, wet grass underfoot, wet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sky above me. I wakened Goldberry singing under window; but nought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wakes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit-folk in the early morning. In the night little folk wake up in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">darkness, and sleep after light has come! Ring a ding dillo! Wake now, my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merry friends! Forget the nightly noises! Ring a ding dillo del! derry del,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my hearties! If you come soon you'll find breakfast on the table. If you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come late you'll get grass and rain-water!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Needless to say - not that Tom's threat sounded very serious - the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits came soon, and left the table late and only when it was beginning lo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look rather empty. Neither Tom nor Goldberry were there. Tom could be heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the house, clattering in the kitchen, and up and down the stairs, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">singing here and there outside. The room looked westward over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mist-clouded valley, and the window was open. Water dripped down from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thatched eaves above. Before they had finished breakfast the clouds had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">joined into an unbroken roof, and a straight grey rain came softly and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steadily down. Behind its deep curtain the Forest was completely veiled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they looked out of the window there came falling gently as if it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowing down the rain out of the sky, the clear voice of Goldberry singing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up above them. They could hear few words, but it seemed plain to them that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the song was a rain-song, as sweet as showers on dry hills, that told the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tale of a river from the spring in the highlands to the Sea far below. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits listened with delight; and Frodo was glad in his heart, and blessed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the kindly weather, because it delayed them from departing. The thought of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going had been heavy upon him from the moment he awoke; but he guessed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they would not go further that day.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The upper wind settled in the West and deeper and wetter clouds rolled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up to spill their laden rain on the bare heads of the Downs. Nothing could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be seen all round the house but falling water. Frodo stood near the open<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">door and watched the white chalky path turn into a little river of milk and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go bubbling away down into the valley. Tom Bombadil came trotting round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">corner of the house, waving his arms as if he was warding off the rain - and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed when he sprang over the threshold he seemed quite dry, except for his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boots. These he took off and put in the chimney-corner. Then he sat in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">largest chair and called the hobbits to gather round him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This is Goldberry's washing day,' he said, â€™and her autumn-cleaning.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Too wet for hobbit-folk - let them rest while they are able! Itâ€™s a good day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for long tales, for questions and for answers, so Tom will start the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talking.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He then told them many remarkable stories, sometimes half as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speaking to himself, sometimes looking at them suddenly with a bright blue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eye under his deep brows. Often his voice would turn to song, and he would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get out of his chair and dance about. He told them tales of bees and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowers, the ways of trees, and the strange creatures of the Forest, about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the evil things and good things, things friendly and things unfriendly,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cruel things and kind things, and secrets hidden under brambles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they listened, they began to understand the lives of the Forest,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">apart from themselves, indeed to feel themselves as the strangers where all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other things were at home. Moving constantly in and out of his talk was Old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Man Willow, and Frodo learned now enough to content him, indeed more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enough, for it was not comfortable lore. Tomâ€™s words laid bare the hearts of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees and their thoughts, which were often dark and strange, and filled with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a hatred of things that go free upon the earth, gnawing, biting, breaking,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hacking, burning: destroyers and usurpers. It was not called the Old Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without reason, for it was indeed ancient, a survivor of vast forgotten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods; and in it there lived yet, ageing no quicker than the hills, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fathers of the fathers of trees, remembering times when they were lords. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">countless years had filled them with pride and rooted wisdom, and with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">malice. But none were more dangerous than the Great Willow: his heart was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rotten, but his strength was green; and he was cunning, and a master of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">winds, and his song and thought ran through the woods on both sides of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">river. His grey thirsty spirit drew power out of the earth and spread like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fine root-threads in the ground, and invisible twig-fingers in the air, till<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it had under its dominion nearly all the trees of the Forest from the Hedge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Downs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly Tomâ€™s talk left the woods and went leaping up the young<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream, over bubbling waterfalls, over pebbles and worn rocks, and among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small flowers in close grass and wet crannies, wandering at last up on to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Downs. They heard of the Great Barrows, and the green mounds, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stone-rings upon the hills and in the hollows among the hills. Sheep were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bleating in flocks. Green walls and white walls rose. There were fortresses<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the heights. Kings of little kingdoms fought together, and the young Sun<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shone like fire on the red metal of their new and greedy swords. There was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">victory and defeat; and towers fell, fortresses were burned, and flames went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up into the sky. Gold was piled on the biers of dead kings and queens; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mounds covered them, and the stone doors were shut; and the grass grew over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all. Sheep walked for a while biting the grass, but soon the hills were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">empty again. A shadow came out of dark places far away, and the bones were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stirred in the mounds. Barrow- wights walked in the hollow places with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clink of rings on cold fingers, and gold chains in the wind.' Stone rings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grinned out of the ground like broken teeth in the moonlight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits shuddered. Even in the Shire the rumour of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barrow- wights of the Barrow-downs beyond the Forest had been heard. But it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was not a tale that any hobbit liked to listen to, even by a comfortable<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fireside far away. These four now suddenly remembered what the joy of this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house had driven from their minds: the house of Tom Bombadil nestled under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the very shoulder of those dreaded hills. They lost the thread of his tale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and shifted uneasily, looking aside at one another.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they caught his words again they found that he had now wandered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into strange regions beyond their memory and beyond their waking thought,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into limes when the world was wider, and the seas flowed straight to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western Shore; and still on and back Tom went singing out into ancient<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">starlight, when only the Elf-sires were awake. Then suddenly he slopped, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they saw that he nodded as if he was falling asleep. The hobbits sat still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before him, enchanted; and it seemed as if, under the spell of his words,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the wind had gone, and the clouds had dried up, and the day had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">withdrawn, and darkness had come from East and West, and all the sky was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">filled with the light of white stars.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Whether the morning and evening of one day or of many days had passed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo could not tell. Ele did not feel either hungry or tired, only filled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with wonder. The stars shone through the window and the silence of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heavens seemed to be round him. He spoke at last out of his wonder and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sudden fear of that silence:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Who are you, Master?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Eh, what?' said Tom sitting up, and his eyes glinting in the gloom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't you know my name yet? That's the only answer. Tell me, who are you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone, yourself and nameless? But you are young and I am old. Eldest, that's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what I am. Mark my words, my friends: Tom was here before the river and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees; Tom remembers the first raindrop and the first acorn. He made paths<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before the Big People, and saw the little People arriving. He was here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before the Kings and the graves and the Barrow- wights. When the Elves passed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">westward, Tom was here already, before the seas were bent. He knew the dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the stars when it was fearless - before the Dark Lord came from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Outside.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A shadow seemed to pass by the window, and the hobbits glanced hastily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the panes. When they turned again, Goldberry stood in the door<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind, framed in light. She held a candle, shielding its flame from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">draught with her hand; and the light flowed through it, like sunlight<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through a white shell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The rain has ended,' she said; 'and new waters are running downhill,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the stars. Let us now laugh and be glad!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And let us have food and drink!' cried Tom. 'Long tales are thirsty.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And long listening's hungry work, morning, noon, and evening!' With that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jumped out of his chair, and with a bound took a candle from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chimney-shelf and lit it in the flame that Goldberry held; then he danced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the table. Suddenly he hopped through the door and disappeared.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Quickly he returned, bearing a large and laden tray. Then Tom and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry set the table; and the hobbits sat half in wonder and half in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laughter: so fair was the grace of Goldberry and so merry and odd the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">caperings of Tom. Yet in some fashion they seemed to weave a single dance,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither hindering the other, in and out of the room, and round about the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table; and with great speed food and vessels and lights were set in order.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The boards blazed with candles, white and yellow. Tom bowed to his guests.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Supper is ready,' said Goldberry; and now the hobbits saw that she was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clothed all in silver with a white girdle, and her shoes were like fishes'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mail. But Tom was all in clean blue, blue as rain-washed forget-me-nots, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had green stockings.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was a supper even better than before. The hobbits under the spell of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's words may have missed one meal or many, but when the food was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them it seemed at least a week since they had eaten. They did not sing or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even speak much for a while, and paid close attention to business. But after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a time their hearts and spirit rose high again, and their voices rang out in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mirth and laughter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After they had eaten, Goldberry sang many songs for them, songs that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began merrily in the hills and fell softly down into silence; and in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silences they saw in their minds pools and waters wider than any they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">known, and looking into them they saw the sky below them and the stars like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jewels in the depths. Then once more she wished them each good night and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left them by the fireside. But Tom now seemed wide awake and plied them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">questions.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He appeared already to know much about them and all their families, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed to know much of all the history and doings of the Shire down from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days hardly remembered among the hobbits themselves. It no longer surprised<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them; but he made no secret that he owed his recent knowledge largely to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Farmer Maggot, whom he seemed to regard as a person of more importance<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they had imagined. 'There's earth under his old feet, and clay on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fingers; wisdom in his bones, and both his eyes are open,' said Tom. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also clear that Tom had dealings with the Elves, and it seemed that in some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fashion, news had reached him from Gildor concerning the flight of Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Indeed so much did Tom know, and so cunning was his questioning, that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo found himself telling him more about Bilbo and his own hopes and fears<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than he had told before even to Gandalf. Tom wagged his head up and down,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there was a glint in his eyes when he heard of the Riders.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Show me the precious Ring!' he said suddenly in the midst of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">story: and Frodo, to his own astonishment, drew out the chain from his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pocket, and unfastening the Ring handed it at once to Tom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It seemed to grow larger as it lay for a moment on his big<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brown-skinned hand. Then suddenly he put it to his eye and laughed. For a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">second the hobbits had a vision, both comical and alarming, of his bright<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blue eye gleaming through a circle of gold. Then Tom put the Ring round the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end of his little finger and held it up to the candlelight. For a moment the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits noticed nothing strange about this. Then they gasped. There was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sign of Tom disappearing!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom laughed again, and then he spun the Ring in the air - and it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished with a flash. Frodo gave a cry - and Tom leaned forward and handed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it back to him with a smile.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked at it closely, and rather suspiciously (like one who has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lent a trinket to a juggler). It was the same Ring, or looked the same and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weighed the same: for that Ring had always seemed to Frodo to weigh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strangely heavy in the hand. But something prompted him to make sure. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps a trifle annoyed with Tom for seeming to make so light of what even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf thought so perilously important. He waited for an opportunity, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the talk was going again, and Tom was telling an absurd story about badgers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and their queer ways - then he slipped the Ring on.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry turned towards him to say something and gave a start, and checked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">an exclamation. Frodo was delighted (in a way): it was his own ring all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right, for Merry was staring blankly at his chair, and obviously could not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see him. He got up and crept quietly away from the fireside towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">outer door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hey there!' cried Tom, glancing towards him with a most seeing look in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his shining eyes. 'Hey! Come Frodo, there! Where be you a-going? Old Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bombadil's not as blind as that yet. Take off your golden ring! Your hand's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more fair without it. Come back! Leave your game and sit down beside me!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must talk a while more, and think about the morning. Tom must teach the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right road, and keep your feet from wandering.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo laughed (trying to feel pleased), and taking off the Ring he came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sat down again. Tom now told them that he reckoned the Sun would shine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tomorrow, and it would be a glad morning, and setting out would be hopeful.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But they would do well to start early; for weather in that country was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing that even Tom could not be sure of for long, and it would change<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sometimes quicker than he could change his jacket. 'I am no weather-master,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said; 'nor is aught that goes on two legs.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By his advice they decided to make nearly due North from his house,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the western and lower slopes of the Downs: they might hope in that way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to strike the East Road in a day's journey, and avoid the Barrows. He told<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them not to be afraid - but to mind their own business.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Keep to the green grass. Don't you go a-meddling with old stone or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold Wights or prying in their houses, unless you be strong folk with hearts<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that never falter!' He said this more than once; and he advised them to pass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">barrows by on the west-side, if they chanced to stray near one. Then he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">taught them a rhyme to sing, if they should by ill-luck fall into any danger<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or difficulty the next day.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ho! Tom Bombadil, Tom Bombadillo!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By water, wood and hill, by the reed and willow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By fire, sun and moon, harken now and hear us!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Come, Tom Bombadil, for our need is near us!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had sung this altogether after him, he clapped them each on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the shoulder with a laugh, and taking candles led them back to their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bedroom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 8 . Fog on the Barrow-Downs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That night they heard no noises. But either in his dreams or out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them, he could not tell which, Frodo heard a sweet singing running in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mind; a song that seemed to come like a pale light behind a grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rain-curtain, and growing stronger to turn the veil all to glass and silver,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until at last it was rolled back, and a far green country opened before him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under a swift sunrise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The vision melted into waking; and there was Tom whistling like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree-full of birds; and the sun was already slanting down the hill and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the open window. Outside everything was green and pale gold.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After breakfast, which they again ate alone, they made ready to say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">farewell, as nearly heavy of heart as was possible on such a morning: cool,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright, and clean under a washed autumn sky of thin blue. The air came fresh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the North-west. Their quiet ponies were almost frisky, sniffing and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moving restlessly. Tom came out of the house and waved his hat and danced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon the doorstep, bidding the hobbits to get up and be off and go with good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They rode off along a path that wound away from behind the house, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went slanting up towards the north end of the hill -brow under which it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sheltered. They had just dismounted to lead their ponies up the last steep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slope, when suddenly Frodo stopped.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Goldberry!' he cried. 'My fair lady, clad all in silver green! We have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never said farewell to her, nor seen her since the evening!' He was so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distressed that he turned back; but at that moment a clear call came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rippling down. There on the hill-brow she stood beckoning to them: her hair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was flying loose, and as it caught the sun it shone and shimmered. A light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like the glint of water on dewy grass flashed from under her feet as she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">danced.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They hastened up the last slope, and stood breathless beside her. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bowed, but with a wave of her arm she bade them look round; and they looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out from the hill-top over lands under the morning. It was now as clear and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far-seen as it had been veiled and misty when they stood upon the knoll in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Forest, which could now be seen rising pale and green out of the dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees in the West. In that direction the land rose in wooded ridges, green,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yellow, russet under the sun, beyond which lay hidden the valley of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandywine. To the South, over the line of the Withywindle, there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distant glint like pale glass where the Brandywine River made a great loop<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the lowlands and flowed away out of the knowledge of the hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Northward beyond the dwindling downs the land ran away in flats and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swellings of grey and green and pale earth -colours, until it faded into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">featureless and shadowy distance. Eastward the Barrow-downs rose, ridge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind ridge into the morning, and vanished out of eyesight into a guess: it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was no more than a guess of blue and a remote white glimmer blending with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hem of the sky, but it spoke to them, out of memory and old tales, of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the high and distant mountains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They took a deep draught of the air, and felt that a skip and a few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stout strides would bear them wherever they wished. It seemed fainthearted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to go jogging aside over the crumpled skirts of the downs towards the Road,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they should be leaping, as lusty as Tom, over the stepping stones of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hills straight towards the Mountains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry spoke to them and recalled their eyes and thoughts. â€™Speed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now, fair guests!â€™ she said. 'And hold to your purpose! North with the wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the left eye and a blessing on your footsteps! Make haste while the Sun<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shines!' And to Frodo she said: 'Farewell, Elf-friend, it was a merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
