<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meeting!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But Frodo found no words to answer. He bowed low, and mounted his pony,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and followed by his friends jogged slowly down the gentle slope behind the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill. Tom Bombadil's house and the valley, and the Forest were lost to view.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The air grew warmer between the green walls of hillside and hillside, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the scent of turf rose strong and sweet as they breathed. Turning back, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they reached the bottom of the green hollow, they saw Goldberry, now small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and slender like a sunlit flower against the sky: she was standing still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watching them, and her hands were stretched out towards them. As they looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">she gave a clear call, and lifting up her hand she turned and vanished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind the hill .<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their way wound along the floor of the hollow, and round the green feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of a steep hill into another deeper and broader valley, and then over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulder of further hills, and down their long limbs, and up their smooth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sides again, up on to new hill-tops and down into new valleys. There was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree nor any visible water: it was a country of grass and short springy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turf, silent except for the whisper of the air over the edges of the land,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and high lonely cries of strange birds. As they journeyed the sun mounted,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and grew hot. Each time they climbed a ridge the breeze seemed to have grown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">less. When they caught a glimpse of the country westward the distant Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to be smoking, as if the fallen rain was steaming up again from leaf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and root and mould. A shadow now lay round the edge of sight, a dark haze<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">above which the upper sky was like a blue cap, hot and heavy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">About mid-day they came to a hill whose top was wide and flattened,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a shallow saucer with a green mounded rim. Inside there was no air<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stirring, and the sky seemed near their heads. They rode across and looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">northwards. Then their hearts rose, for it seemed plain that they had come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">further already than they had expected. Certainly the distances had now all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become hazy and deceptive, but there could be no doubt that the Downs were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming to an end. A long valley lay below them winding away northwards,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until it came to an opening between two steep shoulders. Beyond, there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to be no more hills. Due north they faintly glimpsed a long dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">line. That is a line of trees,' said Merry, 'and that must mark the Road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All along it for many leagues east of the Bridge there are trees growing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Some say they were planted in the old days.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Splendid!' said Frodo. 'If we make as good going this afternoon as we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have done this morning, we shall have left the Downs before the Sun sets and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be jogging on in search of a camping place.' But even as he spoke he turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his glance eastwards, and he saw that on that side the hills were higher and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked down upon them; and all those hills were crowned with green mounds,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and on some were standing stones, pointing upwards like jagged teeth out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green gums.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That view was somehow disquieting; so they turned from the sight and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went down into the hollow circle. In the midst of it there stood a single<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stone, standing tall under the sun above, and at this hour casting no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow. It was shapeless and yet significant: like a landmark, or a guarding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finger, or more like a warning. But they were now hungry, and the sun was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still at the fearless noon; so they set their backs against the east side of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the stone. It was cool, as if the sun had had no power to warm it; but at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that time this seemed pleasant. There they took food and drink, and made as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good a noon-meal under the open sky as anyone could wish; for the food came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from 'down under Hill'. Tom had provided them with plenty for the comfort of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the day. Their ponies unburdened strayed upon the grass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riding over the hills, and eating their fill, the warm sun and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scent of turf, lying a little too long, stretching out their legs and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking at the sky above their noses: these things are, perhaps, enough to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">explain what happened. However, that may be: they woke suddenly and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uncomfortably from a sleep they had never meant to take. The standing stone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was cold, and it cast a long pale shadow that stretched eastward over them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun, a pale and watery yellow, was gleaming through the mist just above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the west wall of the hollow in which they lay; north, south, and east,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond the wall the fog was thick, cold and white. The air was silent, heavy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and chill. Their ponies were standing crowded together with their heads<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits sprang to their feet in alarm, and ran to the western rim.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They found that they were upon an island in the fog. Even as they looked out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in dismay towards the setting sun, it sank before their eyes into a white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sea, and a cold grey shadow sprang up in the East behind. The fog rolled up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the walls and rose above them, and as it mounted it bent over their heads<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until it became a roof: they were shut in a hall of mist whose central<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pillar was the standing stone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They felt as if a trap was closing about them; but they did not quite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lose heart. They still remembered the hopeful view they had had of the line<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Road ahead, and they still knew in which direction it lay. In any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">case, they now had so great a dislike for that hollow place about the stone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that no thought of remaining there was in their minds. They packed up as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quickly as their chilled fingers would work.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Soon they were leading their ponies in single file over the rim and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down the long northward slope of the hill, down into a foggy sea. As they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went down the mist became colder and damper, and their hair hung lank and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dripping on their foreheads. When they reached the bottom it was so cold<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they halted and got out cloaks and hoods, which soon became bedewed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with grey drops. Then, mounting their ponies, they went slowly on again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feeling their way by the rise and fall of the ground. They were steering, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well as they could guess, for the gate-like opening at the far northward end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the long valley which they had seen in the morning. Once they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the gap, they had only lo keep on in anything like a straight line<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they were bound in the end to strike the Road. Their thoughts did not go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond that, except for a vague hope that perhaps away beyond the Downs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there might be no fog.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their going was very slow. To prevent their getting separated and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wandering in different directions they went in file, with Frodo leading. Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was behind him, and after him came Pippin, and then Merry. The valley<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to stretch on endlessly. Suddenly Frodo saw a hopeful sign. On either side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ahead a darkness began to loom through the mist; and he guessed that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were at last approaching the gap in the hills, the north-gate of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barrow-downs. If they could pass that, they would be free.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come on! Follow me!' he called back over his shoulder, and he hurried<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward. But his hope soon changed to bewilderment and alarm. The dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">patches grew darker, but they shrank; and suddenly he saw, towering ominous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before him and leaning slightly towards one another like the pillars of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">headless door, two huge standing stones. He could not remember having seen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any sign of these in the valley, when he looked out from the hill in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">morning. He had passed between them almost before he was aware: and even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he did so darkness seemed to fall round him. His pony reared and snorted,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he fell off. When he looked back he found that he was alone: the others<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had not followed him. 'Sam!' he called. 'Pippin! Merry! Come along! Why<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't you keep up?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was no answer. Fear took him, and he ran back past the stones<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shouting wildly: 'Sam! Sam! Merry! Pippin!' The pony bolted into the mist<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and vanished. From some way off, or so it seemed, he thought he heard a cry:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hoy! Frodo! Hoy!' It was away eastward, on his left as he stood under the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great stones, staring and straining into the gloom. He plunged off in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">direction of the call, and found himself going steeply uphill.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he struggled on he called again, and kept on calling more and more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">frantically; but he heard no answer for some time, and then it seemed faint<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and far ahead and high above him. 'Frodo! Hoy!' came the thin voices out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the mist: and then a cry that sounded like help, help! often repeated,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ending with a last help! that trailed off into a long wail suddenly cut<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">short. He stumbled forward with all the speed he could towards the cries;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the light was now gone, and clinging night had closed about him, so that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it was impossible to be sure of any direction. He seemed all the time to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbing up and up.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Only the change in the level of the ground at his feet told him when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at last came to the top of a ridge or hill. He was weary, sweating and yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chilled. It was wholly dark.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where are you?' he cried out miserably.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was no reply. He stood listening. He was suddenly aware that it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was getting very cold, and that up here a wind was beginning to blow, an icy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind. A change was coming in the weather. The mist was flowing past him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in shreds and tatters. His breath was smoking, and the darkness was less<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near and thick. He looked up and saw with surprise that faint stars were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appearing overhead amid the strands of hurrying cloud and fog. The wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to hiss over the grass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He imagined suddenly that he caught a muffled cry, and he made towards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it; and even as he went forward the mist was rolled up and thrust aside, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the starry sky was unveiled. A glance showed him that he was now facing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southwards and was on a round hill-top, which he must have climbed from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">north. Out of the east the biting wind was blowing. To his right there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">loomed against the westward stars a dark black shape. A great barrow stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Where are you?' he cried again, both angry and afraid.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here!' said a voice, deep and cold, that seemed to come out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground. 'I am waiting for you!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No!' said Frodo; but he did not run away. His knees gave, and he fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the ground. Nothing happened, and there was no sound. Trembling he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up, in time to see a tall dark figure like a shadow against the stars. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaned over him. He thought there were two eyes, very cold though lit with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale light that seemed to come from some remote distance. Then a grip<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stronger and colder than iron seized him. The icy touch froze his bones, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he remembered no more.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he came to himself again, for a moment he could recall nothing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">except a sense of dread. Then suddenly he knew that he was imprisoned,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">caught hopelessly; he was in a barrow. A Barrow-wight had taken him, and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was probably already under the dreadful spells of the Barrow- wights about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which whispered tales spoke. He dared not move, but lay as he found himself:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flat on his back upon a cold stone with his hands on his breast.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But though his fear was so great that it seemed to be part of the very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">darkness that was round him, he found himself as he lay thinking about Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins and his stories, of their jogging along together in the lanes of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire and talking about roads and adventures. There is a seed of courage<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hidden (often deeply, it is true) in the heart of the fattest and most timid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit, wailing for some final and desperate danger to make it grow. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was neither very fat nor very timid; indeed, though he did not know it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo (and Gandalf) had thought him the best hobbit in the Shire. He thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had come to the end of his adventure, and a terrible end, but the thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hardened him. He found himself stiffening, as if for a final spring; he no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer felt limp like a helpless prey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he lay there, thinking and getting a hold of himself, he noticed all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at once that the darkness was slowly giving way: a pale greenish light was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">growing round him. It did not at first show him what kind of a place he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in, for the light seemed to be coming out of himself, and from the floor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beside him, and had not yet reached the roof or wall. He turned, and there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the cold glow he saw lying beside him Sam, Pippin, and Merry. They were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on their backs, and their faces looked deathly pale; and they were clad in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white. About them lay many treasures, of gold maybe, though in that light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they looked cold and unlovely. On their heads were circlets, gold chains<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were about their waists, and on their fingers were many rings. Swords lay by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their sides, and shields were at their feet. But across their three necks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lay one long naked sword.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly a song began: a cold murmur, rising and falling. The voice<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed far away and immeasurably dreary, sometimes high in the air and thin,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sometimes like a low moan from the ground. Out of the formless stream of sad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but horrible sounds, strings of words would now and again shape themselves:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grim, hard, cold words, heartless and miserable. The night was railing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against the morning of which it was bereaved, and the cold was cursing the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warmth for which it hungered. Frodo was chilled to the marrow. After a while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the song became clearer, and with dread in his heart he perceived that it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had changed into an incantation:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Cold be hand and heart and bone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and cold be sleep under stone:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never mare to wake on stony bed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never, till the Sun fails and the Moon is dead.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the black wind the stars shall die,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and still on gold here let them lie,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">till the dark lord lifts his hand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over dead sea and withered land.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He heard behind his head a creaking and scraping sound. Raising himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on one arm he looked, and saw now in the pale light that they were in a kind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of passage which behind them turned a corner. Round the corner a long arm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was groping, walking on its fingers towards Sam, who was lying nearest, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the hilt of the sword that lay upon him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first Frodo felt as if he had indeed been turned into stone by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">incantation. Then a wild thought of escape came to him. He wondered if he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">put on the Ring, whether the Barrow-wight would miss him, and he might find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some way out. He thought of himself running free over the grass, grieving<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for Merry, and Sam, and Pippin, but free and alive himself. Gandalf would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">admit that there had been nothing else he could do.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the courage that had been awakened in him was now too strong: he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not leave his friends so easily. He wavered, groping in his pocket,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then fought with himself again; and as he did so the arm crept nearer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly resolve hardened in him, and he seized a short sword that lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beside him, and kneeling he stooped low over the bodies of his companions.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With what strength he had he hewed at the crawling arm near the wrist, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hand broke off; but at the same moment the sword splintered up to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hilt. There was a shriek and the light vanished. In the dark there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snarling noise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo fell forward over Merry, and Merry's face felt cold. All at once<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back into his mind, from which it had disappeared with the first coming of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the fog, came the memory of the house down under the Hill, and of Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">singing. He remembered the rhyme that Tom had taught them. In a small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desperate voice he began: Ho! Tom Bombadil! and with that name his voice<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to grow strong: it had a full and lively sound, and the dark chamber<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">echoed as if to drum and trumpet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ho! Tom Bombadil, Tom Bombadillo!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By water, wood and hill, by the reed and willow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By fire, sun and moon, harken now and hear us!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Come, Tom Bombadil, for our need is near us!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a sudden deep silence, in which Frodo could hear his heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beating. After a long slow moment he heard plain, but far away, as if it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming down through the ground or through thick walls, an answering voice<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">singing:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bright blue his jacket is, and his boots are yellow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">None has ever caught him yet, for Tom, he is the master:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His songs are stronger songs, and his feet are faster.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a loud rumbling sound, as of stones rolling and falling, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly light streamed in, real light, the plain light of day. A low<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">door -like opening appeared at the end of the chamber beyond Frodo's feet;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there was Tom's head (hat, feather, and all) framed against the light of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the sun rising red behind him. The light fell upon the floor, and upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">faces of the three hobbits lying beside Frodo. They did not stir, but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sickly hue had left them. They looked now as if they were only very deeply<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom stooped, removed his hat, and came into the dark chamber, singing:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Get out, you old Wight! Vanish in the sunlight!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shrivel like the cold mist, like the winds go wailing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Out into the barren lands far beyond the mountains!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Come never here again! Leave your barrow empty!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lost and forgotten be, darker than the darkness,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Where gates stand for ever shut, till the world is mended.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At these words there was a cry and part of the inner end of the chamber<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fell in with a crash. Then there was a long trailing shriek, fading away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into an unguessable distance; and after that silence.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Come, friend Frodo!' said Tom. 'Let us get out on to clean grass! You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must help me bear them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Together they carried out Merry, Pippin, and Sam. As Frodo left the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">barrow for the last time he thought he saw a severed hand wriggling still,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a wounded spider, in a heap of fallen earth. Tom went back in again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there was a sound of much thumping and stamping. When he came out he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bearing in his arms a great load of treasure: things of gold, silver,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">copper, and bronze; many beads and chains and jewelled ornaments. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the green barrow and laid them all on top in the sunshine.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There he stood, with his hat in his hand and the wind in his hair, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked down upon the three hobbits, that had been laid on their backs upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the grass at the west side of the mound. Raising his right hand he said in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clear and commanding voice:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wake now my merry tads! Wake and hear me calling!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Warm now be heart and limb! The cold stone is fallen;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dark door is standing wide; dead hand is broken.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Night under Night is flown, and the Gate is open!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To Frodoâ€™s great joy the hobbits stirred, stretched their arms, rubbed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their eyes, and then suddenly sprang up. They looked about in amazement,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first at Frodo, and then at Tom standing large as life on the barrow-top<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">above them; and then at themselves in their thin white rags, crowned and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">belted with pale gold, and jingling with trinkets.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What in the name of wonder?' began Merry, feeling the golden circlet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that had slipped over one eye. Then he stopped, and a shadow came over his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">face, and he closed his eyes. 'Of course, I remember!' he said. 'The men of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Carn Dym came on us at night, and we were worsted. Ah! the spear in my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heart!' He clutched at his breast. 'No! No!' he said, opening his eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What am I saying? I have been dreaming. Where did you get to, Frodo?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I thought that I was lost,' said Frodo; 'but I don't want to speak of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. Let us think of what we are to do now! Let us go on!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dressed up like this, sir?' said Sam. 'Where are my clothes?' He flung<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his circlet, belt, and rings on the grass, and looked round helplessly, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if he expected to find his cloak, jacket, and breeches, and other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit-garments lying somewhere to hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You won't find your clothes again,' said Tom, bounding down from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mound, and laughing as he danced round them in the sunlight. One would have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought that nothing dangerous or dreadful had happened; and indeed the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horror faded out of their hearts as they looked at him, and saw the merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glint in his eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you mean?' asked Pippin, looking at him, half puzzled and half<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">amused. 'Why not?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But Tom shook his head, saying: 'You've found yourselves again, out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the deep water. Clothes are but little loss, if you escape from drowning. Be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glad, my merry friends, and let the warm sunlight heal now heart and limb!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Cast off these cold rags! Run naked on the grass, while Tom goes a-hunting!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He sprang away down hill, whistling and calling. Looking down after him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo saw him running away southwards along the green hollow between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill and the next, still whistling and crying:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hey! now! Come hoy now! Whither do you wander?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Up, down, near or far, here, there or yonder?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sharp-ears, Wise-nose, Swish-tail and Bumpkin,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">White-socks my little lad, and old Fatty Lumpkin!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So he sang, running fast, tossing up his hat and catching it, until he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was hidden by a fold of the ground: but for some time his hey now! hoy now!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came floating back down the wind, which had shifted round towards the south.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The air was growing very warm again. The hobbits ran about for a while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the grass, as he told them. Then they lay basking in the sun with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delight of those that have been wafted suddenly from bitter winter to a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friendly clime, or of people that, after being long ill and bedridden, wake<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one day to find that they are unexpectedly well and the day is again full of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">promise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By the time that Tom returned they were feeling strong (and hungry). He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reappeared, hat first, over the brow of the hill, and behind him came in an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">obedient line six ponies: their own five and one more. The last was plainly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old Fatty Lumpkin: he was larger, stronger, fatter (and older) than their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own ponies. Merry, to whom the others belonged, had not, in fact, given them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any such names, but they answered to the new names that Tom had given<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the rest of their lives. Tom called them one by one and they climbed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the brow and stood in a line. Then Tom bowed to the hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here are your ponies, now!' he said. 'They've more sense (in some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ways) than you wandering hobbits have - more sense in their noses. For they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sniff danger ahead which you walk right into; and if they run to save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves, then they run the right way. You must forgive them all; for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though their hearts are faithful, to face fear of Barrow- wights is not what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were made for. See, here they come again, bringing all their burdens!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry, Sam, and Pippin now clothed themselves in spare garments from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their packs; and they soon felt too hot, for they were obliged to put on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some of the thicker and warmer things that they had brought against the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">oncoming of winter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where does that other old animal, that Fatty Lumpkin, come from?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He's mine,' said Tom. 'My four-legged friend; though I seldom ride<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, and he wanders often far, free upon the hillsides. When your ponies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stayed with me, they got to know my Lumpkin; and they smelt him in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night, and quickly ran to meet him. I thought he'd look for them and with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his words of wisdom take all their fear away. But now, my jolly Lumpkin, old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's going to ride. Hey! he's coming with you, just to set you on the road;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">so he needs a pony. For you cannot easily talk to hobbits that are riding,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when you're on your own legs trying to trot beside them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits were delighted to hear this, and thanked Tom many times;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but he laughed, and said that they were so good at losing themselves that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would not feel happy till he had seen them safe over the borders of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land. Tve got things to do,' he said: 'my making and my singing, my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talking and my walking, and my watching of the country. Tom can't be always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near to open doors and willow-cracks. Tom has his house to mind, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goldberry is waiting.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was still fairly early by the sun, something between nine and ten,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the hobbits turned their minds to food. Their last meal had been lunch<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beside the standing stone the day before. They breakfasted now off the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remainder of Tom's provisions, meant for their supper, with additions that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom had brought with him. It was not a large meal (considering hobbits and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the circumstances), but they felt much better for it. While they were eating<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom went up to the mound, and looked through the treasures. Most of these he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made into a pile that glistened and sparkled on the grass. He bade them lie<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there 'free to all finders, birds, beasts. Elves or Men, and all kindly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creatures'; for so the spell of the mound should be broken and scattered and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no Wight ever come back to it. He chose for himself from the pile a brooch<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set with blue stones, many-shaded like flax-flowers or the wings of blue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">butterflies. He looked long at it, as if stirred by some memory, shaking his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">head, and saying at last:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here is a pretty toy for Tom and for his lady! Fair was she who long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ago wore this on her shoulder. Goldberry shall wear it now, and we will not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forget her!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For each of the hobbits he chose a dagger, long, leaf-shaped, and keen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of marvellous workmanship, damasked with serpent-forms in red and gold.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gleamed as he drew them from their black sheaths, wrought of some strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">metal, light and strong, and set with many fiery stones. Whether by some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">virtue in these sheaths or because of the spell that lay on the mound, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blades seemed untouched by time, unrusted, sharp, glittering in the sun.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Old knives are long enough as swords for hobbit-people,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Sharp blades are good to have, if Shire-folk go walking, east, south, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far away into dark and danger.' Then he told them that these blades were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forged many long years ago by Men of Westernesse: they were foes of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lord, but they were overcome by the evil king of Carn Dym in the Land of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Angmar.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Few now remember them,' Tom murmured, 'yet still some go wandering,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sons of forgotten kings walking in loneliness, guarding from evil things<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk that are heedless.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits did not understand his words, but as he spoke they had a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vision as it were of a great expanse of years behind them, like a vast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadowy plain over which there strode shapes of Men, tall and grim with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright swords, and last came one with a star on his brow. Then the vision<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">faded, and they were back in the sunlit world. It was time to start again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They made ready, packing their bags and lading their ponies. Their new<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weapons they hung on their leather belts under their jackets, feeling them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very awkward, and wondering if they would be of any use. Fighting had not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before occurred to any of them as one of the adventures in which their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flight would land them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last they set off. They led their ponies down the hill; and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mounting they trotted quickly along the valley. They looked back and saw the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">top of the old mound on the hill, and from it the sunlight on the gold went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up like a yellow flame. Then they turned a shoulder of the Downs and it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hidden from view.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though Frodo looked about him on every side he saw no sign of the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stones standing like a gate, and before long they came to the northern gap<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and rode swiftly through, and the land fell away before them. It was a merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey with Tom Bombadil trotting gaily beside them, or before them, on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fatty Lumpkin, who could move much faster than his girth promised. Tom<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sang<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">most of the time, but it was chiefly nonsense, or else perhaps a strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">language unknown to the hobbits, an ancient language whose words were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mainly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those of wonder and delight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went forward steadily, but they soon saw that the Road was further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away than they had imagined. Even without a fog, their sleep at mid-day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would have prevented them from reaching it until after nightfall on the day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before. The dark line they had seen was not a line of trees but a line of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bushes growing on the edge of a deep dike with a steep wall on the further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side. Tom said that it had once been the boundary of a kingdom, but a very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long lime ago. He seemed to remember something sad about it, and would not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say much.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They climbed down and out of the dike and through a gap in the wall,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then Tom turned due north, for they had been bearing somewhat to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">west. The land was now open and fairly level, and they quickened their pace,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the sun was already sinking low when at last they saw a line of tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees ahead, and they knew that they had come back to the Road after many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpected adventures. They galloped their ponies over the last furlongs,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and halted under the long shadows of the trees. They were on the top of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sloping bank, and the Road, now dim as evening drew on, wound away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. At this point it ran nearly from South-west to North-east, and on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their right it fell quickly down into a wide hollow. It was rutted and bore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many signs of the recent heavy rain; there were pools and pot-holes full of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water. They rode down the bank and looked up and down. There was nothing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be seen. 'Well, here we are again at last!' said Frodo. 'I suppose we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">havenâ€™t lost more than two days by my short cut through the Forest! But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps the delay will prove useful - it may have put them off our trail.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others looked at him. The shadow of the fear of the Black Riders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came suddenly over them again. Ever since they had entered the Forest they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had thought chiefly of getting back to the Road; only now when it lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beneath their feet did they remember the danger which pursued them, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more than likely to be lying in wait for them upon the Road itself. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked anxiously back towards the setting sun, but the Road was brown and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">empty.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you think,' asked Pippin hesitatingly, 'do you think we may be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pursued, tonight?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I hope not tonight,' answered Tom Bombadil; 'nor perhaps the next<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">day. But do not trust my guess; for I cannot tell for certain. Out east my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knowledge fails. Tom is not master of Riders from the Black Land far beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his country.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All the same the hobbits wished he was coming with them. They felt that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he would know how to deal with Black Riders, if anyone did. They would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now be going forward into lands wholly strange to them, and beyond all but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the most vague and distant legends of the Shire, and in the gathering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twilight they longed for home. A deep loneliness and sense of loss was on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. They stood silent, reluctant to make the final parting, and only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slowly became aware that Tom was wishing them farewell, and telling them to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have good heart and to ride on till dark without halting.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Tom will give you good advice, till this day is over (after that your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own luck must go with you and guide you): four miles along the Road you'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come upon a village, Bree under Bree-hill, with doors looking westward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There you'll find an old inn that is called The Prancing Pony. Barliman<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur is the worthy keeper. There you can stay the night, and afterwards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the morning will speed you upon your way. Be bold, but wary! Keep up your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">merry hearts, and ride to meet your fortune!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They begged him to come at least as far as the inn and drink once more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with them; but he laughed and refused, saying:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's country ends here: he will not pass the borders.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom has his house to mind, and Goldberry is waiting!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then he turned, tossed up his hat, leaped on Lumpkin's back, and rode<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up over the bank and away singing into the dusk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits climbed up and watched him until he was out of sight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sorry to take leave of Master Bombadil,' said Sam. 'He's a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
