<p class="p4"><span class="s3">caution and no mistake. I reckon we may go a good deal further and see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">naught better, nor queerer. But I won't deny I'll be glad to see this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Prancing Pony he spoke of. I hope it'll be like The Green Dragon away back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">home! What sort of folk are they in Bree?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are hobbits in Bree,' said Merry, 'as well as Big Folk. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">daresay it will be homelike enough. The Pony is a good inn by all accounts.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">My people ride out there now and again.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It may be all we could wish,' said Frodo; 'but it is outside the Shire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the same. Don't make yourselves too much at home ! Please remember -all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of you - that the name of Baggins must NOT be mentioned. I am Mr. Underhill,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if any name must be given.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They now mounted their ponies and rode off silently into the evening.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Darkness came down quickly, as they plodded slowly downhill and up again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until at last they saw lights twinkling some distance ahead.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before them rose Bree-hill barring the way, a dark mass against misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stars; and under its western flank nestled a large village. Towards it they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now hurried desiring only to find a fire, and a door between them and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 9 . At the Sign of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Prancing Pony<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree was the chief village of the Bree-land, a small inhabited region,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like an island in the empty lands round about. Besides Bree itself, there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was Staddle on the other side of the hill, Combe in a deep valley a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">further eastward, and Archet on the edge of the Chetwood. Lying round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-hill and the villages was a small country of fields and tamed woodland<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only a few miles broad.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Men of Bree were brown-haired, broad, and rather short, cheerful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and independent: they belonged to nobody but themselves; but they were more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friendly and familiar with Hobbits, Dwarves, Elves, and other inhabitants of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the world about them than was (or is) usual with Big People. According to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their own tales they were the original inhabitants and were the descendants<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the first Men that ever wandered into the West of the middle-world. Few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had survived the turmoils of the Elder Days; but when the Kings returned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again over the Great Sea they had found the Bree-men still there, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were still there now, when the memory of the old Kings had faded into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In those days no other Men had settled dwellings so far west, or within<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a hundred leagues of the Shire. But in the wild lands beyond Bree there were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mysterious wanderers. The Bree-folk called them Rangers, and knew nothing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their origin. They were taller and darker than the Men of Bree and were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">believed to have strange powers of sight and hearing, and to understand the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">languages of beasts and birds. They roamed at will southwards, and eastwards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even as far as the Misty Mountains; but they were now few and rarely seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they appeared they brought news from afar, and told strange forgotten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tales which were eagerly listened to; but the Bree-folk did not make friends<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There were also many families of hobbits in the Bree-land and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">claimed to be the oldest settlement of Hobbits in the world, one that was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">founded long before even the Brandywine was crossed and the Shire colonized.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They lived mostly in Staddle though there were some in Bree itself,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">especially on the higher slopes of the hill, above the houses of the Men.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Big Folk and the Little Folk (as they called one another) were on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friendly terms, minding their own affairs in their own ways, but both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rightly regarding themselves as necessary parts of the Bree-folk. Nowhere<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">else in the world was this peculiar (but excellent) arrangement to be found.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Bree-folk, Big and Little, did not themselves travel much; and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">affairs of the four villages were their chief concern. Occasionally the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits of Bree went as far as Buckland, or the Eastfarthing; but though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their link land was not much further than a day's riding east of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Brandywine Bridge, the Hobbits of the Shire now seldom visited it. An<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">occasional Bucklander or adventurous Took would come out to the Inn for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night or two, but even that was becoming less and less usual. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire-hobbits referred to those of Bree, and to any others that lived beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the borders, as Outsiders, and took very little interest in them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">considering them dull and uncouth. There were probably many more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Outsiders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scattered about in the West of the World in those days than the people of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire imagined. Some, doubtless, were no better than tramps, ready to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dig a hole in any bank and stay only as long as it suited them. But in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-land, at any rate, the hobbits were decent and prosperous, and no more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rustic than most of their distant relatives Inside. It was not yet forgotten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that there had been a time when there was much coming and going between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire and Bree. There was Bree-blood in the Brandybucks by all accounts.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The village of Bree had some hundred stone houses of the Big Folk,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mostly above the Road, nestling on the hillside with windows looking west.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On that side, running in more than half a circle from the hill and back to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, there was a deep dike with a thick hedge on the inner side. Over this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Road crossed by a causeway; but where it pierced the hedge it was barred<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by a great gate. There was another gate in the southern comer where the Road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ran out of the village. The gates were closed at nightfall; but just inside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them were small lodges for the gatekeepers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Down on the Road, where it swept to the right to go round the foot of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hill, there was a large inn. It had been built long ago when the traffic<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the roads had been far greater. For Bree stood at an old meeting of ways;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">another ancient road crossed the East Road just outside (he dike at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western end of the village, and in former days Men and other folk of various<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sorts had travelled much on it. Strange as News from Bree was still a saying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Eastfarthing, descending from those days, when news from North,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">South, and East could be heard in the inn, and when the Shire-hobbits used<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to go more often to hear it. But the Northern Lands had long been desolate,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the North Road was now seldom used: it was grass-grown, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-folk called it the Greenway.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Inn of Bree was still there, however, and the innkeeper was an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">important person. His house was a meeting place for the idle, talkative, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inquisitive among the inhabitants, large and small, of the four villages;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a resort of Rangers and other wanderers, and for such travellers (mostly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarves) as still journeyed on the East Road, to and from the Mountains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was dark, and white stars were shining, when Frodo and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companions came at last to the Greenway-crossing and drew near the village.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They came to the West-gate and found it shut, but at the door of the lodge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond it, there was a man sitting. He jumped up and fetched a lantern and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked over the gate at them in surprise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What do you want, and where do you come from?' he asked gruffly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We are making for the inn here,' answered Frodo. 'We are journeying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">east and cannot go further tonight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hobbits ! Four hobbits ! And what's more, out of the Shire by their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talk,' said the gatekeeper, softly as if speaking to himself. He stared at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them darkly for a moment, and then slowly opened the gate and let them ride<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We don't often see Shire-folk riding on the Road at night,' he went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on, as they halted a moment by his door. 'You'll pardon my wondering what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">business takes you away east of Bree! What may your names be, might I ask?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Our names and our business are our own, and this does not seem a good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">place to discuss them,' said Frodo, not liking the look of the man or the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tone of his voice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Your business is your own, no doubt,' said the man; 'but it's my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">business to ask questions after nightfall.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We are hobbits from Buckland, and we have a fancy to travel and to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stay at the inn here,' put in Merry. 'I am Mr. Brandybuck. Is that enough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for you? The Bree-folk used to be fair-spoken to travellers, or so I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right, all right!' said the man. 'I meant no offence. But you'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find maybe that more folk than old Harry at the gate will be asking you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">questions. There's queer folk about. If you go on to The Pony, you'll find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you're oat the only guests.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He wished them good night, and they said no more; but Frodo could see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the lantern-light that the man was still eyeing them curiously. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glad to hear the gate clang to behind them, as they rode forward. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wondered why the man was so suspicious, and whether any one had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for news of a party of hobbits. Could it have been Gandalf? He might have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arrived, while they were delayed in the Forest and the Downs. But there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something in the look and the voice of the gatekeeper that made him uneasy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The man stared after the hobbits for a moment, and then he went back to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his house. As soon as his back was turned, a dark figure climbed quickly in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the gate and melted into the shadows of the village street.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits rode on up a gentle slope, passing a few detached houses,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and drew up outside the inn. The houses looked large and strange to them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam stared up at the inn with its three storeys and many windows, and felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his heart sink. He had imagined himself meeting giants taller than trees,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and other creatures even more terrifying, some time or other in the course<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his journey; but at the moment he was finding his first sight of Men and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their tall houses quite enough, indeed too much for the dark end of a tiring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">day. He pictured black horses standing all saddled in the shadows of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inn-yard, and Black Riders peering out of dark upper windows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We surely aren't going to stay here for the night, are we, sir?' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">exclaimed. 'If there are hobbit-folk in these pans, why don't we look for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some that would be willing to take us in? It would be more homelike.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What's wrong with the inn?' said Frodo. 'Tom Bombadil recommended it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I expect it's homelike enough inside.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Even from the outside the inn looked a pleasant house to familiar eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It had a front on the Road, and two wings running back on land partly cut<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the lower slopes of the hill, so that at the rear the second-floor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windows were level with the ground. There was a wide arch leading to a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">courtyard between the two wings, and on the left under the arch there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large doorway reached by a few broad steps. The door was open and light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">streamed out of it. Above the arch there was a lamp, and beneath it swung a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large signboard: a fat white pony reared up on its hind legs. Over the door<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was painted in white letters: THE PRANCING PONY by BARLIMAN<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">BUTTERBUR. Many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the lower windows showed lights behind thick curtains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they hesitated outside in the gloom, someone began singing a merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">song inside, and many cheerful voices joined loudly in the chorus. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">listened to this encouraging sound for a moment and then got off their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ponies. The song ended and there was a burst of laughter and clapping.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They led their ponies under the arch, and leaving them standing in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yard they climbed up the steps. Frodo went forward and nearly bumped into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">short fat man with a bald head and a red face. He had a white apron on, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was bustling out of one door and in through another, carrying a tray laden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with full mugs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Can weâ€”' began Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Half a minute, if you please!' shouted the man over his shoulder, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished into a babel of voices and a cloud of smoke. In a moment he was out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again, wiping his hands on his apron.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good evening, little master!' he said, bending down. 'What may you be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wanting?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Beds for four, and stabling for five ponies, if that can be managed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Are you Mr. Butterbur?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That's right! Barliman is my name. Barliman Butterbur at your service!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You're from the Shire, eh?' he said, and then suddenly he clapped his hand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to his forehead, as if trying to remember something. 'Hobbits!' he cried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now what does that remind me of? Might I ask your names, sir?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Mr. Took and Mr. Brandybuck,' said Frodo; 'and this is Sam Gamgee. My<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name is Underhill.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There now!' said Mr. Butterbur, snapping his fingers. 'It's gone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again! But it'll come back, when I have time to think. I'm run off my feet;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but I'll see what I can do for you. We don't often get a party out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire nowadays, and I should be sorry not to make you welcome. But there is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">such a crowd already in the house tonight as there hasn't been for long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enough. It never rains but it pours, we say in Bree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hi! Nob!' he shouted. 'Where are you, you woolly -footed slow-coach?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nob!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Coming, sir! Coming!' A cheery-looking hobbit bobbed out of a door,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and seeing the travellers, stopped short and stared at them with great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">interest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where's Bob?' asked the landlord. 'You don't know? Well find him!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Double sharp! I haven't got six legs, nor six eyes neither! Tell Bob there's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">five ponies that have to be stabled. He must find room somehow.' Nob trotted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off with a grin and a wink.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, now, what was I going to say?' said Mr. Butterbur, tapping his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forehead. 'One thing drives out another, so to speak. I'm that busy tonight,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my head is going round. There's a party that came up the Greenway from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">South last night - and that was strange enough to begin with. Then there's a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">travelling company of dwarves going West come in this evening. And now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there's you. If you weren't hobbits, I doubt if we could house you. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we've got a room or two in the north wing that were made special for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits, when this place was built. On the ground floor as they usually<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prefer; round windows and all as they like it. I hope you'll be comfortable.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You'll be wanting supper, I don't doubt. As soon as may be. This way now!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He led them a short way down a passage, and opened a door. 'Here is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nice little parlour!' he said. 'I hope it will suit. Excuse me now. I'm that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">busy. No time for talking. I must be trotting. It's hard work for two legs,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but I don't get thinner. I'll look in again later. If you want anything,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring the hand-bell, and Nob will come. If he don't come, ring and shout!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Off he went at last, and left them feeling rather breathless. He seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">capable of an endless stream of talk, however busy he might be. They found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves in a small and cosy room. There was a bit of bright fire burning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the hearth, and in front of it were some low and comfortable chairs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a round table, already spread with a white cloth, and on it was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large hand-bell. But Nob, the hobbit servant, came bustling in long before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they thought of ringing. He brought candles and a tray full of plates.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Will you be wanting anything to drink, masters?' he asked. 'And shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I show you the bedrooms, while your supper is got ready?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They were washed and in the middle of good deep mugs of beer when Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur and Nob came in again. In a twinkling the table was laid. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was hot soup, cold meats, a blackberry tart, new loaves, slabs of butter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and half a ripe cheese: good plain food, as good as the Shire could show,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and homelike enough to dispel the last of Sam's misgivings (already much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">relieved by the excellence of the beer).<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The landlord hovered round for a link, and then prepared to leave them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know whether you would care to join the company, when you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">supped,' he said, standing at the door. 'Perhaps you would rather go to your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beds. Still the company would be very pleased to welcome you, if you had a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mind. We don't get Outsiders - travellers from the Shire, I should say,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">begging your pardon - often; and we like to hear a bit of news, or any story<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or song you may have in mind. But as you please! Ring the bell, if you lack<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So refreshed and encouraged did they feel at the end of their supper<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(about three quarters of an hour's steady going, not hindered by unnecessary<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talk) that Frodo, Pippin, and Sam decided to join the company. Merry said it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would be too stuffy. 'I shall sit here quietly by the fire for a bit, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps go out later for a sniff of the air. Mind your Ps and Qs, and don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forget that you are supposed to be escaping in secret, and are still on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high-road and not very far from the Shire!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right!' said Pippin. 'Mind yourself! Don't get lost, and don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forget that it is safer indoors!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The company was in the big common-room of the inn. The gathering was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large and mixed, as Frodo discovered, when his eyes got used to the light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This came chiefly from a blazing log-fire, for the three lamps hanging from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the beams were dim, and half veiled in smoke. Barliman Butterbur was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">standing near the fire, talking to a couple of dwarves and one or two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strange-looking men. On the benches were various folk: men of Bree, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">collection of local hobbits (sitting chattering together), a few more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarves, and other vague figures difficult to make out away in the shadows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and comers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as the Shire-hobbits entered, there was a chorus of welcome<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the Bree-landers. The strangers, especially those that had come up the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Greenway, stared at them curiously. The landlord introduced the newcomers to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Bree-folk, so quickly that, though they caught many names, they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seldom sure who the names belonged to. The Men of Bree seemed all to have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rather botanical (and to the Shire-folk rather odd) names, like Rushlight,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Goatleaf, Heathertoes, Appledore, Thistlewool and Ferny (not to mention<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur). Some of the hobbits had similar names. The Mug worts, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">instance, seemed numerous. But most of them had natural names, such as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Banks, Brockhouse, Longholes, Sandheaver, and Tunnelly, many of which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used in the Shire. There were several Underhills from Saddle, and as they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not imagine sharing a name without being related, they took Frodo to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their hearts as a long-lost cousin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Bree-hobbits were, in fact, friendly and inquisitive, and Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">soon found that some explanation of what he was doing would have to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">given. He gave out that he was interested in history and geography (at which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was much wagging of heads, although neither of these words were much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used in the Bree-dialect). He said he was thinking of writing a book (at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which there was silent astonishment), and that he and his friends wanted to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">collect information about hobbits living outside the Shire, especially in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the eastern lands.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At this a chorus of voices broke out. If Frodo had really wanted to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">write a book, and had had many ears, he would have learned enough for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">several chapters in a few minutes. And if that was not enough, he was given<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a whole list of names, beginning with 'Old Barliman here', to whom he could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go for further information. But after a time, as Frodo did not show any sign<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of writing a book on the spot, the hobbits returned to their questions about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doings in the Shire. Frodo did not prove very communicative, and he soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found himself sitting alone in a comer, listening and looking around.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Men and Dwarves were mostly talking of distant events and telling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flews of a kind that was becoming only too familiar. There was trouble away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the South, and it seemed that the Men who had come up the Greenway<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the move, looking for lands where they could find some peace. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-folk were sympathetic, but plainly not very ready to take a large<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">number of strangers into their little land. One of the travellers, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">squint-eyed ill-favoured fellow, was foretelling that more and more people<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would be coming north in the near future. 'If room isn't found for them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they'll find it for themselves. They've a right to live, same as other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk,' he said loudly. The local inhabitants did not look pleased at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prospect.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits did not pay much attention to all this, and it did not at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the moment seem to concern hobbits. Big Folk could hardly beg for lodgings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in hobbit-holes. They were more interested in Sam and Pippin, who were now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feeling quite at home, and were chatting gaily about events in the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin roused a good deal of laughter with an account of the collapse of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roof of the Town Hole in Michel Delving: Will Whitfoot, the Mayor, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fattest hobbit in the Westfarthing, had been buried in chalk, and came out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a floured dumpling. But there were several questions asked that made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo a little uneasy. One of the Bree-landers, who seemed to have been in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire several times, wanted to know where the Underhills lived and who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were related to.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly Frodo noticed that a strange-looking weather-beaten man,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sitting in the shadows near the wall, was also listening intently to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit-talk. He had a tall tankard in front of him, and was smoking a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long-stemmed pipe curiously carved. His legs were stretched out before him,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">showing high boots of supple leather that fitted him well, but had seen much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wear and were now caked with mud. A travel -stained cloak of heavy dark-<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloth was drawn close about him, and in spite of the heat of the room he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wore a hood that overshadowed his face; but the gleam of his eyes could be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seen as he watched the hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Who is that?' Frodo asked, when he got a chance to whisper to Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur. 'I don't think you introduced him?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Him?' said the landlord in an answering whisper, cocking an eye<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without turning his head. 'I don't rightly know. He is one of the wandering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk -Rangers we call them. He seldom talks: not but what he can tell a rare<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tale when he has the mind. He disappears for a month, or a year, and then he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pops up again. He was in and out pretty often last spring; but I haven't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seen him about lately. What his right name is I've never heard: but he's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">known round here as Strider. Goes about at a great pace on his long shanks;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though he don't tell nobody what cause he has to hurry. But there's no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accounting for East and West, as we say in Bree, meaning the Rangers and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire-folk, begging your pardon. Funny you should ask about him.' But at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that moment Mr. Butterbur was called away by a demand for more ale and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last remark remained unexplained.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo found that Strider was now looking at him, as if he had heard or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed all that had been said. Presently, with a wave of his hand and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nod, he invited Frodo to come over and sit by him. As Frodo drew near be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">threw back his hood, showing a shaggy head of dark hair necked with grey,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and in a pale stem face a pair of keen grey eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am called Strider,' he said in a low voice. 'I am very pleased to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meet you. Master - Underhill, if old Butterbur got your name right.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He did,' said Frodo stiffly. He felt far from comfortable under the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stare of those keen eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, Master Underhill,' said Strider, 'if I were you, I should stop<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your young friends from talking too much. Drink, fire, and chance -meeting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are pleasant enough, but, well - this isn't the Shire. There are queer folk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about. Though I say it as shouldn't, you may think,' he added with a wry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smile, seeing Frodo's glance. 'And there have been even stranger travellers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through Bree lately,' he went on, watching Frodo's face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo returned his gaze but said nothing; and Strider made no further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sign. His attention seemed suddenly to be fixed on Pippin. To his alarm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo became aware that the ridiculous young Took, encouraged by his success<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the fat Mayor of Michel Delving, was now actually giving a comic<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">account of Bilbo's farewell party. He was already giving an imitation of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Speech, and was drawing near to the astonishing Disappearance.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was annoyed. It was a harmless enough tale for most of the local<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits, no doubt: just a funny story about those funny people away beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the River; but some (old Butterbur, for instance) knew a thing or two, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had probably heard rumours long ago about Bilbo's vanishing. It would bring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the name of Baggins to their minds, especially if there had been inquiries<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Bree after that name.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo fidgeted, wondering what to do. Pippin was evidently much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enjoying the attention he was getting, and had become quite forgetful of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their danger. Frodo had a sudden fear that in his present mood he might even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mention the Ring; and that might well be disastrous.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You had better do something quick!' whispered Strider in his ear.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo jumped up and stood on a table, and began to talk. The attention<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Pippin's audience was disturbed. Some of the hobbits looked at Frodo and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laughed and clapped, thinking that Mr. Underhill had taken as much ale as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was good for him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo suddenly felt very foolish, and found himself (as was his habit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when making a speech) fingering the things in his pocket. He felt the Ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on its chain, and quite unaccountably the desire came over him to slip it on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and vanish out of the silly situation. It seemed to him, somehow, as if me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suggestion came to him from outside, from someone or something a the room.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He resisted the temptation firmly, and clasped the Ring in his hand, as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to keep a hold on it and prevent it from escaping or doing any mischief. At<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any rate it gave him no inspiration. He spoke 'a few suitable words', as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they would have said in the Shire: We are all very much gratified by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kindness of your reception, and I venture to hope that my brief visit will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help to renew the old ties of friendship between the Shire and Bree; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then he hesitated and coughed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Everyone in the room was now looking at him. 'A song!' shouted one of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hobbits. 'A song! A song!' shouted all the others. 'Come on now, master,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sing us something that we havenâ€™t heard before!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For a moment Frodo stood gaping. Then in desperation he began a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ridiculous song that Bilbo had been rather fond of (and indeed rather proud<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of, for he had made up the words himself). It was about an inn; and that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">probably why it came into Frodo's mind just then. Here it is in full. Only a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">few words of it are now, as a rule, remembered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There is an inn, a merry old inn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beneath an old grey hill,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And there they brew a beer so brown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That the Man in the Moon himself came down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one night to drink his fill.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The ostler has a tipsy cat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that plays a five-stringed fiddle;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And up and down he runs his bow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now squeaking high, now purring low,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now sawing in the middle.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The landlord keeps a little dog<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is mighty fond of jokes;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When there's good cheer among the guests,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He cocks an ear at all the jests<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and laughs until he chokes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They also keep a horned cow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as proud as any queen;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But music turns her head like ale,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And makes her wave her tufted tail<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and dance upon the green.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And O! the rows of silver dishes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the store of silver spoons!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For Sunday* there's a special pair,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And these they polish up with care<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on Saturday afternoons.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Man in the Moon was drinking deep,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the cat began to wail;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A dish and a spoon on the table danced,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The cow in the garden madly pranced,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the little dog chased his tail.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Man in the Moon took another mug,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then rolled beneath his chair;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And there he dozed and dreamed of ale,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Till in the sky the stars were pale,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and dawn was in the air.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then the ostler said to his tipsy cat:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The white horses of the Moon,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They neigh and champ their silver bits;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But their master's been and drowned his wits,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the Sun'll be rising soon!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So the cat on his fiddle played hey-diddle-diddle,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a jig that would wake the dead:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He squeaked and sawed and quickened the tune,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While the landlord shook the Man in the Moon:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's after three!' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They rolled the Man slowly up the hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and bundled him into the Moon,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While his horses galloped up in rear,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And the cow came capering like a deer,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a dish ran up with the spoon.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now quicker the fiddle went deedle-dum-diddle;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dog began to roar,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The cow and the horses stood on their heads;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The guests all bounded from their beds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and danced upon the floor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With a ping and a pong the fiddle-strings broke!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cow jumped over the Moon,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And the little dog laughed to see such fun,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And the Saturday dish went off at a run<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the silver Sunday spoon.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The round Moon rolled behind the hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as the Sun raised up her head.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">She * hardly believed her fiery eyes;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For though it was day, to her surprise<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they all went back to bed!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was loud and long applause. Frodo had a good voice, and the song<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tickled their fancy. 'Where's old Barley?' they cried. 'He ought to hear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this. Bob ought to learn his cat the fiddle, and then we'd have a dance.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They called for more ale, and began to shout: 'Let's have it again, master!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Come on now! Once more!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They made Frodo have another drink, and then begin his song again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while many of them joined in; for the tune was well known, and they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quick at picking up words. It was now Frodo's turn to feel pleased with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself. He capered about on the table; and when he came a second time to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cow jumped over the Moon, he leaped in the air. Much too vigorously; for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he came down, bang, into a tray full of mugs, and slipped, and rolled off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the table with a crash, clatter, and bump! The audience all opened their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mouths wide for laughter, and stopped short a gaping silence; for the singer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disappeared. He simply vanished, as if he had gone slap through the floor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without leaving a hole !<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The local hobbits stared in amazement, and then sprang to their feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and shouted for Barliman. All the company drew away from Pippin and Sam,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found themselves left alone in a comer, and eyed darkly and doubtfully from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a distance. It was plain that many people regarded them now as the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companions of a travelling magician of unknown powers and purpose. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was one swarthy Bree-lander, who stood looking at them with a knowing and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">half-mocking expression that made them feel very uncomfortable. Presently he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slipped out of the door, followed by the squint-eyed southerner: the two had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been whispering together a good deal during the evening. Harry the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gatekeeper also went out just behind them..<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
