<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo felt a fool. Not knowing what else to do, he crawled away under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the tables to the dark comer by Strider, who sat unmoved, giving no sign of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his thoughts. Frodo leaned back against the wall and took off the Ring. How<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it came to be on his finger he could not tell. He could only suppose that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had been handling it in his pocket while he sang, and that somehow it had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slipped on when he stuck out his hand with a jerk to save his fall. For a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moment he wondered if the Ring itself had not played him a trick; perhaps it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had tried to reveal itself in response to some wish or command that was felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the room. He did not like the looks of the men that had gone out.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well?' said Strider, when he reappeared. â€™Why did you do that? Worse<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than anything your friends could have said! You have put your foot in it! Or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should I say your finger?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know what you mean,' said Frodo, annoyed and alarmed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh yes, you do,' answered Strider; 'but we had better wait until the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uproar has died down. Then, if you please, Mr. Baggins, I should like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quiet word with you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What about?' asked Frodo, ignoring the sudden use of his proper name.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A matter of some importance - to us both,' answered Strider, looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo in the eye. 'You may hear something to your advantage.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well,' said Frodo, trying to appear unconcerned. 'I'll talk to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you later.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Meanwhile an argument was going on by the fireplace. Mr. Butterbur had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come trotting in, and he was now trying to listen to several conflicting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accounts of the event at the same time.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I saw him, Mr. Butterbur,' said a hobbit; 'or leastways I didn't see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, if you take my meaning. He just vanished into thin air, in a manner of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speaking.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You don't say, Mr. Mugwort!' said the landlord, looking puzzled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes I do!' replied Mugwort. 'And I mean what I say, what's more.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There's some mistake somewhere,' said Butterbur, shaking his head.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was too much of that Mr. Underhill to go vanishing into thin air; or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into thick air, as is more likely in this room.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, where is he now?' cried several voices.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How should I know? He's welcome to go where he will, so long as he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pays in the morning. There's Mr. Took, now: he's not vanished.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, I saw what I saw, and I saw what I didn't,' said Mugwort<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">obstinately.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I say there's some mistake,' repeated Butterbur, picking up the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tray and gathering up the broken crockery.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course there's a mistake!' said Frodo. 'I haven't vanished. Here I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">am! I've just been having a few words with Strider in the comer.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He came forward into the firelight; but most of the company backed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away,, even more perturbed than before. They were not in the least satisfied<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by his explanation that he had crawled away quickly under the tables after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had fallen. Most of the Hobbits and the Men of Bree went off then and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there in a huff, having no fancy for further entertainment that evening. One<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or two gave Frodo a black look and departed muttering among themselves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dwarves and the two or three strange Men that still remained got up and said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good night to the landlord, but not to Frodo and his friends. Before long no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one was left but Strider, who sat on, unnoticed, by the wall.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Butterbur did not seem much put out. He reckoned, very probably,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that his house would be full again on many future nights, until the present<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mystery had been thoroughly discussed. 'Now what have you been doing, Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Underhill?' he asked. 'Frightening my customers and breaking up my crocks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with your acrobatics!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am very sorry to have caused any trouble,' said Frodo. 'It was quite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unintentional, I assure you. A most unfortunate accident.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All right, Mr. Underhill! But if you're going to do any more tumbling,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or conjuring, or whatever it was, you'd best warn folk beforehand - and warn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me. We're a bit suspicious round here of anything out of the way -uncanny,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if you understand me; and we don't take to it all of a sudden.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I shan't be doing anything of the sort again, Mr. Butterbur, I promise<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you. And now I think I'll be getting to bed. We shall be making an early<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">start. Will you see that our ponies are ready by eight o'clock?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very good! But before you go, I should like a word with you in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">private, Mr. Underhill. Something has just come back to my mind that I ought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to tell you. I hope that you'll not take it amiss. When I've seen to a thing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or two, I'll come along to your room, if you're willing.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Certainly!' said Frodo; but his heart sank. He wondered how many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">private talks he would have before he got to bed, and what they would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reveal. Were these people all in league against him? He began to suspect<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even old Butterbur's fat face of concealing dark designs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 10. Strider<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo, Pippin, and Sam made their way back to the parlour. There was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light. Merry was not there, and the fire had burned low. It was not until<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they had puffed up the embers into a blaze and thrown on a couple of faggots<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they discovered Strider had come with them. There he was calmly sitting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a chair by the door!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hallo!' said Pippin. 'Who are you, and what do you want?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am called Strider,' he answered: 'and though he may have forgotten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, your friend promised to have a quiet talk with me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You said I might hear something to my advantage, I believe,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo. 'What have you to say?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Several things,' answered Strider. 'But, of course, I have my price.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you mean?' asked Frodo sharply.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't be alarmed! I mean just this: I will tell you what I know, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">give you some good advice - but I shall want a reward.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what will that be, pray?' said Frodo. He suspected now that he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fallen in with a rascal, and he thought uncomfortably that he had brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only a little money with him. All of it would hardly satisfy a rogue, and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not spare any of it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No more than you can afford,' answered Strider with a slow smile, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if he guessed Frodo's thoughts. 'Just this: you must take me along with you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until I wish to leave you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh, indeed!' replied Frodo, surprised, but not much relieved. 'Even if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I wanted another companion, I should not agree to any such thing, until I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew a good deal more about you, and your business.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Excellent!' exclaimed Strider, crossing his legs and sitting back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comfortably. 'You seem to be coming to your senses again, and that is all to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the good. You have been much too careless so far. Very well! I will tell you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what I know, and leave the reward to you. You may be glad to grant it, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you have heard me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Go on then!' said Frodo. 'What do you know?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Too much; too many dark things,' said Strider grimly. 'But as for your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">business â€” ' He got up and went to the door, opened it quickly and looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out. Then he shut it quietly and sat down again. 'I have quick ears,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went on, lowering his voice, 'and though I cannot disappear, I have hunted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many wild and wary things and I can usually avoid being seen, if I wish.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now, I was behind the hedge this evening on the Road west of Bree, when four<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits came out of the Downlands. I need not repeat all that they said to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old Bombadil or to one another, but one thing interested me. Please<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remember, said one of them, that the name Baggins must not be mentioned. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">am Mr. Underhill, if any name must be given. That interested me so much that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I followed them here. I slipped over the gate just behind them. Maybe Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins has an honest reason for leaving his name behind; but if so, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should advise him and his friends to be more careful.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't see what interest my name has for any one in Bree,' said Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">angrily, 'and I have still to learn why it interests you. Mr. Strider may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have an honest reason for spying and eavesdropping; but if so, I should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">advise him to explain it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well answered!' said Strider laughing. 'But the explanation is simple:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I was looking for a Hobbit called Frodo Baggins. I wanted to find him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quickly. I had learned that he was carrying out of the Shire, well, a secret<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that concerned me and my friends.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now, don't mistake me!' he cried, as Frodo rose from his seat, and Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jumped up with a scowl. 'I shall take more care of the secret than you do.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And care is needed!' He leaned forward and looked at them. 'Watch every<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow!' he said in a low voice. 'Black horsemen have passed through Bree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On Monday one came down the Greenway, they say; and another appeared<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">later,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming up the Greenway from the south.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a silence. At last Frodo spoke to Pippin and Sam: 'I ought to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have guessed it from the way the gatekeeper greeted us,' he said. 'And the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">landlord seems to have heard something. Why did he press us to join the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">company? And why on earth did we behave so foolishly: we ought to have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stayed quiet in here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It would have been better,' said Strider. 'I would have stopped your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going into the common-room, if I could; but the innkeeper would not let me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in to see you, or take a message.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you think he ' began Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I don't think any harm of old Butterbur. Only he does not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">altogether like mysterious vagabonds of my sort.' Frodo gave him a puzzled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look. 'Well, I have rather a rascally look, have I not?' said Strider with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">curl of his lip and a queer gleam in his eye. 'But I hope we shall get to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know one another better. When we do, I hope you will explain what happened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at the end of your song. For that little prank '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was sheer accident!' interrupted Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder,' said Strider. 'Accident, then. That accident has made your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">position dangerous.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hardly more than it was already,' said Frodo. 'I knew these horsemen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were pursuing me; but now at any rate they seem to have missed me and to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have gone away.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You must not count on that!' said Strider sharply. 'They will return.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And more are coming. There are others. I know their number. I know these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders.' He paused, and his eyes were cold and hard. 'And there are some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk in Bree who are not to be trusted,' he went on. 'Bill Ferny, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">instance. He has an evil name in the Bree-land, and queer folk call at his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house. You must have noticed him among the company: a swarthy sneering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fellow. He was very close with one of the Southern strangers, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slipped out together just after your "accident". Not all of those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Southerners mean well; and as for Ferny, he would sell anything to anybody;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or make mischief for amusement.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What will Ferny sell, and what has my accident got to do with him?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Frodo, still determined not to understand Strider's hints.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'News of you, of course,' answered Strider. 'An account of your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">performance would be very interesting to certain people. After that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would hardly need to be told your real name. It seems to me only too likely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they will hear of it before this night is over. Is that enough? You can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do as you like about my reward: take me as a guide or not. But I may say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I know all the lands between the Shire and the Misty Mountains, for I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have wandered over them for many years. I am older than I look. I might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prove useful. You will have to leave the open road after tonight; for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horsemen will watch it night and day. You may escape from Bree, and be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">allowed to go forward while the Sun is up; but you won't go far. They will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come on you in the wild, in some dark place where there is no help. Do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish them to find you? They are terrible!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits looked at him, and saw with surprise that his face was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drawn as if with pain, and his hands clenched the arms of his chair. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">room was very quiet and still, and the light seemed to have grown dim. For a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while he sat with unseeing eyes as if walking in distant memory or listening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to sounds in the Night far away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There!' he cried after a moment, drawing his hand across his brow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Perhaps I know more about these pursuers than you do. You fear them, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you do not fear them enough, yet. Tomorrow you will have to escape, if you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can. Strider can take you by paths that are seldom trodden. Will you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a heavy silence. Frodo made no answer, his mind was confused<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with doubt and fear. Sam frowned, and looked at his master; and at last he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broke out:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'With your leave, Mr. Frodo, I'd say no! This Strider here, he warns<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he says take care; and I say yes to that, and let's begin with him. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comes out of the Wild, and I never heard no good of such folk. He knows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something, that's plain, and more than I like; but it's no reason why we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should let him go leading us out into some dark place far from help, as he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">puts it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin fidgeted and looked uncomfortable. Strider did not reply to Sam,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but turned his keen eyes on Frodo. Frodo caught his glance and looked away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' he said slowly. 'I don't agree. I think, I think you are not really as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you choose to look. You began to talk to me like the Bree-folk, but your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice has changed. Still Sam seems right in this: I don't see why you should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warn us to take care, and yet ask us to take you on trust. Why the disguise?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Who are you? What do you really know about - about my business; and how<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you know it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The lesson in caution has been well learned,' said Strider with a grim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smile. 'But caution is one thing and wavering is another. You will never get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Rivendell now on your own, and to trust me is your only chance. You must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make up your mind. I will answer some of your questions, if that will help<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you to do so. But why should you believe my story, if you do not trust me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already? Still here it is '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment there came a knock at the door. Mr. Butterbur had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arrived with candles, and behind him was Nob with cans of hot water. Strider<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">withdrew into a dark corner.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I've come to bid you good night,' said the landlord, putting the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">candles on the table. 'Nob! Take the water to the rooms!' He came in and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shut the door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's like this,' he began, hesitating and looking troubled. 'If I've<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">done any harm, I'm sorry indeed. But one thing drives out another, as you'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">admit; and I'm a busy man. But first one thing and then another this week<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have jogged my memory, as the saying goes; and not too late I hope. You see,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I was asked to look out for hobbits of the Shire, and for one by the name of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins in particular.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what has that got to do with me?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah! you know best,' said the landlord, knowingly. 'I won't give you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away; but I was told that this Baggins would be going by the name of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Underhill, and I was given a description that fits you well enough, if I may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say so.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed! Let's have it then!' said Frodo, unwisely interrupting.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A stout little fellow with red cheeks, ' said Mr. Butterbur solemnly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin chuckled, but Sam looked indignant. 'That won't help you much; it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">goes for most hobbits. Barley, he says to me,' continued Mr. Butterbur with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a glance at Pippin. 'But this one is taller than some and fairer than most,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he has a cleft in his chin: perky chap with a bright eye. Begging your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pardon, but he said it, not me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He said it? And who was he?' asked Frodo eagerly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah! That was Gandalf, if you know who I mean. A wizard they say he is,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but he's a good friend of mine, whether or no. But now I don't know what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he'll have to say to me, if I see him again: turn all my ale sour or me into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a block of wood, I shouldn't wonder. He's a bit hasty. Still what's done<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can't be undone. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, what have you done?' said Frodo, getting impatient with the slow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unravelling of Butterbur's thoughts.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where was I?' said the landlord, pausing and snapping his fingers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah, yes ! Old Gandalf. Three months back he walked right into my room<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without a knock. Barley, he says, I'm off in the morning. Will you do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something for me? You've only to name it, I said. I'm in a hurry, said he,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I've no time myself, but I want a message took to the Shire. Have you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anyone you can send, and trust to go? I can find someone, I said, tomorrow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">maybe, or the day after. Make it tomorrow, he says, and then he gave me a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letter.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's addressed plain enough,' said Mr. Butterbur, producing a letter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from his pocket, and reading out the address slowly and proudly (he valued<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his reputation as a lettered man):<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr FRODO BAGGINS, BAG END, HOBBITON in the SHIRE.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A letter for me from Gandalf!' cried Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah!' said Mr. Butterbur. 'Then your right name is Baggins?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is,' said Frodo, 'and you had better give me that letter at once,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and explain why you never sent it. That's what you came to tell me, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suppose, though you've taken a long time to come to the point.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Poor Mr. Butterbur looked troubled. 'You're right, master,' he said,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and I beg your pardon. And I'm mortal afraid of what Gandalf will say, if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">harm comes of it. But I didn't keep it back a-purpose. I put it by safe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then I couldn't find nobody willing to go to the Shire next day, nor the day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after, and none of my own folk were to spare; and then one thing after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">another drove it out of my mind. I'm a busy man. I'll do what I can to set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">matters right, and if there's any help I can give, you've only to name it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Leaving the letter aside, I promised Gandalf no less. Barley, he says<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to me, this friend of mine from the Shire, he may be coming out this way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before long, him and another. He'll be calling himself Underhill. Mind that!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But you need ask no questions. And if I'm not with him, he may be in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trouble, and he may need help. Do whatever you can for him, and I'll be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grateful, he says. And here you are, and trouble is not far off, seemingly.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you mean?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'These black men,' said the landlord lowering his voice. 'They're<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking for Baggins, and if they mean well, then I'm a hobbit. It was on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Monday, and all the dogs were yammering and the geese screaming. Uncanny,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called it. Nob, he came and told me that two black men were at the door<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asking for a hobbit called Baggins. Nob's hair was all stood on end. I bid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the black fellows be off, and slammed the door on them; but they've been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asking the same question all the way to Archet, I hear. And that Ranger,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider, he's been asking questions, too. Tried to get in here to see you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before you'd had bite or sup, he did.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Fie did!' said Strider suddenly, coming forward into the light. 'And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much trouble would have been saved, if you had let him in, Barliman.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The landlord jumped with surprise. 'You!' he cried. 'You're always<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">popping up. What do you want now?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He's here with my leave,' said Frodo. 'He came to offer me his help.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, you know your own business, maybe,' said Mr. Butterbur, looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suspiciously at Strider. 'But if I was in your plight, I wouldn't take up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a Ranger.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then who would you take up with?' asked Strider. 'A fat innkeeper who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only remembers his own name because people shout it at him all day? They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cannot stay in The Pony for ever, and they cannot go home. They have a long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road before them. Will you go with them and keep the black men off?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Me? Leave Bree! I wouldn't do that for any money,' said Mr. Butterbur,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking really scared. 'But why can't you stay here quiet for a bit, Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Underhill? What are all these queer goings on? What are these black men<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after, and where do they come from, I'd like to know?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I'm sorry I can't explain it all,' answered Frodo. 'I am tired and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very worried, and it's a long tale. But if you mean to help me, I ought to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warn you that you will be in danger as long as I am in your house. These<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Black Riders: I am not sure, but I think, I fear they come from '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They come from Mordor,' said Strider in a low voice. 'From Mordor,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barliman, if that means anything to you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Save us!' cried Mr. Butterbur turning pale; the name evidently was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">known to him. 'That is the worst news that has come to Bree in my time.' 'It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is,' said Frodo. 'Are you still willing to help me?' 'I am,' said Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur. 'More than ever. Though I don't know what the likes of me can do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against, against ' he faltered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Against the Shadow in the East,' said Strider quietly. 'Not much,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barliman, but every little helps. You can let Mr. Underhill stay here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tonight, as Mr. Underhill, and you can forget the name of Baggins, till he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is far away.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I'll do that,' said Butterbur. 'But they'll find out he's here without<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help from me, I'm afraid. It's a pity Mr. Baggins drew attention to himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this evening, to say no more. The story of that Mr. Bilbo's going off has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been heard before tonight in Bree. Even our Nob has been doing some guessing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in his slow pate: and there are others in Bree quicker in the uptake than he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, we can only hope the Riders won't come back yet,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope not, indeed,' said Butterbur. 'But spooks or no spooks, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">won't get in The Pony so easy. Don't you worry till the morning. Nob'll say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no word. No black man shall pass my doors, while I can stand on my legs. Me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and my folk'll keep watch tonight; but you had best get some sleep, if you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'In any case we must be called at dawn,' said Frodo. 'We must get off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as early as possible. Breakfast at six-thirty, please.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Right! I'll see to the orders,' said the landlord. 'Good night, Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Baggins - Underhill, I should say! Good night - now, bless me! Where's your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Brandybuck?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I donâ€™t know,' said Frodo with sudden anxiety. They had forgotten all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about Merry, and it was getting late. 'I am afraid he is out. He said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something about going for a breath of air.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, you do want looking after and no mistake: your party might be on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a holiday!' said Butterbur. 'I must go and bar the doors quick, but I'll see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your friend is let in when he comes. I'd better send Nob to look for him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Good night to you all!' At last Mr. Butterbur went out, with another<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubtful look at Strider and a shake of his head. His footsteps retreated<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down the passage.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well?' said Strider. 'When are you going to open that letter?' Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked carefully at the seal before he broke it. It seemed certainly to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf s. Inside, written in the wizard's strong but graceful script, was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the following message:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">THE PRANCING PONY, BREE. Midyear's Day, Shire Year, 1418.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dear Frodo,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bad news has reached me here. I must go off at once. You had better<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leave Bag End soon, and get out of the Shire before the end of July at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">latest. I will return as soon as I can; and I will follow you, if I find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that you are gone. Leave a message for me here, if you pass through Bree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You can trust the landlord (Butterbur). You may meet a friend of mine on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Road: a Man, lean, dark, tall, by some called Strider. He knows our business<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and will help you. Make for Rivendell. There I hope we may meet again. If I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do not come, Elrond will advise you.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Yours in haste<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">GANDALF.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">PS. Do NOT use It again, not far any reason whatever! Do not travel by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">PPS. Make sure that it is the real Strider. There are many strange men<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the roads. His true name is Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All that is gold does not glitter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not all those who wander are lost;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The old that is strong does not wither,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Deep roots are not reached by the frost.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From the ashes a fire shall be woken,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A light from the shadows shall spring;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Renewed shall be blade that was broken,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The crownless again shall be king.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">PPPS. I hope Butterbur sends this promptly. A worthy man, but his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">memory is like a lumber-roam: thing wanted always buried. If he forgets, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall roast him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fare Well 7<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo read the letter to himself, and then passed it to Pippin and Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Really old Butterbur has made a mess of things!' he said. 'He deserves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roasting. If I had got this at once, we might all have been safe in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell by now. But what can have happened to Gandalf? He writes as if he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was going into great danger.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He has been doing that for many years,' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo turned and looked at him thoughtfully, wondering about Gandalf s<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">second postscript. 'Why didn't you tell me that you were Gandalf s friend at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">once?' he asked. 'It would have saved time.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Would it? Would any of you have believed me till now?' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I knew nothing of this letter. For all I knew I had to persuade you to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust me without proofs, if I was to help you. In any case, I did not intend<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to tell you all about myself at once. I had to study you first, and make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sure of you. The Enemy has set traps for me before now. As soon as I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made up my mind, I was ready to tell you whatever you asked. But I must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">admit,' he added with a queer laugh, 'that I hoped you would take to me for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my own sake. A hunted man sometimes wearies of distrust and longs for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friendship. But there, I believe my looks are against me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They are - at first sight at any rate,' laughed Pippin with sudden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">relief after reading Gandalf's letter. 'But handsome is as handsome does, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we say in the Shire; and I daresay we shall all look much the same after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lying for days in hedges and ditches.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It would take more than a few days, or weeks, or years, of wandering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Wild to make you look like Strider,' he answered. 'And you would die<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first, unless you are made of sterner stuff than you look to be.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin subsided; but Sam was not daunted, and he still eyed Strider<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dubiously. 'How do we know you are the Strider that Gandalf speaks about?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he demanded. 'You never mentioned Gandalf, till this letter came out. You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might be a play-acting spy, for all I can see, trying to get us to go with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you. You might have done in the real Strider and took his clothes. What have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you to say to that?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That you are a stout fellow,' answered Strider; 'but I am afraid my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only answer to you, Sam Gamgee, is this. If I had killed the real Strider, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could kill you. And I should have killed you already without so much talk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">If I was after the Ring, I could have it - NOW!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He stood up, and seemed suddenly to grow taller. In his eyes gleamed a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light, keen and commanding. Throwing back his cloak, he laid his hand on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hilt of a sword that had hung concealed by his side. They did not dare to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">move. Sam sat wide-mouthed staring at him dumbly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I am the real Strider, fortunately,' he said, looking down at them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with his face softened by a sudden smile. 'I am Aragorn son of Arathorn; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if by life or death I can save you, I will.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a long silence. At last Frodo spoke with hesitation. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">believed that you were a friend before the letter came,' he said, 'or at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least I wished to. You have frightened me several times tonight, but never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the way that servants of the Enemy would, or so I imagine. I think one of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his spies would - well, seem fairer and feel fouler, if you understand.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I see,' laughed Strider. 'I look foul and feel fair. Is that it? All<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is gold does not glitter, not all those who wander are lost '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Did the verses apply to you then?' asked Frodo. 'I could not make out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what they were about. But how did you know that they were in Gandalf s<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letter, if you have never seen it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I did not know,' he answered. 'But I am Aragorn, and those verses go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with that name.' He drew out his sword, and they saw that the blade was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed broken a foot below the hilt. 'Not much use is it, Sam?' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider. 'But the time is near when it shall be forged anew.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam said nothing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well,' said Strider, 'with Sam's permission we will call that settled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider shall be your guide. We shall have a rough road tomorrow. Even if we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are allowed to leave Bree unhindered, we can hardly hope now to leave it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unnoticed. But I shall try to get lost as soon as possible. I know one or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">two ways out of Bree-land other than the main road. If once we shake off the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pursuit, I shall make for Weathertop.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Weathertop?' said Sam. 'What's that?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is a hill, just to the north of the Road, about half way from here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Rivendell. It commands a wide view all round; and there we shall have a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chance to look about us. Gandalf will make for that point, if he follows us.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After Weathertop our journey will become more difficult, and we shall have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to choose between various dangers.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™When did you last see Gandalf?' asked Frodo. 'Do you know where he is,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or what he is doing?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider looked grave. 'I do not know,' he said. 'I came west with him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the spring. I have often kept watch on the borders of the Shire in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last few years, when he was busy elsewhere. He seldom left it unguarded. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last met on the first of May: at Sam Ford down the Brandywine. He told me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that his business with you had gone well, and that you would be starting for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell in the last week of September. As I knew he was at your side, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went away on a journey of my own. And that has proved ill; for plainly some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">news reached him, and I was not at hand to help.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am troubled, for the first time since I have known him. We should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have had messages, even if he could not come himself. When I returned, many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days ago, I heard the ill news. The tidings had gone far and wide that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf was missing and the horsemen had been seen. It was the Elven-folk of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gildor that told me this; and later they told me that you had left your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">home; but there was no news of your leaving Buckland. I have been watching<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the East Road anxiously.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you think the Black Riders have anything to do with it - with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf's absence, I mean?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know of anything else that could have hindered him, except<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Enemy himself,' said Strider. 'But do not give up hope ! Gandalf is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greater than you Shire-folk know - as a rule you can only see his jokes and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">toys. But this business of ours will be his greatest task.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin yawned. 'I am sorry,' he said, 'but I am dead tired. In spite of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the danger and worry I must go to bed, or sleep where I sit. Where is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that silly fellow, Merry? It would be the last straw, if we had to go out in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dark to look for him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment they heard a door slam; then feet came running along the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passage. Merry came in with a rush followed by Nob. He shut the door<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
