<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hastily, and leaned against it. He was out of breath. They stared at him in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alarm for a moment before he gasped: 'I have seen them, Frodo! I have seen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them! Black Riders!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Black Riders!' cried Frodo. 'Where?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here. In the village. I stayed indoors for an hour. Then as you did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not come back, I went out for a stroll. I had come back again and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">standing just outside the light of the lamp looking at the stars. Suddenly I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shivered and felt that something horrible was creeping near: there was a son<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of deeper shade among the shadows across the road, just beyond the edge of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the lamplight. It slid away at once into the dark without a sound. There was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no horse.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Which way did it go?' asked Strider, suddenly and sharply. Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">started, noticing the stranger for the first time. 'Go on!' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'This is a friend of Gandalf's. I will explain later.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It seemed to make off up the Road, eastward,' continued Merry. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tried to follow. Of course, it vanished almost at once; but I went round the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">corner and on as far as the last house on the Road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider looked at Merry with wonder. 'You have a stout heart,' he said;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'but it was foolish.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know,' said Merry. 'Neither brave nor silly, I think. I could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hardly help myself. I seemed to be drawn somehow. Anyway, I went, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly I heard voices by the hedge. One was muttering; and the other was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whispering, or hissing. I couldn't hear a word that was said. I did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creep any closer, because I began to tremble all over. Then I felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terrified, and I turned back, and was just going to bolt home, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something came behind me and I... I fell over.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I found him, sir,' put in Nob. 'Mr. Butterbur sent me out with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lantern. I went down to West-gate, and then back up towards South-gate. Just<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nigh Bill Ferny's house I thought I could see something in the Road. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">couldn't swear to it, but it looked to me as if two men was stooping over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something, lilting it. I gave a shout, but where I got up to the spot there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was no signs of them, and only Mr. Brandybuck lying by the roadside. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to be asleep. "I thought I had fallen into deep water," he says to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me, when I shook him. Very queer he was, and as soon as I had roused him, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">got up and ran back here like a hare.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am afraid that's true,' said Merry, 'though I don't know what I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said. I had an ugly dream, which I can't remember. I went to pieces. I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know what came over me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do,' said Strider. 'The Black Breath. The Riders must have left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their horses outside, and passed back through the South-gate in secret. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will know all the news now, for they have visited Bill Ferny; and probably<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that Southerner was a spy as well. Something may happen in the night, before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we leave Bree.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What will happen?' said Merry. 'Will they attack the inn?' 'No, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think not,' said Strider. 'They are not all here yet. And in any case that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is not their way. In dark and loneliness they are strongest; they will not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">openly attack a house where there are lights and many people -not until they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are desperate, not while all the long leagues of Eriador still lie before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us. But their power is in terror, and already some in Bree are in their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clutch. They will drive these wretches to some evil work: Ferny, and some of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the strangers, and, maybe, the gatekeeper too. They had words with Harry at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">West-gate on Monday. I was watching them. He was white and shaking when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We seem to have enemies all round,' said Frodo. 'What are we to do?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Stay here, and do not go to your rooms ! They are sure to have found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out which those are. The hobbit-rooms have windows looking north and close<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the ground. We will all remain together and bar this window and the door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But first Nob and I will fetch your luggage.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While Strider was gone, Frodo gave Merry a rapid account of all that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had happened since supper. Merry was still reading and pondering Gandalf's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letter when Strider and Nob returned.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well Masters,' said Nob, 'I've ruffled up the clothes and put in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bolster down the middle of each bed. And I made a nice imitation of your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">head with a brown woollen mat, Mr. Bag - Underhill, sir,' he added with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin laughed. 'Very life-like!' he said. 'But what will happen when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they have penetrated the disguise?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We shall see,' said Strider. 'Fet us hope to hold the fort till<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">morning.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good night to you,' said Nob, and went off to take his part in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watch on the doors.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their bags and gear they piled on the parlour-floor. They pushed a low<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chair against the door and shut the window. Peering out, Frodo saw that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night was still clear. The Sickle was swinging bright above the shoulders of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-hill. He then closed and barred the heavy inside shutters and drew the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">curtains together. Strider built up the fire and blew out all the candles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits lay down on their blankets with their feet towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hearth; but Strider settled himself in the chair against the door. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talked for a little, for Merry still had several questions to ask.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Jumped over the Moon!' chuckled Merry as he rolled himself in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blanket. 'Very ridiculous of you, Frodo! But I wish I had been there to see.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The worthies of Bree will be discussing it a hundred years hence.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope so,' said Strider. Then they all fell silent, and one by one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hobbits dropped off to sleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 11. A Knife in the Dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they prepared for sleep in the inn at Bree, darkness lay on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Buckland; a mist strayed in the dells and along the river -bank. The house at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Crickhollow stood silent. Fatty Bolger opened the door cautiously and peered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out. A feeling of fear had been growing on him all day, and he was unable to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rest or go to bed: there was a brooding threat in the breathless night-air.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he stared out into the gloom, a black shadow moved under the trees; the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gate seemed to open of its own accord and close again without a sound.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Terror seized him. He shrank back, and for a moment he stood trembling in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hall. Then he shut and locked the door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The night deepened. There came the soft sound of horses led with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stealth along the lane. Outside the gate they stopped, and three black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">figures entered, like shades of night creeping across the ground. One went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the door, one to the corner of the house on either side; and there they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stood, as still as the shadows of stones, while night went slowly on. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house and the quiet trees seemed to be waiting breathlessly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a faint stir in the leaves, and a cock crowed far away. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold hour before dawn was passing. The figure by the door moved. In the dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without moon or stars a drawn blade gleamed, as if a chill light had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unsheathed. There was a blow, soft but heavy, and the door shuddered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Open, in the name of Mordor!' said a voice thin and menacing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At a second blow the door yielded and fell back, with timbers burst and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lock broken. The black figures passed swiftly in.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment, among the trees nearby, a horn rang out. It rent the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night like fire on a hill -top.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">AWAKE! FEAR! FIRE! FOES! AWAKE!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fatty Bolger had not been idle. As soon as he saw the dark shapes creep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the garden, he knew that he must run for it, or perish. And run he did,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the back door, through the garden, and over the fields. When he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached the nearest house, more than a mile away, he collapsed on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doorstep. 'No, no, no!' he was crying. 'No, not me! I haven't got it!' It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was some time before anyone could make out what he was babbling about.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last they got the idea that enemies were in Buckland, some strange invasion<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the Old Forest. And then they lost no more time.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">FEAR! FIRE! FOES!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Brandybucks were blowing the Horn-call of Buckland, that had not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been sounded for a hundred years, not since the white wolves came in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fell Winter, when the Brandywine was frozen over.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">AWAKE! AWAKE!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Far-away answering horns were heard. The alarm was spreading. The black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">figures fled from the house. One of them let fall a hobbit-cloak on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">step, as he ran. In the lane the noise of hoofs broke out, and gathering to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a gallop, went hammering away into the darkness. All about Crickhollow there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was the sound of horns blowing, and voices crying and feet running. But the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Black Riders rode like a gale to the North-gate. Let the little people blow!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sauron would deal with them later. Meanwhile they had another errand: they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew now that the house was empty and the Ring had gone. They rode down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guards at the gate and vanished from the Shire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the early night Frodo woke from deep sleep, suddenly, as if some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sound or presence had disturbed him. He saw that Strider was sitting alert<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in his chair: his eyes gleamed in the light of the fire, which had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tended and was burning brightly; but he made no sign or movement.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo soon went to sleep again; but his dreams were again troubled with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the noise of wind and of galloping hoofs. The wind seemed to be curling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round the house and shaking it; and far off he heard a horn blowing wildly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He opened his eyes, and heard a cock crowing lustily in the inn-yard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider had drawn the curtains and pushed back the shutters with a clang.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The first grey light of day was in the room, and a cold air was coming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the open window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as Strider had roused them all, he led the way to their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bedrooms. When they saw them they were glad that they had taken his advice:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the windows had been forced open and were swinging, and the curtains were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flapping; the beds were tossed about, and the bolsters slashed and flung<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon the floor; the brown mat was torn to pieces.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider immediately went to fetch the landlord. Poor Mr. Butterbur<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked sleepy and frightened. He had hardly closed his eyes all night (so he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said), but he had never heard a sound.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Never has such a thing happened in my time!' he cried, raising his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hands in horror. â€™Guests unable to sleep in their beds, and good bolsters<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ruined and all! What are we coming to?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dark times,' said Strider. 'But for the present you may be left in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peace, when you have got rid of us. We will leave at once. Never mind about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">breakfast: a drink and a bite standing will have to do. We shall be packed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a few minutes.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Butterbur hurried off to see that their ponies were got ready, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to fetch them a 'bite'. But very soon he came back in dismay. The ponies had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished! The stable-doors had all been opened in the night, and they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone: not only Merry's ponies, but every other horse and beast in the place.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was crushed by the news. How could they hope to reach Rivendell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on foot, pursued by mounted enemies? They might as well set out for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Moon. Strider sat silent for a while, looking at the hobbits, as if he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weighing up their strength and courage.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ponies would not help us to escape horsemen,' he said at last,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thoughtfully, as if he guessed what Frodo had in mind. 'We should not go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much slower on foot, not on the roads that I mean to take. I was going to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walk in any case. It is the food and stores that trouble me. We cannot count<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on getting anything to eat between here and Rivendell, except what we take<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with us; and we ought to take plenty to spare; for we may be delayed, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forced to go round-about, far out of the direct way. How much are you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prepared to carry on your backs?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As much as we must,' said Pippin with a sinking heart, but trying to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">show that he was tougher than he looked (or felt).<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I can carry enough for two,' said Sam defiantly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Can't anything be done, Mr. Butterbur?' asked Frodo. 'Can't we get a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">couple of ponies in the village, or even one just for the baggage? I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suppose we could hire them, but we might be able to buy them,' he added,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubtfully, wondering if he could afford it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I doubt it,' said the landlord unhappily. 'The two or three<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">riding-ponies that there were in Bree were stabled in my yard, and they're<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone. As for other animals, horses or ponies for draught or what not, there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are very few of them in Bree, and they won't be for sale. But I'll do what I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can. I'll rout out Bob and send him round as soon as may be.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Strider reluctantly, 'you had better do that. I am afraid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we shall have to try to get one pony at least. But so ends all hope of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">starting early, and slipping away quietly! We might as well have blown a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horn to announce our departure. That was part of their plan, no doubt.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is one crumb of comfort,' said Merry, 'and more than a crumb, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hope: we can have breakfast while we wait - and sit down to it. Let's get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hold of Nob!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the end there was more than three hours' delay. Bob came back with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the report that no horse or pony was to be got for love or money in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neighbourhood - except one: Bill Ferny had one that he might possibly sell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A poor old half-starved creature it is,' said Bob; 'but he won't part with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it for less than thrice its worth, seeing how you're placed, not if I knows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bill Ferny.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bill Ferny?' said Frodo. 'Isn't there some trick? Wouldn't the beast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bolt back to him with all our stuff, or help in tracking us, or something?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder,' said Strider. 'But I cannot imagine any animal running home<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to him, once it got away. I fancy this is only an afterthought of kind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Master Ferny's: just a way of increasing his profits from the affair. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chief danger is that the poor beast is probably at death's door. But there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">does not seem any choice. What does he want for it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bill Ferny's price was twelve silver pennies; and that was indeed at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least three times the pony's value in those pans. It proved to be a bony,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">underfed, and dispirited animal; but it did not look like dying just yet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Butterbur paid for it himself, and offered Merry another eighteen pence<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as some compensation for the lost animals. He was an honest man, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well-off as things were reckoned in Bree; but thirty silver pennies was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sore blow to him, and being cheated by Bill Ferny made it harder to bear.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Asa matter of fact he came out on the right side in the end. It turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out later that only one horse had been actually stolen. The others had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">driven off, or had bolted in terror, and were found wandering in different<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">corners of the Bree-land. Merry's ponies had escaped altogether, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eventually (having a good deal of sense) they made their way to the Downs in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">search of Fatty Lumpkin. So they came under the care of Tom Bombadil for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while, and were well-off. But when news of the events at Bree came to Tom's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ears, he sent them to Mr. Butterbur, who thus got five good beasts at a very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fair price. They had to work harder in Bree, but Bob treated them well; so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the whole they were lucky: they missed a dark and dangerous journey. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they never came to Rivendell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">However, in the meanwhile for all Mr. Butterbur knew his money was gone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for good, or for bad. And he had other troubles. For there was a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">commotion as soon as the remaining guests were astir and heard news of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">raid on the inn. The southern travellers had lost several horses and blamed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the innkeeper loudly, until it became known that one of their own number had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also disappeared in the night, none other than Bill Ferny's squint-eyed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companion. Suspicion fell on him at once.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If you pick up with a horse-thief, and bring him to my house,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Butterbur angrily, 'you ought to pay for all the damage yourselves and not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come shouting at me. Go and ask Ferny where your handsome friend is!' But it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared that he was nobody's friend, and nobody could recollect when he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">joined their party.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After their breakfast the hobbits had to re-pack, and get together<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">further supplies for the longer journey they were now expecting. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">close on ten o'clock before they at last got off. By that time the whole of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree was buzzing with excitement. Frodo's vanishing trick; the appearance of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the black horsemen; the robbing of the stables; and not least the news that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider the Ranger had joined the mysterious hobbits, made such a tale as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would last for many uneventful years. Most of the inhabitants of Bree and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Staddle, and many even from Combe and Archet, were crowded in the road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see the travellers start. The other guests in the inn were at the doors or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hanging out of the windows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider had changed his mind, and he decided to leave Bree by the main<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road. Any attempt to set off across country at once would only make matters<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worse: half the inhabitants would follow them, to see what they were up to,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and to prevent them from trespassing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They said farewell to Nob and Bob, and took leave of Mr. Butterbur with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many thanks. 'I hope we shall meet again some day, when things are merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">once more,' said Frodo. 'I should like nothing better than to stay in your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">house in peace for a while.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They tramped off, anxious and downhearted, under the eyes of the crowd.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not all the faces were friendly, nor all the words that were shouted. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider seemed to be held in awe by most of the Bree-landers, and those that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he stared at shut their mouths and drew away. He walked in front with Frodo;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">next came Merry and Pippin; and last came Sam leading the pony, which was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">laden with as much of their baggage as they had the heart to give it; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already it looked less dejected, as if it approved of the change in its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fortunes. Sam was chewing an apple thoughtfully. He had a pocket full of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them: a parting present from Nob and Bob. 'Apples for walking, and a pipe<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for sitting,' he said. 'But I reckon I'll miss them both before long.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits took no notice of the inquisitive heads that peeped out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors, or popped over walls and fences, as they passed. But as they drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near to the further gate, Frodo saw a dark ill-kept house behind a thick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hedge: the last house in the village. In one of the windows he caught a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimpse of a sallow face with sly, slanting eyes; but it vanished at once.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So that's where that southerner is hiding!' he thought. 'He looks more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than half like a goblin.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Over the hedge another man was staring boldly. He had heavy black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brows, and dark scornful eyes; his large mouth curled in a sneer. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smoking a short black pipe. As they approached he took it out of his mouth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and spat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Morning, Longshanks!' he said. 'Off early? Found some friends at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last?' Strider nodded, but did not answer. 'Morning, my little friends!' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said to the others. 'I suppose you know who you've taken up with? That's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Stick -at-naught Strider, that is! Though I've heard other names not so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pretty. Watch out tonight! And you, Sammie, don't go ill-treating my poor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old pony! Pah!' He spat again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam turned quickly. 'And you. Ferny,' he said, 'put your ugly face out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of sight, or it will get hurt.' With a sudden flick, quick as lightning, an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">apple left his hand and hit Bill square on the nose. He ducked too late, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">curses came from behind the hedge. 'Waste of a good apple,' said Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">regretfully, and strode on.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last they left the village behind. The escort of children and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stragglers that had followed them got tired and turned back at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">South-gate. Passing through, they kept on along the Road for some miles. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bent to the left, curving back into its eastward line as it rounded the feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Bree-hill, and then it began to run swiftly downwards into wooded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">country. To their left they could see some of the houses and hobbit -holes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Staddle on the gentler south-eastern slopes of the hill; down in a deep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hollow away north of the Road there were wisps of rising smoke that showed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where Combe lay;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Archet was hidden in the trees beyond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After the Road had run down some way, and had left Bree-hill standing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tall and brown behind, they came on a narrow track that led off towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">North. 'This is where we leave the open and take to cover,' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not a "short cut", I hope,' said Pippin. 'Our last short cut through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods nearly ended in disaster.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah, but you had not got me with you then,' laughed Strider. 'My cuts,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">short or long, don't go wrong.' He took a look up and down the Road. No one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was in sight; and he led the way quickly down towards the wooded valley.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His plan, as far as they could understand it without knowing the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">country, was to go towards Archet at first, but to bear right and pass it on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the east, and then to steer as straight as he could over the wild lands to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Weathertop Hill. In that way they would, if all went well, cut off a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">loop of the Road, which further on bent southwards to avoid the Midgewater<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Marshes. But, of course, they would have to pass through the marshes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves, and Strider's description of them was not encouraging.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">However, in the meanwhile, walking was not unpleasant. Indeed, if it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had not been for the disturbing events of the night before, they would have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enjoyed this pan of the journey better than any up to that time. The sun was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shining, clear but not too hot. The woods in the valley were still leafy and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">full of colour, and seemed peaceful and wholesome. Strider guided them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">confidently among the many crossing paths, although left to themselves they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would soon have been at a loss. He was taking a wandering course with many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turns and doublings, to put off any pursuit.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bill Ferny will have watched where we left the Road, for certain,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said; 'though I don't think he will follow us himself. He knows the land<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round here well enough, but he knows he is not a match for me in a wood. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is what he may tell others that I am afraid of. I don't suppose they are far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away. If they think we have made for Archet, so much the better.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Whether because of Strider's skill or for some other reason, they saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no sign and heard no sound of any other living thing all that day: neither<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">two-footed, except birds; nor four-footed, except one fox and a few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">squirrels. The next day they began to steer a steady course eastwards; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still all was quiet and peaceful. On the third day out from Bree they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the Chetwood. The land had been falling steadily, ever since they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turned aside from the Road, and they now entered a wide flat expanse of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">country, much more difficult to manage. They were far beyond the borders of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Bree-land, out in the pathless wilderness, and drawing near to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Midge- water Marshes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The ground now became damp, and in places boggy and here and there they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came upon pools, and wide stretches of reeds and rushes filled with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warbling of little hidden birds. They had to pick their way carefully to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">keep both dry-footed and on their proper course. At first they made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fan-progress, but as they went on, their passage became slower and more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dangerous. The marshes were bewildering and treacherous, and there was no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">permanent trail even for Rangers to find through their shifting quagmires.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The flies began to torment them, and the air was full of clouds of tiny<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">midges that crept up their sleeves and breeches and into their hair.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am being eaten alive!' cried Pippin. 'Midgewater! There are more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">midges than water!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do they live on when they can't get hobbit?' asked Sam,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scratching his neck.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They spent a miserable day in this lonely and unpleasant country. Their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">camping-place was damp, cold, and uncomfortable; and the biting insects<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would not let them sleep. There were also abominable creatures haunting the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reeds and tussocks that from the sound of them were evil relatives of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cricket. There were thousands of them, and they squeaked all round,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neek-breek, breek-neek, unceasingly all the night, until the hobbits were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearly frantic.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The next day, the fourth, was little better, and the night almost as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comfortless. Though the Neekerbreekers (as Sam called them) had been left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind, the midges still pursued them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Frodo lay, tired but unable to close his eyes, it seemed to him that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far away there came a light in the eastern sky: it flashed and faded many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">times. It was not the dawn, for that was still some hours off.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is the light?' he said to Strider, who had risen, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">standing, gazing ahead into the night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know,' Strider answered. 'It is too distant to make out. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is like lightning that leaps up from the hill-tops.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo lay down again, but for a long while he could still see the white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flashes, and against them the tall dark figure of Strider, standing silent<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and watchful. At last he passed into uneasy sleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had not gone far on the fifth day when they left the last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">straggling pools and reed-beds of the marshes behind them. The land before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them began steadily to rise again. Away in the distance eastward they could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now see a line of hills. The highest of them was at the right of the line<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a little separated from the others. It had a conical top, slightly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flattened at the summit.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is Weathertop,' said Strider. 'The Old Road, which we have left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far away on our right, runs to the south of it and passes not far from its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foot. We might reach it by noon tomorrow, if we go straight towards it. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suppose we had better do so.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What do you mean?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I mean: when we do get there, it is not certain what we shall find. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is close to the Road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But surely we were hoping to find Gandalf there?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes; but the hope is faint. If he comes this way at all, he may not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pass through Bree, and so he may not know what we are doing. And anyway,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unless by luck we arrive almost together, we shall miss one another; it will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not be safe for him or for us to wait there long. If the Riders fail to find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us in the wilderness, they are likely to make for Weathertop themselves. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">commands a wide view all round. Indeed, there are many birds and beasts in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this country that could see us, as we stand here, from that hill-top. Not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the birds are to be trusted, and there are other spies more evil than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they are.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits looked anxiously at the distant hills. Sam looked up into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pale sky, fearing to see hawks or eagles hovering over them with bright<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unfriendly eyes. 'You do make me feel uncomfortable and lonesome, Strider!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you advise us to do?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think,' answered Strider slowly, as if he was not quite sure, 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think the best thing is to go as straight eastward from here as we can, to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make for the line of hills, not for Weathertop. There we can strike a path I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know that runs at their feet; it will bring us to Weathertop from the north<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and less openly. Then we shall see what we shall see.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All that day they plodded along, until the cold and early evening came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down. The land became drier and more barren; but mists and vapours lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind them on the marshes. A few melancholy birds were piping and wailing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until the round red sun sank slowly into the western shadows; then an empty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silence fell. The hobbits thought of the soft light of sunset glancing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the cheerful windows of Bag End far away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the day's end they came to a stream that wandered down from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills to lose itself in the stagnant marshland, and they went up along its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">banks while the light lasted. It was already night when at last they halted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and made their camp under some stunted alder -trees by the shores of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream. Ahead there loomed now against the dusky sky the bleak and treeless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">backs of the hills. That night they set a watch, and Strider, it seemed, did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not sleep at all. The moon was waxing, and in the early night -hours a cold<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey light lay on the land.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Next morning they set out again soon after sunrise. There was a frost<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the air, and the sky was a pale clear blue. The hobbits felt refreshed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as if they had had a night of unbroken sleep. Already they were getting used<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to much walking on short commons - shorter at any rate than what in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire they would have thought barely enough to keep them on their legs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin declared that Frodo was looking twice the hobbit that he had been.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very odd,' said Frodo, tightening his belt, 'considering that there is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">actually a good deal less of me. I hope the thinning process will not go on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indefinitely, or I shall become a wraith.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do not speak of such things!' said Strider quickly, and with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">surprising earnestness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hills drew nearer. They made an undulating ridge, often rising<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost to a thousand feet, and here and there falling again to low clefts or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passes leading into the eastern land beyond. Along the crest of the ridge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hobbits could see what looked to be the remains of green-grown walls and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dikes, and in the clefts there still stood the ruins of old works of stone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By night they had reached the feet of the westward slopes, and there they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">camped. It was the night of the fifth of October, and they were six days out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Bree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the morning they found, for the first time since they had left the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chetwood, a track plain to see. They turned right and followed it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southwards. It ran cunningly, taking a line that seemed chosen so as to keep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as much hidden as possible from the view, both of the hill-tops above and of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the flats to the west. It dived into dells, and hugged steep banks; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where it passed over flatter and more open ground on either side of it there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were lines of large boulders and hewn stones that screened the travellers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost like a hedge.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder who made this path, and what for,' said Merry, as they walked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">along one of these avenues, where the stones were unusually large and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">closely set. 'I am not sure that I like it: it has a - well, rather a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">barrow- wightish look. Is there any barrow on Weathertop?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No. There is no barrow on Weathertop, nor on any of these hills,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">answered Strider. 'The Men of the West did not live here; though in their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">latter days they defended the hills for a while against the evil that came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of Angmar. This path was made to serve the forts along the walls. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long before, in the first days of the North Kingdom, they built a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watch-tower on Weathertop, Amon Syl they called it. It was burned and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broken, and nothing remains of it now but a tumbled ring, like a rough crown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the old hill's head. Yet once it was tall and fair. It is told that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elendil stood there watching for the coming of Gil-galad out of the West, in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the days of the Last Alliance.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits gazed at Strider. It seemed that he was learned in old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lore, as well as in the ways of the wild. 'Who was Gil-galad?' asked Merry;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but Strider did not answer, and seemed to be lost in thought. Suddenly a low<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice murmured:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gil-galad was an Elven-king.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of him the harpers sadly sing:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the last whose realm was fair and free<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between the Mountains and the Sea.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His sword was long, his lance was keen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his shining helm afar was seen;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the countless stars of heaven's field<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were mirrored in his silver shield.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But long ago he rode away,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and where he dwelleth none can say;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for into darkness fell his star<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Mordor where the shadows are.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
