<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others turned in amazement, for the voice was Sam's.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't stop!' said Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That's all I know,' stammered Sam, blushing. 'I learned it from Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo when I was a lad. He used to tell me tales like that, knowing how I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was always one for hearing about Elves. It was Mr. Bilbo as taught me my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letters. He was mighty book -learned was dear old Mr. Bilbo. And he wrote<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">poetry. He wrote what I have just said.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He did not make it up,' said Strider. 'It is pan of the lay that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called The Fall of Gil-galad, which is in an ancient tongue. Bilbo must have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">translated it. I never knew that.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There was a lot more,' said Sam, 'all about Mordor. I didn't learn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that part, it gave me the shivers I never thought I should be going that way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">myself!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Going to Mordor!' cried Pippin. 'I hope it won't come to that!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do not speak that name so loudly!' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was already mid-day when they drew near the southern end of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">path, and saw before them, in the pale clear light of the October sun, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey-green bank, leading up like a bridge on to the northward slope of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill They decided to make for the top at once, while the daylight was broad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Concealment was no longer possible, and they could only hope that no enemy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or spy was observing them. Nothing was to be seen moving on the hill. If<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf was anywhere about, there was no sign of him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the western flank of Weathertop they found a sheltered hollow, at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the bottom of which there was a bowl -shaped dell with grassy sides. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they left Sam and Pippin with the pony and their packs and luggage. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other three went on. After half an hour's plodding climb Strider reached the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crown of the hill; Frodo and Merry followed, tired and breathless. The last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slope had been steep and rocky.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the top they found, as Strider had said, a wide ring of ancient<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stonework, now crumbling or covered with age-long grass. But in the centre a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cairn of broken stones had been piled. They were blackened as if with fire.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">About them the turf was burned to the roots and all within the ring the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass was scorched and shrivelled, as if flames had swept the hill-top; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was no sign of any living thing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Standing upon the rim of the ruined circle, they saw all round below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them a wide prospect, for the most pan of lands empty and featureless,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">except for patches of woodland away to the south, beyond which they caught<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here and there the glint of distant water. Beneath them on this southern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side there ran like a ribbon the Old Road, coming out of the West and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">winding up and down, until it faded behind a ridge of dark land to the east.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nothing was moving on it. Following its line eastward with their eyes they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saw the Mountains: the nearer foothills were brown and sombre;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind them stood taller shapes of grey, and behind those again were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high white peaks glimmering among the clouds.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, here we are!' said Merry. 'And very cheerless and uninviting it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looks! There is no water and no shelter. And no sign of Gandalf. But I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blame him for not waiting - if he ever came here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder,' said Strider, looking round thoughtfully. 'Even if he was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">day or two behind us at Bree, he could have arrived here first. He can ride<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very swiftly when need presses.â€™ Suddenly he stooped and looked at the stone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the top of the cairn; it was flatter than the others, and whiter, as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it had escaped the fire. He picked it up and examined it, turning it in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fingers. "This has been handled recently,' he said. 'What do you think of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these marks?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the flat under-side Frodo saw some scratches: 'There seems to he a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stroke, a dot, and three more strokes,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The stroke on the left might be a G-rune with thin branches,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider. 'It might be a sign left by Gandalf, though one cannot be sure. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scratches are fine, and they certainly look fresh. But the marks might mean<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something quite different, and have nothing to do with us. Rangers use<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">runes, and they come here sometimes.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What could they mean, even if Gandalf made them?' asked Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I should say,' answered Strider, 'that they stood for G3, and were a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sign that Gandalf was here on October the third: that is three days ago now.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It would also show that he was in a hurry and danger was at hand, so that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had no time or did not dare to write anything longer or plainer. If that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">so, we must be wary.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wish we could feel sure that he made the marks, whatever they may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mean,' said Frodo 'It would be a great comfort to know that he was on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way, in front of us or behind us.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Perhaps,' said Strider. 'For myself, I believe that he was here, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was in danger. There have been scorching flames here; and now the light that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we saw three nights ago in the eastern sky comes back to my mind. I guess<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he was attacked on this hill-top, but with what result I cannot tell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He is here no longer, and we must now look after ourselves and make our own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way to Rivendell, as best we can '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How far is Rivendell?' asked Merry, gazing round wearily. The world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked wild and wide from Weathertop.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know if the Road has ever been measured in miles beyond the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Forsaken Inn, a day's journey east of Bree,' answered Strider. 'Some say it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is so far, and some say otherwise. It is a strange road, and folk are glad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to reach their journey's end, whether the time is long or short. But I know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">how long it would take me on my own feet, with fair weather and no ill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fortune twelve days from here to the Ford of Bruinen, where the Road crosses<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Loudwater that runs out of Rivendell. We have at least a fortnight's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey before us, for I do not think we shall be able to use the Road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A fortnight!' said Frodo. 'A lot may happen in that time.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It may,' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They stood for a while silent on the hill -top, near its southward edge.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In that lonely place Frodo for the first time fully realized his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">homelessness and danger. He wished bitterly that his fortune had left him in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the quiet and beloved Shire. He stared down at the hateful Road, leading<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back westward - to his home. Suddenly he was aware that two black specks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were moving slowly along it, going westward; and looking again he saw that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three others were creeping eastward to meet them. He gave a cry and clutched<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider's arm.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look,' he said, pointing downwards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At once Strider flung himself on the ground behind the ruined circle,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pulling Frodo down beside him. Merry threw himself alongside.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is it?' he whispered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know, but I fear the worst,' answered Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slowly they crawled up to the edge of the ring again, and peered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through a cleft between two jagged stones. The light was no longer bright,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the clear morning had faded, and clouds creeping out of the East had now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">overtaken the sun, as it began to go down. They could all see the black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">specks, but neither Frodo nor Merry could make out their shapes for certain;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yet something told them that there, far below, were Black Riders assembling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the Road beyond the foot of the hill.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Strider, whose keener sight left him in no doubt. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enemy is here!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hastily they crept away and slipped down the north side of the hill to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find their companions.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam and Peregrin had not been idle. They had explored the small dell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the surrounding slopes. Not far away they found a spring of clear water<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the hillside, and near it footprints not more than a day or two old. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dell itself they found recent traces of a fire, and other signs of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hasty camp. There were some fallen rocks on the edge of the dell nearest to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hill. Behind them Sam came upon a small store of firewood neatly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stacked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder if old Gandalf has been here,' he said to Pippin. 'Whoever it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was put this stuff here meant to come back it seems.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider was greatly interested in these discoveries. 'I wish I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waited and explored the ground down here myself,' he said, hurrying off to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the spring to examine the footprints.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is just as I feared,' he said, when he came back. 'Sam and Pippin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have trampled the soft ground, and the marks are spoilt or confused. Rangers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have been here lately. It is they who left the firewood behind. But there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are also several newer tracks that were not made by Rangers. At least one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set was made, only a day or two ago, by heavy boots. At least one. I cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now be certain, but I think there were many booted feet.' He paused and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stood in anxious thought.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Each of the hobbits saw in his mind a vision of the cloaked and booted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders. If the horsemen had already found the dell, the sooner Strider led<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them somewhere else the better. Sam viewed the hollow with great dislike,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now that he had heard news of their enemies on the Road, only a few miles<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hadn't we better clear out quick, Mr. Strider?' he asked impatiently.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is getting late, and I don't like this hole: it makes my heart sink<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">somehow.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, we certainly must decide what to do at once,' answered Strider,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking up and considering the time and the weather. 'Well, Sam,' he said at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last, 'I do not like this place either; but I cannot think of anywhere<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">better that we could reach before nightfall. At least we are out of sight<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the moment, and if we moved we should be much more likely to be seen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spies. All we could do would be to go right out of our way back north on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this side of the line of hills, where the land is all much the same as it is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here. The Road is watched, but we should have to cross it, if we tried to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take cover in the thickets away to the south. On the north side of the Road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond the hills the country is bare and flat for miles.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Can the Riders see ?' asked Merry. 'I mean, they seem usually to have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used their noses rather than their eyes, smelling for us, if smelling is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right word, at least in the daylight. But you made us lie down flat when you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saw them down below; and now you talk of being seen, if we move.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I was too careless on the hill-top,' answered Strider. 'I was very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anxious to find some sign of Gandalf; but it was a mistake for three of us<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to go up and stand there so long. For the black horses can see, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders can use men and other creatures as spies, as we found at Bree. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves do not see the world of light as we do, but our shapes cast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadows in their minds, which only the noon sun destroys; and in the dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they perceive many signs and forms that are hidden from us: then they are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">most to be feared. And at all times they smell the blood of living things,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desiring and hating it. Senses, too, there are other than sight or smell. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can feel their presence - it troubled our hearts, as soon as we came here,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and before we saw them; they feel ours more keenly. Also,' he added, and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice sank to a whisper, 'the Ring draws them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Is there no escape then?' said Frodo, looking round wildly. 'If I move<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I shall be seen and hunted! If I stay, I shall draw them to me!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider laid his hand on his shoulder. 'There is still hope,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are not alone. Let us take this wood that is set ready for the fire as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a sign. There is little shelter or defence here, but fire shall serve for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">both. Sauron can put fire to his evil uses, as he can all things, but these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders do not love it, and fear those who wield it. Fire is our friend in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the wilderness.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe,' muttered Sam. 'It is also as good a way of saying "here we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are" as I can think of, bar shouting.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Down in the lowest and most sheltered corner of the dell they lit a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fire, and prepared a meal. The shades of evening began to fall, and it grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold. They were suddenly aware of great hunger, for they had not eaten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything since breakfast; but they dared not make more than a frugal supper.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The lands ahead were empty of all save birds and beasts, unfriendly places<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deserted by all the races of the world. Rangers passed at times beyond the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills, but they were few and did not stay. Other wanderers were rare, and of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil sort: trolls might stray down at times out of the northern valleys of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Misty Mountains. Only on the Road would travellers be found, most often<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarves, hurrying along on business of their own, and with no help and few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">words to spare for strangers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't see how our food can be made to last,' said Frodo. 'We have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been careful enough in the last few days, and this supper is no feast; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we have used more than we ought, if we have two weeks still to go, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps more.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is food in the wild,' said Strider; 'berry, root, and herb; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I have some skill as a hunter at need. You need not be afraid of starving<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before winter comes. But gathering and catching food is long and weary work,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and we need haste. So tighten your belts, and think with hope of the tables<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Elrond's house!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The cold increased as darkness came on. Peering out from the edge of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dell they could see nothing but a grey land now vanishing quickly into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow. The sky above had cleared again and was slowly filled with twinkling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stars. Frodo and his companions huddled round the fire, wrapped in every<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">garment and blanket they possessed; but Strider was content with a single<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloak, and sat a little apart, drawing thoughtfully at his pipe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As night fell and the light of the fire began to shine out brightly he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to tell them tales to keep their minds from fear. He knew many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">histories and legends of long ago, of Elves and Men and the good and evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deeds of the Elder Days. They wondered how old he was, and where he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">learned all this lore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tell us of Gil-galad,â€™ said Merry suddenly, when he paused at the end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of a story of the Elf-Kingdoms. 'Do you know any more of that old lay that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you spoke of?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do indeed,' answered Strider. 'So also does Frodo, for it concerns<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam and Merry got up and walked away from the fire. Frodo and Pippin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remained seated in silence. Strider was watching the moonlight on the hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">intently. All seemed quiet and still, but Frodo felt a cold dread creeping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over his heart, now that Strider was no longer speaking. He huddled closer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the fire. At that moment Sam came running back from the edge of the dell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know what it is,' he said, 'but I suddenly felt afraid. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">durstn't go outside this dell for any money; I felt that something was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creeping up the slope.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Did you see anything?' asked Frodo, springing to his feet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, sir. I saw nothing, but I didn't stop to look.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I saw something,' said Merry; 'or I thought I did - away westwards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the moonlight was falling on the flats beyond the shadow of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill-tops, I thought there were two or three black shapes. They seemed to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moving this way.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Keep close to the fire, with your faces outward!' cried Strider. 'Get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some of the longer sticks ready in your hands!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For a breathless time they sat there, silent and alert, with their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">backs turned to the wood-fire, each gazing into the shadows that encircled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. Nothing happened. There was no sound or movement in the night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stirred, feeling that he must break the silence: he longed to shout out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aloud.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hush!' whispered Strider. 'What's that?' gasped Pippin at the same<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moment.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Over the lip of the little dell, on the side away from the hill, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt, rather than saw, a shadow rise, one shadow or more than one. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strained their eyes, and the shadows seemed to grow. Soon there could be no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubt:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three or four tall black figures were standing there on the slope,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking down on them. So black were they that they seemed like black holes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the deep shade behind them. Frodo thought that he heard a faint hiss as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of venomous breath and felt a thin piercing chill. Then the shapes slowly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">advanced.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Terror overcame Pippin and Merry, and they threw themselves flat on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground. Sam shrank to Frodo's side. Frodo was hardly less terrified than his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companions; he was quaking as if he was bitter cold, but his terror was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swallowed up in a sudden temptation to put on the Ring. The desire to do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this laid hold of him, and he could think of nothing else. Fie did not forget<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Barrow, nor the message of Gandalf; but something seemed to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">compelling him to disregard all warnings, and he longed to yield. Not with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hope of escape, or of doing anything, either good or bad: he simply felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he must take the Ring and put it on his finger. Fie could not speak. Fie<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt Sam looking at him, as if he knew that his master was in some great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trouble, but he could not turn towards him. He shut his eyes and struggled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for a while; but resistance became unbearable, and at last he slowly drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out the chain, and slipped the Ring on the forefinger of his left hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Immediately, though everything else remained as before, dim and dark,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the shapes became terribly clear. He was able to see beneath their black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wrappings. There were five tall figures: two standing on the lip of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dell, three advancing. In their white faces burned keen and merciless eyes;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under their mantles were long grey robes; upon their grey hairs were helms<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of silver; in their haggard hands were swords of steel. Their eyes fell on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him and pierced him, as they rushed towards him. Desperate, he drew his own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sword, and it seemed to him that it flickered red, as if it was a firebrand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Two of the figures halted. The third was taller than the others: his hair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was long and gleaming and on his helm was a crown. In one hand he held a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long sword, and in the other a knife; both the knife and the hand that held<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it glowed with a pale light. He sprang forward and bore down on Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment Frodo threw himself forward on the ground, and he heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself crying aloud: O Elbereth! Gilthoniel! At the same time he struck at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the feet of his enemy. A shrill cry rang out in the night; and he felt a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pain like a dart of poisoned ice pierce his left shoulder. Even as he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swooned he caught, as through a swirling mist, a glimpse of Strider leaping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the darkness with a flaming brand of wood in either hand. With a last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">effort Frodo, dropping his sword, slipped the Ring from his finger and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">closed his right hand tight upon it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 12 . Flight to the Ford<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When Frodo came to himself he was still clutching the Ring desperately.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He was lying by the fire, which was now piled high and burning brightly. His<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">three companions were bending over him. 'What has happened? Where is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale king?' he asked wildly. They were too overjoyed to hear him speak to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">answer for a while; nor did they understand his question. At length he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gathered from Sam that they had seen nothing but the vague shadowy shapes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming towards them. Suddenly to his horror Sam found that his master had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished; and at that moment a black shadow rushed past him, and he fell. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard Frodoâ€™s voice, but it seemed to come from a great distance, or from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the earth, crying out strange words. They saw nothing more, until they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stumbled over the body of Frodo, lying as if dead, face downwards on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass with his sword beneath him. Strider ordered them to pick him up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lay him near the fire, and then he disappeared. That was now a good while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ago.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam plainly was beginning to have doubts again about Strider; but while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were talking he returned, appearing suddenly out of the shadows. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">started, and Sam drew his sword and stood over Frodo; but Strider knelt down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swiftly at his side.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am not a Black Rider, Sam,' he said gently, 'nor in league with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them. I have been trying to discover something of their movements; but I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have found nothing. I cannot think why they have gone and do not attack<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. But there is no feeling of their presence anywhere at hand.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he heard what Frodo had to tell, he became full of concern, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shook his head and sighed. Then he ordered Pippin and Merry to heat as much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water as they could in their small kettles, and to bathe the wound with it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Keep the fire going well, and keep Frodo warm!' he said. Then he got up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walked away, and called Sam to him. 'I think I understand things better<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now,' he said in a low voice. 'There seem only to have been five of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enemy. Why they were not all here, I don't know; but I don't think they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expected to be resisted. They have drawn off for the time being. But not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far, I fear. They will come again another night, if we cannot escape. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are only waiting, because they think that their purpose is almost<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">accomplished, and that the Ring cannot fly much further. I fear, Sam, that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they believe your master has a deadly wound that will subdue him to their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will. We shall see!' Sam choked with tears. 'Don't despair!' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You must trust me now. Your Frodo is made of sterner stuff than I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed, though Gandalf hinted that it might prove so. He is not slain, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I think he will resist the evil power of the wound longer than his enemies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expect. I will do all I can to help and heal him. Guard him well, while I am<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away!' He hurried off and disappeared again into the darkness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo dozed, though the pain of his wound was slowly growing, and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deadly chill was spreading from his shoulder to his arm and side. His<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends watched over him, warming him, and bathing his wound. The night<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed slowly and wearily. Dawn was growing in the sky, and the dell was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">filling with grey light, when Strider at last returned.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look!' he cried; and stooping he lifted from the ground a black cloak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that had lain there hidden by the darkness. A foot above the lower hem there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a slash. 'This was the stroke of Frodo's sword,' he said. 'The only hurt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that it did to his enemy, I fear; for it is unharmed, but all blades perish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that pierce that dreadful King. More deadly to him was the name of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elbereth.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And more deadly to Frodo was this!' He stooped again and lifted up a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long thin knife. There was a cold gleam in it. As Strider raised it they saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that near the end its edge was notched and the point was broken off. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even as he held it up in the growing light, they gazed in astonishment, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the blade seemed to melt, and vanished like a smoke in the air, leaving only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hilt in Strider's hand. 'Alas!' he cried. 'It was this accursed knife<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that gave the wound. Few now have the skill in healing to match such evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weapons. But I will do what I can.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He sat down on the ground, and taking the dagger -hilt laid it on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knees, and he sang over it a slow song in a strange tongue. Then setting it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside, he turned to Frodo and in a soft tone spoke words the others could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not catch. From the pouch at his belt he drew out the long leaves of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">plant.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'These leaves,' he said, 'I have walked far to find; for this plant<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">does not grow in the bare hills; but in the thickets away south of the Road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I found it in the dark by the scent of its leaves.' He crushed a leaf in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fingers, and it gave out a sweet and pungent fragrance. 'It is fortunate<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I could find it, for it is a healing plant that the Men of the West<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brought to Middle-earth. Athelas they named it, and it grows now sparsely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and only near places where they dwelt or camped of old; and it is not known<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the North, except to some of those who wander in the Wild. It has great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">virtues, but over such a wound as this its healing powers may be small.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He threw the leaves into boiling water and bathed Frodo's shoulder. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fragrance of the steam was refreshing, and those that were unhurt felt their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">minds calmed and cleared. The herb had also some power over the wound, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo felt the pain and also the sense of frozen cold lessen in his side;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the life did not return to his arm, and he could not raise or use his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hand. He bitterly regretted his foolishness, and reproached himself for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weakness of will; for he now perceived that in putting on the Ring he obeyed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not his own desire but the commanding wish of his enemies. He wondered if he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would remain maimed for life, and how they would now manage to continue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their journey. He fell too weak to stand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others were discussing this very question. They quickly decided to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leave Weathertop as soon as possible. 'I think now,' said Strider, 'that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enemy has been watching this place for some days. If Gandalf ever came here,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then he must have been forced to ride away, and he will not return. In any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">case we are in great peril here after dark, since the attack of last night,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and we can hardly meet greater danger wherever we go.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as the daylight was full, they had some hurried food and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">packed. It was impossible for Frodo to walk, so they divided the greater<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">part of their baggage among the four of them, and put Frodo on the pony. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the last few days the poor beast had improved wonderfully; it already seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fatter and stronger, and had begun to show an affection for its new masters,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">especially for Sam. Bill Ferny's treatment must have been very hard for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey in the wild to seem so much better than its former life.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They started off in a southerly direction. This would mean crossing the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Road, but. it was the quickest way to more wooded country. And they needed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fuel; for Strider said that Frodo must be kept warm, especially at night,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while fire would be some protection for them all. It was also his plan to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shorten their journey by cutting across another great loop of the Road: east<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond Weathertop it changed its course and took a wide bend northwards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They made their way slowly and cautiously round the south-western<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slopes of the hill, and came in a little while to the edge of the Road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was no sign of the Riders. But even as they were hurrying across they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard far away two cries: a cold voice calling and a cold voice answering.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Trembling they sprang forward, and made for the thickets that lay ahead. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land before them sloped away southwards, but it was wild and pathless;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bushes and stunted trees grew in dense patches with wide barren spaces in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between. The grass was scanty, coarse, and grey; and the leaves in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thickets were faded and falling. It was a cheerless land, and their journey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was slow and gloomy. They spoke little as they trudged along. Frodo's heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was grieved as he watched them walking beside him with their heads down,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their backs bowed under their burdens. Even Strider seemed tired and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heavy-hearted.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before the first day's march was over Frodo's pain began to grow again,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but he did not speak of it for a long time. Four days passed, without the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground or the scene changing much, except that behind them Weathertop<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slowly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sank, and before them the distant mountains loomed a little nearer. Yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since that far cry they had seen and heard no sign that the enemy had marked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their flight or followed them. They dreaded the dark hours, and kept watch<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in pairs by night, expecting at any time to see black shapes stalking in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey night, dimly lit by the cloud- veiled moon; but they saw nothing, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard no sound but the sigh of withered leaves and grass. Not once did they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feel the sense of present evil that had assailed them before the attack in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dell. It seemed too much to hope that the Riders had already lost their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trail again. Perhaps they were waiting to make some ambush in a narrow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">place?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the end of the fifth day the ground began once more to rise slowly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of the wide shallow valley into which they had descended. Strider now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turned their course again north-eastwards, and on the sixth day they reached<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the top of a long slow-climbing slope, and saw far ahead a huddle of wooded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills. Away below them they could see the Road sweeping round the feet of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hills; and to their right a grey river gleamed pale in the thin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sunshine. In the distance they glimpsed yet another river in a stony valley<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">half-veiled in mist.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"I am afraid we must go back to the Road here for a while,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider. 'We have now come to the River Hoarwell, that the Elves call<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mitheithel. It flows down out of the Ettenmoors, the troll-fells north of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell, and joins the Loud water away in the South. Some call it the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Greyflood after that. It is a great water before it finds the Sea. There is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no way over it below its sources in the Ettenmoors, except by the Last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bridge on which the Road crosses.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What is that other river we can see far away there?' asked Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is Loudwater, the Bruinen of Rivendell,' answered Strider. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Road runs along the edge of the hills for many miles from the Bridge to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ford of Bruinen. But I have not yet thought how we shall cross that water.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One river at a time! We shall be fortunate indeed if we do not find the Last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bridge held against us.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Next day, early in the morning, they came down again to the borders of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Road. Sam and Strider went forward, but they found no sign of any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">travellers or riders. Here under the shadow of the hills there had been some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rain. Strider judged that it had fallen two days before, and had washed away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all footprints. No horseman had passed since then, as far as he could see.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They hurried along with all the speed they could make, and after a mile<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or two they saw the Last Bridge ahead, at the bottom of a short steep slope.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They dreaded to see black figures waiting there, but they saw none. Strider<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made them take cover in a thicket at the side of the Road, while he went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward to explore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before long he came hurrying back. 'I can see no sign of the enemy,' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said, 'and I wonder very much what that means. But I have found something<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very strange.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He held out his hand, and showed a single pale-green jewel. 'I found it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the mud in the middle of the Bridge,' he said. 'It is a beryl, an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">elf-stone. Whether it was set there, or let fall by chance, I cannot say;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but it brings hope to me. I will take it as a sign that we may pass the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bridge; but beyond that I dare not keep to the Road, without some clearer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">token.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At once they went on again. They crossed the Bridge in safety, hearing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no sound but the water swirling against its three great arches. A mile<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">further on they came to a narrow ravine that led away northwards through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steep lands on the left of the Road. Here Strider turned aside, and soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were lost in a sombre country of dark trees winding among the feet of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sullen hills.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits were glad to leave the cheerless lands and the perilous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Road behind them; but this new country seemed threatening and unfriendly. As<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they went forward the hills about them steadily rose. Here and there upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heights and ridges they caught glimpses of ancient walls of stone, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ruins of towers: they had an ominous look. Frodo, who was not walking, had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time to gaze ahead and to think. He recalled Bilbo's account of his journey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the threatening towers on the hills north of the Road, in the country<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near the Troll's wood where his first serious adventure had happened. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessed that they were now in the same region, and wondered if by chance<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they would pass near the spot.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who lives in this land?' he asked. 'And who built these towers? Is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this troll-country?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No!' said Strider. 'Trolls do not build. No one lives in this land.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Men once dwelt here, ages ago; but none remain now. They became an evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">people, as legends tell, for they fell under the shadow of Angmar. But all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were destroyed in the war that brought the North Kingdom to its end. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is now so long ago that the hills have forgotten them, though a shadow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still lies on the land.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where did you learn such tales, if all the land is empty and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgetful?' asked Peregrin. 'The birds and beasts do not tell tales of that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">son.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The heirs of Elendil do not forget all things past,' said Strider;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
