<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and many more things than I can tell are remembered in Rivendell.' 'Have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you often been to Rivendell?' said Frodo. 'I have,' said Strider. 'I dwelt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there once, and still I return when I may.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There my heart is; but it is not my fate to sit in peace, even in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fair house of Elrond.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hills now began to shut them in. The Road behind held on its way to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the River Bruinen, but both were now hidden from view. The travellers came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into a long valley; narrow, deeply cloven, dark and silent. Trees with old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and twisted roots hung over cliffs, and piled up behind into mounting slopes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of pine-wood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits grew very weary. They advanced slowly, for they had to pick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their way through a pathless country, encumbered by fallen trees and tumbled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rocks. As long as they could they avoided climbing for Frodo's sake, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">because it was in fact difficult to find any way up out of the narrow dales.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had been two days in this country when the weather turned wet. The wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to blow steadily out of the West and pour the water of the distant<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seas on the dark heads of the hills in fine drenching rain. By nightfall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were all soaked, and their camp was cheerless, for they could not get<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any fire to burn. The next day the hills rose still higher and steeper<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before them, and they were forced to turn away northwards out of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course. Strider seemed to be getting anxious: they were nearly ten days out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Weathertop, and their stock of provisions was beginning to run low. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went on raining.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That night they camped on a stony shelf with a rock -wall behind them,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in which there was a shallow cave, a mere scoop in the cliff. Frodo was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">restless. The cold and wet had made his wound more painful than ever, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ache and sense of deadly chill took away all sleep. He lay tossing and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turning and listening fearfully to the stealthy night-noises: wind in chinks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of rock, water dripping, a crack, the sudden rattling fall of a loosened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stone. He felt that black shapes were advancing to smother him; but when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sat up he saw nothing but the back of Strider sitting hunched up, smoking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his pipe, and watching. He lay down again and passed into an uneasy dream,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in which he walked on the grass in his garden in the Shire, but it seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">faint and dim, less clear than the tall black shadows that stood looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over the hedge.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the morning he woke to find that the rain had stopped. The clouds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were still thick, but they were breaking, and pale strips of blue appeared<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between them. The wind was shifting again. They did not start early.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Immediately after their cold and comfortless breakfast Strider went off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone, telling the others to remain under the shelter of the cliff, until he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came back. He was going to climb up, if he could, and get a look at the lie<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the land.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he returned he was not reassuring. 'We have come too far to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">north,' he said, 'and we must find some way to turn back southwards again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">If we keep on as we are going we shall get up into the Ettendales far north<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Rivendell. That is troll-country, and little known to me. We could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perhaps find our way through and come round to Rivendell from the north; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it would take too long, for I do not know the way, and our food would not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last. So somehow or other we must find the Ford of Bruinen.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The rest of that day they spent scrambling over rocky ground. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found a passage between two hills that led them into a valley running<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">south-east, the direction that they wished to take; but towards the end of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the day they found their road again barred by a ridge of high land; its dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">edge against the sky was broken into many bare points like teeth of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blunted saw. They had a choice between going back or climbing over it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They decided to attempt the climb, but it proved very difficult. Before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long Frodo was obliged to dismount and struggle along on foot. Even so they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">often despaired of getting their pony up, or indeed of finding a path for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves, burdened as they were. The light was nearly gone, and they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all exhausted, when at last they reached the top. They had climbed on to a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">narrow saddle between two higher points, and the land fell steeply away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again, only a short distance ahead. Frodo threw himself down, and lay on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground shivering. His left arm was lifeless, and his side and shoulder felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as if icy claws were laid upon them. The trees and rocks about him seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadowy and dim.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We cannot go any further,' said Merry to Strider. 'I am afraid this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has been too much for Frodo. I am dreadfully anxious about him. What are we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to do? Do you think they will be able to cure him in Ri vendell, if we ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get there?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We shall see,' answered Strider. 'There is nothing more that I can do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the wilderness; and it is chiefly because of his wound that I am so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anxious to press on. But I agree that we can go no further tonight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is the matter with my master?' asked Sam in a low voice, looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appealingly at Strider. 'His wound was small, and it is already closed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There's nothing to be seen but a cold white mark on his shoulder.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Frodo has been touched by the weapons of the Enemy,' said Strider,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and there is some poison or evil at work that is beyond my skill to drive<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out. But do not give up hope, Sam!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Night was cold up on the high ridge. They lit a small fire down under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the gnarled roots of an old pine, that hung over a shallow pit: it looked as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if stone had once been quarried there. They sat huddled together. The wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blew chill through the pass, and they heard the tree-tops lower down moaning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sighing. Frodo lay half in a dream, imagining that endless dark wings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were sweeping by above him, and that on the wings rode pursuers that sought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him in all the hollows of the hill s.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The morning dawned bright and fair; the air was clean, and the light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale and clear in a rain- washed sky. Their hearts were encouraged, but (hey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longed for the sun to warm their cold stiff limbs. As soon as it was light,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider took Merry with him and went to survey the country from the height<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the east of the pass. The sun had risen and was shining brightly when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">returned with more comforting news. They were now going more or less in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right direction. If they went on, down the further side of the ridge, they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would have the Mountains on their left. Some way ahead Strider had caught a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glimpse of the Loudwater again, and he knew that, though it was hidden from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">view, the Road to the Ford was not far from the River and lay on the side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearest to them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We must make for the Road again,' he said. 'We cannot hope to find a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">path through these hills. Whatever danger may beset it, the Road is our only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way to the Ford.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as they had eaten they set out again. They climbed slowly down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the southern side of the ridge; but the way was much easier than they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expected, for the slope was far less steep on this side, and before long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was able to ride again. Bill Ferny's poor old pony was developing an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpected talent for picking out a path, and for sparing its rider as many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jolts as possible. The spirits of the party rose again. Even Frodo felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">better in the morning light, but every now and again a mist seemed to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">obscure his sight, and he passed his hands over his eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pippin was a little ahead of the others. Suddenly he turned round and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called to them. 'There is a path here!' he cried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they came up with him, they saw that he had made no mistake:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were clearly the beginnings of a path, that climbed with many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">windings out of the woods below and faded away on the hill-top behind. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places it was now faint and overgrown, or choked with fallen stones and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees; but at one time it seemed to have been much used. It was a path made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by strong arms and heavy feet. Here and there old trees had been cut or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broken down, and large rocks cloven or heaved aside to make a way.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They followed the track for some while, for it offered much the easiest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">way down, but they went cautiously, and their anxiety increased as they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the dark woods, and the path grew plainer and broader. Suddenly coming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out of a belt of fir-trees it ran steeply down a slope, and turned sharply<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the left round the comer of a rocky shoulder of the hill. When they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the comer they looked round and saw that the path ran on over a level<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strip under the face of a low cliff overhung with trees. In the stony wall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was a door hanging crookedly ajar upon one great hinge.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Outside the door they all halted. There was a cave or rock-chamber<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind, but in the gloom inside nothing could be seen. Strider, Sam, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry pushing with all their strength managed to open the door a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wider, and then Strider and Merry went in. They did not go far, for on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">floor lay many old bones, and nothing else was to be seen near the entrance<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">except some great empty jars and broken pots.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Surely this is a troll-hole, if ever there was one!' said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Come out, you two, and let us get away. Now we know who made the path -<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we had better get off it quick.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is no need, I think,' said Strider, coining out. 'It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">certainly a troll-hole, but it seems to have been long forsaken. I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think we need be afraid. But let us go on down warily, and we shall see.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The path went on again from the door, and turning to the right again<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">across the level space plunged down a thick wooded slope. Pippin, not liking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to show Strider that he was still afraid, went on ahead with Merry. Sam and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider came behind, one on each side of Frodo's pony, for the path was now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broad enough for four or five hobbits to walk abreast. But they had not gone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very far before Pippin came running back, followed by Merry. They both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked terrified.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are trolls!' Pippin panted. 'Down in a clearing in the woods not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far below. We got a sight of them through the tree-trunks. They are very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">large!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We will come and look at them,' said Strider, picking up a stick.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo said nothing, but Sam looked scared.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun was now high, and it shone down through the half-stripped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches of the trees, and lit the clearing with bright patches of light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They halted suddenly on the edge, and peered through the tree-trunks,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">holding their breath. There stood the trolls: three large trolls. One was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stooping, and the other two stood staring at him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider walked forward unconcernedly. 'Get up, old stone!' he said, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broke his stick upon the stooping troll.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nothing happened. There was a gasp of astonishment from the hobbits,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then even Frodo laughed. 'Well!' he said. 'We are forgetting our family<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">history! These must be the very three that were caught by Gandalf,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quarrelling over the right way to cook thirteen dwarves and one hobbit.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I had no idea we were anywhere near the place!' said Pippin. He knew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the story well. Bilbo and Frodo had told it often; but as a matter of fact<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had never more than half believed it. Even now he looked at the stone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trolls with suspicion, wondering if some magic might not suddenly bring them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to life again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are forgetting not only your family history, but all you ever knew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about trolls,' said Strider. 'It is broad daylight with a bright sun, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yet you come back trying to scare me with a tale of live trolls waiting for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us in this glade! In any case you might have noticed that one of them has an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old bird's nest behind his ear. That would be a most unusual ornament for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">live troll!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They all laughed. Frodo felt his spirits reviving: the reminder of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo's first successful adventure was heartening. The sun, too, was warm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and comforting, and the mist before his eyes seemed to be lifting a little.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They rested for some time in the glade, and took their mid-day meal right<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the shadow of the trolls' large legs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Won't somebody give us a bit of a song, while the sun is high?' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry, when they had finished. 'We haven't had a song or a tale for days.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not since Weathertop,' said Frodo. The others looked at him. 'Don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worry about me!' he added. 'I feel much better, but I don't think I could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sing. Perhaps Sam could dig something out of his memory.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come on, Sam!' said Merry. 'There's more stored in your head than you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">let on about.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know about that,' said Sam. 'But how would this suit? It ain't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what I call proper poetry, if you understand me: just a bit of nonsense. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these old images here brought it to my mind.' Standing up, with his hands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind his back, as if he was at school, he began to sing to an old tune.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Troll sat alone on his seat of stone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And munched and mumbled a bare old bone;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For many a year he had gnawed it near,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For meat was hard to come by.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Done by! Gum by!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In a case in the hills he dwelt alone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And meat was hard to come by.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Up came Tom with his big boots on.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Said he to Troll: 'Pray, what is yon?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For it looks like the shin o' my nuncle Tim,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As should be a-lyin ' in graveyard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Caveyard! Paveyard!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This many a year has Tim been gone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And I thought he were lyin ' in graveyard. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My lad, ' said Troll, 'this bone I stole.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But what be bones that lie in a hole?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Thy nuncle was dead as a lump o' lead,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Afore I found his shinbone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tinbone! Thinbone!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He can spare a share for a poor old troll,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For he don't need his shinbone. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Said Tom: 7 don't see why the likes o' thee<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Without axin ' leave should go makin 'free<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With the shank or the shin o' my father's kin;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So hand the old bone over!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rover! Trover!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though dead he be, it belongs to he;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So hand the old bone over!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'For a couple o' pins,' says Troll, and grins,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I'll eat thee too, and gnaw thy shins.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A bit o' fresh meal will go down sweet!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I'll try my teeth on thee now.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hee now! See now!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I'm tired o' gnawing old bones and skins;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I've a mind to dine on thee now. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But just as he thought his dinner was caught,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He found his hands had hold of naught.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before he could mind, Tom slipped behind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And gave him the boot to lam him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Warn him! Darn him!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A bump o' the boot on the seat, Tom thought,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Would be the way to lam him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But harder than stone is the flesh and bone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of a troll that sits in the hills alone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As well set your boot to the mountain's root,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For the seat of a troll don 't feel it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Peel it! Heal it!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Old Troll laughed, when he heard Tom groan,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And he knew his toes could feel it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tom's leg is game, since home he came,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And his bootless foot is lasting lame;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But Troll don't care, and he's still there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With the bone he boned from its owner.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Doner! Boner!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Troll's old seat is still the same,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And the bone he boned from its owner!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, that's a warning to us all!' laughed Merry. 'It is as well you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">used a stick, and not your hand, Strider!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where did you come by that, Sam?' asked Pippin. 'I've never heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those words before.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam muttered something inaudible. 'It's out of his own head, of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course,' said Frodo. 'I am learning a lot about Sam Gamgee on this journey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">First he was a conspirator, now he's a jester. He'll end up by becoming a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard - or a warrior!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope not,' said Sam. 'I don't want to be neither!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the afternoon they went on down the woods. They were probably<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">following the very track that Gandalf, Bilbo, and the dwarves had used many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years before. After a few miles they came out on the top of a high bank<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">above the Road. At this point the Road had left the Hoarwell far behind in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its narrow valley, and now clung close to the feet of the hills, rolling and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">winding eastward among woods and heather -covered slopes towards the Ford<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Mountains. Not far down the bank Strider pointed out a stone in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grass. On it roughly cut and now much weathered could still be seen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf-runes and secret marks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There!' said Merry. 'That must be the stone that marked the place<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the trolls' gold was hidden. How much is left of Bilbo's share, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonder, Frodo?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked at the stone, and wished that Bilbo had brought home no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treasure more perilous, nor less easy to pan with. 'None at all,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bilbo gave it all away. He told me he did not feel it was really his, as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came from robbers.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Road lay quiet under the long shadows of early evening. There was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no sign of any other travellers to be seen. As there was now no other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">possible course for them to take, they climbed down the bank, and turning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left went off as fast as they could. Soon a shoulder of the hills cut off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the light of the fast westering sun. A cold wind flowed down to meet them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the mountains ahead.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They were beginning to look out for a place off the Road, where they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could camp for the night, when they heard a sound that brought sudden fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back into their hearts: the noise of hoofs behind them. They looked back,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but they could not see far because of the many windings and rollings of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Road. As quickly as they could they scrambled off the beaten way and up into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the deep heather and bilberry brushwood on the slopes above, until they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to a small patch of thick-growing hazels. As they peered out from among the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bushes, they could see the Road, faint and grey in the failing light, some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thirty feel below them. The sound of hoofs drew nearer. They were going<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fast, with a light clippety-clippely-clip. Then faintly, as if it was blown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away from them by the breeze, they seemed to catch a dim ringing, as of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small bells tinkling.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That does not sound like a Black Rider's horse!' said Frodo, listening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">intently. The other hobbits agreed hopefully that it did not, but they all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remained full of suspicion. They had been in fear of pursuit for so long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that any sound from behind seemed ominous and unfriendly. But Strider was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now leaning forward, stooped to the ground, with a hand to his ear, and a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look of joy on his face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The light faded, and the leaves on the bushes rustled softly. Clearer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and nearer now the bells jingled, and clippety-clip came the quick trotting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feet. Suddenly into view below came a white horse, gleaming in the shadows,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">running swiftly. In the dusk its headstall flickered and flashed, as if it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were studded with gems like living stars. The rider's cloak streamed behind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, and his hood was thrown back; his golden hair flowed shimmering in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind of his speed. To Frodo it appeared that a white light was shining<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the form and raiment of the rider, as if through a thin veil.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider sprang from hiding and dashed down towards the Road, leaping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a cry through the heather; but even before he had moved or called, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rider had reined in his horse and halted, looking up towards the thicket<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where they stood. When he saw Strider, he dismounted and ran to meet him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">calling out: Ai na vedui DÂ®nadan! Mae govannen! His speech and clear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ringing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice left no doubt in their hearts: the rider was of the Elven-folk. No<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">others that dwelt in the wide world had voices so fair to hear. But there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to be a note of haste or fear in his call, and they saw that he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now speaking quickly and urgently to Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Soon Strider beckoned to them, and the hobbits left the bushes and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hurried down to the Road. 'This is Glorfindel, who dwells in the house of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond,' said Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hail, and well met at last!' said the Elf-lord to Frodo. 'I was sent<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Rivendell to look for you. We feared that you were in danger upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then Gandalf has reached Rivendell?' cried Frodo joyfully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No. He had not when I departed; but that was nine days ago,' answered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel. 'Elrond received news that troubled him. Some of my kindred,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journeying in your land beyond the Baranduin,* learned that things were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">amiss, and sent messages as swiftly as they could. They said that the Nine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were abroad, and that you were astray bearing a great burden without<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guidance, for Gandalf had not returned. There are few even in Rivendell that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can ride openly against the Nine; but such as there were, Elrond sent out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">north, west, and south. It was thought that you might turn far aside to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">avoid pursuit, and become lost in the Wilderness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was my lot to take the Road, and I came to the Bridge of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mitheithel, and left a token there, nigh on seven days ago. Three of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">servants of Sauron were upon the Bridge, but they withdrew and I pursued<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them westward. I came also upon two others, but they turned away southward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Since then I have searched for your trail. Two days ago I found it, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed it over the Bridge; and today I marked where you descended from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills again. But come! There is no time for further news. Since you are here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we must risk the peril of the Road and go. There are five behind us, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when they find your trail upon the Road they will ride after us like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind. And they are not all. Where the other four may be, I do not know. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fear that we may find the Ford is already held against us.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While Glorfindel was speaking the shades of evening deepened. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt a great weariness come over him. Ever since the sun began to sink the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mist before his eyes had darkened, and he felt that a shadow was coming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between him and the faces of his friends. Now pain assailed him, and he felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold. He swayed, clutching at Sam's arm.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My master is sick and wounded,' said Sam angrily. 'He can't go on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">riding after nightfall. He needs rest.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel caught Frodo as he sank to the ground, and taking him gently<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in his arms he looked in his face with grave anxiety.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Briefly Strider told of the attack on their camp under Weathertop, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the deadly knife. He drew out the hilt, which he had kept, and handed it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Elf. Glorfindel shuddered as he took it, but he looked intently at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are evil things written on this hilt,' he said; 'though maybe<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your eyes cannot see them. Keep it, Aragorn, till we reach the house of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond! But be wary, and handle it as little as you may! Alas! the wounds of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this weapon are beyond my skill to heal. I will do what I can - but all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more do I urge you now to go on without rest.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He searched the wound on Frodo's shoulder with his fingers, and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">face grew graver, as if what he learned disquieted him. But Frodo felt the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chill lessen in his side and arm; a little warmth crept down from his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulder to his hand, and the pain grew easier. The dusk of evening seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to grow lighter about him, as if a cloud had been withdrawn. He saw his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends' faces more clearly again, and a measure of new hope and strength<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">returned.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You shall ride my horse,' said Glorfindel. 'I will shorten the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stirrups up to the saddle-skins, and you must sit as tight as you can. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you need not fear: my horse will not let any rider fall that I command him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to bear. His pace is light and smooth; and if danger presses too near, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will bear you away with a speed that even the black steeds of the enemy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cannot rival.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, he will not!' said Frodo. 'I shall not ride him, if I am to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">carried off to Rivendell or anywhere else, leaving my friends behind in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">danger.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel smiled. 'I doubt very much,' he said, 'if your friends would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be in danger if you were not with them! The pursuit would follow you and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leave us in peace, I think. It is you, Frodo, and that which you bear that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brings us all in peril.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To that Frodo had no answer, and he was persuaded to mount Glorfindel's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white horse. The pony was laden instead with a great part of the others'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">burdens, so that they now marched lighter, and for a time made good speed;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the hobbits began to find it hard to keep up with the swift tireless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feet of the Elf. On he led them, into the mouth of darkness, and still on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the deep clouded night. There was neither star nor moon. Not until the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey of dawn did he allow them to halt. Pippin, Merry, and Sam were by that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time nearly asleep on their stumbling legs; and even Strider seemed by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sag of his shoulders to be weary. Frodo sat upon the horse in a dark dream.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They cast themselves down in the heather a few yards from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road-side, and fell asleep immediately. They seemed hardly to have closed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their eyes when Glorfindel, who had set himself to watch while they slept,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">awoke them again. The sun had now climbed far into the morning, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clouds and mists of the night were gone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Drink this!' said Glorfindel to them, pouring for each in turn a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little liquor from his silver-studded flask of leather. It was clear as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spring water and had no taste, and it did not feel either cool or warm in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the mouth; but strength and vigour seemed to flow into all their limbs as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they drank it. Eaten after that draught the stale bread and dried fruit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(which was now all that they had left) seemed to satisfy their hunger better<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than many a good breakfast in the Shire had done.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had rested rather less than five hours when they took to the Road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. Glorfindel still urged them on, and only allowed two brief halts<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">during the day's march. In this way they covered almost twenty miles before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nightfall, and came to a point where the Road bent right and ran down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the bottom of the valley, now making straight for the Bruinen. So<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far there had been no sign or sound of pursuit that the hobbits could see or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hear; but often Glorfindel would halt and listen for a moment, if they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lagged behind, and a look of anxiety clouded his face. Once or twice he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke to Strider in the elf-tongue.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But however anxious their guides might be, it was plain that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits could go no further that night. They were stumbling along dizzy with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weariness, and unable to think of anything but their feet and legs. Frodo's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pain had redoubled, and during the day things about him faded to shadows of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ghostly grey. He almost welcomed the coming of night, for then the world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed less pale and empty.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits were still weary, when they set out again early next<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">morning. There were many miles yet to go between them and the Ford, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbled forward at the best pace they could manage.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Our peril will be greatest just ere we reach the river,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel; 'for my heart warns me that the pursuit is now swift behind us,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and other danger may be waiting by the Ford.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Road was still running steadily downhill, and there was now in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places much grass at either side, in which the hobbits walked when they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could, to ease their tired feet. In the late afternoon they came to a place<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the Road went suddenly under the dark shadow of tall pine-trees, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then plunged into a deep cutting with steep moist walls of red stone. Echoes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ran along as they hurried forward; and there seemed to be a sound of many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">footfalls following their own. All at once, as if through a gate of light,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Road ran out again from the end of the tunnel into the open. There at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the bottom of a sharp incline they saw before them a long flat mile, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond that the Ford of Rivendell. On the further side was a steep brown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bank, threaded by a winding path; and behind that the tall mountains<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbed, shoulder above shoulder, and peak beyond peak, into the fading sky.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was still an echo as of following feet in the cutting behind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them; a rushing noise as if a wind were rising and pouring through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches of the pines. One moment Glorfindel turned and listened, then he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprang forward with a loud cry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Fly!' he called. 'Fly! The enemy is upon us!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The white horse leaped forward. The hobbits ran down the slope.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel and Strider followed as rear -guard. They were only half way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">across the flat, when suddenly there was a noise of horses galloping. Out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the gate in the trees that they had just left rode a Black Rider. He reined<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his horse in, and halted, swaying in his saddle. Another followed him, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then another; then again two more.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Ride forward! Ride!' cried Glorfindel to Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He did not obey at once, for a strange reluctance seized him. Checking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon their great steeds like threatening statues upon a hill, dark and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly he knew in his heart that they were silently commanding him to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and gripped the hilt of his sword, and with a red flash he drew it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ride on! Ride on!' cried Glorfindel, and then loud and clear he called<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the horse in the elf-tongue: noro lim, noro lim, Asfaloth!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At once the white horse sprang away and sped like the wind along the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last lap of the Road. At the same moment the black horses leaped down the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill in pursuit, and from the Riders came a terrible cry, such as Frodo had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard filling the woods with horror in the Eastfarthing far away. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">answered; and to the dismay of Frodo and his friends out from the trees and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rocks away on the left four other Riders came flying. Two rode towards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo: two galloped madly towards the Ford to cut off his escape. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to him to run like the wind and to grow swiftly larger and darker, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their courses converged with his.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked back for a moment over his shoulder. He could no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see his friends. The Riders behind were falling back: even their great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">steeds were no match in speed for the white elf-horse of Glorfindel. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked forward again, and hope faded. There seemed no chance of reaching the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ford before he was cut off by the others that had lain in ambush. He could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see them clearly now: they appeared to have cast aside their hoods and black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloaks, and they were robed in white and grey. Swords were naked in their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale hands; helms were on their heads. Their cold eyes glittered, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fear now filled all Frodo's mind. He thought no longer of his sword. No<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cry came from him. He shut his eyes and clung to the horse's mane. The wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whistled in his ears, and the bells upon the harness rang wild and shrill. A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before the face of the foremost Rider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo heard the splash of water. It foamed about his feet. He felt the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
