<p class="p4"><span class="s3">path. He was climbing the steep bank. He was across the Ford.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the pursuers were close behind. At the top of the bank the horse<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halted and turned about neighing fiercely. There were Nine Riders at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water's edge below, and Frodo's spirit quailed before the threat of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uplifted faces. He knew of nothing that would prevent them from crossing as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">easily as he had done; and he felt that it was useless to try to escape over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the long uncertain path from the Ford to the edge of Rivendell, if once the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders crossed. In any case he felt that he was commanded urgently to halt.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hatred again stirred in him, but he had no longer the strength to refuse.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly the foremost Rider spurred his horse forward. It checked at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Go back!' he cried. 'Go back to the Land of Mordor, and follow me no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more! ' His voice sounded thin and shrill in his own ears. The Riders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halted, but Frodo had not the power of Bombadil. His enemies laughed at him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mordor we will take you!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Go back!' he whispered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Ring! The Ring!' they cried with deadly voices; and immediately<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their leader urged his horse forward into the water, followed closely by two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">others.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'By Elbereth and LÂ®thien the Fair,' said Frodo with a last effort,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then the leader, who was now half across the Ford, stood up menacing in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the black horses had almost set foot upon the shore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment there came a roaring and a rushing: a noise of loud<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waters rolling many stones. Dimly Frodo saw the river below him rise, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down along its course there came a plumed cavalry of waves. White flames<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to Frodo to flicker on their crests and he half fancied that he saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disappeared, buried suddenly under angry foam. Those that were behind drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With his last failing senses Frodo heard cries, and it seemed to him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he saw, beyond the Riders that hesitated on the shore, a shining figure<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The black horses were filled with madness, and leaping forward in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terror they bore their riders into the rushing flood. Their piercing cries<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were drowned in the roaring of the river as it carried them away. Then Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt himself falling, and the roaring and confusion seemed to rise and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">engulf him together with his enemies. He heard and saw no more.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 1 . Many Meetings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo woke and found himself lying in bed. At first he thought that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had slept late, after a long unpleasant dream that still hovered on the edge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of memory. Or perhaps he had been ill? But the ceiling looked strange; it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was flat, and it had dark beams richly carved. He lay a little while longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking at patches of sunlight on the wall, and listening to the sound of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waterfall.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where am I, and what is the time?' he said aloud to the ceiling. 'In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the House of Elrond, and it is ten o'clock in the morning.' said a voice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is the morning of October the twenty -fourth, if you want to know.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gandalf!' cried Frodo, sitting up. There was the old wizard, sitting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a chair by the open window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' he said, 'I am here. And you are lucky to be here, too, after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the absurd things you have done since you left home.' Frodo lay down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. He felt too comfortable and peaceful to argue, and in any case he did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not think he would get the better of an argument. He was fully awake now,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the memory of his journey was returning: the disastrous 'short cut'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the Old Forest the 'accident' at The Prancing Pony ; and his madness<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in putting on the Ring in the dell under Weathertop. While he was thinking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of all these things and trying in vain to bring his memory down to his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">arriving in Rivendell, there was a long silence, broken only by the soft<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">puffs of Gandalf s pipe, as he blew white smoke -rings out of the window.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where's Sam?' Frodo asked at length. 'And are the others all right?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, they are all safe and sound,' answered Gandalf. 'Sam was here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until I sent him off to get some rest, about half an hour ago.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What happened at the Ford?' said Frodo. 'It all seemed so dim somehow;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and it still does.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, it would. You were beginning to fade,' answered Gandalf. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wound was overcoming you at last. A few more hours and you would have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond our aid. But you have some strength in you, my dear hobbit! As you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">showed in the Barrow. That was touch and go: perhaps the most dangerous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moment of all. I wish you could have held out at Weathertop.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You seem to know a great deal already,' said Frodo. 'I have not spoken<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the others about the Barrow. At first it was too horrible; and afterwards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there were other things to think about. How do you know about it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You have talked long in your sleep, Frodo,' said Gandalf gently, 'and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it has not been hard for me to read your mind and memory. Do not worry!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though I said "absurd" just now, I did not mean it. I think well of you-and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the others. It is no small feat to have come so far, and through such<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dangers, still bearing the Ring.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We should never have done it without Strider,' said Frodo. 'But we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">needed you. I did not know what to do without you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I was delayed,' said Gandalf, 'and that nearly proved our ruin. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yet I am not sure; it may have been better so.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wish you would tell me what happened!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All in good time! You are not supposed to talk or worry about anything<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">today, by Elrond's orders.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But talking would stop me thinking and wondering, which are quite as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Still that must be expected,' said Gandalf to himself. 'He is not half<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through yet, and to what he will come in the end not even Elrond can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foretell. Not to evil, I think. He may become like a glass filled with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clear light for eyes to see that can.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You look splendid,' he said aloud. 'I will risk a brief tale without<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">consulting Elrond. But quite brief, mind you, and then you must sleep again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">This is what happened, as far as I can gather. The Riders made straight for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you, as soon as you fled. They did not need the guidance of their horses any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer: you had become visible to them, being already on the threshold of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their world. And also the Ring drew them. Your friends sprang aside, off the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road, or they would have been ridden down. They knew that nothing could save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you, if the white horse could not. The Riders were too swift to overtake,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and too many to oppose. On foot even Glorfindel and Aragorn together could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not with stand all the Nine at once.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'When the Ring wraiths swept by, your friends ran up behind. Close to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Ford there is a small hollow beside the road masked by a few stunted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees. There they hastily kindled fire; for Glorfindel knew that a flood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would come down, if the Riders tried to cross, and then he would have to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deal with any that were left on his side of the river. The moment the flood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">appeared, he rushed out, followed by Aragorn and the. others with flaming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brands. Caught between fire and water, and seeing an Elf-lord revealed in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his wrath, they were dismayed, and their horses were stricken with madness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Three were carried away by the first assault of the flood; the others were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now hurled into the water by their horses and overwhelmed.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And is that the end of the Black Riders?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' said Gandalf. 'Their horses must have perished, and without them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they are crippled. But the Ringwraiths themselves cannot be so easily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">destroyed. However, there is nothing more to fear from them at present. Your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friends crossed after the flood had passed; and they found you lying on your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">face at the top of the bank, with a broken sword under you. The horse was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">standing guard beside you. You were pale and cold, and they feared that you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were dead, or worse. Elrond's folk met them, carrying you slowly towards<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ri vendell. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who made the flood?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Elrond commanded it,' answered Gandalf. 'The river of this valley is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under his power, and it will rise in anger when he has great need to bar the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ford. As soon as the captain of the Ringwraiths rode into the water the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flood was released. If I may say so, I added a few touches of my own: you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may not have noticed, but some of the waves took the form of great white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horses with shining white riders; and there were many rolling and grinding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great vigour in the waters that come down from the snows of the Misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, it all comes back to me now,â€™ said Frodo: 'the tremendous<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roaring. I thought I was drowning, with my friends and enemies and all. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf looked quickly at Frodo, but he had shut his eyes. 'Yes, you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are all safe for the present. Soon there will be feasting and merrymaking to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, there are many reasons why they should,â€™ said Gandalf, smiling.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am one good reason. The Ring is another: you are the Ring-bearer. And you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are the heir of Bilbo, the Ring-finder.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dear Bilbo!â€™ said Frodo sleepily. 'I wonder where he is. I wish he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here and could hear all about it. It would have made him laugh, The cow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jumped over the Moon! And the poor old troll!â€™ With that he fell fast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was now safe in the Fast Homely House east of the Sea. That house<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was, as Bilbo had long ago reported, 'a perfect house, whether you like food<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As the evening drew on, Frodo woke up again, and he found that he no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer felt in need of rest or sleep, but had a mind for food and drink, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">probably for singing and story-telling afterwards. He got out of bed and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">discovered that his arm was already nearly as useful again as it ever had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reflection of himself than he remembered: it looked remarkably like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but the eyes looked out at him thoughtfully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, you have seen a thing or two since you last peeped out of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking-glass,' he said to his reflection. 'But now for a merry meeting!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He stretched out his arms and whistled a tune.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment there was a knock on the door, and Sam came in. He ran<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hullo, Sam!â€™ said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's warm!' said Sam. 'Meaning your hand, Mr. Frodo. It has felt so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am ready,' said Frodo. 'Let's go and look for the rest of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I can take you to them, sir,' said Sam. 'It's a big house this, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very peculiar. Always a bit more to discover, and no knowing what you'll<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find round a corner. And Elves, sir! Elves here, and Elves there! Some like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kings, terrible and splendid; and some as merry as children. And the music<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the singing-not that I have had the time or the heart for much listening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since we got here. But I'm getting to know some of the ways of the place.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I know what you have been doing, Sam,' said Frodo, taking his arm.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam led him along several passages and down many steps and out into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high garden above the steep bank of the river. He found his friends sitting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">summer still lingered in Elrond's gardens.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hurray!' cried Pippin, springing up. 'Here is our noble cousin! Make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hush!' said Gandalf from the shadows at the back of the porch. 'Evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in a fortress. Outside it is getting dark.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gandalf has been saying many cheerful things like that,â€™ said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That will soon be cured,â€™ said Pippin. 'You have shown your usual<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hall of Elrond's house was filled with folk: Elves for the most<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">next to him on the one side sat Glorfindel, on the other side sat Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked at them in wonder, for he had never before seen Elrond, of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel, and even Gandalf, whom he thought he knew so well, were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glorfindel was tall and straight; his hair was of shining gold, his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The face of Elrond was ageless, neither old nor young, though in it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">written the memory of many things both glad and sorrowful. His hair was dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as the shadows of twilight, and upon it was set a circlet of silver; his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eyes were grey as a clear evening, and in them was a light like the light of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stars. Venerable he seemed as a king crowned with many winters, and yet hale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as a tried warrior in the fulness of his strength. He was the Lord of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell and mighty among both Elves and Men.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the middle of the table, against the woven cloths upon the wall,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was a chair under a canopy, and there sat a lady fair to look upon,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and so like was she in form of womanhood to Elrond that Frodo guessed that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">she was one of his close kindred. Young she was and yet not so. The braids<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of her dark hair were touched by no frost, her white arms and clear face<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were flawless and smooth, and the light of stars was in her bright eyes,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey as a cloudless night; yet queenly she looked, and thought and knowledge<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were in her glance, as of one who has known many things that the years<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bring. Above her brow her head was covered with a cap of silver lace netted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with small gems, glittering white; but her soft grey raiment had no ornament<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">save a girdle of leaves wrought in silver.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So it was that Frodo saw her whom few mortals had yet seen; Arwen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">daughter of Elrond, in whom it was said that the likeness of LÂ®thien had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come on earth again; and she was called Undumiel, for she was the Evenstar<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of her people. Long she had been in the land of her mother's kin, in Lurien<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond the mountains, and was but lately returned to Rivendell to her<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">father's house. But her brothers, Elladan and Elrohir, were out upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">errantry: for they rode often far afield with the Rangers of the North,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgetting never their mother's torment in the dens of the ores.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Such loveliness in living thing Frodo had never seen before nor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">imagined in his mind; and he was both surprised and abashed to find that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had a seat at Elrond' s table among all these folk so high and fair. Though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had a suitable chair, and was raised upon several cushions, he felt very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small, and rather out of place; but that feeling quickly passed. The feast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was merry and the food all that his hunger could desire. It was some time<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before he looked about him again or even turned to his neighbours.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He looked first for his friends. Sam had begged to be allowed to wait<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on his master, but had been told that for this time he was a guest of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">honour. Frodo could see him now, sitting with Pippin and Merry at the upper<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end of one of the side-tables close to the dais. He could see no sign of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Next to Frodo on his right sat a dwarf of important appearance, richly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dressed. His beard, very long and forked, was white, nearly as white as the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snow-white cloth of his garments. He wore a silver belt, and round his neck<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hung a chain of silver and diamonds. Frodo stopped eating to look at him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome and well met!' said the dwarf, turning towards him. Then he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">actually rose from his seat and bowed. 'Gluin at your service,' he said, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bowed still lower.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Frodo Baggins at your service and your family's,' said Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">correctly, rising in surprise and scattering his cushions. 'Am I right in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guessing that you are the Gluin, one of the twelve companions of the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Thorin Oaken shield?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Quite right,' answered the dwarf, gathering up the cushions and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">courteously assisting Frodo back into his seat. 'And I do not ask, for I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have already been told that you are the kinsman and adopted heir of our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">friend Bilbo the renowned. Allow me to congratulate you on your recovery.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Thank you very much,â€™ said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You have had some very strange adventures, I hear,' said Gluin. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wonder greatly what brings four hobbits on so long a journey. Nothing like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it has happened since Bilbo came with us. But perhaps I should not inquire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">too closely, since Elrond and Gandalf do not seem disposed to talk of this?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think we will not speak of it, at least not yet,' said Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">politely.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He guessed that even in Elrond's house the matter of the Ring was not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one for casual talk; and in any case he wished to forget his troubles for a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time. 'But I am equally curious,' he added, 'to learn what brings so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">important a dwarf so far from the Lonely Mountain.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gluin looked at him. 'If you have not heard, I think we will not speak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yet of that either. Master Elrond will summon us all ere long, I believe,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and then we shall all hear many things. But there is much else that may be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">told.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Throughout the rest of the meal they talked together, but Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">listened more than he spoke; for the news of the Shire, apart from the Ring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed small and far-away and unimportant, while Gluin had much to tell of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">events in the northern regions of Wilderland. Frodo learned that Grimbeorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Old, son of Beorn, was now the lord of many sturdy men, and to their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land between the Mountains and Mirkwood neither ore nor wolf dared to go.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed,' said Gluin, 'if it were not for the Beornings, the passage<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Dale to Rivendell would long ago have become impossible. They are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">valiant men and keep open the High Pass and the Ford of Carrock. But their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tolls are high,' he added with a shake of his head; 'and like Beorn of old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they are not over fond of dwarves. Still, they are trusty, and that is much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in these days. Nowhere are there any men so friendly to us as the Men of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dale. They are good folk, the Bardings. The grandson of Bard the Bowman<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rules them, Brand son of Bain son of Bard. He is a strong king, and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">realm now reaches far south and east of Esgaroth.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what of your own people?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is much to tell, good and bad,' said Gluin; 'yet it is mostly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good: we have so far been fortunate, though we do not escape the shadow of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">these times. If you really wish to hear of us, I will tell you tidings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gladly. But stop me when you are weary! Dwarves' tongues run on when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speaking of their handiwork, they say.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And with that Gluin embarked on a long account of the doings of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dwarf-kingdom. He was delighted to have found so polite a listener; for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo showed no sign of weariness and made no attempt to change the subject,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though actually he soon got rather lost among the strange names of people<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and places that he had never heard of before. He was interested, however, to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hear that Dbin was still King under the Mountain, and was now old (having<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed his two hundred and fiftieth year), venerable, and fabulously rich.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of the ten companions who had survived the Battle of Five Armies seven were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still with him: Dwalin, Gluin, Dori, Nori, Bifur, Bofur, and Bombur. Bombur<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was now so fat that he could not move himself from his couch to his chair at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">table, and it took six young dwarves to lift him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And what has become of Balin and Ori and Uin?' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A shadow passed over Gluin's face. 'We do not know,' he answered. 'It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is largely on account of Balin that I have come to ask the advice of those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that dwell in Rivendell. But tonight let us speak of merrier things!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gluin began then to talk of the works of his people, telling Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about their great labours in Dale and under the Mountain. 'We have done<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well,' he said. 'But in metalwork we cannot rival our fathers, many of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whose, secrets are lost. We make good armour and keen swords, but we cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again make mail or blade to match those that were made before the dragon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came. Only in mining and building have we surpassed the old days. You should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see the waterways of Dale, Frodo, and the fountains, and the pools! You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should see the stone-paved roads of many colours! And the halls and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cavernous streets under the earth with arches carved like trees; and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terraces and towers upon the Mountainâ€™s sides! Then you would see that we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have not been idle.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will come and see them, if ever I can,' said Frodo. 'How surprised<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo would have been to see all the changes in the Desolation of Smaug!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gluin looked at Frodo and smiled. 'You were very fond of Bilbo were you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not?' he asked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' answered Frodo. 1 would rather see him than all the towers and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">palaces in the world.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length the feast came to an end. Elrond and Arwen rose and went down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the hall, and the company followed them in due order. The doors were thrown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">open, and they went across a wide passage and through other doors, and came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into a further hall. In it were no tables, but a bright fire was burning in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a great hearth between the carven pillars upon either side.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo found himself walking with Gandalf. 'This is the Hall of Fire'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said the wizard. 'Here you will hear many songs and tales-if you can keep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">awake. But except on high days it usually stands empty and quiet, and people<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come here who wish for peace, and thought. There is always a fire here, all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the year round, but there is little other light.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Elrond entered and went towards the seat prepared for him, elvish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">minstrels began to make sweet music. Slowly the hall filled, and Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked with delight upon the many fair faces that were gathered together;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the golden firelight played upon them and shimmered in their hair. Suddenly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he noticed, not far from the further end of the fire, a small dark figure<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seated on a stool with his back propped against a pillar. Beside him on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground was a drinking-cup and some bread. Frodo wondered whether he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">(if people were ever ill in Ri vendell), and had been unable to come to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feast. His head seemed sunk in sleep on his breast, and a fold of his dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond went forward and stood beside the silent figure. 'Awake little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">master, he said, with a smile. Then, turning to Frodo, he beckoned to him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now at last the hour has come that you have wished for, Frodo,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The dark figure raised its head and uncovered its face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bilbo!' cried Frodo with sudden recognition, and he sprang forward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hullo, Frodo my lad!â€™ said Bilbo. 'So you have got here at last. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hoped you would manage it. Well, well! So all this feasting is in your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why weren't you there?' cried Frodo. 'And why haven't I been allowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Because you were asleep. I have seen a good deal of you. I have sat by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What were you doing?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to know, you have all come out from your feast too soon, and you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond laughed. 'He shall be found,' he said. 'Then you two shall go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the meanwhile Frodo and Bilbo sat side by side, and Sam came quickly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is. A remarkable place altogether.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hear all kinds of news, from over the Mountains, and out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course. Gandalf has been here often. Not that he has told me a great deal,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he has become closer than ever these last few years. The DÂ®nadan has told me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more. Fancy that ring of mine causing such a disturbance! It is a pity that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tottering about in the Wild.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And Gandalf said: "The Ring has passed on, Bilbo. It would do no good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Have you got it here?' he asked in a whisper. I can't help feeling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, I've got it,' answered Frodo, feeling a strange reluctance. 'It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, I should just like to see it for a moment,' said Bilbo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When he had dressed, Frodo found that while he slept the Ring had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The music and singing round them seemed to falter and a silence fell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo looked quickly at Frodo's face and passed his hand across his eyes. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I suppose not. Someone else always has to carry on the story. Well, it can't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be helped. I wonder if it's any good trying to finish my book? But don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo hid the Ring away, and the shadow passed leaving hardly a shred<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smiled and laughed happily. Every item of news from the Shire that Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Strider!' said Frodo. 'You seem to have a lot of names.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, Strider is one that I haven't heard before, anyway,' said Bilbo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you call him that for?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They call me that in Bree,â€™ said Strider laughing, 'and that is how I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was introduced to him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And why do you call him DÂ®nadan?â€™ asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' The DÂ®nadan,' said Bilbo. 'Fie is often called that here. But I thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you knew enough Elvish at least to know dÂ®n-udan: Man of the West,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Where have you been, my friend? Why weren't you at the feast? The Fady<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Arwen was there.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider looked down at Bilbo gravely. 'I know,' he said. 'But often I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must put mirth aside. Elladan and Elrohir have returned out of the Wild<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, my dear fellow,' said Bilbo, 'now you've heard the news, can't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider smiled. 'Come then!' he said. 'Fet me hear it!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was left to himself for a while, for Sam had fallen asleep. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first the beauty of the melodies and of the interwoven words in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There he wandered long in a dream of music that turned into running<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
