<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Do you wish for the House of Elendil to return to the Land of Gondor?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo felt Bilbo stir impatiently at his side. Evidently he was annoyed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All that is gold does not glitter,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not all those who wander are lost;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The old that is strong does not wither,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Deep roots are not reached by the frost.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From the ashes a fire shall be woken,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Renewed shall be blade that was broken:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not very good perhaps, but to the point â€” if you need more beyond the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">word of Elrond. If that was worth a journey of a hundred and ten days to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn smiled at him; then he turned to Boromir again. 'For my part I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgive your doubt,' he said. 'Little do I resemble the figures of Elendil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I am but the heir of Isildur, not Isildur himself. I have had a hard life<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and a long; and the leagues that lie between here and Gondor are a small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">part in the count of my journeys. I have crossed many mountains and many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rivers, and trodden many plains, even into the far countries of Rhyn and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Harad where the stars are strange.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But my home, such as I have, is in the North. For here the heirs of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Valandil have ever dwelt in long line unbroken from father unto son for many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">generations. Our days have darkened, and we have dwindled; but ever the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sword has passed to a new keeper. And this I will say to you, Boromir, ere I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end. Lonely men are we, Rangers of the wild, huntersâ€” but hunters ever of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the servants of the Enemy; for they are found in many places, not in Mordor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If Gondor, Boromir, has been a stalwart tower, we have played another<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">part. Many evil things there are that your strong walls and bright swords do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not stay. You know little of the lands beyond your bounds. Peace and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">freedom, do you say? The North would have known them little but for us. Fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would have destroyed them. But when dark things come from the houseless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills, or creep from sunless woods, they fly from us. What roads would any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dare to tread, what safety would there be in quiet lands, or in the homes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">simple men at night, if the DÂ®nedain were asleep, or were all gone into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grave?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And yet less thanks have we than you. Travellers scowl at us, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">countrymen give us scornful names. "Strider" I am to one fat man who lives<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">within a day's march of foes that would freeze his heart or lay his little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">town in ruin, if he were not guarded ceaselessly. Yet we would not have it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">otherwise. If simple folk are free from care and fear, simple they will be,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and we must be secret to keep them so. That has been the task of my kindred,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while the years have lengthened and the grass has grown.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But now the world is changing once again. A new hour comes. Isildur's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bane is found. Battle is at hand. The Sword shall be reforged. I will come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Minas Tirith.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Isildur's Bane is found, you say,' said Boromir. 'I have seen a bright<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring in the Halfling's hand; but Isildur perished ere this age of the world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began, they say. How do the Wise know that this ring is his? And how has it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed down the years, until it is brought hither by so strange a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">messenger?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That shall be told,' said Elrond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But not yet, I beg, Master!â€™ said Bilbo. 'Already the Sun is climbing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to noon, and I feel the need of something to strengthen me.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I had not named you,â€™ said Elrond smiling. 'But I do so now. Come!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tell us your tale. And if you have not yet cast your story into verse, you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may tell it in plain words. The briefer, the sooner shall you be refreshed.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well,' said Bilbo. 'I will do as you bid. But I will now tell the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">true story, and if some here have heard me tell it otherwise' â€” he looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sidelong at Gluin â€” l ask them to forget it and forgive me. I only wished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to claim the treasure as my very own in those days, and to be rid of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name of thief that was put on me. But perhaps I understand things a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">better now. Anyway, this is what happened.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To some there Bilbo's tale was wholly new, and they listened with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">amazement while the old hobbit, actually not at all displeased, recounted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his adventure with Gollum, at full length. He did not omit a single riddle.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He would have given also an account of his party and disappearance from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire, if he had been allowed; but Elrond raised his hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well told, my friend,' he said, 'but that is enough at this time. For<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the moment it suffices to know that the Ring passed to Frodo, your heir. Let<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him now speak!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then, less willingly than Bilbo, Frodo told of all his dealings with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Ring from the day that it passed into his keeping. Every step of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey from Hobbiton to the Ford of Bruinen was questioned and considered,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and everything that he could recall concerning the Black Riders was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">examined. At last he sat down again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not bad,' Bilbo said to him. 'You would have made a good story of it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if they hadn't kept on interrupting. I tried to make a few notes, but we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall have to go over it all again together some time, if I am to write it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up. There are whole chapters of stuff before you ever got here!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, it made quite a long tale,' answered Frodo. 'But the story still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">does not seem complete to me. I still want to know a good deal, especially<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about Gandalf.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galdor of the Havens, who sat near by, overheard him. 'You speak for me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also,â€™ he cried, and turning to Elrond he said: 'The Wise may have good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reason to believe that the halfling's trove is indeed the Great Ring of long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">debate, unlikely though that may seem to those who know less. But may we not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hear the proofs? And I would ask this also. What of Saruman? He is learned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the lore of the Rings, yet he is not among us. What is his counsel-if he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knows the things that we have heard?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The questions that you ask, Galdor, are bound together,' said Elrond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I had not overlooked them, and they shall be answered. But these things it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is the part of Gandalf to make clear; and I call upon him last, for it is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the place of honour, and in all this matter he has been the chief.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Some, Galdor,' said Gandalf, 'would think the tidings of Gluin, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pursuit of Frodo, proof enough that the halfling's trove is a thing of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great worth to the Enemy. Yet it is a ring. What then? The Nine the Nazgyl<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">keep. The Seven are taken or destroyed.' At this Gluin stirred, but did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">speak. 'The Three we know of. What then is this one that he desires so much?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is indeed a wide waste of time between the River and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountain, between the loss and the finding. But the gap in the knowledge of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Wise has been filled at last. Yet too slowly. For the Enemy has been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">close behind, closer even than I feared. And well is it that not until this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year, this very summer, as it seems, did he learn the full truth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Some here will remember that many years ago I myself dared to pass the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors of the Necromancer in Dol Guldur, and secretly explored his ways, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found thus that our fears were true: he was none other than Sauron, our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Enemy of old, at length taking shape and power again. Some, too, will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remember also that Saruman dissuaded us from open deeds against him, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long we watched him only. Yet at last, as his shadow grew, Saruman yielded,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the Council put forth its strength and drove the evil out of Mirkwood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and that was in the very year of the finding of this Ring: a strange chance,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if chance it was.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But we were too late, as Elrond foresaw. Sauron also had watched us,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and had long prepared against our stroke, governing Mordor from afar through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Minas Morgul, where his Nine servants dwelt, until all was ready. Then he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave way before us, but only feigned to flee, and soon after came to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dark Tower and openly declared himself. Then for the last time the Council<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">met; for now we learned that he was seeking ever more eagerly for the One.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We feared then that he had some news of it that we knew nothing of. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Saruman said nay, and repeated what he had said to us before: that the One<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would never again be found in Middle-earth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"At the worst," said he, "our Enemy knows that we have it not and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that it still is lost. But what was lost may yet be found, he thinks. Fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not! His hope will cheat him. Have I not earnestly studied this matter? Into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Anduin the Great it fell; and long ago, while Sauron slept, it was rolled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down the River to the Sea. There let it lie until the End.'"<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf fell silent, gazing eastward from the porch to the far peaks of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Misty Mountains, at whose great roots the peril of the world had so long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lain hidden. He sighed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There I was at fault,' he said. 'I was lulled by the words of Saruman<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Wise; but I should have sought for the truth sooner, and our peril would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now be less.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We were all at fault,â€™ said Elrond, 'and but for your vigilance the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Darkness, maybe, would already be upon us. But say on!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'From the first my heart misgave me, against all reason that I knew,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Gandalf, 'and I desired to know how this thing came to Gollum, and how<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long he had possessed it. So I set a watch for him, guessing that he would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ere long come forth from his darkness to seek for his treasure. He came, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he escaped and was not found. And then alas ! I let the matter rest, watching<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and waiting only, as we have too often done.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Time passed with many cares, until my doubts were awakened again to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sudden fear. Whence came the hobbit's ring? What, if my fear was true,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should be done with it? Those things I must decide. But I spoke yet of my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dread to none, knowing the peril of an untimely whisper, if it went astray.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In all the long wars with the Dark Tower treason has ever been our greatest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That was seventeen years ago. Soon I became aware that spies of many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sorts, even beasts and birds, were gathered round the Shire, and my fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew. I called for the help of the DÂ®nedain, and their watch was doubled;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I opened my heart to Aragorn, the heir of Isildur.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I,' said Aragorn, 'counselled that we should hunt for Gollum. too<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">late though it may seem. And since it seemed fit that Isildur's heir should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">labour to repair Isildur's fault, I went with Gandalf on the long and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hopeless search.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then Gandalf told how they had explored the whole length of Wilderland,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down even to the Mountains of Shadow and the fences of Mordor. 'There we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rumour of him, and we guess that he dwelt there long in the dark hills; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we never found him, and at last I despaired. And then in my despair I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought again of a test that might make the finding of Gollum unneeded. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ring itself might tell if it were the One. The memory of words at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Council came back to me: words of Saruman, half-heeded at the time. I heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them now clearly in my heart.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "The Nine, the Seven, and the Three," he said, "had each their proper<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gem. Not so the One. It was round and unadorned, as it were one of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lesser rings; but its maker set marks upon it that the skilled, maybe, could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still see and read."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What those marks were he had not said. Who now would know? The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">maker.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And Saruman? But great though his lore may be, it must have a source. What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hand save Sauronâ€™s ever held this thing, ere it was lost? The hand of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Isildur alone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'With that thought, I forsook the chase, and passed swiftly to Gondor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In former days the members of my order had been well received there, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Saruman most of all. Often he had been for long the guest of the Lords of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the City. Less welcome did the Lord Denethor show me then than of old, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grudgingly he permitted me to search among his hoarded scrolls and books.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™ "If indeed you look only, as you say, for records of ancient days,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the beginnings of the City, read on! " he said. "For to me what was is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">less dark than what is to come, and that is my care. But unless you have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more skill even than Saruman, who has studied here long, you will find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">naught that is not well known to me, who am master of the lore of this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">City."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So said Denethor. And yet there lie in his hoards many records that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">few now can read, even of the lore-masters, for their scripts and tongues<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have become dark to later men. And Boromir, there lies in Minas Tirith<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still, unread, I guess, by any save Saruman and myself since the kings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">failed, a scroll that Isildur made himself. For Isildur did not march away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">straight from the war in Mordor, as some have told the tale.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Some in the North, maybe,' Boromir broke in. 'All know in Gondor that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he went first to Minas Anor and dwelt a while with his nephew Meneldil,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">instructing him, before he committed to him the rule of the South Kingdom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In that time he planted there the last sapling of the White Tree in memory<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his brother.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But in that time also he made this scroll,' said Gandalf; 'and that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not remembered in Gondor, it would seem. For this scroll concerns the Ring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and thus wrote Isildur therein:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Great Ring shall go now to be an heirloom of the North Kingdom; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">records of it shall be left in Gondor, where also dwell the heirs of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elendil, lest a time come when the memory of these great matters shall grow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dim.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And after these words Isildur described the Ring, such as he found it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was hot when I first took it, hot as a glede, and my hand was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">scorched, so that I doubt if ever again I shall be free of the pain of it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Yet even as I write it is cooled, and it seemeth to shrink, though it loseth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither its beauty nor its shape. Already the writing upon it, which at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first was as clear as red flame, fadeth and is now only barely to be read.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is fashioned in an elven-script of Eregion, for they have no letters in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mordor for such subtle work; but the language is unknown to me. I deem it to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be a tongue of the Black Land, since it is foul and uncouth. What evil it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saith I do not know; but I trace here a copy of it, lest it fade beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">recall. The Ring misseth, maybe, the heat of Sauron's hand, which was black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and yet burned like fire, and so Gil-galad was destroyed; and maybe were the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gold made hot again, the writing would be refreshed, gut for my part I will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">risk no hurt to this thing: of all the works of Sauron the only fair. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">precious to me, though I buy it with great pain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™When I read these words, my quest was ended. For the traced writing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was indeed as Isildur guessed, in the tongue of Mordor and the servants of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Tower. And what was said therein was already known. For in the day that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sauron first put on the One, Celebrimbor, maker of the Three, was aware of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, and from afar he heard him speak these words, and so his evil purposes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were revealed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'At once I took my leave of Denethor, but even as I went northwards,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">messages came to me out of Lurien that Aragorn had passed that way, and that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had found the creature called Gollum. Therefore I went first to meet him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and hear his tale. Into what deadly perils he had gone alone I dared not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guess.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is little need to tell of them,â€™ said Aragorn. 'If a man must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">needs walk in sight of the Black Gate, or tread the deadly flowers of Morgul<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Vale, then perils he will have. I, too, despaired at last, and I began my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">homeward journey. And then, by fortune, I came suddenly on what I sought:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the marks of soft feet beside a muddy pool. But now the trail was fresh and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swift, and it led not to Mordor but away. Along the skirts of the Dead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Marshes I followed it, and then I had him. Lurking by a stagnant mere,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peering in the water as the dark eve fell, I caught him, Gollum. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">covered with green slime. He will never love me, I fear; for he bit me, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I was not gentle. Nothing more did I ever get from his mouth than the marks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his teeth. I deemed it the worst part of all my journey, the road back,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watching him day and night, making him walk before me with a halter on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neck, gagged, until he was tamed by lack of drink and food, driving him ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards Mirkwood. I brought him there at last and gave him to the Elves, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we had agreed that this should be done; and I was glad to be rid of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">company, for he stank. For my part I hope never to look upon him again; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf came and endured long speech with him.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, long and weary,' said Gandalf, 'but not without profit. For one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing, the tale he told of his loss agreed with that which Bilbo has now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">told openly for the first time; but that mattered little, since I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already guessed it. But I learned then first that Gollum's ring came out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Great River nigh to the Gladden Fields. And I learned also that he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">possessed it long. Many lives of his small kind. The power of the ring had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lengthened his years far beyond their span; but that power only the Great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rings wield.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And if that is not proof enough, Galdor, there is the other test that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I spoke of. Upon this very ring which you have here seen held aloft, round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and unadorned, the letters that Isildur reported may still be read, if one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has the strength of will to set the golden thing in the fire a while. That I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have done, and this I have read:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ash nazg durbatulyk, ush nazg gimbatul, ash nazg thrakatulyk agh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">burzum-ishi krimpatul. '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The change in the wizard's voice was astounding. Suddenly it became<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">menacing, powerful, harsh as stone. A shadow seemed to pass over the high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun, and the porch for a moment grew dark. All trembled, and the Elves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stopped their ears.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Never before has any voice dared to utter the words of that tongue in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Imladris, Gandalf the Grey,â€™ said Elrond, as the shadow passed and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">company breathed once more.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And let us hope that none will ever speak it here again,' answered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf. 'Nonetheless I do not ask your pardon, Master Elrond. For if that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tongue is not soon to be heard in every corner of the West, then let all put<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubt aside that this thing is indeed what the Wise have declared: the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treasure of the Enemy, fraught with all his malice; and in it lies a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">part of his strength of old. Out of the Black Years come the words that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Smiths of Eregion heard, and knew that they had been betrayed:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, One Ring to bring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them all and in the Darkness bind them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Know also, my friends, that I learned more yet from Gollum. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">loth to speak and his tale was unclear, but it is beyond all doubt that he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went to Mordor, and there all that he knew was forced from him. Thus the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Enemy knows now that the One is found, that it was long in the Shire; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">since his servants have pursued it almost to our door, he soon will know,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already he may know, even as I speak, that we have it here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All sat silent for a while, until at length Boromir spoke. 'He is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small thing, you say, this Gollum? Small, but great in mischief. What became<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of him? To what doom did you put him?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He is in prison, but no worse,' said Aragorn. 'He had suffered much.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There is no doubt that he was tormented, and the fear of Sauron lies black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on his heart. Still I for one am glad that he is safely kept by the watchful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves of Mirkwood. His malice is great and gives him a strength hardly to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">believed in one so lean and withered. He could work much mischief still, if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he were free. And I do not doubt that he was allowed to leave Mordor on some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil errand.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Alas! alas!â€™ cried Legolas, and in his fair elvish face there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great distress. 'The tidings that I was sent to bring must now be told. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are not good, but only here have I learned how evil they may seem to this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">company. Smjagol, who is now called Gollum, has escaped.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Escaped?' cried Aragorn. 'That is ill news indeed. We shall all rue it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bitterly, I fear. How came the folk of Thranduil to fail in their trust?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not through lack of watchfulness,' said Legolas; 'but perhaps through<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over -kindliness. And we fear that the prisoner had aid from others, and that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more is known of our doings than we could wish. We guarded this creature day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and night, at Gandalf s bidding, much though we wearied of the task. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf bade us hope still for his cure, and we had not the heart to keep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him ever in dungeons under the earth, where he would fall back into his old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You were less tender to me,' said Gluin with a flash of his eyes as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elven-king's halls.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now come!' said Gandalf. 'Pray do not interrupt, my good Gluin. That<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a regrettable misunderstanding, long set right. If all the grievances<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that stand between Elves and Dwarves are to be brought up here, we may as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well abandon this Council.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gluin rose and bowed, and Legolas continued. 'In the days of fair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">weather we led Gollum through the woods; and there was a high tree standing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone far from the others which he liked to climb. Often we let him mount up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the highest branches, until he felt the free wind; but we set a guard at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the tree's foot. One day he refused to come down, and the guards had no mind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to climb after him: he had learned the trick of clinging to boughs with his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feet as well as with his hands; so they sat by the tree far into the night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was that very night of summer, yet moonless and starless, that Ores<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came on us at unawares. We drove them off after some time; they were many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and fierce, but they came from over the mountains, and were unused to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods. When the battle was over, we found that Gollum was gone, and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guards were slain or taken. It then seemed plain to us that the attack had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been made for his rescue, and that he knew of it beforehand. How that was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">contrived we cannot guess; but Gollum is cunning, and the spies of the Enemy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are many. The dark things that were driven out in the year of the Dragon's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have failed to recapture Gollum. We came on his trail among those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, well, he is gone,' said Gandalf. 'We have no time to seek for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And now I will answer Galdor's other questions. What of Saruman? What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'At the end of June I was in the Shire, but a cloud of anxiety was on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is one of my order, but I had not seen him for many a year.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Your information was correct," I said. "But do not put it that way,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "I have an urgent errand," he said. "My news is evil." Then he looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I knew then what I had dreaded without knowing it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">" "The enemy must have some great need or purpose," said Radagast; "but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">v "What do you mean? " said I.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">v "I have been told that wherever they go the Riders ask for news of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "The Shire," I said; but my heart sank. For even the Wise might fear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Saruman the White," answered Radagast. "And he told me to say that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And that message brought me hope. For Saruman the White is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greatest of my order. Radagast is, of course, a worthy Wizard, a master of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shapes and changes of hue; and he has much lore of herbs and beasts, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">birds are especially his friends. But Saruman has long studied the arts of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Enemy himself, and thus we have often been able to forestall him. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "I will go to Saruman," I said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Then you must go now," said Radagast; "for I have wasted time in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking for you, and the days are running short. I was told to find you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I myself shall turn back at once." And with that he mounted and would have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Stay a moment! " I said. "We shall need your help, and the help of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"I will do that," he said, and rode off as if the Nine were after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I could not follow him then and there. I had ridden very far already<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that day, and I was as weary as my horse; and I needed to consider matters.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I stayed the night in Bree, and decided that I had no time to return to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shire. Never did I make a greater mistake!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'However, I wrote a message to Frodo, and trusted to my friend the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">innkeeper to send it to him. I rode away at dawn; and I came at long last to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Misty Mountains, not far from the Gap of Rohan. And Boromir will tell you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that that is a great open vale that lies between the Misty Mountains and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">northmost foothills of Ered Nimrais, the White Mountains of his home. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and in the midst of that valley is a tower of stone called Orthanc. It was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not made by Saruman, but by the Men of NÂ®menor long ago; and it is very tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and has many secrets; yet it looks not to be a work of craft. It cannot be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached save by passing the circle of Isengard; and in that circle there is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only one gate.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Late one evening I came to the gate, like a great arch in the wall of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watch for me and told me that Saruman awaited me. I rode under the arch, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the gate closed silently behind me, and suddenly I was afraid, though I knew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no reason for it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But I rode to the foot of Orthanc, and came to the stair of Saruman<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there he met me and led me up to his high chamber. He wore a ring on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finger.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"So you have come, Gandalf," he said to me gravely; but in his eyes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there seemed to be a white light, as if a cold laughter was in his heart.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">v "Yes, I have come," I said. "I have come for your aid, Saruman the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">White." And that title seemed to anger him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Have you indeed, Gandalf the Grey l " he scoffed. "For aid? It has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">How long. I wonder, have you concealed from me, the head of the Council, a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dyed. The white page can be overwritten; and the white light can be broken."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "In which case it is no longer white," said I. "And he that breaks a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™He was cold now and perilous. "Yes," he said. "I did not expect you to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That the Nine had indeed arisen I felt assured, apart from the words<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had many friends of old. And the Eagles of the Mountains went far and wide,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
