<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Then I must have a steed on land," I said, "and a steed surpassingly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swift, for I have never had such need of haste before."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Then I will bear you to Edoras, where the Lord of Rohan sits in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halls," he said; "for that is not very far off." And I was glad, for in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riddermark of Rohan the Rohirrim, the Horse-lords, dwell, and there are no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horses like those that are bred in that great vale between the Misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains and the White.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Are the Men of Rohan still to be trusted, do you think? " I said to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gwaihir, for the treason of Saruman had shaken my faith.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "They pay a tribute of horses," he answered, "and send many yearly to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mordor, or so it is said; but they are not yet under the yoke. But if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Saruman has become evil, as you say, then their doom cannot be long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delayed."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He set me down in the land of Rohan ere dawn; and now I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lengthened my tale over long. The rest must be more brief. In Rohan I found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil already at work: the lies of Saruman; and the king of the land would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not listen to my warnings. He bade me take a horse and be gone; and I chose<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one much to my liking, but little to his. I took the best horse in his land,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I have never seen the like of him.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Then he must be a noble beast indeed,â€™ said Aragorn; 'and it grieves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me more than many tidings that might seem worse to learn that Sauron levies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">such tribute. It was not so when last I was in that land.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nor is it now, I will swear,â€™ said Boromir. 'It is a lie that comes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the Enemy. I know the Men of Rohan; true and valiant, our allies,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwelling still in the lands that we gave them long ago.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The shadow of Mordor lies on distant lands,â€™ answered Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Saruman has fallen under it. Rohan is beset. Who knows what you will find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there, if ever you return?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not this at least.â€™ said Boromir, â€™that they will buy their lives with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horses. They love their horses next to their kin. And not without reason,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the horses of the Riddermark come from the fields of the North, far from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shadow, and their race, as that of their masters, is descended from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">free days of old.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™True indeed!â€™ said Gandalf. 'And there is one among them that might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have been foaled in the morning of the world. The horses of the Nine cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vie with him; tireless, swift as the flowing wind. Shadowfax they called<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him. By day his coat glistens like silver; and by night it is like a shade,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he passes unseen. Light is his footfall! Never before had any man<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mounted him, but I took him and I tamed him, and so speedily he bore me that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I reached the Shire when Frodo was on the Barrow-downs, though I set out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Rohan only when he set out from Hobbiton.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But fear grew in me as I rode. Ever as I came north I heard tidings of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Riders, and though I gained on them day by day, they were ever before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me. They had divided their forces, I learned: some remained on the eastern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borders, not far from the Greenway. and some invaded the Shire from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">south. I came to Hobbiton and Frodo had gone; but I had words with old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gamgee. Many words and few to the point. He had much to say about the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shortcomings of the new owners of Bag End.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "I can't abide changes," said he, "not at my time of life, and least<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of all changes for the worst." "Changes for the worst," he repeated many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">times.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Worst is a bad word," I said to him, "and I hope you do not live to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see it." But amidst his talk I gathered at last that Frodo had left Hobbiton<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">less than a week before, and that a black horseman had come to the Hill the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">same evening. Then I rode on in fear. I came to Buckland and found it in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uproar, as busy as a hive of ants that has been stirred with a stick. I came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the house at Crickhollow, and it was broken open and empty; but on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">threshold there lay a cloak that had been Frodo's. Then for a while hope<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left me, and I did not wait to gather news, or I might have been comforted;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but I rode on the trail of the Riders. It was hard to follow, for it went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many ways, and I was at a loss. But it seemed to me that one or two had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ridden towards Bree; and that way I went, for I thought of words that might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be said to the innkeeper.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Butterbur they call him," thought I. "If this delay was his fault, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will melt all the butter in him. I will roast the old fool over a slow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fire." He expected no less, and when he saw my face he fell down flat and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to melt on the spot.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What did you do to him?' cried Frodo in alarm. 'He was really very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kind to us and did all that he could.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf laughed. 'Don't be afraid!' he said. 'I did not bite, and I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">barked very little. So overjoyed was I by the news that I got out of him,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when he stopped quaking, that I embraced the old fellow. How it happened I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not then guess, but I learned that you had been in Bree the night<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before, and had gone off that morning with Strider.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' "Strider! " I cried, shouting for joy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"Yes, sir, I am afraid so, sir," said Butterbur, mistaking me. "He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">got at them, in spite of all that I could do, and they took up with him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They behaved very queer all the time they were here: wilful, you might say."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"Ass! Fool! Thrice worthy and beloved Barliman! " said I. "It's the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">best news I have had since midsummer: it's worth a gold piece at the least.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">May your beer be laid under an enchantment of surpassing excellence for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seven years! " said I. "Now I can take a night's rest, the first since I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have forgotten when."<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Sol stayed there that night, wondering much what had become of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders; for only of two had there yet been any news in Bree, it seemed. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the night we heard more. Five at least came from the west, and they threw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down the gates and passed through Bree like a howling wind; and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bree-folk are still shivering and expecting the end of the world. I got up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before dawn and went after them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know, but it seems clear to me that this is what happened.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their Captain remained in secret away south of Bree, while two rode ahead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the village, and four more invaded the Shire. But when these were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foiled in Bree and at Crickhollow, they returned to their Captain with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tidings, and so left the Road unguarded for a while, except by their spies.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Captain then sent some eastward straight across country, and he himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the rest rode along the Road in great wrath.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I galloped to Weathertop like a gale, and I reached it before sundown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on my second day from Bree-and they were there before me. They drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from me, for they felt the coming of my anger and they dared not face it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while the Sun was in the sky. But they closed round at night, and I was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">besieged on the hill -top, in the old ring of Amon Syl. I was hard put to it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed: such light and flame cannot have been seen on Weathertop since the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">war-beacons of old.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'At sunrise I escaped and fled towards the north. I could not hope to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do more. It was impossible to find you, Frodo, in the wilderness, and it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would have been folly to try with all the Nine at my heels. Sol had to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust to Aragorn. But I hoped to draw some of them off, and yet reach<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell ahead of you and send out help. Four Riders did indeed follow me,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but they turned back after a while and made for the Ford, it seems. That<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">helped a little, for there were only five, not nine, when your camp was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">attacked.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™I reached here at last by a long hard road, up the Floarwell and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the Ettenmoors, and down from the north. It took me nearly fourteen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days from Weathertop, for I could not ride among the rocks of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troll-fells, and Shadowfax departed. I sent him back to his master; but a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great friendship has grown between us, and if I have need he will come at my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">call. But so it was that I came to Rivendell only three days before the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring, and news of its peril had already been brought here-which proved well<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And that, Frodo, is the end of my account. May Elrond and the others<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgive the length of it. But such a thing has not happened before, that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf broke tryst and did not come when he promised. An account to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ring-bearer of so strange an event was required, I think.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, the Tale is now told, from first to last. Here we all are, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here is the Ring. But we have not yet come any nearer to our purpose. What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall we do with it?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was silence. At last Elrond spoke again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'This is grievous news concerning Saruman,' he said; 'for we trusted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him and he is deep in all our counsels. It is perilous to study too deeply<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the arts of the Enemy, for good or for ill. But such falls and betrayals,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alas, have happened before. Of the tales that we have heard this day the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tale of Frodo was most strange to me. I have known few hobbits, save Bilbo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here; and it seems to me that he is perhaps not so alone and singular as I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had thought him. The world has changed much since I last was on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">westward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roads.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Barrow- wights we know by many names; and of the Old Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tales have been told: all that now remains is but an outlier of its northern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">march. Time was when a squirrel could go from tree to tree from what is now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire to Dunland west of Isengard. In those lands I journeyed once, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many things wild and strange I knew. But I had forgotten Bombadil, if indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this is still the same that walked the woods and hills long ago, and even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then was older than the old. That was not then his name. Iarwain Ben-adar we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called him, oldest and fatherless. But many another name he has since been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">given by other folk: Forn by the Dwarves, Orald by Northern Men, and other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">names beside. He is a strange creature, but maybe I should have summoned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to our Council.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He would not have come,' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Dark Lord long ago. Are they idle? I see Elf-lords here. Will they not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Elves returned no answer. 'Did you not hear me, Gluin?â€™ said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond. 'The Three were not made by Sauron, nor did he ever touch them. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of them it is not permitted to speak. So much only in this' hour of doubt I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may now say. They are not idle. But they were not made as weapons of war or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">conquest: that is not their power. Those who made them did not desire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strength or domination or hoarded wealth, but understanding, making, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">healing, to preserve all things unstained. These things the Elves of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Middle-earth have in some measure gained, though with sorrow. But all that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has been wrought by those who wield the Three will turn to their undoing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and their minds and hearts will become revealed to Sauron, if he regains the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One. It would be better if the Three had never been. That is his purpose.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But what then would happen, if the Ruling Ring were destroyed as you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">counsel?â€™ asked Gluin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We know not for certain,' answered Elrond sadly. 'Some hope that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Three Rings, which Sauron has never touched, would then become free, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their rulers might heal the hurts of the world that he has wrought. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">maybe when the One has gone, the Three will fail, and many fair things will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fade and be forgotten. That is my belief.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yet all the Elves are willing to endure this chance,' said Glorfindel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'if by it the power of Sauron may be broken, and the fear of his dominion be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">taken away for ever.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Thus we return once more to the destroying of the Ring,' said Erestor,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'and yet we come no nearer. What strength have we for the finding of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fire in which it was made? That is the path of despair. Of folly I would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say, if the long wisdom of Elrond did not forbid me.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Despair, or folly?' said Gandalf. 'It is not despair, for despair is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only for those who see the end beyond all doubt. We do not. It is wisdom to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">recognize necessity, when all other courses have been weighed, though as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folly it may appear to those who cling to false hope. Well, let folly be our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloak, a veil before the eyes of the Enemy! For he is very wise, and weighs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all things to a nicety in the scales of his malice. But the only measure<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he knows is desire, desire for power; and so he judges all hearts. Into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his heart the thought will not enter that any will refuse it, that having<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Ring we may seek to destroy it. If we seek this, we shall put him out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reckoning.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'At least for a while,' said Elrond. 'The road must be trod, but it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will be very hard. And neither strength nor wisdom will carry us far upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Yet such is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well, very well, Master Elrond!' said Bilbo suddenly. 'Say no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more! It is plain enough what you are pointing at. Bilbo the silly hobbit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">started this affair, and Bilbo had better finish it, or himself. I was very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comfortable here, and getting on with my book. If you want to know, I am<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">just writing an ending for it. I had thought of putting: and he lived<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">happily ever afterwards to the end of his days. It is a good ending, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">none the worse for having been used before. Now I shall have to alter that:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it does not look like coming true; and anyway there will evidently have to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be several more chapters, if I live to write them. It is a frightful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nuisance. When ought I to start?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' Boromir looked in surprise at Bilbo, but the laughter died on his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lips when he saw that all the others regarded the old hobbit with grave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">respect. Only Gluin smiled, but his smile came from old memories.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course, my dear Bilbo,â€™ said Gandalf. 'If you had really started<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this affair, you might be expected to finish it. But you know well enough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now that starting is too great a claim for any, and that only a small part<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is played in great deeds by any hero. You need not bow! Though the word was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meant, and we do not doubt that under jest you are making a valiant offer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But one beyond your strength, Bilbo. You cannot take this thing back. It has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed on. If you need my advice any longer, I should say that your part is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ended, unless as a recorder. Finish your book, and leave the ending<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unaltered! There is still hope for it. But get ready to write a sequel, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they come back.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo laughed. 'I have never known you give me pleasant advice before.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said. 'As all your unpleasant advice has been good, I wonder if this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">advice is not bad. Still, I don't suppose I have the strength or luck left<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to deal with the Ring. It has grown, and I have not. But tell me: what do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you mean by they?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The messengers who are sent with the Ring.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Exactly! And who are they to be? That seems to me what this Council<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has to decide, and all that it has to decide. Elves may thrive on speech<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone, and Dwarves endure great weariness; but I am only an old hobbit, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I miss my meal at noon. Can't you think of some names now? Or put it off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">till after dinner?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">No one answered. The noon-bell rang. Still no one spoke. Frodo glanced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at all the faces, but they were not turned to him. All the Council sat with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">downcast eyes, as if in deep thought. A great dread fell on him, as if he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was awaiting the pronouncement of some doom that he had long foreseen and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vainly hoped might after all never be spoken. An overwhelming longing to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rest and remain at peace by Bilbo's side in Rivendell filled all his heart.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last with an effort he spoke, and wondered to hear his own words, as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some other will was using his small voice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will take the Ring,' he said, 'though I do not know the way.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond raised his eyes and looked at him, and Frodo felt his heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pierced by the sudden keenness of the glance. 'If I understand aright all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I have heard,' he said, 'I think that this task is appointed for you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo; and that if you do not find a way, no one will. This is the hour of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire-folk, when they arise from their quiet fields to shake the towers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and counsels of the Great. Who of all the Wise could have foreseen it? Or,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if they are wise, why should they expect to know it, until the hour has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">struck?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But it is a heavy burden. So heavy that none could lay it on another.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I do not lay it on you. But if you take it freely, I will say that your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">choice is right; and though all the mighty elf-friends of old, Hador, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">HÂ®rin, and TÂ®rin, and Beren himself were assembled together your seat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be among them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But you won't send him off alone surely, Master?' cried Sam, unable to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">contain himself any longer, and jumping up from the corner where he had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quietly sitting on the floor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No indeed!' said Elrond, turning towards him with a smile. 'You at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least shall go with him. It is hardly possible to separate you from him,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even when he is summoned to a secret council and you are not.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam sat down, blushing and muttering. 'A nice pickle we have landed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ourselves in, Mr. Frodo!â€™ he said, shaking his head.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 3 . The Ring Goes South<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Later that day the hobbits held a meeting of their own in Bilbo's room.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry and Pippin were indignant when they heard that Sam had crept into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Council, and had been chosen as Frodo's companion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's most unfair,' said Pippin. 'Instead of throwing him out, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clapping him in chains, Elrond goes and rewards him for his cheek!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Rewards!' said Frodo. 'I can't imagine a more severe punishment. You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are not thinking what you are saying: condemned to go on this hopeless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey, a reward? Yesterday I dreamed that my task was done, and I could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rest here, a long while, perhaps for good.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't wonder,' said Merry, 'and I wish you could. But we are envying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam, not you. If you have to go, then it will be a punishment for any of us<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be left behind, even in Rivendell. We have come a long way with you and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been through some stiff times. We want to go on.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That's what I meant,' said Pippin. 'We hobbits ought to stick<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">together, and we will. I shall go, unless they chain me up. There must be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">someone with intelligence in the party.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then you certainly will not be chosen, Peregrin Took!' said Gandalf,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking in through the window, which was near the ground. 'But you are all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worrying yourselves unnecessarily. Nothing is decided yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nothing decided!â€™ cried Pippin. â€™Then what were you all doing? You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were shut up for hours.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"Talking,' said Bilbo. 'There was a deal of talk, and everyone had an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eye-opener. Even old Gandalf. I think Legolas's bit of news about Gollum<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">caught even him on the hop, though he passed it off.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You were wrong,' said Gandalf. 'You were inattentive. I had already<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard of it from Gwaihir. If you want to know, the only real eye-openers, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you put it, were you and Frodo; and I was the only one that was not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">surprised.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, anyway,' said Bilbo, 'nothing was decided beyond choosing poor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo and Sam. I was afraid all the time that it might come to that, if I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was let off. But if you ask me, Elrond will send out a fair number, when the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reports come in. Have they started yet, Gandalf?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said the wizard. 'Some of the scouts have been sent out already.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">More will go tomorrow. Elrond is sending Elves, and they will get in touch<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the Rangers, and maybe with Thranduil's folk in Mirkwood. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has gone with Elrond's sons. We shall have to scour the lands all round for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many long leagues before any move is made. So cheer up, Frodo! You will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">probably make quite along stay here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah!' said Sam gloomily. 'We'll just wait long enough for winter to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That can't be helped,' said Bilbo. 'It's your fault partly, Frodo my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lad: insisting on waiting for my birthday. A funny way of honouring it, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can't help thinking. Not the day I should have chosen for letting the S.-B.s<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into Bag End. But there it is: you can't wait now fill spring; and you can't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go till the reports come back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When winter first begins to bite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and stones crack in the frosty night,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when pools are black and trees are bare,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'tis evil in the Wild to fare.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But that I am afraid will be just your luck.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am afraid it will,' said Gandalf. 'We can't start until we have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">found out about the Riders.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">T thought they were all destroyed in the flood,' said Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You cannot destroy Ringwraiths like that,' said Gandalf. 'The power of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their master is in them, and they stand or fall by him. We hope that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were all unhorsed and unmasked, and so made for a while less dangerous; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we must find out for certain. In the meantime you should try and forget your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">troubles, Frodo. I do not know if I can do anything to help you; but I will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whisper this in your ears. Someone said that intelligence would be needed in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the party. He was right. I think I shall come with you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So great was Frodo's delight at this announcement that Gandalf left the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">window-sill, where he had been sitting, and took off his hat and bowed. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only said I think I shall come. Do not count on anything yet. In this matter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond will have much to say, and your friend the Strider. Which reminds me,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I want to see Elrond. I must be off.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How long do you think I shall have here?â€™ said Frodo to Bilbo when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf had gone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh, I don't know. I can't count days in Rivendell,' said Bilbo. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quite long, I should think. We can have many a good talk. What about helping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me with my book, and making a start on the next? Have you thought of an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ending?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, several, and all are dark and unpleasant,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Oh, that won't do!' said Bilbo. 'Books ought to have good endings. How<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would this do: and they all settled down and lived together happily ever<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It will do well, if it ever comes to that,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah!' said Sam. 'And where will they live? That's what I often wonder.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For a while the hobbits continued to talk and think of the past journey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and of the perils that lay ahead; but such was the virtue of the land of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell that soon all fear and anxiety was lifted from their minds. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">future, good or ill, was not forgotten, but ceased to have any power over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the present. Health and hope grew strong in them, and they were content with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">each good day as it came, taking pleasure in every meal, and in every word<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and song.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So the days slipped away, as each morning dawned bright and fair, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">each evening followed cool and clear. But autumn was waning fast; slowly the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">golden light faded to pale silver, and the lingering leaves fell from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">naked trees. A wind began to blow chill from the Misty Mountains to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">east. The Hunter's Moon waxed round in the night sky, and put to flight all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the lesser stars. But low in the South one star shone red. Every night, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Moon waned again, it shone brighter and brighter. Frodo could see it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from his window, deep in the heavens burning like a watchful eye that glared<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">above the trees on the brink of the valley.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The hobbits had been nearly two months in the House of Elrond, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">November had gone by with the last shreds of autumn, and December was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passing, when the scouts began to return. Some had gone north beyond the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">springs of the Hoarwell into the Ettenmoors; and others had gone west, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the help of Aragorn and the Rangers had searched the lands far down the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Greyflood, as far as Tharbad, where the old North Road crossed the river by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a ruined town. Many had gone east and south; and some of these had crossed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Mountains and entered Mirkwood, while others had climbed the pass at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">source of the Gladden River, and had come down into Wilderland and over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gladden Fields and so at length had reached the old home of Radagast at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rhosgobel. Radagast was not there; and they had returned over the high pass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that was called the Dimrill Stair. The sons of Elrond, Elladan and Elrohir,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were the last to return; they had made a great journey, passing down the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Silverlode into a strange country, but of their errand they would not speak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to any save to Elrond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In no region had the messengers discovered any signs or tidings of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders or other servants of the Enemy. Even from the Eagles of the Misty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains they had learned no fresh news. Nothing had been seen or heard of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gollum; but the wild wolves were still gathering, and were hunting again far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up the Great River. Three of the black horses had been found at once drowned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the flooded Ford. On the rocks of the rapids below it searchers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">discovered the bodies of five more, and also a long black cloak, slashed and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tattered. Of the Black Riders no other trace was to be seen, and nowhere was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their presence to be felt. It seemed that they had vanished from the North.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Eight out of the Nine are accounted for at least,' said Gandalf. 'It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is rash to be too sure, yet I think that we may hope now that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ringwraiths were scattered, and have been obliged to return as best they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could to their Master in Mordor, empty and shapeless.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tf that is so, it will be some time before they can begin the hunt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. Of course the Enemy has other servants, but they will have to journey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the way to the borders of Rivendell before they can pick up our trail.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And if we are careful that will be hard to find. But we must delay no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond summoned the hobbits to him. He looked gravely at Frodo. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time has come,' he said. 'If the Ring is to set out, it must go soon. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those who go with it must not count on their errand being aided by war or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">force. They must pass into the domain of the Enemy far from aid. Do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still hold to your word, Frodo, that you will be the Ring-bearer?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do,' said Frodo. 'I will go with Sam.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then I cannot help you much, not even with counsel,' said Elrond. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can foresee very little of your road; and how your task is to be achieved I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">do not know. The Shadow has crept now to the feet of the Mountains, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">draws nigh even to the borders of Greyflood; and under the Shadow all is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark to me. You will meet many foes, some open, and some disguised; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may find friends upon your way when you least look for it. I will send out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">messages, such as I can contrive, to those whom I know in the wide world;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but so perilous are the lands now become that some may well miscarry, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come no quicker than you yourself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I will choose you companions to go with you, as far as they will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or fortune allows. The number must be few, since your hope is in speed and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secrecy. Had I a host of Elves in armour of the Elder Days, it would avail<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little, save to arouse the power of Mordor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The Company of the Ring shall be Nine; and the Nine Walkers shall be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set against the Nine Riders that are evil. With you and your faithful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">servant, Gandalf will go; for this shall be his great task, and maybe the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end of his labours.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'For the rest, they shall represent the other Free Peoples of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">World: Elves, Dwarves, and Men. Legolas shall be for the Elves; and Gimli<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">son of Gluin for the Dwarves. They are willing to go at least to the passes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Mountains, and maybe beyond. For men you shall have Aragorn son of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Arathorn, for the Ring of Isildur concerns him closely.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Strider!' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Yes,' he said with a smile. 'I ask leave once again to be your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companion, Frodo.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I would have begged you to come,â€™ said Frodo, 'only I thought you were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going to Minas Tirith with Boromir.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am,' said Aragorn. 'And the Sword-that-was-Broken shall be reforged<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ere I set out to war. But your road and our road lie together for many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hundreds of miles. Therefore Boromir will also be in the Company. He is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">valiant man.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™There remain two more to be found,' said Elrond. "These I will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">consider. Of my household I may find some that it seems good to me to send.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But that will leave no place for us!' cried Pippin in dismay. 'We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don't want to be left behind. We want to go with Frodo.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is because you do not understand and cannot imagine what lies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ahead,' said Elrond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Neither does Frodo,' said Gandalf, unexpectedly supporting Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nor do any of us see clearly. It is true that if these hobbits understood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the danger, they would not dare to go. But they would still wish to go, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish that they dared, and be shamed and unhappy. I think, Elrond, that in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this matter it would be well to trust rather to their friendship than to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could not storm the Dark Tower, nor open the road to the Fire by the power<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is in him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You speak gravely,' said Elrond, 'but I am in doubt. The Shire, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back there as messengers, to do what they could, according to the fashion of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their country, to warn the people of their danger. In any case, I judge that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the younger of these two, Peregrin Took, should remain. My heart is against<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his going.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then, Master Elrond, you will have to lock me in prison, or send me<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Company.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let it be so then. You shall go,â€™ said Elrond, and he sighed. 'Now the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tale of Nine is filled. In seven days the Company must depart.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Sword of Elendil was forged anew by Elvish smiths, and on its blade<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was traced a device of seven stars set between the crescent Moon and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rayed Sun, and about them was written many runes; for Aragorn son of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Arathorn was going to war upon the marches of Mordor. Very bright was that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the light of the moon shone cold, and its edge was hard and keen. And<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn gave it a new name and called it AndÂ®ril, Flame of the West.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn and Gandalf walked together or sat speaking of their road and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the perils they would meet; and they pondered the storied and figured maps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and books of lore that were in the house of Elrond. Sometimes Frodo was with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them; but he was content to lean on their guidance, and he spent as much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In those last days the hobbits sat together in the evening in the Hall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Fire, and there among many tales they heard told in full the lay of Beren<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and LÂ®thien and the winning of the Great Jewel; but in the day, while Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still seemed very incomplete), or scraps of his verses, or would take notes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the morning of the last day Frodo was alone with Bilbo, and the old<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here is your sword,' he said. 'But it was broken, you know. I took it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to keep it safe but I've forgotten to ask if the smiths could mend it. No<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time now.. So I thought, perhaps, you would care to have this, don't you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He took from the box a small sword in an old shabby leathern scabbard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo accepted it gratefully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Also there is this!' said Bilbo, bringing out a parcel which seemed to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's a pretty thing, isn't it?' said Bilbo, moving it in the light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And useful. It is my dwarf-mail that Thorin gave me. I got it back from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Michel Delving before I started, and packed it with my luggage: I brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the mementoes of my Journey away with me, except the Ring. But I did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expect to use this, and I don't need it now, except to look at sometimes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You hardly feel any weight when you put it on.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I should look â€” well, I don't think I should look right in it,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Just what I said myself,â€™ said Bilbo. 'But never mind about looks. You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
