<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with me. Don't tell anybody else! But I should feel happier if I knew you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Riders,' he ended in a low voice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well, I will take it,' said Frodo. Bilbo put it on him, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fastened Sting upon the glittering belt; and then Frodo put over the top his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old weather-stained breeches, tunic, and jacket.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Just a plain hobbit you look,' said Bilbo. 'But there is more about<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Don't try!' said the old hobbit, turning round and slapping him on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hobbits must stick together, and especially Bagginses. All I ask in return<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is: take as much care of yourself as you can. and bring back all the news<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I am spared.' He broke off and turned to the window again, singing softly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I sit beside the fire and think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of all that I have seen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of meadow-flowers and butterflies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in summers that have been;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of yellow leaves and gossamer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in autumns that there were,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with morning mist and silver sun<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and wind upon my hair.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I sit beside the fire and think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of how the world will be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when winter comes without a spring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I shall ever see.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For still there are so many things<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I have never seen:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in every wood in every spring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there is a different green.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I sit beside the fire and think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of people long ago,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and people who will see a world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I shall never know.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But all the while I sit and think<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of times there were before,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I listen for returning feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and voices at the door.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was a cold grey day near the end of December. The East Wind was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">streaming through the bare branches of the trees, and seething in the dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pines on the hills. Ragged clouds were hurrying overhead, dark and low. As<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cheerless shadows of the early evening began to fall the Company made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ready to set out. They were to start at dusk, for Elrond counselled them to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You should fear the many eyes of the servants of Sauron,' he said. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company took little gear of war, for their hope was in secrecy not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Loud and clear it sounds in the valleys of the hills,' he said, 'and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then let all the foes of Gondor flee!â€™ Putting it to his lips he blew a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blast, and the echoes leapt from rock to rock, and all that heard that voice<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slow should you be to wind that horn again, Boromir, said Elrond.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'until you stand once more on the borders of your land, and dire need is on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe,' said Boromir. 'But always I have let my horn cry at setting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forth, and though thereafter we may walk in the shadows, I will not go forth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli the dwarf alone wore openly a short shirt of steel-rings, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarves make light of burdens; and in his belt was a broad-bladed axe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas had a bow and a quiver, and at his belt a long white knife. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">younger hobbits wore the swords that they had taken from the barrow; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo took only Sting; and his mail-coat, as Bilbo wished, remained hidden.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf bore his staff, but girt at his side was the elven-sword Glamdring,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the mate of Orcrist that lay now upon the breast of Thorin under the Lonely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All were well furnished by Elrond with thick warm clothes, and they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jackets and cloaks lined with fur. Spare food and clothes and blankets and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">other needs were laden on a pony, none other than the poor beast that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had brought from Bree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">?he stay in Rivendell had worked a great wonder of change on him: he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was glossy and seemed to have the vigour of youth. It was Sam who had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">insisted on choosing him, declaring that Bill (as he called him) would pine,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if he did not come.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That animal can nearly talk,' he said, 'and would talk, if he stayed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here much longer. He gave me a look as plain as Mr. Pippin could speak it:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if you don't let me go with you, Sam, I'll follow on my own.' So Bill was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going as the beast of burden, yet he was the only member of the Company that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did not seem depressed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their farewells had been said in the great hall by the fire, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were only waiting now for Gandalf, who had not yet come out of the house. A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gleam of firelight came from the open doors, and soft lights were glowing in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many windows. Bilbo huddled in a cloak stood silent on the doorstep beside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo. Aragorn sat with his head bowed to his knees; only Elrond knew fully<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what this hour meant to him. The others could be seen as grey shapes in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">darkness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam was standing by the pony, sucking his teeth, and staring moodily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the gloom where the river roared stonily below; his desire for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">adventure was at its lowest ebb.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Bill, my lad,â€™ he said, 'you oughtn't to have took up with us. You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could have stayed here and et the best hay till the new grass comes.' Bill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swished his tail and said nothing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam eased the pack on his shoulders, and went over anxiously in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mind all the things that he had stowed in it, wondering if he had forgotten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything: his chief treasure, his cooking gear; and the little box of salt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he always carried and refilled when he could; a good supply of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pipe- weed (but not near enough, I'll warrant); flint and tinder; woollen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hose: linen; various small belongings of his master's that Frodo had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgotten and Sam had stowed to bring them out in triumph when they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">called for. He went through them all.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Rope!' he muttered. 'No rope! And only last night you said to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yourself: "Sam, what about a bit of rope? You'll want it, if you haven't got<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it:" Well, I'll want it. I can't get it now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment Elrond came out with Gandalf, and he called the Company<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to him. 'This is my last word,' he said in a low voice. 'The Ring-bearer is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">setting out on the Quest of Mount Doom. On him alone is any charge laid:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither to cast away the Ring, nor to deliver it to any servant of the Enemy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nor indeed to let any handle it, save members of the Company and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Council, and only then in gravest need. The others go with him as free<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">companions, to help him on his way. You may tarry, or come back, or turn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside into other paths, as chance allows. The further you go, the less easy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will it be to withdraw; yet no oath or bond is laid on you to go further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than you will. For you do not yet know the strength of your hearts, and you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cannot foresee what each may meet upon the road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Faithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens,' said Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe,' said Elrond, 'but let him not vow to walk in the dark, who has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not seen the nightfall.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yet sworn word may strengthen quaking heart,' said Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Or break it,' said Elrond. 'Look not too far ahead! But go now with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good hearts ! Farewell, and may the blessing of Elves and Men and all Free<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Folk go with you. May the stars shine upon your faces!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good . . . good luck!' cried Bilbo, stuttering with the cold. 'I don't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suppose you will be able to keep a diary, Frodo my lad, but I shall expect a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">full account when you get back. And don't be too long! Farewell!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Many others of Elrond's household stood in the shadows and watched them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go, bidding them farewell with soft voices. There was no laughter, and no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">song or music. At last they turned away and faded silently into the dusk.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They crossed the bridge and wound slowly up the long steep paths that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">led out of the cloven vale of Rivendell; and they came at length to the high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moor where the wind hissed through the heather. Then with one glance at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Last Flomely Flouse twinkling below them they strode away far into the night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the Ford of Bruinen they left the Road and turning southwards went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on by narrow paths among the folded lands. Their purpose was to hold this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">course west of the Mountains for many miles and days. The country was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rougher and more barren than in the green vale of the Great River in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wilderland on the other side of the range, and their going would be slow;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but they hoped in this way to escape the notice of unfriendly eyes. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spies of Sauron had hitherto seldom been seen in this empty country, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paths were little known except to the people of Rivendell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf walked in front, and with him went Aragorn, who knew this land<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even in the dark. The others were in file behind, and Legolas whose eyes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were keen was the rearguard. The first part of their journey was hard and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dreary, and Frodo remembered little of it, save the wind. For many sunless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days an icy blast came from the Mountains in the east, and no garment seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">able to keep out its searching fingers. Though the Company was well clad,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they seldom felt warm, either moving or at rest. They slept uneasily during<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the middle of the day, in some hollow of the land, or hidden under the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tangled thorn-bushes that grew in thickets in many places. In the late<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afternoon they were roused by the watch, and took their chief meal: cold and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cheerless as a rule, for they could seldom risk the lighting of a fire. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the evening they went on again, always as nearly southward as they could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">find a way.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first it seemed to the hobbits that although they walked and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stumbled until they were weary, they were creeping forward like snails, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">getting nowhere. Each day the land looked much the same as it had the day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before. Yet steadily the mountains were drawing nearer. South of Rivendell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they rose ever higher, and bent westwards; and about the feet of the main<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">range there was tumbled an ever wider land of bleak hills, and deep valleys<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">filled with turbulent waters. Paths were few and winding, and led them often<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only to the edge of some sheer fall, or down into treacherous swamps.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had been a fortnight on the way when the weather changed. The wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">suddenly fell and then veered round to the south. The swift-flowing clouds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lifted and melted away, and the sun came out, pale and bright. There came a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold clear dawn at the end of a long stumbling night-march. The travellers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reached a low ridge crowned with ancient holly -trees whose grey-green trunks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to have been built out of the very stone of the hills. Their dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves shone and their berries glowed red in the light of the rising sun.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Away in the south Frodo could see the dim shapes of lofty mountains<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that seemed now to stand across the path that the Company was taking. At the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left of this high range rose three peaks; the tallest and nearest stood up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a tooth tipped with snow; its great, bare, northern precipice was still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">largely in the shadow, but where the sunlight slanted upon it, it glowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">red.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf stood at Frodoâ€™s side and looked out under his hand. 'We have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">done well,â€™ he said. 'We have reached the borders of the country that Men<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">call Hollin; many Elves lived here in happier days, when Eregion was its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name. Five-and-forty leagues as the crow flies we have come, though many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long miles further our feet have walked. The land and the weather will be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">milder now, but perhaps all the more dangerous.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dangerous or not, a real sunrise is mighty welcome,â€™ said Frodo,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">throwing back his hood and letting the morning light fall on his face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™But the mountains are ahead of us,â€™ said Pippin. 'We must have turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastwards in the night.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No,' said Gandalf. 'But you see further ahead in the clear light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beyond those peaks the range bends round south-west. There are many maps<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elrond's house, but I suppose you never thought to look at them?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes I did, sometimes,' said Pippin, 'but I don't remember them. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">has a better head for that sort of thing.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I need no map,' said Gimli, who had come up with Legolas, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gazing out before him with a strange light in his deep eyes. 'There is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land where our fathers worked of old, and we have wrought the image of those<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains into many works of metal and of stone, and into many songs and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tales. They stand tall in our dreams: Baraz, Zirak, Shathyr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Only once before have I seen them from afar in waking life, but I know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them and their names, for under them lies Khazad-dym, the Dwarrowdelf, that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is now called the Black Pit, Moria in the Elvish tongue. Yonder stands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Barazinbar, the Redhorn, cruel Caradhras; and beyond him are Silvertine and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Cloudyhead: Celebdil the White, and Fanuidhol the Grey, that we call<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Zirak-zigil and Bundushathyr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There the Misty Mountains divide, and between their arms lies the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep-shadowed valley which we cannot forget: Azanulbizar, the Dimrill Dale,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which the Elves call Nanduhirion.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is for the Dimrill Dale that we are making,' said Gandalf. 'If we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climb the pass that is called the Redhorn Gate, under the far side of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Caradhras, we shall come down by the Dimrill Stair into the deep vale of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dwarves. There lies the Mirrormere, and there the River Silverlode rises in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its icy springs.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dark is the water of Kheled-zvram,' said Gimli, 'and cold are the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">springs of Kibil-nvla. My heart trembles at the thought that I may see them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'May you have joy of the sight, my good dwarf f said Gandalf. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whatever you may do, we at least cannot stay in that valley. We must go down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Silverlode into the secret woods, and so to the Great River, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">f<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He paused.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes, and where then?' asked Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'To the end of the journey â€” in the end,' said Gandalf. 'We cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look too far ahead. Let us be glad that the first stage is safely over. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think we will rest here, not only today but tonight as well. There is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wholesome air about Hollin. Much evil must befall a country before it wholly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forgets the Elves, if once they dwelt there.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That is true,' said Legolas. 'But the Elves of this land were of a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">race strange to us of the silvan folk, and the trees and the grass do not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now remember them: Only I hear the stones lament them: deep they delved us,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fair they wrought us, high they builded us; but they are gone. They are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone. They sought the Elavens long ago.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That morning they lit a fire in a deep hollow shrouded by great bushes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of holly, and their supper -breakfast was merrier than it had been since they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the night to sleep in, and they did not mean to go on again until the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he left the Company and wandered on to the ridge; there he stood in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as if he was listening. Then he returned to the brink of the dell and looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is the matter, Strider?â€™ Merry called up. â€™What are you looking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for? Do you miss the East Wind?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™No indeed,â€™ he answered. 'But I miss something. I have been in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">country of Hollin in many seasons. No folk dwell here now, but many other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">creatures live here at all times, especially birds. Yet now all things but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you are silent. I can feel it. There is no sound for miles about us, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your voices seem to make the ground echo. I do not understand it.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf looked up with sudden interest. 'But what do you guess is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reason?â€™ he asked. 'Is there more in it than surprise at seeing four<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbits, not to mention the rest of us, where people are so seldom seen or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I hope that is it,â€™ answered Aragorn. 'But I have a sense of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watchfulness, and of fear, that I have never had here before.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"Then we must be more careful,â€™ said Gandalf. â€™If you bring a Ranger<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with you, it is well to pay attention to him, especially if the Ranger is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn. We must stop talking aloud, rest quietly, and set the watch.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was Samâ€™s turn that day to take the first watch, but Aragorn joined<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him. The others fell asleep. Then the silence grew until even Sam felt it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The breathing of the sleepers could be plainly heard. The swish of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ponyâ€™s tail and the occasional movements of his feet became loud noises. Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, and over all hung a clear blue sky, as the Sun rode up from the East.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Away in the South a dark patch appeared, and grew, and drove north like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flying smoke in the wind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What's that, Strider? It donâ€™t look like a cloud,' said Sam in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whisper to Aragorn. He made no answer, he was gazing intently at the sky;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but before long Sam could see for himself what was approaching. Flocks of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">birds, flying at great speed, were wheeling and circling, and traversing all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the land as if they were searching for something; and they were steadily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lie flat and still!' hissed Aragorn, pulling Sam down into the shade<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were a kind of crow of large size. As they passed overhead, in so dense<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not until they had dwindled into the distance, north and west, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Regiments of black crows are flying over all the land between the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mountains and the Greyflood,' he said, 'and they have passed over Hollin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They are not natives here; they are crebain out of Fangorn and Dunland. I do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not know what they are about: possibly there is some trouble away south from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">also glimpsed many hawks flying high up in the sky. I think we ought to move<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And in that case so is the Redhorn Gate,' said Gandalf; 'and how we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can get over that without being seen, I cannot imagine. But we will think of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Luckily our fire made little smoke, and had burned low before the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well if that isn't a plague and a nuisance!' said Pippin. The news: no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, you can go on looking forward,' said Gandalf. 'There may be many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unexpected feasts ahead for you. For myself I should like a pipe to smoke in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">comfort, and warmer feet. However, we are certain of one thing at any rate:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it will get warmer as we get south.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Too warm, I shouldn't wonder,' muttered Sam to Frodo. 'But I'm<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning to think it's time we got a sight of that Fiery Mountain and saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or whatever its name is, might be it, till Gimli spoke his piece. A fair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All that day the Company remained in hiding. The dark birds passed over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Guided by Aragorn they struck a good path. It looked to Frodo like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Many of them looked to have been worked by hands, though now they lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was the cold chill hour before the first stir of dawn, and the moon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, but I felt it, whatever it was,' he answered. 'It may be nothing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was moving fast then,' muttered Aragorn, 'and not with the wind.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nothing further happened that night. The next morning dawned even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
