<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains towered up, nearer and nearer. On the third morning Caradhras rose<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before them, a mighty peak, tipped with snow like silver, but with sheer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">naked sides, dull red as if stained with blood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a black look in the sky, and the sun was wan. The wind had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gone now round to the north-east. Gandalf snuffed the air and looked back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Winter deepens behind us,' he said quietly to Aragorn. 'The heights<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away north are whiter than they were; snow is lying far down their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulders. Tonight we shall be on our way high up towards the Redhorn Gate.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We may well be seen by watchers on that narrow path, and waylaid by some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil; but the weather may prove a more deadly enemy than any. What do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think of your course now, Aragorn?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo overheard these words, and understood that Gandalf and Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were continuing some debate that had begun long before. He listened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anxiously.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I think no good of our course from beginning to end, as you know well,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf,' answered Aragorn. 'And perils known and unknown will grow as we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on. But we must go on; and it is no good our delaying the passage of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains. Further south there are no passes, till one comes to the Gap of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rohan. I do not trust that way since your news of Saruman. Who knows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side now the marshals of the Horse-lords serve?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Who knows indeed!' said Gandalf. 'But there is another way, and not by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pass of Caradhras: the dark and secret way that we have spoken of.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But let us not speak of it again! Not yet. Say nothing to the others I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beg, not until it is plain that there is no other way.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We must decide before we go further,' answered Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then let us weigh the matter in our minds, while the others rest and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep,' said Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the late afternoon, while the others were finishing their breakfast,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf and Aragorn went aside together and stood looking at Caradhras. Its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sides were now dark and sullen, and its head was in grey cloud. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watched them, wondering which way the debate would go. When they returned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Company Gandalf spoke, and then he knew that it had been decided to face<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the weather and the high pass. He was relieved. He could not guess what was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the other dark and secret way, but the very mention of it had seemed to fill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn with dismay, and Frodo was glad that it had been abandoned.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'From signs that we have seen lately,â€™ said Gandalf, â€™I fear that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Redhorn Gate may be watched; and also I have doubts of the weather that is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">coming up behind. Snow may come. We must go with all the speed that we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Even so it will take us more than two marches before we reach the top of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pass. Dark will come early this evening. We must leave as soon as you can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get ready.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will add a word of advice, if I may,' said Boromir. 'I was born<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the shadow of the White Mountains and know something of journeys<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the high places. We shall meet bitter cold, if no worse, before we come down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the other side. It will not help us to keep so secret that we are frozen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to death. When we leave here, where there are still a few trees and bushes,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">each of us should carry a faggot of wood, as large as he can bear.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And Bill could take a bit more, couldn't you lad?' said Sam. The pony<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked at him mournfully.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Very well,' said Gandalf. 'But we must not use the wood â€” not unless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it is a choice between fire and death.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company set out again with good speed at first; but soon their way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">became steep and difficult. The twisting and climbing road had in many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places almost disappeared, and was blocked with many fallen stones. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night grew deadly dark under great clouds. A bitter wind swirled among the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rocks. By midnight they had climbed to the knees of the great mountains. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">narrow path now wound under a sheer wall of cliffs to the left, above which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the grim flanks of Caradhras towered up invisible in the gloom; on the right<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a gulf of darkness where the land fell suddenly into a deep ravine.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Laboriously they climbed a sharp slope and halted for a moment at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">top. Frodo felt a soft touch on his face. He put out his arm and saw the dim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white flakes of snow settling on his sleeve.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went on. But before long the snow was falling fast, filling all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the air, and swirling into Frodo's eyes. The dark bent shapes of Gandalf and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn only a pace or two ahead could hardly be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't like this at all,' panted Sam just behind. 'Snow's all right<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on a fine morning, but I like to be in bed while it's falling. I wish this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lot would go off to Hobbiton! Folk might welcome it there.' Except on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high moors of the Northfarthing a heavy fall was rare in the Shire, and was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">regarded as a pleasant event and a chance for fun. No living hobbit (save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Bilbo) could remember the Fell Winter of 131 1, when the white wolves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">invaded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Shire over the frozen Brandywine.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf halted. Snow was thick on his hood and shoulders; it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already ankle-deep about his boots.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">"This is what I feared,' he said. 'What do you say now, Aragorn?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That I feared it too,' Aragorn answered, 'but less than other things.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I knew the risk of snow, though it seldom falls heavily so far south, save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high up in the mountains. But we are not high yet; we are still far down,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the paths are usually open all the winter.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wonder if this is a contrivance of the Enemy,' said Boromir. "They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say in my land that he can govern the storms in the Mountains of Shadow that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stand upon the borders of Mordor. He has strange powers and many allies.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'His arm has grown long indeed,' said Gimli, 'if he can draw snow down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the North to trouble us here three hundred leagues away.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'His arm has grown long,' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While they were halted, the wind died down, and the snow slackened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">until it almost ceased. They tramped on again. But they had not gone more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than a furlong when the storm returned with fresh fury. The wind whistled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the snow became a blinding blizzard. Soon even Boromir found it hard to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">keep going. The hobbits, bent nearly double, toiled along behind the taller<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folk, but it was plain that they could not go much further, if the snow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">continued. Frodo's feet felt like lead. Pippin was dragging behind. Even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli, as stout as any dwarf could be, was grumbling as he trudged.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company halted suddenly, as if they had come to an agreement<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without any words being spoken. They heard eerie noises in the darkness<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round them. It may have been only a trick of the wind in the cracks and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gullies of the rocky wall, but the sounds were those of shrill cries, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wild howls of laughter. Stones began to fall from the mountain-side,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whistling over their heads, or crashing on the path beside them. Every now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and again they heard a dull rumble, as a great boulder rolled down from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hidden heights above.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We cannot go further tonight,' said Boromir. 'Let those call it the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind who will; there are fell voices on the air; and these stones are aimed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at us.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do call it the wind,' said Aragorn. 'But that does not make what you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say untrue. There are many evil and unfriendly things in the world that have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little love for those that go on two legs, and yet are not in league with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sauron, but have purposes of their own. Some have been in this world longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than he.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Caradhras was called the Cruel, and had an ill name, said Gimli, 'long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">years ago, when rumour of Sauron had not been heard in these lands.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It matters little who is the enemy, if we cannot beat off his attack;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But what can we do?' cried Pippin miserably. He was leaning on Merry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Frodo, and he was shivering.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Either stop where we are, or go back,' said Gandalf. â€™It is no good<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going on. Only a little higher, if I remember rightly, this path leaves the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cliff and runs into a wide shallow trough at the bottom of a long hard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slope. We should have no shelter there from snow, or stones â€” or anything<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">else.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And it is no good going back while the storm holds,' said Aragorn. 'We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have passed no place on the way up that offered more shelter than this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cliff-wall we are under now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Shelter!' muttered Sam. 'If this is shelter, then one wall and no roof<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make a house.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company now gathered together as close to the cliff as they could.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It faced southwards, and near the bottom it leaned out a little, so that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they hoped it would give them some protection from the northerly wind and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the falling stones. But eddying blasts swirled round them from every<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side, and the snow flowed down in ever denser clouds.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They huddled together with their backs to the wall. Bill the pony stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">patiently but dejectedly in front of the hobbits, and screened them a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little; but before long the drifting snow was above his hocks, and it went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on mounting. If they had had no larger companions the hobbits would soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have been entirely buried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A great sleepiness came over Frodo; he felt himself sinking fast into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">warm and hazy dream. He thought a fire was heating his toes, and out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadows on the other side of the hearth he heard Bilbo's voice speaking. /<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">don 't think much of your diary , he said. Snowstorms on January the twelfth:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was no need to come back to report that!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But I wanted rest and sleep, Bilbo , Frodo answered with an effort, when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he felt himself shaken, and he came back painfully to wakefulness. Boromir<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had lifted him off the ground out of a nest of snow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'This will be the death of the halflings, Gandalf,' said Boromir. 'It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is useless to sit here until the snow goes over our heads. We must do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something to save ourselves.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Give them this,â€™ said Gandalf, searching in his pack and drawing out a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leathern flask. 'Just a mouthful each â€” for all of us. It is very precious.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It is miruvor, the cordial of Imladris. Elrond gave it to me at our parting.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Pass it round!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as Frodo had swallowed a little of the warm and fragrant liquor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he felt a new strength of heart, and the heavy drowsiness left his limbs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others also revived and found fresh hope and vigour. But the snow did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not relent. It whirled about them thicker than ever, and the wind blew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">louder.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What do you say to fire?â€™ asked Boromir suddenly. â€™The choice seems<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near now between fire and death, Gandalf. Doubtless we shall be hidden from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all unfriendly eyes when the snow has covered us, but that will not help<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™You may make a fire, if you can,â€™ answered Gandalf. â€™If there are any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">watchers that can endure this storm, then they can see us, fire or no.â€™ But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though they had brought wood and kindlings by the advice of Boromir, it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed the skill of Elf or even Dwarf to strike a flame that would hold amid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the swirling wind or catch in the wet fuel. At last reluctantly Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself took a hand. Picking up a faggot he held it aloft for a moment, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then with a word of command, naur an edraith ammen ! he thrust the end of his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">staff into the midst of it. At once a great spout of green and blue flame<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprang out, and the wood flared and sputtered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If there are any to see, then I at least am revealed to them,â€™ he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said. â€™I have written Gandalf is here in signs that all can read from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell to the mouths of Anduin.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the Company cared no longer for watchers or unfriendly eyes. Their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hearts were rejoiced to see the light of the fire. The wood burned merrily;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and though all round it the snow hissed, and pools of slush crept under<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their feet, they warmed their hands gladly at the blaze. There they stood,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stooping in a circle round the little dancing and blowing flames. A red<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light was on their tired and anxious faces; behind them the night was like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">black wall.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But the wood was burning fast, and the snow still fell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The fire burned low. and the last faggot was thrown on.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The night is getting old,' said Aragorn. "The dawn is not far off.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If any dawn can pierce these clouds,' said Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir stepped out of the circle and stared up into the blackness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The snow is growing less,' he said, 'and the wind is quieter.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo gazed wearily at the flakes still falling out of the dark to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">revealed white for a moment in the light of the dying fire; but for a long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time he could see no sign of their slackening. Then suddenly, as sleep was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning to creep over him again, he was aware that the wind had indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fallen, and the flakes were becoming larger and fewer. Very slowly a dim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light began to grow. At last the snow stopped altogether.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As the light grew stronger it showed a silent shrouded world. Below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their refuge were white humps and domes and shapeless deeps beneath which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the path that they had trodden was altogether lost; but the heights above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were hidden in great clouds still heavy with the threat of snow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli looked up and shook his head. 'Caradhras has not forgiven us.' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said. 'He has more snow yet to fling at us, if we go on. The sooner we go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back and down the better.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To this all agreed, but their retreat was now difficult. It might well<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prove impossible. Only a few paces from the ashes of their fire the snow lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many feet deep, higher than the heads of the hobbits; in places it had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If Gandalf would go before us with a bright flame, he might melt a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">path for you,' said Legolas. The storm had troubled him little, and he alone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Company remained still light of heart.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If Elves could fly over mountains, they might fetch the Sun to save<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us,â€™ answered Gandalf. 'But I must have something to work on. I cannot burn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snow.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well,' said Boromir, 'when heads are at a loss bodies must serve, as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we say in my country. The strongest of us must seek a way. See! Though all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is now snow-clad, our path, as we came up, turned about that shoulder of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rock down yonder. It was there that the snow first began to burden us. If we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could reach that point, maybe it would prove easier beyond. It is no more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than a furlong off, I guess.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then let us force a path thither, you and I!â€™ said Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn was the tallest of the Company, but Boromir, little less in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">height, was broader and heavier in build. He led the way, and Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed him. Slowly they moved off, and were soon toiling heavily. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places the snow was breast-high, and often Boromir seemed to be swimming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">burrowing with his great arms rather than walking.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas watched them for a while with a smile upon his lips, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he turned to the others. 'The strongest must seek a way, say you? But I say:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">let a ploughman plough, but choose an otter for swimming, and for running<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light over grass and leaf or over snow-an Elf.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With that he sprang forth nimbly, and then Frodo noticed as if for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">first time, though he had long known it, that the Elf had no boots, but wore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only light shoes, as he always did, and his feet made little imprint in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Farewell!' he said to Gandalf. 'I go to find the Sun!' Then swift as a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">runner over firm sand he shot away, and quickly overtaking the toiling men,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a wave of his hand he passed them, and sped into the distance, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vanished round the rocky turn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others waited huddled together, watching until Boromir and Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwindled into black specks in the whiteness. At length they too passed from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sight. The time dragged on. The clouds lowered, and now a few flakes of snow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came curling down again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">An hour, maybe, went by, though it seemed far longer, and then at last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they saw Legolas coming back. At the same time Boromir and Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reappeared round the bend far behind him and came labouring up the slope.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well,' cried Legolas as he ran up, 'I have not brought the Sun. She is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walking in the blue fields of the South, and a little wreath of snow on this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Redhorn hillock troubles her not at all. But I have brought back a gleam of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good hope for those who are doomed to go on feet. There is the greatest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind-drift of all just beyond the turn, and there our Strong Men were almost<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">buried. They despaired, until I returned and told them that the drift was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">little wider than a wall. And on the other side the snow suddenly grows<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">less, while further down it is no more than a white coverlet to cool a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit's toes.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah, it is as I said,' growled Gimli. 'It was no ordinary storm. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ill will of Caradhras. He does not love Elves and Dwarves, and that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drift was laid to cut off our escape.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But happily your Caradhras has forgotten that you have Men with you,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Boromir, who came up at that moment. 'And doughty Men too, if I may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">say<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it; though lesser men with spades might have served you better. Still, we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have thrust a lane through the drift; and for that all here may be grateful<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who cannot run as light as Elves.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But how are we to get down there, even if you have cut through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drift?' said Pippin, voicing the thought of all the hobbits.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Have hope!' said Boromir. 'I am weary, but I still have some strength<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left, and Aragorn too. We will bear the little folk. The others no doubt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will make shift to tread the path behind us. Come, Master Peregrin! I will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">begin with you.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He lifted up the hobbit. 'Cling to my back! I shall need my arms' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said and strode forward. Aragorn with Merry came behind. Pippin marvelled at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his strength, seeing the passage that he had already forced with no other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tool than his great limbs. Even now, burdened as he was, he was widening the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">track for those who followed, thrusting the snow aside as he went.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They came at length to the great drift. It was flung across the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountain-path like a sheer and sudden wall, and its crest, sharp as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shaped with knives, reared up more than twice the height of Boromir; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the middle a passage had been beaten, rising and falling like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bridge. On the far side Merry and Pippin were set down, and there they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waited with Legolas for the rest of the Company to arrive.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a while Boromir returned carrying Sam. Behind in the narrow but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now well-trodden track came Gandalf, leading Bill with Gimli perched among<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the baggage. Last came Aragorn carrying Frodo. They passed through the lane;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but hardly had Frodo touched the ground when with a deep rumble there rolled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down a fall of stones and slithering snow. The spray of it half blinded the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Company as they crouched against the cliff, and when the air cleared again<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they saw that the path was blocked behind them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Enough, enough!' cried Gimli. 'We are departing as quickly as we may!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And indeed with that last stroke the malice of the mountain seemed to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">expended, as if Caradhras was satisfied that the invaders had been beaten<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off and would not dare to return. The threat of snow lifted; the clouds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to break and the light grew broader.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Legolas had reported, they found that the snow became steadily more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shallow as they went down, so that even the hobbits could trudge along. Soon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they all stood once more on the flat shelf at the head of the steep slope<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where they had felt the first flakes of snow the night before.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The morning was now far advanced. From the high place they looked back<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">westwards over the lower lands. Far away in the tumble of country that lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at the foot of the mountain was the dell from which they had started to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climb the pass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodoâ€™s legs ached. He was chilled to the bone and hungry; and his head<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was dizzy as he thought of the long and painful march downhill. Black specks<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swam before his eyes. He rubbed them, but the black specks remained. In the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">distance below him, but still high above the lower foothills, dark dots were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">circling in the air.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The birds again!â€™ said Aragorn, pointing down.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That cannot be helped now,â€™ said Gandalf. 'Whether they are good or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil, or have nothing to do with us at all, we must go down at once. Not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even on the knees of Caradhras will we wait for another night-fall!â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A cold wind flowed down behind them, as they turned their backs on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Redhorn Gate, and stumbled wearily down the slope. Caradhras had defeated<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 4 . A Journey in the Dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was evening, and the grey light was again waning fast, when they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halted for the night. They were very weary. The mountains were veiled in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deepening dusk, and the wind was cold. Gandalf spared them one more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">each of the miruvor of Rivendell. When they had eaten some food he called a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We cannot, of course, go on again tonight,' he said. 'The attack on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And then where are we to go? â€™ asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We still have our journey and our errand before us,' answered Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have no choice but to go on, or to return to Rivendell.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wish I was back there,â€™ he said. 'But how can I return without shame<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€” unless there is indeed no other way, and we are already defeated? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are right, Frodo,' said Gandalf: 'to go back is to admit defeat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there: we shall not be able to set out again. Then sooner or later Rivendell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Ringwraiths are deadly enemies, but they are only shadows yet of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">power and terror they would possess if the Ruling Ring was on their master's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then we must go on, if there is a way,' said Frodo with a sigh. Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sank back into gloom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There is a way that we may attempt,' said Gandalf. I thought from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beginning, when first I considered this journey, that we should try it. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it is not a pleasant way, and I have not spoken of it to the Company before.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn was against it, until the pass over the mountains had at least been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If it is a worse road than the Redhorn Gate, then it must be evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">indeed,' said Merry. 'But you had better tell us about it, and let us know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The road that I speak of leads to the Mines of Moria,' said Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Only Gimli lifted up his head; a smouldering fire was in his eyes. On all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the others a dread fell at the mention of that name. Even to the hobbits it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a legend of vague fear:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The road may lead to Moria, but how can we hope that it will lead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through Moria? â€™ said Aragorn darkly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is a name of ill omen,' said Boromir. 'Nor do I see the need to go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there. If we cannot cross the mountains, let us journey southwards, until we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come to the Gap of Rohan, where men are friendly to my people, taking the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">road that I followed on my way hither. Or we might pass by and cross the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Isen into Langstrand and Lebennin, and so come to Gondor from the regions<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nigh to the sea.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Things have changed since you came north, Boromir,' answered Gandalf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of my own ere all is over. But the Ring must not come near Isengard, if that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can by any means be prevented. The Gap of Rohan is closed to us while we go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As for the longer road: we cannot afford the time. We might spend a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year in such a journey, and we should pass through many lands that are empty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and harbourless. Yet they would not be safe. The watchful eyes both of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the Enemy's eyes only one stray wanderer from the South and a matter of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you return now as a member of the Ring's Company, and you are in peril as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Since our open attempt on the mountain -pass our plight has become more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desperate, I fear. I see now little hope, if we do not soon vanish from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither over the mountains, nor round them, but under them. That is a road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at any rate that the Enemy will least expect us to take.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We do not know what he expects,' said Boromir. 'lie may watch all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roads, likely and unlikely. In that case to enter Moria would be to walk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">itself. The name of Moria is black.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You speak of what you do not know, when you liken Moria to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the dungeons of the Dark Lord, and only in his older and lesser dwelling in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dol Guldur. Those who pass the gates of Barad-dyr do not return. But I would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are Ores there, it may prove ill for us, that is true. But most of the Ores<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Misty Mountains were scattered or destroyed in the Battle of Five<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Armies. The Eagles report that Ores are gathering again from afar; but there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™I will tread the path with you, Gandalf! â€™ said Gimli. â€™I will go and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look on the halls of Durin, whatever may wait there-if you can find the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors that are shut.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good, Gimli! ' said Gandalf. 'You encourage me. We will seek the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I too once passed the Dimrill Gate,' said Aragorn quietly; 'but though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I don't wish to enter it even once,' said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nor me,' muttered Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Of course not! ' said Gandalf. 'Who would? But the question is: who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will,' said Gimli eagerly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will,' said Aragorn heavily. 'You followed my lead almost to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">disaster in the snow, and have said no word of blame. I will follow your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The morning was passing towards noon, and still the Company wandered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
