<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly Gimli, who had pressed on ahead, called back to them. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">standing on a knoll and pointing to the right. Hurrying up they saw below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them a deep and narrow channel. It was empty and silent, and hardly a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trickle of water flowed among the brown and red-stained stones of its bed;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but on the near side there was a path, much broken and decayed, that wound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">its way among the ruined walls and paving-stones of an ancient highroad.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Ah! Here it is at last! ' said Gandalf. 'This is where the stream ran:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sirannon, the Gate-stream, they used to call it. But what has happened to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the water, I cannot guess; it used to be swift and noisy. Come! We must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hurry on. We are late.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company were footsore and tired; but they trudged doggedly along<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the rough and winding track for many miles. The sun turned from the noon and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began to go west. After a brief halt and a hasty meal they went on again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Before them the mountains frowned, but their path lay in a deep trough of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land and they could see only the higher shoulders and the far eastward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peaks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length they came to a sharp bend. There the road, which had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">veering southwards between the brink of the channel and a steep fall of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land to the left, turned and went due east again. Rounding the corner they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saw before them a low cliff, some five fathoms high, with a broken and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">jagged top. Over it a trickling water dripped, through a wide cleft that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to have been carved out by a fall that had once been strong and full.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed things have changed! ' said Gandalf. 'But there is no mistaking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the place. There is all that remains of the Stair Falls. If I remember<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right, there was a flight of steps cut in the rock at their side, but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">main road wound away left and climbed with several loops up to the level<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ground at the top. There used to be a shallow valley beyond the falls right<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up to the Walls of Moria, and the Sirannon flowed through it with the road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beside it. Let us go and see what things are like now ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They found the stone steps without difficulty, and Gimli sprang swiftly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up them, followed by Gandalf and Frodo. When they reached the top they saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they could go no further that way, and the reason for the drying up of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Gate-stream was revealed. Behind them the sinking Sun filled the cool<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western sky with glimmering gold. Before them stretched a dark still lake.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Neither sky nor sunset was reflected on its sullen surface. The Sirannon had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been dammed and had filled all the valley. Beyond the ominous water were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reared vast cliffs, their stern faces pallid in the fading light: final and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">impassable. No sign of gate or entrance, not a fissure or crack could Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see in the frowning stone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are the Walls of Moria,' said Gandalf, pointing across the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water. 'And there the Gate stood once upon a time, the Elven Door at the end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the road from Flollin by which we have come. But this way is blocked. None<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Company, I guess, will wish to swim this gloomy water at the end of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the day. It has an unwholesome look.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We must find a way round the northern edge,' said Gimli. 'The first<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing for the Company to do is to climb up by the main path and see where<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that will lead us. Even if there were no lake, we could not get our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">baggage-pony up this stair.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But in any case we cannot take the poor beast into the Mines,â€™ said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf. 'The road under the mountains is a dark road, and there are places<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">narrow and steep which he cannot tread, even if we can.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Poor old Bill! ' said Frodo. 'I had not thought of that. And poor Sam!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I wonder what he will say? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sorry,' said Gandalf. 'Poor Bill has been a useful companion and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it goes to my heart to turn him adrift now. I would have travelled lighter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and brought no animal, least of all this one that Sam is fond of, if I had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had my way. I feared all along that we should be obliged to take this road.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The day was drawing to its end, and cold stars were glinting in the sky<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high above the sunset, when the Company, with all the speed they could,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbed up the slopes and reached the side of the lake. In breadth it looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be no more than two or three furlongs at the widest point. How far it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stretched away southward they could not see in the failing light; but its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">northern end was no more than half a mile from where they stood, and between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the stony ridges that enclosed the valley and the water's edge there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rim of open ground. They hurried forward, for they had still a mile or two<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to go before they could reach the point on the far shore that Gandalf was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">making for; and then he had still to find the doors.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they came to the northernmost corner of the lake they found a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">narrow creek that barred their way. It was green and stagnant, thrust out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a slimy arm towards the enclosing hills. Gimli strode forward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">undeterred, and found that the water was shallow, no more than ankle-deep at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the edge. Behind him they walked in file, threading their way with care, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the weedy pools were sliding and greasy stones, and footing was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">treacherous. Frodo shuddered with disgust at the touch of the dark unclean<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water on his feet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Sam, the last of the Company, led Bill up on to the dry ground on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the far side, there came a soft sound: a swish, followed by a plop, as if a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fish had disturbed the still surface of the water. Turning quickly they saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ripples, black-edged with shadow in the waning light: great rings were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">widening outwards from a point far out in the lake. There was a bubbling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">noise, and then silence. The dusk deepened, and the last gleams of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sunset were veiled in cloud.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf now pressed on at a great pace, and the others followed as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quickly as they could. They reached the strip of dry land between the lake<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the cliffs: it was narrow, often hardly a dozen yards across, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">encumbered with fallen rock and stones; but they found a way, hugging the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cliff, and keeping as far from the dark water as they might. A mile<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southwards along the shore they came upon holly trees. Stumps and dead<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boughs were rotting in the shallows, the remains it seemed of old thickets,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or of a hedge that had once lined the road across the drowned valley. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">close under the cliff there stood, still strong and living, . two tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees, larger than any trees of holly that Frodo had ever seen or imagined.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their great roots spread from the wall to the water. Under the looming<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cliffs they had looked like mere bushes, when seen far off from the top of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Stair; but now they towered overhead, stiff, dark, and silent, throwing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep night-shadows about their feet, standing like sentinel pillars at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end of the road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, here we are at last! 'said Gandalf. 'Here the Elven-way from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hollin ended. Holly was the token of the people of that land, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">planted it here to mark the end of their domain; for the West -door was made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chiefly for their use in their traffic with the Lords of Moria. Those were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">happier days, when there was still close friendship at times between folk of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">different race, even between Dwarves and Elves.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was not the fault of the Dwarves that the friendship waned,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have not heard that it was the fault of the Elves,' said Legolas.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have heard both,' said Gandalf; 'and I will not give judgement now.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But I beg you two, Legolas and Gimli, at least to be friends, and to help<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">me. I need you both. The doors are shut and hidden, and the sooner we find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them the better. Night is at hand! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Turning to the others he said: 'While I am searching, will you each<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make ready to enter the Mines? For here I fear we must say farewell to our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">good beast of burden. You must lay aside much of the stuff that we brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against bitter weather: you will not need it inside, nor, I hope, when we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come through and journey on down into the South. Instead each of us must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take a share of what the pony carried, especially the food and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water-skins.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But you can't leave poor old Bill behind in this forsaken place, Mr.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf! ' cried Sam, angry and distressed. 'I won't have it, and that's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flat. After he has come so far and all ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sorry, Sam,' said the wizard. 'But when the Door opens I do not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">think you will be able to drag your Bill inside, into the long dark of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Moria. You will have to choose between Bill and your master.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He'd follow Mr. Frodo into a dragon's den, if I led him,' protested<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam. 'It'd be nothing short of murder to turn him loose with all these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wolves about.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It will be short of murder, I hope,' said Gandalf. He laid his hand on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pony's head, and spoke in a low voice. 'Go with words of guard and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guiding on you,â€™ he said. 'You are a wise beast, and have learned much in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell. Make your ways to places where you can find grass, and so come in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time to Elrond's house, or wherever you wish to go.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There, Sam! He will have quite as much chance of escaping wolves and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">getting home as we have.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam stood sullenly by the pony and returned no answer. Bill, seeming to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">understand well what was going on, nuzzled up to him, putting his nose to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam's ear. Sam burst into tears, and fumbled with the straps, unlading all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pony's packs and throwing them on the ground. The others sorted out the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">goods, making a pile of all that could be left behind, and dividing up the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rest.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When this was done they turned to watch Gandalf. He appeared to have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">done nothing. He was standing between the two trees gazing at the blank wall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the cliff, as if he would bore a hole into it with his eyes. Gimli was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wandering about, tapping the stone here and there with his axe. Legolas was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pressed against the rock, as if listening.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, here we are and all ready,' said Merry; 'but where are the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Doors? I can't see any sign of them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dwarf-doors are not made to be seen when shut,' said Gimli. 'They are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">invisible, and their own masters cannot find them or open them, if their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secret is forgotten.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But this Door was not made to be a secret known only to Dwarves,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf, coming suddenly to life and turning round. 'Unless things are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">altogether changed, eyes that know what to look for may discover the signs.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He walked forward to the wall. Right between the shadow of the trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was a smooth space, and over this he passed his hands to and fro,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">muttering words under his breath. Then he stepped back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look!' he said. 'Can you see anything now?â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Moon now shone upon the grey face of the rock; but they could see<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing else for a while. Then slowly on the surface, where the wizard's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hands had passed, faint lines appeared, like slender veins of silver running<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the stone. At first they were no more than pale gossamer-threads, so fine<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they only twinkled fitfully where the Moon caught them, but steadily<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they grew broader and clearer, until their design could be guessed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the top, as high as Gandalf could reach, was an arch of interlacing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">letters in an Elvish character. Below, though the threads were in places<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blurred or broken, the outline could be seen of an anvil and a hammer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">surmounted by a crown with seven stars. Beneath these again were two trees,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">each bearing crescent moons. More clearly than all else there shone forth in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the middle of the door a single star with many rays.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are the emblems of Dunn!' cried Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And there is the Tree of the High Elves!' said Legolas.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And the Star of the House of Flanor,' said Gandalf. 'They are wrought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of ithildin that mirrors only starlight and moonlight, and sleeps until it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is touched by one who speaks words now long forgotten in Middle-earth. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long since I heard them, and I thought deeply before I could recall them to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my mind.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What does the writing say?â€™ asked Frodo, who was trying to decipher<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the inscription on the arch. â€™I thought I knew the elf-letters but I cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">read these.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The words are in the elven-tongue of the West of Middle-earth in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elder Days,â€™ answered Gandalf. â€™But they do not say anything of importance<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to us. They say only: The Doors ofDurin, Lord ofMoria. Speak, friend, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enter. And underneath small and faint is written: I, Narvi, made them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Celebrimbor ofHollin drew these signs.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What does it mean by speak, friend, and enter!' asked Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™That is plain enough,â€™ said Gimli. 'If you are a friend, speak the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">password, and the doors will open, and you can enter.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Yes,' said Gandalf, 'these doors are probably governed by words. Some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf-gates will open only at special times, or for particular persons; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some have locks and keys that are still needed when all necessary times and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">words are known. These doors have no key. In the days of Durin they were not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secret. They usually stood open and doorwards sat here. But if they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shut, any who knew the opening word could speak it and pass in. At least so<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it is recorded, is it not, Gimli? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is,' said the dwarf. 'But what the word was is not remembered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Narvi and his craft and all his kindred have vanished from the earth.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™But do not you know the word, Gandalf? â€™ asked Boromir in surprise.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No! â€™ said the wizard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others looked dismayed; only Aragorn, who knew Gandalf well,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remained silent and unmoved.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Then what was the use of bringing us to this accursed spot?â€™ cried<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir, glancing back with a shudder at the dark water. 'You told us that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you had once passed through the Mines. How could that be, if you did not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">know how to enter? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The answer to your first question, Boromir,â€™ said the wizard, 'is that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I do not know the word-yet. But we shall soon see. And,â€™ he added, with a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glint in his eyes under their bristling brows, 'you may ask what is the use<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of my deeds when they are proved useless. As for your other question: do you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubt my tale? Or have you no wits left? I did not enter this way. I came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the East.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If you wish to know, I will tell you that these doors open outwards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From the inside you may thrust them open with your hands. From the outside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing will move them save the spell of command. They cannot be forced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inwards.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What are you going to do then? â€™ asked Pippin, undaunted by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wizard's bristling brows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Knock on the doors with your head, Peregrin Took,' said Gandalf. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if that does not shatter them, and I am allowed a little peace from foolish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">questions, I will seek for the opening words.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I once knew every spell in all the tongues of Elves or Men or Ores<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that was ever used for such a purpose. I can still remember ten score of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them without searching in my mind. But only a few trials, I think, will be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">needed; and I shall not have to call on Gimli for words of the secret<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf-tongue that they teach to none. The opening words were Elvish, like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the writing on the arch: that seems certain.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ele stepped up to the rock again, and lightly touched with his staff the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver star in the middle beneath the sign of the anvil.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Annon edhellen, edro hi ammen!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fennas nogothrim, lasto beth lammen!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said in a commanding voice. The silver lines faded, but the blank<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey stone did not stir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Many times he repeated these words in different order, or varied them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then he tried other spells, one after another, speaking now faster and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">louder, now soft and slow. Then he spoke many single words of Elvish speech.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nothing happened. The cliff towered into the night, the countless stars were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">kindled, the wind blew cold, and the doors stood fast.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Again Gandalf approached the wall, and lifting up his arms he spoke in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tones of command and rising wrath. Edro, edro! he cried, and struck the rock<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with his staff. Open, open! he shouted, and followed it with the same<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">command in every language that had ever been spoken in the West of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Middle-earth. Then he threw his staff on the ground, and sat down in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silence.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment from far off the wind bore to their listening ears the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">howling of wolves. Bill the pony started in fear, and Sam sprang to his side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and whispered softly to him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do not let him run away! ' said Boromir. 'It seems that we shall need<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him still, if the wolves do not find us. How I hate this foul pool! ' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stooped and picking up a large stone he cast it far into the dark water.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The stone vanished with a soft slap; but at the same instant there was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a swish and a bubble. Great rippling rings formed on the surface out beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the stone had fallen, and they moved slowly towards the foot of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cliff.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Why did you do that, Boromir? ' said Frodo. V I hate this place, too,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I am afraid. I don't know of what: not of wolves, or the dark behind the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors, but of something else. I am afraid of the pool. Don't disturb it! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'1 wish we could get away! ' said Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why doesn't Gandalf do something quick? ' said Pippin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf took no notice of them. He sat with his head bowed, either in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">despair or in anxious thought. The mournful howling of the wolves was heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. The ripples on the water grew and came closer; some were already<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lapping on the shore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With a suddenness that startled them all the wizard sprang to his feet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He was laughing! V I have it! ' he cried. 'Of course, of course! Absurdly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">simple, like most riddles when you see the answer.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Picking up his staff he stood before the rock and said in a clear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice: Mellon!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The star shone out briefly and faded again. Then silently a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doorway was outlined, though not a crack or joint had been visible before.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slowly it divided in the middle and swung outwards inch by inch, until both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors lay back against the wall. Through the opening a shadowy stair could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be seen climbing steeply up; but beyond the lower steps the darkness was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deeper than the night. The Company stared in wonder.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">V I was wrong after all,' said Gandalf, 'and Gimli too. Merry, of all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">people, was on the right track. The opening word was inscribed on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">archway all the time! The translation should have been: Say "Friend" and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enter. I had only to speak the Elvish word for friend and the doors opened.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Quite simple. Too simple for a learned lore-master in these suspicious days.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Those were happier times. Now let us go!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He strode forward and set his foot on the lowest step. But at that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moment several things happened. Frodo felt something seize him by the ankle,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he fell with a cry. Bill the pony gave a wild neigh of fear, and turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tail and dashed away along the lakeside into the darkness. Sam leaped after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, and then hearing Frodoâ€™s cry he ran back again, weeping and cursing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others swung round and saw the waters of the lake seething, as if a host<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of snakes were swimming up from the southern end.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Out from the water a long sinuous tentacle had crawled; it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale-green and luminous and wet. Its fingered end had hold of Frodo's foot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and was dragging him into the water. Sam on his knees was now slashing at it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The arm let go of Frodo, and Sam pulled him away, crying out for help.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Twenty others arms came rippling out. The dark water boiled, and there was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Into the gateway! Up the stairs! Quick! ' shouted Gandalf leaping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back. Rousing them from the horror that seemed to have rooted all but Sam to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ground where they stood, he drove them forward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They were just in time. Sam and Frodo were only a few steps up, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf had just begun to climb, when the groping tentacles writhed across<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the narrow shore and fingered the cliff- wall and the doors. One came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wriggling over the threshold, glistening in the starlight. Gandalf turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and paused. If he was considering what word would close the gate again from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">within, there was no need. Many coiling arms seized the doors on either<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they slammed, and all light was lost. A noise of rending and crashing came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam, clinging to Frodoâ€™s arm, collapsed on a step in the black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wolves and snakes! But the snakes were too much for him. I had to choose,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mr. Frodo. I had to come with you.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They heard Gandalf go back down the steps and thrust his staff against<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the doors. There was a quiver in the stone and the stairs trembled, .but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doors did not open. 'Well, well! â€™ said the wizard. 'The passage is blocked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind us now and there is only one way outâ€” on the other side of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains. I fear from the sounds that boulders have been piled up, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees uprooted and thrown across the gate. I am sorry; for the trees were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beautiful, and had stood so long.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I felt that something horrible was near from the moment that my foot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many of them? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know,' answered Gandalf, 'but the arms were all guided by one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir muttered under his breath, but the echoing stone magnified the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this deadly dark? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I will,' said Gandalf, 'and Gimli shall walk with me. Follow my staff!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">t<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As the wizard passed on ahead up the great steps, he held his staff<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aloft, and from its tip there came a faint radiance. The wide stairway was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sound and undamaged. Two hundred steps they counted, broad and shallow;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at the top they found an arched passage with a level floor leading on into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let us sit and rest and have something to eat, here on the landing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The proposal was welcomed by all; and they sat down on the upper steps,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It will not last much longer, I am afraid,â€™ he said; 'but I think we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How long is that going to take us? ' asked Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I cannot say,' answered Gandalf. 'It depends on many chances. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">going straight, without mishap or losing our way, we shall take three or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">four marches, I expect. It cannot be less than forty miles from West -door to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After only a brief rest they started on their way again. All were eager<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or of Glamdring; and that was some comfort, for being the work of Elvish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were near at hand. Behind Frodo went Sam, and after him Legolas, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The passage twisted round a few turns, and then began to descend. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went steadily down for a long while before it became level once again. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">air grew hot and stifling, but it was not foul, and at times they felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the walls. There were many of these. In the pale ray of the wizard's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">staff, Frodo caught glimpses of stairs and arches and of other passages and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tunnels, sloping up, or running steeply down, or opening blankly dark on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">either side. It was bewildering beyond hope of remembering.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli aided Gandalf very little, except by his stout courage. At least<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was not, as were most of the others, troubled by the mere darkness in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">itself. Often the wizard consulted him at points where the choice of way was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubtful; but it was always Gandalf who had the final word. The Mines of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Moria were vast and intricate beyond the imagination of Gimli, Gluin's son,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf of the mountain-race though he was. To Gandalf the far-off memories of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do not be afraid! ' said Aragorn. There was a pause longer than usual,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Gandalf and Gimli were whispering together; the others were crowded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
