<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wall; but still Gandalf could be seen, glimmering in the gloom; he seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">small, and altogether alone: grey and bent, like a wizened tree before the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">onset of a storm.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From out of the shadow a red sword leaped flaming.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Glamdring glittered white in answer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a ringing clash and a stab of white fire. The Balrog fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back and its sword flew up in molten fragments. The wizard swayed on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bridge, stepped back a pace, and then again stood still.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You cannot pass! ' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With a bound the Balrog leaped full upon the bridge. Its whip whirled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and hissed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He cannot stand alone! ' cried Aragorn suddenly and ran back along the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bridge. 'Elendil!' he shouted. 'I am with you, Gandalf! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gondor! ' cried Boromir and leaped after him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment Gandalf lifted his staff, and crying aloud he smote the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bridge before him. The staff broke asunder and fell from his hand. A<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blinding sheet of white flame sprang up. The bridge cracked. Right at the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Balrog's feet it broke, and the stone upon which it stood crashed into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gulf, while the rest remained, poised, quivering like a tongue of rock<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thrust out into emptiness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With a terrible cry the Balrog fell forward, and its shadow plunged<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down and vanished. But even as it fell it swung its whip, and the thongs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lashed and curled about the wizardâ€™s knees, dragging him to the brink. He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">staggered and fell, grasped vainly at the stone, and slid into the abyss.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Fly, you fools! ' he cried, and was gone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The fires went out, and blank darkness fell. The Company stood rooted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with horror staring into the pit. Even as Aragorn and Boromir came flying<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back, the rest of the bridge cracked and fell. With a cry Aragorn roused<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Come! I will lead you now ! ' he called. 'We must obey his last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">command. Follow me! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They stumbled wildly up the great stairs beyond the door. Aragorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leading, Boromir at the rear. At the top was a wide echoing passage. Along<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this they fled. Frodo heard Sam at his side weeping, and then he found that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he himself was weeping as he ran. Doom, doom, doom the drum-beats rolled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind, mournful now and slow; doom!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They ran on. The light grew before them; great shafts pierced the roof.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They ran swifter. They passed into a hall, bright with daylight from its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high windows in the east. They fled across it. Through its huge broken doors<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they passed, and suddenly before them the Great Gates opened, an arch of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blazing light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a guard of ores crouching in the shadows behind the great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">door posts towering on either side, but the gates were shattered and cast<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down. Aragorn smote to the ground the captain that stood in his path, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the rest fled in terror of his wrath. The Company swept past them and took<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no heed of them. Out of the Gates they ran and sprang down the huge and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">age-worn steps, the threshold of Moria.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Thus, at last, they came beyond hope under the sky and felt the wind on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their faces.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They did not halt until they were out of bowshot from the walls.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Dimrill Dale lay about them. The shadow of the Misty Mountains lay upon it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but eastwards there was a golden light on the land. It was but one hour<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after noon. The sun was shining; the clouds were white and high.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They looked back. Dark yawned the archway of the Gates under the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountain-shadow. Faint and far beneath the earth rolled the slow drum-beats:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doom. A thin black smoke trailed out. Nothing else was to be seen; the dale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all around was empty. Doom. Grief at last wholly overcame them, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wept long: some standing and silent, some cast upon the ground. Doom, doom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The drum-beats faded.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 6 . Lothlurien<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Alas! I Fear we cannot stay here longer,' said Aragorn. He looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">towards the mountains and held up his sword. 'Farewell, Gandalf ! ' he cried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Did I not say to you: if you pass the doors of Moria, bewarel Alas that I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke true! What hope have we without you? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He turned to the Company. 'We must do without hope,' he said. 'At least<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we may yet be avenged. Let us gird ourselves and weep no more! Come! We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a long road, and much to do.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They rose and looked about them. Northward the dale ran up into a glen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of shadows between two great arms of the mountains, above which three white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peaks were shining: Celebdil, Fanuidhol, Caradhras. the Mountains of Moria.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the head of the glen a torrent flowed like a white lace over an endless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ladder of short falls, and a mist of foam hung in the air about the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains' feet.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yonder is the Dimrill Stair,' said Aragorn, pointing to the falls.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Down the deep-cloven way that climbs beside the torrent we should have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come, if fortune had been kinder.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Or Caradhras less cruel,' said Gimli. 'There he stands smiling in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun! ' He shook his fist at the furthest of the snow-capped peaks and turned<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To the east the outflung arm of the mountains marched to a sudden end,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and far lands could be descried beyond them, wide and vague. To the south<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Misty Mountains receded endlessly as far as sight could reach. Less than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a mile away, and a little below them, for they still stood high up on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">west side of the dale, there lay a mere. It was long and oval, shaped like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great spear-head thrust deep into the northern glen; but its southern end<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was beyond the shadows under the sunlit sky. Yet its waters were dark: a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep blue like clear evening sky seen from a lamp-lit room. Its face was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still and unruffled. About it lay a smooth sward, shelving down on all sides<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to its bare unbroken rim.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There lies the Mirrormere, deep Kheled-zvram! ' said Gimli sadly. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remember that he said: "May you have joy of the sight! But we cannot linger<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there." Now long shall I journey ere I have joy again. It is I that must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hasten away, and he that must remain.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company now went down the road from the Gates. It was rough and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">broken, fading to a winding track between heather and whin that thrust amid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cracking stones. But still it could be seen that once long ago a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paved way had wound upwards from the lowlands of the Dwarf-kingdom.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places there were ruined works of stone beside the path, and mounds of green<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">topped with slender birches, or fir-trees sighing in the wind. An eastward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bend led them hard by the sward of Mirrormere, and there not far from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">roadside stood a single column broken at the top.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is Durin's Stone! ' cried Gimli. 'I cannot pass without turning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside for a moment to look at the wonder of the dale ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Be swift then! ' said Aragorn, looking back towards the Gates. 'The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sun sinks early. The Ores will not, maybe, come out till after dusk, but we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must be far away before nightfall. The Moon is almost spent, and it will be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark tonight.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come with me, Frodo! ' cried the dwarf, springing from the road. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">would not have you go without seeing Kheled-zvram.' He ran down the long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green slope. Frodo followed slowly, drawn by the still blue water in spite<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of hurt and weariness; Sam came up behind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beside the standing stone Gimli halted and looked up. It was cracked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and weather-worn, and the faint runes upon its side could not be read. 'This<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pillar marks the spot where Durin first looked in the Mirrormere,' said the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwarf. 'Let us look ourselves once, ere we go!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They stooped over the dark water. At first they could see nothing. Then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slowly they saw the forms of the encircling mountains mirrored in a profound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blue, and the peaks were like plumes of white flame above them; beyond there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a space of sky. There like jewels sunk in the deep shone glinting stars,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">though sunlight was in the sky above. Of their own stooping forms no shadow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'O Kheled-zvram fair and wonderful! ' said Gimli. 'There lies the Crown<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Durin till he wakes. Farewell! ' He bowed, and turned away, and hastened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back up the green-sward to the road again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What did you see? ' said Pippin to Sam, but Sam was too deep in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought to answer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The road now turned south and went quickly downwards, running out from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between the arms of the dale. Some way below the mere they came on a deep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">well of water, clear as crystal, from which a freshet fell over a stone lip<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and ran glistening and gurgling down a steep rocky channel.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here is the spring from which the Silverlode rises.' said Gimli. 'Do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not drink of it! It is icy cold.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Soon it becomes a swift river, and it gathers water from many other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountain- streams,' said Aragorn. 'Our road leads beside it for many miles.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For I shall take you by the road that Gandalf chose, and first I hope to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come to the woods where the Silverlode flows into the Great River-out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yonder.' They looked as he pointed, and before them they could see the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream leaping down to the trough of the valley, and then running on and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away into the lower lands, until it was lost in a golden haze.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There lie the woods of Lothlurien! â€™ said Legolas. 'That is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fairest of all the dwellings of my people. There are no trees like the trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of that land. For in the autumn their leaves fall not, but turn to gold. Not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">till the spring comes and the new green opens do they fall, and then the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boughs are laden with yellow flowers; and the floor of the wood is golden,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and golden is the roof, and its pillars are of silver, for the bark of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees is smooth and grey. So still our songs in Mirkwood say. My heart would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'My heart will be glad, even in the winter,' said Aragorn. 'But it lies<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many miles away. Let us hasten! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For some time Frodo and Sam managed to keep up with the others; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn was leading them at a great pace, and after a while they lagged<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind. They had eaten nothing since the early morning. Sam's cut was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">burning like fire, and his head felt light. In spite of the shining sun the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wind seemed chill after the warm darkness of Moria. He shivered. Frodo felt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At last Legolas turned, and seeing them now far behind, he spoke to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn. The others halted, and Aragorn ran back, calling to Boromir to come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am sorry, Frodo! ' he cried, full of concern. 'So much has happened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this day and we have such need of haste, that I have forgotten that you were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hurt; and Sam too. You should have spoken. We have done nothing to ease<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as we ought, though all the ores of Moria were after us. Come now! A little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Soon afterwards they came upon another stream that ran down from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While Gimli and the two younger hobbits kindled a fire of brush- and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fir-wood, and drew water, Aragorn tended Sam and Frodo. Sam's wound was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep, but it looked ugly, and Aragornâ€™s face was grave as he examined it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a moment he looked up with relief.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Good luck, Sam! â€™ he said. 'Many have received worse than this in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He opened his pouch and drew out some withered leaves. 'They are dry<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and some of their virtue has one, he said, but here I have still some of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and wash the wound clean, and I will bind it. Now it is your turn. Frodo! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am all right,' said Frodo, reluctant to have his garments touched.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All I needed was some food and a little rest.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No! ' said Aragorn. 'We must have a look and see what the hammer and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Look, my friends!â€™ he called. 'Here's a pretty hobbit-skin to wrap an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">el ven -princeling in! If it were known that hobbits had such hides, all the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hunters of Middle-earth would be riding to the Shire.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And all the arrows of all the hunters in the world would be in vain,'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Gimli, gazing at the mail in wonder. 'It is a mithril-coat. Mithril! I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have never seen or heard tell of one so fair. Is this the coat that Gandalf<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke of? Then he undervalued it. But it was well given! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have often wondered what you and Bilbo were doing, so close in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I hope we get a chance of telling him about it! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a dark and blackened bruise on Frodo's right side and breast.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Under the mail there was a shirt of soft leather, but at one point the rings<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'The mail is marvellously light,' he said. 'Put it on again, if you can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bear it. My heart is glad to know that you have such a coat. Do not lay it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had eaten, the Company got ready to go on. They put out the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was dark. Deep night had fallen. There were many clear stars, hut<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the fast- waning moon would not be seen till late. Gimli and Frodo were at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not a sound but the wind,' he said. 'There are no goblins near, or my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ears are made of wood. It is to be hoped that the Ores will be content with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">driving us from Moria. And maybe that was all their purpose, and they had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing else to do with us-with the Ring. Though Ores will often pursue foes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo did not answer. He looked at Sting, and the blade was dull. Yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about them and the road behind was dim, he had heard again the quick patter<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What is it? ' said the dwarf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I don't know.' answered Frodo. 'I thought I heard feet, and I thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I saw a light-like eyes. I have thought so often, since we first entered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli halted and stooped to the ground. 'I hear nothing but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lothlurien! ' cried Legolas. 'Lothlurien! We have come to the eaves of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Under the night the trees stood tall before them, arched over the road<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and stream that ran suddenly beneath their spreading boughs. In the dim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Lothlurien! ' said Aragorn. 'Glad I am to hear again the wind in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees! We are still little more than five leagues from the Gates, but we can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go no further. Here let us hope that the virtue of the Elves will keep us<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If Elves indeed still dwell here in the darkening world,' said Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is long since any of my own folk journeyed hither back to the land<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed deep in the wood they dwell,' said Aragorn, and sighed as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some memory stirred in him. 'We must fend for ourselves tonight. We will go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward a short way, until the trees are all about us, and then we will turn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside from the path and seek a place to rest in.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He stepped forward; but Boromir stood irresolute and did not follow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Is there no other way? ' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What other fairer way would you desire? â€™ said Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'A plain road, though it led through a hedge of swords,' said Boromir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'By strange paths has this Company been led, and so far to evil fortune.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Against my will we passed under the shades of Moria, to our loss. And now we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must enter the Golden Wood, you say. But of that perilous land we have heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Gondor, and it is said that few come out who once go in; and of that few<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">none have escaped unscathed.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Say not unscathed, but if you say unchanged, then maybe you will speak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the truth said Aragorn. But lore wanes in Gondor, Boromir, if in the city of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">those who once were wise they now speak evil of Lothlurien. Believe what you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will, there is no other way for us â€” unless you would go back to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Moria-gate, or scale the pathless mountains, or swim the Great River all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then lead on! ' said Boromir. 'But it is perilous.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Perilous indeed,' said Aragorn, 'fair and perilous; but only evil need<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fear it, or those who bring some evil with them. Follow me! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had gone little more than a mile into the forest when they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon another stream flowing down swiftly from the tree-clad slopes that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">climbed back westward towards the mountains. They heard it splashing over a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fall away among the shadows on their right. Its dark hurrying waters ran<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">across the path before them, and joined the Silverlode in a swirl of dim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pools among the roots of trees.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here is Nimrodel! ' said Legolas. 'Of this stream the Silvan Elves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made many songs long ago, and still we sing them in the North, remembering<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the rainbow on its falls, and the golden flowers that floated in its foam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All is dark now and the Bridge of Nimrodel is broken down. I will bathe my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feet, for it is said that the water is healing to the weary.' He went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward and climbed down the deep-cloven bank and stepped into the stream.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Follow me!â€™ he cried. 'The water is not deep. Let us wade across! On<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the further bank we can rest, and the sound of the falling water may bring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">us sleep and forgetfulness of grief.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One by one they climbed down and followed Legolas. For a moment Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stood near the brink and let the water flow over his tired feet. It was cold<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but its touch was clean, and as he went on and it mounted to his knees, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt that the stain of travel and all weariness was washed from his limbs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When all the Company had crossed, they sat and rested and ate a little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">food; and Legolas told them tales of Lothlurien that the Elves of Mirkwood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still kept in their hearts, of sunlight and starlight upon the meadows by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Great River before the world was grey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length a silence fell, and they heard the music of the waterfall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">running sweetly in the shadows. Almost Frodo fancied that he could hear a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice singing, mingled with the sound of the water.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Do you hear the voice of Nimrodel? ' asked Legolas. 'I will sing you a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">song of the maiden Nimrodel, who bore the same name as the stream beside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which she lived lung ago. It is a fair song in our woodland tongue; but this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is how it runs in the Westron Speech, as some in Rivendell now sing it.' In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a soft voice hardly to be heard amid the rustle of the leaves above them he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">began:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">An Elven-maid there was of old,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A shining star by day:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Her mantle white was hemmed with gold,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Her shoes of silver-grey.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A star was bound upon her brows,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A light was on her hair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As sun upon the golden boughs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In Lurien the fair.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Her hair was long, her limbs were white,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And fair she was and free;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And in the wind she went as light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As leaf of linden-tree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beside the falls of Nimrodel,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">By water clear and cool,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Her voice as falling silver fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Into the shining pool.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Where now she wanders none can tell,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In sunlight or in shade;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For lost of yore was Nimrodel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And in the mountains strayed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The elven-ship in haven grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beneath the mountain-lee<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Awaited her for many a day<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beside the roaring sea.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A wind by night in Northern lands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Arose, and loud it cried,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And drove the ship from elven-strands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Across the streaming tide.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When dawn came dim the land was lost,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The mountains sinking grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beyond the heaving waves that tossed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Their plumes of blinding spray.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Amroth beheld the fading shore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now low beyond the swell,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And cursed the faithless ship that bore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Him far from Nimrodel.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of old he was an Elven-king,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A lord of tree and glen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When golden were the boughs in spring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In fair Lothlurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From helm to sea they saw him leap,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As arrow from the string,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And dive into the water deep,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As mew upon the wing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The wind was in his flowing hair,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The foam about him shone;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Afar they saw him strong and fair<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Go riding like a swan.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But from the West has come no word,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And on the Hither Shore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">No tidings Elven-folk have heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of Amroth evermore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The voice of Legolas faltered, and the song ceased. 'I cannot sing any<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more,' he said. 'That is but a part, for I have forgotten much. It is long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sad, for it tells how sorrow came upon Lothlurien, Lurien of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Blossom, when the Dwarves awakened evil in the mountains.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But the Dwarves did not make the evil,' said Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I said not so; yet evil came,' answered Legolas sadly. 'Then many of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Elves of Nimrodel's kindred left their dwellings and departed and she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was lost far in the South, in the passes of the White Mountains; and she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came not to the ship where Amroth her lover waited for her. But in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spring when the wind is in the new leaves the echo of her voice may still be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard by the falls that bear her name. And when the wind is in the South the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voice of Amroth comes up from the sea; for Nimrodel flows into Silverlode,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that Elves call Celebrant, and Celebrant into Anduin the Great, and Anduin<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flows into the Bay of B elf alas whence the Elves of Lurien set sail. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">neither Nimrodel nor Amroth ever came back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is told that she had a house built in the branches of a tree that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew near the falls; for that was the custom of the Elves of Lurien, to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwell in the trees, and maybe it is so still. Therefore they were called the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galadhrim, the Tree -people. Deep in their forest the trees are very great.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The people of the woods did not delve in the ground like Dwarves, nor build<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strong places of stone before the Shadow came.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And even in these latter days dwelling in the trees might be thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">safer than sitting on the ground,' said Gimli. He looked across the stream<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the road that led back to Dimrill Dale, and then up into the roof of dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boughs above.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Your words bring good counsel, Gimli,' said Aragorn. 'We cannot build<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a house, but tonight we will do as the Galadhrim and seek refuge in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree-tops, if we can. We have sat here beside the road already longer than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was wise.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company now turned aside from the path, and went into the shadow of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the deeper woods, westward along the mountain-stream away from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Silverlode.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not far from the falls of Nimrodel they found a cluster of trees, some of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There were no more sounds. Even the leaves were silent, and the very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thankful that they had not been caught on the ground; but he felt that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees offered little protection, except concealment. Ores were as keen as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hounds on a scent, it was said, but they could also climb. He drew out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sting: it flashed and glittered like a blue flame and then slowly faded<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again and grew dull. In spite of the fading of his sword the feeling of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">immediate danger did not leave Frodo, rather it grew stronger. He got up and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crawled to the opening and peered down. He was almost certain that he could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hear stealthy movements at the treeâ€™s foot far below.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not Elves; for the woodland folk were altogether noiseless in their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to be scrabbling on the bark of the tree-trunk. He stared down into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Something was now climbing slowly, and its breath came like a soft<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Immediately afterwards Haldir came climbing swiftly up through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he said. 'It was not an ore. It fled as soon as I touched the tree -stem. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to be wary, and to have some skill in trees, or I might have thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I did not shoot, for I dared not arouse any cries: we cannot risk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Orophin has now gone in haste back to our dwellings to warn our<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shadow has crept northward all about us. Some speak of departing, yet for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that it already seems too late. The mountains to the west are growing evil;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the east the lands are waste, and full of Sauronâ€™s creatures; and it is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rumoured that we cannot now safely pass southward through Rohan, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mouths of the Great River are watched by the Enemy. Even if we could come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the shores of the Sea, we should find no longer any shelter there. It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said that there are still havens of. the High Elves, but they are far north<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and west, beyond the land of the Halflings. But where that may be, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Lord and Lady may know, I do not.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You ought at least to guess, since you have seen us,â€™ said Merry.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There are Elf-havens west of my land, the Shire where Hobbits live.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Happy folk are Hobbits to dwell near the shores of the sea! â€™ said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir. â€™It is long indeed since any of my folk have looked on it, yet still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we remember it in song. Tell me of these havens as we walk.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I cannot,â€™ said Merry. 'I have never seen them. I have never been out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of my own land before. And if I had known what the world outside was like. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">donâ€™t think I should have had the heart to leave it.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Not even to see fair Lothlurien? â€™ said Haldir. â€™The world is indeed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">full of peril, and in it there are many dark places; but still there is much<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that is fair, and though in all lands love is now mingled with grief, it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grows perhaps the greater.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Some there are among us who sing that the Shadow will draw back and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">peace shall come again. Yet I do not believe that the world about us will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever again be as it was of old, or the light of the Sun as it was aforetime.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For the Elves, I fear, it will prove at best a truce, in which they may pass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Sea unhindered and leave the Middle-earth for ever. Alas for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lothlurien that I love! It would be a poor life in a land where no mallorn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew. But if there are mallorn-trees beyond the Great Sea, none have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reported it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they spoke thus, the Company filed slowly along the paths in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wood, led by Haldir, while the other Elf walked behind. They felt the ground<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beneath their feet smooth and soft, and after a while they walked more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">freely, without fear of hurt or fall. Being deprived of sight, Frodo found<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his hearing and other senses sharpened. He could smell the trees and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trodden grass. He could hear many different notes in the rustle of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaves overhead, the river murmuring away on his right, and the thin clear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">voices of birds in the sky. He felt the sun upon his face and hands when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they passed through an open glade.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As soon as he set foot upon the far bank of Silverlode a strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">feeling had come upon him, and it deepened as he walked on into the Naith:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it seemed to him that he had stepped over a bridge of time into a corner of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Elder Days, and was -now walking in a world that was no more. In<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rivendell there was memory of ancient things; in Lurien the ancient things<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still lived on in the waking world. Evil had been seen and heard there,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sorrow had been known; the Elves feared and distrusted the world outside:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wolves were howling on the wood's borders: but on the land of Lurien no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow lay.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All that day the Company marched on, until they felt the cool evening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come and heard the early night- wind whispering among many leaves. Then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rested and slept without fear upon the ground; for their guides would not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">permit them to unbind their eyes, and they could not climb. In the morning<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they went on again, walking without haste. At noon they halted, and Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was aware that they had passed out under the shining Sun. Suddenly he heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the sound of many voices all around him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A marching host of Elves had come up silently: they were hastening<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">toward the northern borders to guard against any attack from Moria; and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brought news, some of which Haldir reported. The marauding ores had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">waylaid and almost all destroyed; the remnant had fled westward towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains, and were being pursued. A strange creature also had been seen,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">running with bent back and with hands near the ground, like a beast and yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">notofbeast-shape.lt had eluded capture, and they had not shot it, not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knowing whether it was good or ill, and it had vanished down the Silverlode<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Also,' said Haldir, "they bring me a message from the Lord and Lady of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Galadhrim. You are all to walk free, even the dwarf Gimli. It seems that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Lady knows who and what is each member of your Company. New<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">messages<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have come from Rivendell perhaps.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He removed the bandage first from Gimli' s eyes. 'Your pardon! ' he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said, bowing low. "Look on us now with friendly eyes! Look and be glad, for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you are the first dwarf to behold the trees of the Naith of Lurien since<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Durin's Day! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When his eyes were in turn uncovered, Frodo looked up and caught his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">breath. They were standing in an open space. To the left stood a great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mound, covered with a sward of grass as green as Spring-time in the Elder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Days. Upon it, as a double crown, grew two circles of trees: the outer had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bark of snowy white, and were leafless but beautiful in their shapely<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nakedness; the inner were mallorn-trees of great height, still arrayed in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale gold. High amid the branches of a towering tree that stood in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">centre of all there gleamed a white flet. At the feet of the trees, and all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the green hillsides the grass was studded with small golden flowers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shaped like stars. Among them, nodding on slender stalks, were other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowers, white and palest green: they glimmered as a mist amid the rich hue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the grass. Over all the sky was blue, and the sun of afternoon glowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon the hill and cast long green shadows beneath the trees.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Behold! You are come to Cerin Amroth,' said Haldir. "For this is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heart of the ancient realm as it was long ago, and here is the mound of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Amroth, where in happier days his high house was built. Here ever bloom the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">winter flowers in the unfading grass: the yellow elanor, and the pale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">niphredil. Here we will stay awhile, and come to the city of the Galadhrim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at dusk.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others cast themselves down upon the fragrant grass, but Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stood awhile still lost in wonder. It seemed to him that he had stepped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through a high window that looked on a vanished world. A light was upon it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for which his language had no name. All that he saw was shapely, but the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shapes seemed at once clear cut, as if they had been first conceived and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drawn at the uncovering of his eyes, and ancient as if they had endured for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever. He saw no colour but those he knew, gold and white and blue and green,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but they were fresh and poignant, as if he had at that moment first<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perceived them and made for them names new and wonderful. In winter here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heart could mourn for summer or for spring. No blemish or sickness or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deformity could be seen in anything that grew upon the earth. On the land of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lurien there was no stain.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He turned and saw that Sam was now standing beside him, looking round<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a puzzled expression, and rubbing his eyes as if he was not sure that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was awake. 'It's sunlight and bright day, right enough,' he said. 'I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought that Elves were all for moon and stars: but this is more elvish than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">anything I ever heard tell of. I feel as if I was inside a song, if you take<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
