<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my meaning.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir looked at them, and he seemed indeed to take the meaning of both<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought and word. He smiled. 'You feel the power of the Lady of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galadhrim,' he said. 'Would it please you to climb with me up Cerin Amroth?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">f<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They followed him as he stepped lightly up the grass-clad slopes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though he walked and breathed, and about him living leaves and flowers were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stirred by the same cool wind as fanned his face, Frodo felt that he was in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a timeless land that did not fade or change or fall into forgetfulness. When<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had gone and passed again into the outer world, still Frodo the wanderer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the Shire would walk there, upon the grass among elanor and niphredil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in fair Lothlurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They entered the circle of white trees. As they did so the South Wind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blew upon Cerin Amroth and sighed among the branches. Frodo stood still,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hearing far off_ great seas upon beaches that had long ago been washed away,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and sea-birds crying whose race had perished from the earth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir had gone on and was now climbing to the high flet. As Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prepared to follow him, he laid his hand upon the tree beside the ladder:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">never before had he been so suddenly and so keenly aware of the feel and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">texture of a tree's skin and of the life within it. He felt a delight in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wood and the touch of it, neither as forester nor as carpenter; it was the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delight of the living tree itself.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he stepped out at last upon the lofty platform, Haldir took his hand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and turned him toward the South. 'Look this way first! â€™ he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked and saw, still at some distance, a hill of many mighty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees, or a city of green towers: which it was he could not tell. Out of it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it seemed to him that the power and light came that held all the land in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sway. He longed suddenly to fly like a bird to rest in the green city. Then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he looked eastward and saw all the land of Lurien running down to the pale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gleam of Anduin, the Great River. He lifted his eyes across the river and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the light went out, and he was back again in the world he knew. Beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the river the land appeared flat and empty, formless and vague, until far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away it rose again like a wall, dark and drear. The sun that lay on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lothlurien had no power to enlighten the shadow of that distant height.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There lies the fastness of Southern Mirkwood,' said Haldir. 'It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clad in a forest of dark fir, where the trees strive one against another and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their branches rot and wither. In the midst upon a stony height stands Dol<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Guldur, where long the hidden Enemy had his dwelling. We fear that now it is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">inhabited again, and with power sevenfold. A black cloud lies often over it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of late. In this high place you may see the two powers that are opposed one<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to another; and ever they strive now in thought, but whereas the light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">perceives the very heart of the darkness, its own secret has not been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">discovered. Not yet.' He turned and climbed swiftly down, and they followed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At the hill's foot Frodo found Aragorn, standing still and silent as a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree; but in his hand was a small golden bloom of elanor, and a light was in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his eyes. He was wrapped in some fair memory: and as Frodo looked at him he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew that he beheld things as they once had been in this same place. For the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grim years were removed from the face of Aragorn, and he seemed clothed in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white, a young lord tall and fair; and he spoke words in the Elvish tongue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to one whom Frodo could not see. Arwen vanimelda, nambril! he said, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he drew a breath, and returning out of his thought he looked at Frodo and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smiled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here is the heart of Elvendom on earth,' he said, 'and here my heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dwells ever, unless there be a light beyond the dark roads that we still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must tread, you and I. Come with me! ' And taking Frodo's hand in his, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">left the hill of Cerin Amroth and came there never again as living man.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 7 . The Mirror of Galadriel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun was sinking behind the mountains, and the shadows were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deepening in the woods, when they went on again. Their paths now went into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thickets where the dusk had already gathered. Night came beneath the trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as they walked, and the Elves uncovered their silver lamps.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly they came out into the open again and found themselves under a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale evening sky pricked by a few early stars. There was a wide treeless<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">space before them, running in a great circle and bending away on either<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hand. Beyond it was a deep fosse lost in soft shadow, but the grass upon its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">brink was green, as if it glowed still in memory of the sun that had gone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Upon the further side there rose to a great height a green wall encircling a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green hill thronged with mallorn-trees taller than any they had yet seen in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the land. Their height could not be guessed, but they stood up in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twilight like living towers. In their, many -tiered branches and amid their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever-moving leaves countless lights were gleaming, green and gold and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver. Haldir turned towards the Company.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome to Caras Galadhon! ' he said. 'Here is the city of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galadhrim where dwell the Lord Celeborn and Galadriel the Lady of Lurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But we cannot enter here, for the gates do not look northward. We must go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">round to the southern side, and the way is not short, for the city is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a road paved with white stone running on the outer brink of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the fosse. Along this they went westward, with the city ever climbing up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like a green cloud upon their left; and as the night deepened more lights<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprang forth, until all the hill seemed afire with stars. They came at last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to a white bridge, and crossing found the great gates of the city: they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">faced south-west, set between the ends of the encircling wall that here<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">overlapped, and they were tall and strong, and hung with many lamps.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir knocked and spoke, and the gates opened soundlessly; but of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">guards Lrodo could see no sign. The travellers passed within, and the gates<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shut behind them. They were in a deep lane between the ends of the wall, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passing quickly through it they entered the City of the Trees. No folk could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they see, nor hear any feet upon the paths; but there were many voices,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about them, and in the air above. Ear away up on the hill they could hear<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the sound of singing falling from on high like soft rain upon leaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They went along many paths and climbed many stairs, until they came to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the high places and saw before them amid a wide lawn a fountain shimmering.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was lit by silver lamps that swung from the boughs of trees, and it fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into a basin of silver, from which a white stream spilled. Upon the south<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side of the lawn there stood the mightiest of all the trees; its great<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smooth bole gleamed like grey silk, and up it towered, until its first<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branches, far above, opened their huge limbs under shadowy clouds of leaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beside it a broad white ladder stood, and at its foot three Elves were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seated. They sprang up as the travellers approached, and Frodo saw that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were tall and clad in grey mail, and from their shoulders hung long white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloaks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here dwell Celeborn and Galadriel,' said Haldir. v It is their wish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that you should ascend and speak with them.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One of the Elf-wardens then blew a clear note on a small horn, and it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was answered three times from far above. V I will go first,' said Haldir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let Frodo come next and with him Legolas. The others may follow as they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish. It is a long climb for those that are not accustomed to such stairs,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but you may rest upon the way.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As he climbed slowly up Frodo passed many flets: some on one side, some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on another, and some set about the bole of the tree, so that the ladder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed through them. At a great height above the ground he came to a wide<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talan, like the deck of a great ship. On it was built a house, so large that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost it would have served for a hall of Men upon the earth. He entered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">behind Haldir, and found that he was in a chamber of oval shape, in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">midst of which grew the trunk of the great mallorn, now tapering towards its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crown, and yet making still a pillar of wide girth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The chamber was filled with a soft light; its walls were green and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver and its roof of gold. Many Elves were seated there. On two chairs<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beneath the bole of the tree and canopied by a living bough there sat, side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by side, Celeborn and Galadriel. They stood up to greet their guests, after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the manner of Elves, even those who were accounted mighty kings. Very tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were, and the Lady no less tall than the Lord; and they were grave and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beautiful. They were clad wholly in white; and the hair of the Lady was of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep gold, and the hair of the Lord Celeborn was of silver long and bright;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but no sign of age was upon them, unless it were in the depths of their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eyes; for these were keen as lances in the starlight, and yet profound, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wells of deep memory.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir led Frodo before them, and the Lord welcomed him in his own<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tongue. The Lady Galadriel said no word but looked long upon his face.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Sit now beside my chair, Frodo of the Shire! ' said Celeborn. 'When<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all have come we will speak together.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Each of the companions he greeted courteously by name as they entered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome Aragorn son of Arathorn! â€™ he said. 'It is eight and thirty years<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the world outside since you came to this land; and those years lie heavy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on you. But the end is near, for good or ill. Here lay aside your burden for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a while ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome son of Thranduil! Too seldom do my kindred journey hither from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the North.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Welcome Gimli son of Gluin! It is long indeed since we saw one of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Durin's folk in Caras Galadhon. But today we have broken our long law. May<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it be a sign that though the world is now dark better days are at hand, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that friendship shall be renewed between our peoples.' Gimli bowed low.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When all the guests were seated before his chair the Lord looked at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them again. 'Here there are eight,' he said. 'Nine were to set out: so said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the messages. But maybe there has been some change of counsel that we have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not heard. Elrond is far away, and darkness gathers between us, and all this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">year the shadows have grown longer.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nay, there was no change of counsel,' said the Lady Galadriel speaking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the first time. Her voice was clear and musical, but deeper than woman's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wont. 'Gandalf the Grey set out with the Company, but he did not pass the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borders of this land. Now tell us where he is; for I much desired to speak<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with him again. But I cannot see him from afar, unless he comes within the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fences of Lothlurien: a grey mist is about him, and the ways of his feet and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of his mind are hidden from me.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Alas! ' said Aragorn. 'Gandalf the Grey fell into shadow. He remained<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Moria and did not escape.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At these words all the Elves in the hall cried aloud in grief and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">amazement. 'These are evil tidings,' said Celeborn, 'the most evil that have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been spoken here in long years full of grievous deeds.' He turned to Haldir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why has nothing of this been told to me before? ' he asked in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elven-tongue.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have not spoken to Haldir of our deeds or our purpose,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas. 'At first we were weary and danger was too close behind and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">afterwards we almost forgot our grief for a time, as we walked in gladness<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the fair paths of Lurien.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yet our grief is great and our loss cannot be mended,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Gandalf was our guide, and he led us through Moria; and when our escape<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed beyond hope he saved us, and he fell.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tell us now the full tale! ' said Celeborn:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then Aragorn recounted all that had happened upon the pass of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Caradhras, and in the days that followed; and he spoke of Balin and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">book, and the fight in the Chamber of Mazarbul, and the fire, and the narrow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bridge, and the coming of the Terror. 'An evil of the Ancient World it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed, such as I have never seen before,' said Aragorn. 'It was both a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow and a flame, strong and terrible.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It was a Balrog of Morgoth,' said Legolas; 'of all elf-banes the most<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deadly, save the One who sits in the Dark Tower.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed I saw upon the bridge that which haunts our darkest dreams 1<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">saw Durin's Bane,' said Gimli in a low voice, and dread was in his eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Alas! ' said Celeborn. 'We long have feared that under Caradhras a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terror slept. But had I known that the Dwarves had stirred up this evil in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Moria again, 1 would have forbidden you to pass the northern borders, you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and all that went with you. And if it were possible, one would say that at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the last Gandalf fell from wisdom into folly, going needlessly into the net<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Moria.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'He would be rash indeed that said that thing,' said Galadriel gravely.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Needless were none of the deeds of Gandalf in life. Those that followed him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew not his mind and cannot report his full purpose. But however it may be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the guide, the followers are blameless. Do not repent of your welcome<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Dwarf. If our folk had been exiled long and far from Lothlurien, who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Galadhrim, even Celeborn the Wise, would pass nigh and would not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to look upon their ancient home, though it had become an abode of dragons?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Dark is the water of Kheled-zvram, and cold are the springs of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Kibil-nvla, and fair were the many -pillared halls of Khazad-dym in Elder<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Days before the fall of mighty kings beneath the stone.' She looked upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli, who sat glowering and sad, and she smiled. And the Dwarf, hearing the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">names given in his own ancient tongue, looked up and met her eyes; and it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed to him that he looked suddenly into the heart of an enemy and saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there love and understanding. Wonder came into his face, and then he smiled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in answer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He rose clumsily and bowed in dwarf-fashion, saying: 'Yet more fair is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the living land of Lurien, and the Lady Galadriel is above all the jewels<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that lie beneath the earth! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a silence. At length Celeborn spoke again. 'I did not know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that your plight was so evil,â€™ he said. 'Let Gimli forget my harsh words: I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke in the trouble of my heart. I will do what I can to aid you, each<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">according to his wish and need, but especially that one of the little folk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who bears the burden.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Your quest is known to us,' said Galadriel, looking at Frodo. 'But we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will not here speak of it more openly. Yet not in vain will it prove, maybe,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that you came to this land seeking aid, as Gandalf himself plainly purposed.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For the Lord of the Galadhrim is accounted the wisest of the Elves of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Middle-earth, and a giver of gifts beyond the power of kings. He has dwelt<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the West since the days of dawn, and I have dwelt with him years<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uncounted; for ere the fall of Nargothrond or Gondolin I passed over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountains, and together through ages of the world we have fought the long<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">defeat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™I it was who first summoned the White Council. And if my designs had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not gone amiss, it would have been governed by Gandalf the Grey, and then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mayhap things would have gone otherwise. But even now there is hope left. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will not give you counsel, saying do this, or do that. For not in doing or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">contriving, nor in choosing between this course and another, can I avail;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but only in knowing what was and is, and in part also what shall be. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this I will say to you: your Quest stands upon the edge of a knife. Stray<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but a little and it will fail, to the ruin of all. Yet hope remains while<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all the Company is true.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And with that word she held them with her eyes, and in silence looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">searchingly at each of them in turn. None save Legolas and Aragorn could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">long endure her glance. Sam quickly blushed and hung his head.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length the Lady Galadriel released them from her eyes, and she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smiled. 'Do not let your hearts be troubled,' she said. 'Tonight you shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep in peace.' Then they sighed and felt suddenly weary, as those who have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">been questioned long and deeply, though no words had been spoken openly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Go now! ' said Celeborn. 'You are worn with sorrow and much toil. Even<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if your Quest did not concern us closely, you should have refuge in this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">City, until you were healed and refreshed. Now you shall rest, and we will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not speak of your further road for a while.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That night the Company slept upon the ground, much to the satisfaction<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the hobbits. The Elves spread for them a pavilion among the trees near<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the fountain, and in it they laid soft couches; then speaking words of peace<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with fair elvish voices they left them. For a little while the travellers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">talked of their night before in the tree-tops, and of their day's journey,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and of the Lord and Lady; for they had not yet the heart to look further<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What did you blush for, Sam? â€™ said Pippin. 'You soon broke down.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Anyone would have thought you had a guilty conscience. I hope it was nothing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">worse than a wicked plot to steal one of my blankets.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I never thought no such thing,â€™ answered Sam, in no mood for jest. â€™If<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you want to know, I felt as if I hadnâ€™t got nothing on, and I didn't like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. She seemed to be looking inside me and asking me what I would do if she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave me the chance of flying back home to the Shire to a nice little hole<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with-with a bit of garden of my own.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That's funny,' said Merry. 'Almost exactly what I felt myself; only,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only well, I don't think I'll say any more,' he ended lamely.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All of them, it seemed, had fared alike: each had felt that he was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">offered a choice between a shadow full of fear that lay ahead, and something<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that he greatly desired: clear before his mind it lay, and to get it he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only to turn aside from the road and leave the Quest and the war against<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sauron to others.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And it seemed to me, too,' said Gimli, 'that my choice would remain<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">secret and known only to myself.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'To me it seemed exceedingly strange,' said Boromir. 'Maybe it was only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a test, and she thought to read our thoughts for her own good purpose; but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">almost I should have said that she was tempting us, and offering what she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pretended to have the power to give. It need not be said that I refused to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">listen. The Men of Minas Tirith are true to their word.â€™ But what he thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that the Lady had offered him Boromir did not tell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And as for Frodo, he would not speak, though Boromir pressed him with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">questions. 'She held you long in her gaze, Ring -bearer,â€™ he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Frodo; 'but whatever came into my mind then I will keep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, have a care! 'said Boromir. 'I do not feel too sure of this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elvish Lady and her purposes.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Speak no evil of the Lady Galadriel! ' said Aragorn sternly. 'You know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not what you say. There is in her and in this land no evil, unless a man<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bring it hither himself . Then let him beware ! But tonight I shall sleep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without fear for the first time since I left Rivendell. And may I sleep<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep, and forget for a while my grief! I am weary in body and in heart.' He<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cast himself down upon his couch and fell at once into a long sleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others soon did the same, and no sound or dream disturbed their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slumber. When they woke they found that the light of day was broad upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lawn before the pavilion, and the fountain rose and fell glittering in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sun.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They remained some days in Lothlurien, so far as they could tell or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remember. All the while that they dwelt there the sun shone clear, save for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a gentle rain that fell at times, and passed away leaving all things fresh<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and clean. The air was cool and soft, as if it were early spring, yet they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">felt about them the deep and thoughtful quiet of winter. It seemed to them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they did little but eat and drink and rest, and walk among the trees;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and it was enough.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had not seen the Lord and Lady again, and they had little speech<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the Elven-folk; for few of these knew or would use the Westron tongue.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Haldir had bidden them farewell and gone back again to the fences of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">North, where great watch was now kept since the tidings of Moria that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Company had brought. Legolas was away much among the Galadhrim, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">after<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the first night he did not sleep with the other companions, though he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">returned to eat and talk with them. Often he took Gimli with him when he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went abroad in the land, and the others wondered at this change.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now as the companions sat or walked together they spoke of Gandalf, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">all that each had known and seen of him came clear before their minds. As<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were healed of hurt and weariness of body the grief of their loss grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more keen. Often they heard nearby Elvish voices singing, and knew that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were making songs of lamentation for his fall, for they caught his name<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">among the sweet sad words that they could not understand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mithrandir, Mithrandir sang the Elves, O Pilgrim Grey! For so they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">loved to call him. But if Legolas was with the Company, he would not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">interpret the songs for them, saying that he had not the skill, and that for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him the grief was still too near, a matter for tears and not yet for song.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">It was Frodo who first put something of his sorrow into halting words.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He was seldom moved to make song or rhyme; even in Ri vendell he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">listened<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and had not sung himself, though his memory was stored with many things that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">others had made before him. But now as he sat beside the fountain in Lurien<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and heard about him the voices of the Elves, his thought took shape in a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">song that seemed fair to him; yet when he tried to repeat it to Sam only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">snatches remained, faded as a handful of withered leaves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When evening in the Shire was grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his footsteps on the Hill were heard;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before the dawn he went away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on journey long without a word.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">From Wilderland to Western shore,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from northern waste to southern hill,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through dragon-lair and hidden door<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and darkling woods he walked at will.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With Dwarf and Hobbit, Elves and Men,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with mortal and immortal folk,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with bird on bough and beast in den,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in their own secret tongues he spoke.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A deadly sword, a healing hand,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a back that bent beneath its load;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a trumpet-voice, a burning brand,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a weary pilgrim on the road.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">A lord of wisdom throned he sat,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swift in anger, quick to laugh;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">an old man in a battered hat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">who leaned upon a thorny staff.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He stood upon the bridge alone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and Fire and Shadow both defied;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his staff was broken on the stone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in Khazad-dym his wisdom died.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why, you'll be beating Mr. Bilbo next! ' said Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I am afraid not,' said Frodo. 'But that is the best I can do yet.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, Mr. Frodo, if you do have another go, I hope you'll say a word<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about his fireworks,' said Sam. 'Something like this:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The finest rockets ever seen:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they burst in stars of blue and green,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">or after thunder golden showers<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">came falling like a rain of flowers.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Though that doesn't do them justice by a long road.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I'll leave that to you, Sam. Or perhaps to Bilbo. But-well. I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can't talk of it any more. I can't bear to think of bringing the news to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One evening Frodo and Sam were walking together in the cool twilight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Both of them felt restless again. On Frodo suddenly the shadow of parting<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had fallen: he knew somehow that the time was very near when he must leave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lothlurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What do you think of Elves now, Sam? â€™ he said. 'I asked you the same<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">question once before-it seems a very long while ago; but you have seen more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of them since then.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have indeed! ' said Sam. 'And I reckon there's Elves and Elves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They're all elvish enough, but they're not all the same. Now these folk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aren't wanderers or homeless, and seem a bit nearer to the likes of us: they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seem to belong here, more even than Flobbits do in the Shire. Whether they've<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made the land, or the land's made them, it's hard to say, if you take my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meaning. It's wonderfully quiet here. Nothing seems to be going on, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nobody seems to want it to. If there's any magic about, it's right down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep, where I can't lay my hands on it, in a manner of speaking.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You can see and feel it everywhere,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well,' said Sam, 'you can't see nobody working it. No fireworks like<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">poor Gandalf used to show. I wonder we don't see nothing of the Lord and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lady in all these days. I fancy now that she could do some wonderful things,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if she had a mind. I'd dearly love to see some Elf-magic, Mr. Frodo! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I wouldn't,' said Frodo. 'I am content. And I don't miss Gandalf's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fireworks, but his bushy eyebrows, and his quick temper, and his voice.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You're right,' said Sam. 'And don't think I'm finding fault. I've<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">often wanted to see a bit of magic like what it tells of in old tales, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I've never heard of a better land than this. It's like being at home and on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a holiday at the same time, if you understand me. I don't want to leave. All<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the same, I'm beginning to feel that if weâ€™ve got to go on, then we'd best<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get it over.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It's the job that's never started as takes longest to finish, as my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">old gaffer used to say. And I don't reckon that these folk can do much more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to help us, magic or no. It's when we leave this land that we shall miss<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf worse, I'm thinking.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I am afraid that's only too true, Sam,' said Frodo. 'Yet I hope very<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much that before we leave we shall see the Lady of the Elves again.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Even as he spoke, they saw, as if she came in answer to their words,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Lady Galadriel approaching. Tall and white and fair she walked beneath<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the trees. She spoke no word, but beckoned to them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Turning aside, she led them toward the southern slopes of the hill of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Caras Galadhon, and passing through a high green hedge they came into an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">enclosed garden. No trees grew there, and it lay open to the sky. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evening star had risen and was shining with white fire above the western<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods. Down a long flight of steps the Lady went into a deep green hollow,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through which ran murmuring the silver stream that issued from the fountain<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the hill. At the bottom, upon a low pedestal carved like a branching<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tree, stood a basin of silver, wide and shallow, and beside it stood a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver ewer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With water from the stream Galadriel filled the basin to the brim, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">breathed on it, and when the water was still again she spoke. 'Here is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mirror of Galadriel,â€™ she said. â€™I have brought you here so that you may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look in it, if you will.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The air was very still, and the dell was dark, and the Elf-lady beside<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him was tall and pale. 'What shall we look for, and what shall we see? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">asked Frodo, filled with awe.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Many things I can command the Mirror to reveal,' she answered, 'and to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some I can show what they desire to see. But the Mirror will also show<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things unbidden, and those are often stranger and more profitable than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">things which we wish to behold. What you will see, if you leave the Mirror<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">free to work, I cannot tell. For it shows things that were, and things that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are, things that yet may be. But which it is that he sees, even the wisest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cannot always tell. Do you wish to look? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo did not answer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And you? â€™ she said, turning to Sam. 'For this is what your folk would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">call magic. I believe; though I do not understand clearly what they mean;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they seem also to use the same word of the deceits of the Enemy. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this, if you will, is the magic of Galadriel. Did you not say that you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wished to see Elf-magic? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I did,' said Sam, trembling a little between fear and curiosity. Til<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have a peep, Lady, if you're willing.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And I'd not mind a glimpse of what's going on at home,' he said in an<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">aside to Frodo. 'It seems a terrible long time that I've been away. But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there, like as not I'll only see the stars, or something that I won't<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">understand.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Like as not,' said the Lady with a gentle laugh. 'But come, you shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">look and see what you may. Do not touch the water! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam climbed up on the foot of the pedestal and leaned over the basin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The water looked hard and dark. Stars were reflected in it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There's only stars, as I thought,' he said. Then he gave a low gasp,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for the stars went out. As if a dark veil had been withdrawn, the Mirror<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew grey, and then clear. There was sun shining, and the branches of trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were waving and tossing in the wind. But before Sam could make up his mind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what it was that he saw, the light faded; and now he thought he saw Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with a pale face lying fast asleep under a great dark cliff. Then he seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to see himself going along a dim passage, and climbing an endless winding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stair. It came to him suddenly that he was looking urgently for something,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">but what it was he did not know. Like a dream the vision shifted and went<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back, and he saw the trees again. But this time they were not so close, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he could see what was going on: they were not waving in the wind, they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">falling, crashing to the ground.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hi!' cried Sam in an outraged voice. 'There's that Ted Sandyman<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a-cutting down trees as he shouldn't. They didn't ought to be felled: it's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that avenue beyond the Mill that shades the road to Bywater. I wish I could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">get at Ted, and I'd fell himV<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But now Sam noticed that the Old Mill had vanished, and a large<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">red-brick building was being put up where it had stood. Lots of folk were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">busily at work. There was a tall red chimney nearby. Black smoke seemed to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cloud the surface of the Mirror.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'There's some devilry at work in the Shire,' he said. 'Elrond knew what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was about when he wanted to send Mr. Merry back.' Then suddenly Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gave<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a cry and sprang away. 'I can't stay here,' he said wildly. 'I must go home.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
