<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your finger since you knew what you possessed. Do not try! It would destroy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you. Did not Gandalf tell you that the rings give power according to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">measure of each possessor? Before you could use that power you would need<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become far stronger, and to train your will to the domination of others. Yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">even so, as Ring-bearer and as one that has borne it on finger and seen that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which is hidden, your sight is grown keener. You have perceived my thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">more clearly than many that are accounted wise. You saw the Eye of him that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">holds the Seven and the Nine. And did you not see and recognize the ring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon my finger? Did you see my ring? â€™ she asked turning again to Sam.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, Lady,' he answered. 'To tell you the truth, I wondered what you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were talking about. I saw a star through your finger. But if you'll pardon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my speaking out, I think my master was right. I wish you'd take his Ring.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">You'd put things to rights. You'd stop them digging up the gaffer and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">turning him adrift. You'd make some folk pay for their dirty work.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I would,' she said. 'That is how it would begin. But it would not stop<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with that, alas! We will not speak more of it. Let us go!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 8 . Farewell to Lurien<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">That night the Company was again summoned to the chamber of Celeborn,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and there the Lord and Lady greeted them with fair words. At length Celeborn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spoke of their departure.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now is the time,' he said, 'when those who wish to continue the Quest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must harden their hearts to leave this land. Those who no longer wish to go<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward may remain here, for a while. But whether they stay or go, none can<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be sure of peace. For we are come now to the edge of doom. Here those who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish may await the oncoming of the hour till either the ways of the world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lie open again, or we summon them to the last need of Lurien. Then they may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">return to their own lands, or else go to the long home of those that fall in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">battle.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a silence. 'They all resolved to go forward,â€™ said Galadriel<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking in their eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As for me,â€™ said Boromir, 'my way home lies onward and not back.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is true,â€™ said Celeborn, 'but is all this Company going with you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to Minas Tirith? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have not decided our course,â€™ said Aragorn. â€™Beyond Lothlurien I do<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not know what Gandalf intended to do. Indeed I do not think that even he had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">any clear purpose.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe not,â€™ said Celeborn, 'yet when you leave this land, you can no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">longer forget the Great River. As some of you know well, it cannot be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crossed by travellers with baggage between Lurien and Gondor, save by boat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And are not the bridges of Osgiliath broken down and all the landings held<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now by the Enemy?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'On which side will you journey? The way to Minas Tirith lies upon this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side, upon the west; but the straight road of the Quest lies east of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River, upon the darker shore. Which shore will you now take? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'If my advice is heeded, it will be the western shore, and the way to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Minas Tirith,â€™ answered Boromir. 'But I am not the leader of the Company.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others said nothing, and Aragorn looked doubtful and troubled.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I see that you do not yet know what to do,â€™ said Celeborn. 'It is not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">my part to choose for you; but I will help you as I may. There are some<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">among you who can handle boats: Legolas, whose folk know the swift Forest<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River; and Boromir of Gondor; and Aragorn the traveller.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And one Hobbit! ' cried Merry. 'Not all of us look on boats as wild<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horses. My people live by the banks of the Brandywine.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'That is well,â€™ said Celeborn. 'Then I will furnish your Company with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boats. They must be small and light, for if you go far by water, there are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">places where you will be forced to carry them. You will come to the rapids<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Sarn Gebir, and maybe at last to the great falls of Rauros where the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">River thunders down from Nen Hithoel; and there are other perils. Boats may<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">make your journey less toilsome for awhile. Yet they will not give you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">counsel: in the end you must leave them and the River, and turn west-or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">east.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn thanked Celeborn many times. The gift of boats comforted him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">much, not least because there would now be no need to decide his course for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">some days. The others, too, looked more hopeful. Whatever perils lay ahead,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it seemed better to float down the broad tide of Anduin to meet them than to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">plod forward with bent backs. Only Sam was doubtful: he at any rate still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thought boats as bad as wild horses, or worse, and not all the dangers that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had survived made him think better of them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'All shall be prepared for you and await you at the haven before noon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tomorrow,' said Celeborn. 'I will send my people to you in the morning to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">help you make ready for the journey. Now we will wish you all a fair night<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and untroubled sleep.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Good night, my friends! ' said Galadriel. 'Sleep in peace! Do not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trouble your hearts overmuch with thought of the road tonight. Maybe the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paths that you each shall tread are already laid before your feet, though<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you do not see them. Good night! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company now took their leave and returned to their pavilion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas went with them, for this was to be their last night in Lothlurien,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and in spite of the words of Galadriel they wished to take counsel together.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">For a long time they debated what they should do, and how it would be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">best to attempt the fulfilling of their purpose with the Ring: but they came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to no decision. It was plain that most of them desired to go first to Minas<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tirith, and to escape at least for a while from the terror of the Enemy.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They would have been willing to follow a leader over the River and into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow of Mordor; but Frodo spoke no word, and Aragorn was still divided in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his mind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">His own plan, while Gandalf remained with them, had been to go with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir, and with his sword help to deliver Gondor. For he believed that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">message of the dreams was a summons, and that the hour had come at last<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">when<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the heir of Elendil should come forth and strive with Sauron for the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mastery. But in Moria the burden of Gandalf had been laid on him; and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knew that he could not now forsake the Ring, if Frodo refused in the end to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">go with Boromir. And yet what help could he or any of the Company give to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo, save to walk blindly with him into the darkness?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I shall go to Minas Tirith, alone if need be, for it is my duty,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir; and after that he was silent for a while, sitting with his eyes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fixed on Frodo, as if he was trying to read the Halflingâ€™s thoughts. At<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">length he spoke again, softly, as if he was debating with himself. 'If you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wish only to destroy the Ring,â€™ he said, "then there is little use in war<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and weapons; and the Men of Minas Tirith cannot help. But if you wish to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">destroy the armed might of the Dark Lord, then it is folly to go without<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">force into his domain; and folly to throw away.' He paused suddenly, as if<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he had become aware that he was speaking his thoughts aloud. 'It would be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">folly to throw lives away, I mean,' he ended. 'It is a choice between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">defending a strong place and walking openly into the arms of death. At<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">least, that is how I see it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo caught something new and strange in Boromir's glance, and he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked hard at him. Plainly Boromir's thought was different from his final<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">words. It would be folly to throw away: what? The Ring of Power? He had said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">something like this at the Council, but then he had accepted the correction<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Elrond. Frodo looked at Aragorn, but he seemed deep in his own thought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and made no sign that he had heeded Boromir's words. And so their debate<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ended. Merry and Pippin were already asleep, and Sam was nodding. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">night<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was growing old.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the morning, as they were beginning to pack their slender goods,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves that could speak their tongue came to them and brought them many gifts<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of food and clothing for the journey. The food was mostly in the form of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">very thin cakes, made of a meal that was baked a light brown on the outside,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and inside was the colour of cream. Gimli took up one of the cakes and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looked at it with a doubtful eye.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Cram,' he said under his breath, as he broke off a crisp corner and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nibbled at it. His expression quickly changed, and he ate all the rest of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the cake with relish.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No more, no more!' cried the Elves laughing. 'You have eaten enough<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">already for a long dayâ€™s march.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I thought it was only a kind of cram , such as the Dale-men make for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journeys in the wild,â€™ said the Dwarf.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'So it is,â€™ they answered. 'But we call it lembas or waybread, and it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is more strengthening than any food made by Men, and it is more pleasant<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">than cram, by all accounts.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed it is,â€™ said Gimli. â€™Why it is better than the honey-cakes of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Beornings, and that is great praise, for the Beornings are the best<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bakers that I know of; but they are none too willing to deal out their cakes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to travellers in these days. You are kindly hosts! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™All the same, we bid you spare the food,â€™ they said. â€™Eat little at a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">time, and only at need. For these things are given to serve you when all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">else fails. The cakes will keep sweet for many many days, if they are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unbroken and left in their leaf- wrappings, as we have brought them. One will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">keep a traveller on his feet for a day of long labour, even if he be one of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the tall Men of Minas Tirith.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Elves next unwrapped and gave to each of the Company the clothes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they had brought. For each they had provided a hood and cloak, made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">according to his size, of the light but warm silken stuff that the Galadhrim<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wove. It was hard to say of what colour they were: grey with the hue of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twilight under the trees they seemed to be; and yet if they were moved, or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">set in another light, they were green as shadowed leaves, or brown as fallow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fields by night, dusk-silver as water under the stars. Each cloak was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fastened about the neck with a brooch like a green leaf veined with silver.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Are these magic cloaks? â€™ asked Pippin, looking at them with wonder.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know what you mean by that,â€™ answered the leader of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elves. 'They are fair garments, and the web is good, for it was made in this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">land. They are elvish robes certainly, if that is what you mean. Leaf and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">branch, water and stone: they have the hue and beauty of all these things<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under the twilight of Lurien that we love; for we put the thought of all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that we love into all that we make. Yet they are garments, not armour, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they will not turn shaft or blade. But they should serve you well: they are<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light to wear, and warm enough or cool enough at need. And you will find<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them a great aid in keeping out of the sight of unfriendly eyes, whether you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">walk among the stones or the trees. You are indeed high in the favour of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lady! For she herself and her maidens wove this stuff; and never before have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">we clad strangers in the garb of our own people.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After their morning meal the Company said farewell to the lawn by the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fountain. Their hearts were heavy; for it was a fair place, and it had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">become like home to them, though they could not count the days and nights<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that they had passed there. As they stood for a moment looking at the white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water in the sunlight, Haldir came walking towards them over the green grass<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the glade. Frodo greeted him with delight.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have returned from the Northern Fences,' said the Elf, 'and I am<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sent now to be your guide again. The Dimrill Dale is full of vapour and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clouds of smoke, and the mountains are troubled. There are noises in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deeps of the earth. If any of you had thought of returning northwards to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">your homes, you would not have been able to pass that way. But come! Your<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">path now goes south.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As they walked through Caras Galadhon the green ways were empty; but in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the trees above them many voices were murmuring and singing. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">themselves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">went silently. At last Haldir led them down the southward slopes of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hill, and they came again to the great gate hung with lamps, and to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white bridge; and so they passed out and left the city of the Elves. Then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they turned away from the paved road and took a path that went off into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep thicket of mallorn-trees, and passed on, winding through rolling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woodlands of silver shadow, leading them ever down, southwards and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastwards, towards the shores of the River.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They had gone some ten miles and noon was at hand when they came on a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">high green wall. Passing through an opening they came suddenly out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees. Before them lay a long lawn of shining grass, studded with golden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">elanor that glinted in the sun. The lawn ran out into a narrow tongue<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between bright margins: on the right and west the Silverlode flowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glittering; on the left and east the Great River rolled its broad waters,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">deep and dark. On the further shores the woodlands still marched on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southwards as far as the eye could see, but all the banks were bleak and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bare. No mallorn lifted its gold-hung boughs beyond the Land of Lurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the bank of the Silverlode, at some distance up from the meeting of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the streams, there was a hythe of white stones and white wood. By it were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">moored many boats and barges. Some were brightly painted, and shone with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver and gold and green, but most were either white or grey. Three small<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey boats had been made ready for the travellers, and in these the Elves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stowed their goods. And they added also coils of rope, three to each boat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slender they looked, but strong, silken to the touch, grey of hue like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">elven-cloaks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What are these? ' asked Sam, handling one that lay upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">greensward.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ropes indeed! ' answered an Elf from the boats. 'Never travel far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without a rope! And one that is long and strong and light. Such are these.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They may be a help in many needs.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You don't need to tell me that! ' said Sam. I came without any and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I've been worried ever since. But I was wondering what these were made of,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">knowing a bit about rope -making: it's in the family as you might say.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They are made of hithlain,' said the Elf, 'but there is no time now to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">instruct you in the art of their making. Had we known that this craft<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">delighted you, we could have taught you much. But now alas! unless you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">should at some time return hither, you must be content with our gift. May it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">serve you well ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come! ' said Haldir. 'All is now ready for you. Enter the boats! But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">take care at first! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Heed the words! ' said the other Elves. 'These boats are light-built,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and they are crafty and unlike the boats of other folk. They will not sink,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lade them as you will; but they are wayward if mishandled. It would be wise<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">if you accustomed yourselves to stepping in and out, here where there is a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">landing-place, before you set off downstream.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company was arranged in this way: Aragorn, Frodo, and Sam were in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one boat; Boromir, Merry, and Pippin in another; and in the third were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas and Gimli, who had now become fast friends. In this last boat most<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the goods and packs were stowed. The boats were moved and steered with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">short-handled paddles that had broad leaf-shaped blades. When all was ready<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn led them on a trial up the Silverlode. The current was swift and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they went forward slowly. Sam sat in the bows, clutching the sides, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">looking back wistfully to the shore. The sunlight glittering on the water<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dazzled his eyes. As they passed beyond the green field of the Tongue, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trees drew down to the river's brink. Here and there golden leaves tossed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and floated on the rippling stream. The air was very bright and still, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was a silence, except for the high distant song of larks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They turned a sharp bend in the river, and there, sailing proudly down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the stream toward them, they saw a swan of great size. The water rippled on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">either side of the white breast beneath its curving neck. Its beak shone<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like burnished gold, and its eyes glinted like jet set in yellow stones; its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">huge white wings were half lifted. A music came down the river as it drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nearer; and suddenly they perceived that it was a ship, wrought and carved<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with elven-skill in the likeness of a bird. Two elves clad in white steered<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it with black paddles. In the midst of the vessel sat Celeborn, and behind<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him stood Galadriel, tall and white; a circlet of golden flowers was in her<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hair, and in her hand she held a harp, and she sang. Sad and sweet was the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sound of her voice in the cool clear air:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I sang of leaves, of leaves of gold, and leaves of gold there grew:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Of wind I sang, a wind there came and in the branches blew.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beyond the Sun, beyond the Moon, the foam was on the Sea,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And by the strand of Ilmarin there grew a golden Tree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Beneath the stars of Ever-eve in Eldamar it shone,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In Eldamar beside the walls of Elven Tirion.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There long the golden leaves have grown upon the branching years,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">While here beyond the Sundering Seas now fall the Elven-tears.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O Lurien! The Winter comes, the bare and leafless Day;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The leaves are falling in the stream, the River flows away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">O Lurien! Too long I have dwelt upon this Hither Shore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And in a fading crown have twined the golden elanor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But if of ships I now should sing, what ship would come to me,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">What ship would bear me ever back across so wide a Sea?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn stayed his boat as the Swan-ship drew alongside. The Lady ended<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her song and greeted them. 'We have come to bid you our last farewell,' she<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said, 'and to speed you with blessings from our land.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Though you have been our guests,â€™ said Celeborn, 'you have not yet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eaten with us, and we bid you, therefore, to a parting feast, here between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the flowing waters that will bear you far from Lurien.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Swan passed on slowly to the hythe, and they turned their boats and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">followed it. There in the last end of Egladil upon the green grass the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">parting feast was held; but Frodo ate and drank little, heeding only the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beauty of the Lady and her voice. She seemed no longer perilous or terrible,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nor filled with hidden power. Already she seemed to him, as by men of later<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days Elves still at times are seen: present and yet remote, a living vision<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of that which has already been left far behind by the flowing streams of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Time.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After they had eaten and drunk, sitting upon the grass, Celeborn spoke<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to them again of their journey, and lifting his hand he pointed south to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">woods beyond the Tongue.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As you go down the water,' he said, 'you will find that the trees will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fail, and you will come to a barren country. There the River flows in stony<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">vale amid high moors, until at last after many leagues it comes to the tall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">island of the Tindrock, that we call Tol Brandir. There it casts its arms<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about the steep shores of the isle, and falls then with a great noise and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smoke over the cataracts of Rauros down into the Nindalf, the Wetwang as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is called in your tongue. That is a wide region of sluggish fen where the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream becomes tortuous and much divided. There the Entwash flows in by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mouths from the Forest of Fangorn in the west. About that stream, on this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side of the Great River, lies Rohan. On the further side are the bleak hills<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Emyn Muil. The wind blows from the East there, for they look out over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Dead Marshes and the Noman-lands to Cirith Gorgor and the black gates of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mordor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Boromir, and any that go with him seeking Minas Tirith, will do well<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to leave the Great River above Rauros and cross the Entwash before it finds<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the marshes. Yet they should not go too far up that stream, nor risk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">becoming entangled in the Forest of Fangorn. That is a strange land, and is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now little known. But Boromir and Aragorn doubtless do not need this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Indeed we have heard of Fangorn in Minas Tirith,' said Boromir. 'But<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">what I have heard seems to me for the most part old wives' tales, such as we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tell to our children. All that lies north of Rohan is now to us so far away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that fancy can wander freely there. Of old Fangorn lay upon the borders of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">our realm; but it is now many lives of men since any of us visited it, to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">prove or disprove the legends that have come down from distant years.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have myself been at whiles in Rohan, but I have never crossed it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">northwards. When I was sent out as a messenger, I passed through the Gap by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into Northerland. A long and wearisome journey. Four hundred leagues I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">reckoned it, and it took me many months; for I lost my horse at Tharbad, at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the fording of the Greyflood. After that journey, and the road I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trodden with this Company, I do not much doubt that I shall find a way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through Rohan, and Fangorn too, if need be.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then I need say no more,' said Celeborn. 'But do not despise the lore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that has come down from distant years; for oft it may chance that old wives<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Now it is time to drink the cup of farewell,' she said. 'Drink, Lord<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then she brought the cup to each of the Company, and bade them drink<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We have drunk the cup of parting,' she said, 'and the shadows fall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between us. But before you go, I have brought in my ship gifts which the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

</span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo took the phial, and for a moment as it shone between them, he saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her again standing like a queen, great and beautiful, but no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">terrible. He bowed, but found no words to say.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now the Lady arose, and Celeborn led them back to the hythe. A yellow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">noon lay on the green land of the Tongue, and the water glittered with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silver. All at last was made ready. The Company took their places in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boats as before. Crying farewell, the Elves of Lurien with long grey poles<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thrust them out into the flowing stream, and the rippling waters bore them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slowly away. The travellers sat still without moving or speaking. On the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">green bank near to the very point of the Tongue the Lady Galadriel stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">alone and silent. As they passed her they turned and their eyes watched her<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slowly floating away from them. For so it seemed to them: Lurien was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">slipping backward, like a bright ship masted with enchanted trees, sailing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on to forgotten shores, while they sat helpless upon the margin of the grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and leafless world.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Even as they gazed, the Silverlode passed out into the currents of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Great River, and their boats turned and began to speed southwards. Soon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white form of the Lady was small and distant. She shone like a window of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">glass upon a far hill in the westering sun, or as a remote lake seen from a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountain: a crystal fallen in the lap of the land. Then it seemed to Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that she lifted her arms in a final farewell, and far but piercing-clear on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the following wind came the sound of her voice singing. But now she sang in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the ancient tongue of the Elves beyond the Sea, and he did not understand<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the words: fair was the music, but it did not comfort him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Yet as is the way of Elvish words, they remained graven in his memory,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and long afterwards he interpreted them, as well as he could: the language<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was that of Elven-song and spoke of things little known on Middle-earth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

</span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nambril! Nai hiruvalyl Valimar.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah! like gold fall the leaves in the wind, long years numberless as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the wings of trees ! The long years have passed like swift draughts of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sweet mead in lofty halls beyond the West, beneath the blue vaults of Varda<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wherein the stars tremble in the song of her voice, holy and queenly. Who<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">now shall refill the cup for me? For now the Kindler, Varda, the Queen of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the Stars, from Mount Everwhite has uplifted her hands like clouds, and all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paths are drowned deep in shadow; and out of a grey country darkness lies on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the foaming waves between us, and mist covers the jewels of Calacirya for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ever. Now lost, lost to those from the East is Valimar! Farewell! Maybe thou<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shalt find Valimar. Maybe even thou shalt find it. Farewell! ' Varda is the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">name of that Fady whom the Elves in these lands of exile name Elbereth.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly the River swept round a bend, and the banks rose upon either<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side, and the light of Furien was hidden. To that fair land Frodo never came<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The travellers now turned their faces to the journey; the sun was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before them, and their eyes were dazzled, for all were filled with tears.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli wept openly.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I have looked the last upon that which was fairest,' he said to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fegolas his companion. 'Henceforward I will call nothing fair, unless it be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">her gift.' He put his hand to his breast.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Tell me, Fegolas, why did I come on this Quest? Tittle did I know<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">where the chief peril lay! Truly Elrond spoke, saying that we could not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">foresee what we might meet upon our road. Torment in the dark was the danger<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that I feared, and it did not hold me back. But I would not have come, had I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">known the danger of light and joy. Now I have taken my worst wound in this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">parting, even if I were to go this night straight to the Dark Ford. Alas for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli son of Gluin! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Nay! â€™ said Fegolas. 'Alas for us all! And for all that walk the world<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in these after-days. For such is the way of it: to find and lose, as it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seems to those whose boat is on the running stream. But I count you blessed,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli son of Gluin: for your loss you suffer of your own free will, and you<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">might have chosen otherwise. But you have not forsaken your companions,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the least reward that you shall have is that the memory of Fothlurien shall<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">remain ever clear and unstained in your heart, and shall neither fade nor<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grow stale.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Maybe,' said Gimli; 'and I thank you for your words. True words<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubtless; yet all such comfort is cold. Memory is not what the heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desires. That is only a mirror, be it clear as Kheled-zvram. Or so says the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heart of Gimli the Dwarf. Elves may see things otherwise. Indeed I have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard that for them memory is more like to the waking world than to a dream.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Not so for Dwarves.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But let us talk no more of it. Look to the boat! She is too low in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">water with all this baggage, and the Great River is swift. I do not wish to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drown my grief in cold water.' He took up a paddle, and steered towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western bank, following Aragorn's boat ahead, which had already moved out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the middle stream.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So the Company went on their long way, down the wide hurrying waters,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">borne ever southwards. Bare woods stalked along either bank, and they could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not see any glimpse of the lands behind. The breeze died away and the River<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowed without a sound. No voice of bird broke the silence. The sun grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">misty as the day grew old, until it gleamed in a pale sky like a high white<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pearl. Then it faded into the West, and dusk came early, followed by a grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and starless night. Far into the dark quiet hours they floated on, guiding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their boats under the overhanging shadows of the western woods. Great trees<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed by like ghosts, thrusting their twisted thirsty roots through the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mist down into the water. It was dreary and cold. Frodo sat and listened to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the faint lap and gurgle of the River fretting among the tree-roots and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">driftwood near the shore, until his head nodded and he fell into an uneasy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 9 . The Great River<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo was roused by Sam. He found that he was lying, well wrapped,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under tall grey -skinned trees in a quiet corner of the woodlands on the west<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bank of the Great River, Anduin. He had slept the night away, and the grey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of morning was dim among the bare branches. Gimli was busy with a small fire<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near at hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They started again before the day was broad. Not that most of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Company were eager to hurry southwards: they were content that the decision,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which they must make at latest when they came to Rauros and the Tindrock<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Isle, still lay some days ahead; and they let the River bear them on at its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own pace, having no desire to hasten towards the perils that lay beyond,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whichever course they took in the end. Aragorn let them drift with the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stream as they wished, husbanding their strength against weariness to come.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But he insisted that at least they should start early each day and journey<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on far into the evening; for he felt in his heart that time was pressing,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he feared that the Dark Lord had not been idle while they lingered in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nonetheless they saw no sign of an enemy that day, nor the next. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dull grey hours passed without event. As the third day of their voyage wore<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the lands changed slowly: the trees thinned and then failed altogether.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">On the eastern bank to their left they saw long formless slopes stretching<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">up and away toward the sky; brown and withered they looked, as if fire had<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed over them, leaving no living blade of green: an unfriendly waste<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">without even a broken tree or a bold stone to relieve the emptiness. They<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had come to the Brown Lands that lay, vast and desolate, between Southern<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Mirkwood and the hills of the Emyn Muil. What pestilence or war or evil deed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the Enemy had so blasted all that region even Aragorn could not tell.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Upon the west to their right the land was treeless also, but it was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flat, and in many places green with wide plains of grass. On this side of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the River they passed forests of great reeds, so tall that they shut out all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">view to the west, as the little boats went rustling by along their<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fluttering borders. Their dark withered plumes bent and tossed in the light<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cold airs, hissing softly and sadly. Here and there through openings Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could catch sudden glimpses of rolling meads, and far beyond them hills in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the sunset, and away on the edge of sight a dark line, where marched the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southernmost ranks of the Misty Mountains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was no sign of living moving things, save birds. Of these there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were many: small fowl whistling and piping in the reeds, but they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Swans! ' said Sam. 'And mighty big ones too! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yes,' said Aragorn, â€™and they are black swans.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How wide and empty and mournful all this country looks! â€™ said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I always imagined that as one journeyed south it got warmer and merrier,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™But we have not journeyed far south yet,â€™ answered Aragorn. 'It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam looked from bank to bank uneasily. The trees had seemed hostile<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before, as if they harboured secret eyes and lurking dangers; now he wished<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the next day or two, as they went on, borne steadily southwards,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the East. On the other side the meads had become rolling downs of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The heart of Legolas was running under the stars of a summer night in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam had long ago made up his mind that, though boats were maybe not as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dangerous as he had been brought up to believe, they were far more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">uncomfortable than even he had imagined. Fie was cramped and miserable,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As dusk drew down on the fourth day, he was looking back over the bowed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">In the dead hours Frodo came out of a deep dark sleep to find Sam<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He lay down, and Frodo sat up, huddled in his blankets, and fought off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
