<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will keep watch for what is left of the night. I wish I could lay my hands<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">on the wretch. We might make him useful. But if I cannot, we shall have to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">try and lose him. He is very dangerous. Quite apart from murder by night on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his own account, he may put any enemy that is about on our track.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The night passed without Gollum showing so much as a shadow again.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After that the Company kept a sharp look-out, but they saw no more of Gollum<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">while the voyage lasted. If he was still following, he was very wary and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">cunning. At Aragornâ€™s bidding they paddled now for long spells, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">banks went swiftly by. But they saw little of the country, for they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journeyed mostly by night and twilight, resting by day, and lying as hidden<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as the land allowed. In this way the time passed without event until the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seventh day.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The weather was still grey and overcast, with wind from the East, but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as evening drew into night the sky away westward cleared, and pools of faint<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">light, yellow and pale green, opened under the grey shores of cloud. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the white rind of the new Moon could be seen glimmering in the remote lakes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam looked at it and puckered his brows.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The next day the country on either side began to change rapidly. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">banks began to rise and grow stony. Soon they were passing through a hilly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rocky land, and on both shores there were steep slopes buried in deep brakes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of thorn and sloe, tangled with brambles and creepers. Behind them stood low<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">crumbling cliffs, and chimneys of grey weathered stone dark with ivy; and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beyond these again there rose high ridges crowned with wind-writhen firs.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They were drawing near to the grey hill -country of the Emyn Muil, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">southern march of Wilderland.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There were many birds about the cliffs and the rock-chimneys, and all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">day high in the air flocks of birds had been circling, black against the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">pale sky. As they lay in their camp that day Aragorn watched the flights<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">doubtfully, wondering if Gollum had been doing some mischief and the news<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their voyage was now moving in the wilderness. Later as the sun was setting,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and the Company was stirring and getting ready to start again, he descried a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark spot against the fading light: a great bird high and far off, now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wheeling, now flying on slowly southwards.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™What is that, Legolas? ' he asked, pointing to the northern sky. 'Is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, as I think, an eagle? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Yes.' said Legolas. 'It is an eagle, a hunting eagle. I wonder what<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that forebodes. It is far from the mountains.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We will not start until it is fully dark,' said Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The eighth night of their journey came. It was silent and windless; the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grey east wind had passed away. The thin crescent of the Moon had fallen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">early into the pale sunset, but the sky was clear above, and though far away<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in the South there were great ranges of cloud that still shone faintly, in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the West stars glinted bright.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come! ' said Aragorn. 'We will venture one more journey by night. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">are coming to reaches of the River that I do not know well: for I have never<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journeyed by water in these parts before, not between here and the rapids of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sarn Gebir. But if I am right in my reckoning, those are still many miles<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ahead. Still there are dangerous places even before we come there: rocks and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">stony eyots in the stream. We must keep a sharp watch and not try to paddle<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swiftly.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">To Sam in the leading boat was given the task of watchman. He lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">forward peering into the gloom. The night grew dark, but the stars above<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were strangely bright, and there was a glimmer On the face of the River. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was close on midnight, and they had been drifting for some while, hardly<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">using the paddles, when suddenly Sam cried out. Only a few yards ahead dark<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shapes loomed up in the stream and he heard the swirl of racing water. There<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was a swift current which swung left, towards the eastern shore where the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thrust out far into the stream like a ridge of teeth. The boats were all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">huddled together.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Hoy there, Aragorn! â€™ shouted Boromir, as his boat bumped into the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leader. 'This is madness! We cannot dare the Rapids by night! But no boat<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can live in Sarn Gebir, be it night or day.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Back, back! â€™ cried Aragorn. Turn! Turn if you can! â€™ He drove his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paddle into the water, trying to hold the boat and bring it round.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™I am out of my reckoning,â€™ he said to Frodo. â€™I did not know that we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had come so far: Anduin flows faster than I thought. Sarn Gebir must be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">close at hand already.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">With great efforts they checked the boats and slowly brought them<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">about; but at first they could make only small headway against the current,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and all the time they were carried nearer and nearer to the eastern bank.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Now dark and ominous it loomed up in the night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™All together, paddle! â€™ shouted Boromir. â€™Paddle! Or we shall be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">driven on the shoals.â€™ Even as he spoke Frodo felt the keel beneath him<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grate upon stone.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At that moment there was a twang of bowstrings: several arrows whistled<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over them, and some fell among them. One smote Frodo between the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shoulders<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and he lurched forward with a cry, letting go his paddle: but the arrow fell<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">back, foiled by his hidden coat of mail. Another passed through Aragorn's<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hood; and a third stood fast in the gunwale of the second boat, close by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Merry's hand. Sam thought he could glimpse black figures running to and fro<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' Yrch !' said Legolas, falling into his own tongue.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ores! ' cried Gimli.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gollum's doing, I'll be bound.' said Sam to Frodo. 'And a nice place<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to choose, too. The River seems set on taking us right into their arms! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They all leaned forward straining at the paddles: even Sam took a hand.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Every moment they expected to feel the bite of black -feathered arrows. Many<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">whined overhead or struck the water nearby; but there were no more hits. It<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was dark, but not too dark for the night-eyes of Ores, and in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">star-glimmer they must have offered their cunning foes some mark, unless it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was that the grey cloaks Of Lurien and the grey timber of the elf- wrought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boats defeated the malice of the archers of Mordor.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Stroke by stroke they laboured on. In the darkness it was hard to be<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sure that they were indeed moving at all; but slowly the swirl of the water<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grew less, and the shadow of the eastern bank faded back into the night. At<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">last, as far as they could judge, they had reached the middle of the stream<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again and had driven their boats back some distance above the jutting rocks.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then half turning they thrust them with all their strength towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western shore. Under the shadow Of bushes leaning out over the water they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halted and drew breath.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Legolas laid down his paddle and took up the bow that he had brought<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from Lurien. Then he sprang ashore and climbed a few paces up the bank.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Stringing the bow and fitting an arrow he turned, peering back over the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">nothing could be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked up at the Elf standing tall above him, as he gazed into<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the night, seeking a mark to shoot at. His head was dark, crowned with sharp<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">white stars that glittered in the black pools of the sky behind. But now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rising and sailing up from the South the great clouds advanced, sending out<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark outriders into the starry fields. A sudden dread fell on the Company.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">' Elbereth Gilthoniel!' sighed Legolas as he looked up. Even as he did<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">so, a dark shape, like a cloud and yet not a cloud, for it moved far more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">swiftly, came out of the blackness in the South, and sped towards the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Company, blotting out all light as it approached. Soon it appeared as a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great winged creature, blacker than the pits in the night. Fierce voices<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rose up to greet it from across the water. Frodo felt a sudden chill running<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through him and clutching at his heart; there was a deadly cold, like the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly the great bow of Lurien sang. Shrill went the arrow from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">elven-string. Frodo looked up. Almost above him the winged shape swerved.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a harsh croaking scream, as it fell out of the air, vanishing down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into the gloom of the eastern shore. The sky was clean again. There was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tumult of many voices far away, cursing and wailing in the darkness, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">then silence. Neither shaft nor cry came again from the east that night.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">After a while Aragorn led the boats back upstream. They felt their way<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">along the waterâ€™s edge for some distance, until they found a small shallow<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bay. A few low trees grew there close to the water, and behind them rose a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was useless to attempt to move further by night. They made no camp and lit<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Praised be the bow of Galadriel, and the hand and eye of Legolas ! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">said Gimli, as he munched a wafer of lembas. 'That was a mighty shot in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dark, my friend!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But who can say what it hit?' said Legolas.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I cannot,' said Gimli. 'But I am glad that the shadow came no nearer.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">I liked it not at all. Too much it reminded me of the shadow in Moria â€” the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trickling from the terraces further inland.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">One by one Boromir and Aragorn carried the boats, while the others<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">toiled and scrambled after them with the baggage. At last all was removed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and laid on the portage-way. Then with little further hindrance, save from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprawling briars and many fallen stones, they moved forward all together.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fog still hung in veils upon the crumbling rock-wall, and to their left mist<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shrouded the River: they could hear it rushing and foaming over the sharp<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shelves and stony teeth of Sarn Gebir, but they could not see it. Twice they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">made the journey, before all was brought safe to the southern landing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There the portage-way, turning back to the water-side, ran gently down<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the shallow edge of a little pool. It seemed to have been scooped in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">river-side, not by hand, but by the water swirling down from Sarn Gebir<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">against a low pier of rock that jutted out some way into the stream. Beyond<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it the shore rose sheer into a grey cliff, and there was no further passage<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for those on foot.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Already the short afternoon was past, and a dim cloudy dusk was closing<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in. They sat beside the water listening to the confused rush and roar of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Rapids hidden in the mist; they were tired and sleepy, and their hearts were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">as gloomy as the dying day.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, here we are, and here we must pass another night,' said Boromir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We need sleep, and even if Aragorn had a mind to pass the Gates of Argonath<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by night, we are all too tired-except, no doubt, our sturdy dwarf.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gimli made no reply: he was nodding as he sat.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let us rest as much as we can now,' said Aragorn. 'Tomorrow we must<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">journey by day again. Unless the weather changes once more and cheats us, we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall have a good chance of slipping through, unseen by any eyes on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastern shore. But tonight two must watch together in turns: three hours off<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and one on guard.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nothing happened that night worse than a brief drizzle of rain an hour<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before dawn. As soon as it was fully light they started. Already the fog was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thinning. They kept as close as they could to the western side, and they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">could see the dim shapes of the low cliffs rising ever higher, shadowy walls<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with their feet in the hurrying river. In the mid-morning the clouds drew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">down lower, and it began to rain heavily. They drew the skin -covers over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their boats to prevent them from being flooded, and drifted on: little could<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">be seen before them or about them through the grey falling curtains.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The rain, however, did not last long. Slowly the sky above grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lighter, and then suddenly the clouds broke, and their draggled fringes<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trailed away northward up the River. The fogs and mists were gone. Before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the travellers lay a wide ravine, with great rocky sides to which clung,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon shelves and in narrow crevices, a few thrawn trees. The channel grew<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">narrower and the River swifter. Now they were speeding along with little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hope of stopping or turning, whatever they might meet ahead. Over them was a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">lane of pale-blue sky, around them the dark overshadowed River, and before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them black, shutting out the sun, the hills of Emyn Muil, in which no<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">opening could be seen.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo peering forward saw in the distance two great rocks approaching:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like great pinnacles or pillars of stone they seemed. Tall and sheer and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ominous they stood upon either side of the stream. A narrow gap appeared<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between them, and the River swept the boats towards it.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Behold the Argonath, the Pillars of the Kings! ' cried Aragorn. 'We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall pass them soon. Keep the boats in line, and as far apart as you can!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hold the middle of the stream! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">As Frodo was borne towards them the great pillars rose like towers to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">meet him. Giants they seemed to him, vast grey figures silent but<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">threatening. Then he saw that they were indeed shaped and fashioned: the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">craft and power of old had wrought upon them, and still they preserved<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through the suns and rains of forgotten years the mighty likenesses in which<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they had been hewn. Upon great pedestals founded in the deep waters stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">two great kings of stone: still with blurred eyes and crannied brows they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">frowned upon the North. The left hand of each was raised palm outwards in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gesture of warning; in each right hand there was an axe; upon each head<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there was a crumbling helm and crown. Great power and majesty they still<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">wore, the silent wardens of a long -vanished kingdom. Awe and fear fell upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo, and he cowered down, shutting his eyes and not daring to look up as<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sentinels of NÂ®menor. So they passed into the dark chasm of the Gates.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sheer rose the dreadful cliffs to unguessed heights on either side. Far<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">off was the dim sky. The black waters roared and echoed, and a wind screamed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">over them. Frodo crouching over his knees heard Sam in front muttering and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">groaning: 'What a place! What a horrible place! Just let me get out of this<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boat, and I'll never wet my toes in a puddle again, let alone a river! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Fear not!' said a strange voice behind him. Frodo turned and saw<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Strider, and yet not Strider; for the weatherworn Ranger was no longer<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there. In the stern sat Aragorn son of Arathorn, proud and erect, guiding<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blowing in the wind, a light was in his eyes: a king returning from exile to<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his own land.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™Fear not! ' he said. 'Long have I desired to look upon the likenesses<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Isildur and Anbrion, my sires of old. Under their shadow Elessar, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elfstone son of Arathorn of the House of Valandil Isildurâ€™s son heir of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Elendil, has nought to dread! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then the light of his eyes faded, and he spoke to himself: 'Would that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Gandalf were here! How my heart yearns for Minas Anor and the walls of my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own city! But whither now shall I go? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The chasm was long and dark, and filled with the noise of wind and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">rushing water and echoing stone. It bent somewhat towards the west so that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">at first all was dark ahead; but soon Frodo saw a tall gap of light before<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">him, ever growing. Swiftly it drew near, and suddenly the boats shot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">through, out into a wide clear light.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The sun, already long fallen from the noon, was shining in a windy sky.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The pent waters spread out into a long oval lake, pale Nen Hithoel, fenced<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">by steep grey hills whose sides were clad with trees, but their heads were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bare, cold-gleaming in the sunlight. At the far southern end rose three<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">them, an island in the waters, about which the flowing River flung pale<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shimmering arms. Distant but deep there came up on the wind a roaring sound<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">like the roll of thunder heard far away.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Behold Tol Brandir! ' said Aragorn, pointing south to the tall peak.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Upon the left stands Amon Lhaw, and upon the right is Amon Hen the Hills of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Hearing and of Sight. In the days of the great kings there were high seats<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon them, and watch was kept there. But it is said that no foot of man or<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beast has ever been set upon Tol Brandir. Ere the shade of night falls we<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall come to them. I hear the endless voice of Rauros calling.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The Company rested now for a while, drifting south on the current that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flowed through the middle of the lake. They ate some food, and then they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">took to their paddles and hastened on their way. The sides of the westward<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills fell into shadow, and the Sun grew round and red. Here and there a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">misty star peered out. The three peaks loomed before them, darkling in the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">twilight. Rauros was roaring with a great voice. Already night was laid on<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the flowing waters when the travellers came at last under the shadow of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hills.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The tenth day of their journey was over. Wilderland was behind them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They could go no further without choice between the east-way and the west.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The last stage of the Quest was before them.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Chapter 10. The Breaking of the Fellowship<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn led them to the right arm of the River. Here upon its western<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">side under the shadow of Tol Brandir a green lawn ran down to the water from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the feet of Amon Hen. Behind it rose the first gentle slopes of the hill<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">clad with trees, and trees marched away westward along the curving shores of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the lake. A little spring fell tumbling down and fed the grass.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Here we will rest tonight,' said Aragorn. 'This is the lawn of Parth<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Galen: a fair place in the summer days of old. Let us hope that no evil has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yet come here.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">They drew up their boats on the green banks, and beside them they made<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their camp. They set a watch, but had no sight nor sound of their enemies.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">If Gollum had contrived to follow them, he remained unseen and unheard.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Nonetheless as the night wore on Aragorn grew uneasy, tossing often in his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sleep and waking. In the small hours he got up and came to Frodo, whose turn<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it was to watch.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why are you waking? ' asked Frodo. 'It is not your watch.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not know,â€™ answered Aragorn; 'but a shadow and a threat has been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">growing in my sleep. It would be well to draw your sword.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why? â€™ said Frodo. 'Are enemies at hand? â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Let us see what Sting may show,' answered Aragorn.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo then drew the elf-blade from its sheath. To his dismay the edges<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gleamed dimly in the night. 'Ores! â€™ he said. 'Not very near, and yet too<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">near, it seems.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I feared as much,' said Aragorn. 'But maybe they are not on this side<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of the River. The light of Sting is faint, and it may point to no more than<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">spies of Mordor roaming on the slopes of Amon Lhaw. I have never heard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">before of Ores upon Amon Hen. Yet who knows what may happen in these<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">evil<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">days, now that Minas Tirith no longer holds secure the passages of Anduin.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">We must go warily tomorrow.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The day came like fire and smoke. Low in the East there were black bars<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of cloud like the fumes of a great burning. The rising sun lit them from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">beneath with flames of murky red; but soon it climbed above them into a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">eastward and gazed at the tall island. Its sides sprang sheer out of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">When they had eaten, Aragorn called the Company together. 'The day has<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come at last,' he said: 'the day of choice which we have long delayed. What<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shall now become of our Company that has travelled so far in fellowship?<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shall we turn west with Boromir and go to the wars of Gondor; or turn east<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to the Fear and Shadow; or shall we break our fellowship and go this way and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">that as each may choose? Whatever we do must be done soon. We cannot<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halt here. The enemy is on the eastern shore, we know; but I fear that the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Ores may already be on this side of the water.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was a long silence in which no one spoke or moved.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Well, Frodo,' said Aragorn at last. 'I fear that the burden is laid<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were here now the choice would still wait on you. Such is your fate.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo did not answer at once. Then he spoke slowly. 'I know that haste<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and I will speak. Let me be alone! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Aragorn looked at him with kindly pity. 'Very well, Frodo son of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo sat for a moment with his head bowed. Sam, who had been watching<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Presently Frodo got up and walked away; and Sam saw that while the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Wandering aimlessly at first in the wood, Frodo found that his feet<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He sat down upon the stone and cupped his chin in his hands, staring<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">still he was no nearer to a choice.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Suddenly he awoke from his thoughts: a strange feeling came to him that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I was afraid for you, Frodo,' he said, coming forward. 'If Aragorn is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">right and Ores are near, then none of us should wander alone, and you least<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of all: so much depends on you. And my heart too is heavy. May I stay now<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">may perhaps find wisdom.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You are kind,' answered Frodo. 'But I do not think that any speech<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will help me. For I know what I should do, but I am afraid of doing it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir stood silent. Rauros roared endlessly on. The wind murmured in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">â€™I think I know already what counsel you would give, Boromir,' said<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Warning? Warning against what? ' said Boromir sharply.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Against delay. Against the way that seems easier. Against refusal of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the burden that is laid on me. Against -well, if it must be said, against<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trust in the strength and truth of Men.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Yet that strength has long protected you far away in your little<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I do not doubt the valour of your people. But the world is changing.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The walls of Minas Tirith may be strong, but they are not strong enough. If<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they fail, what then? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'We shall fall in battle valiantly. Yet there is still hope that they<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will not fail.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No hope while the Ring lasts,' said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Ah! The Ring! ' said Boromir, his eyes lighting. 'The Ring! Is it not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt for so small a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thing? So small a thing! And I have seen it only for an instant in the House<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Elrond. Could I not have a sight of it again? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo looked up. His heart went suddenly cold. He caught the strange<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gleam in Boromir's eyes, yet his face was still kind and friendly. 'It is<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'As you wish. I care not,' said Boromir. 'Yet may I not even speak of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it? For you seem ever to think only of its power in the hands of the Enemy:<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of its evil uses not of its good. The world is changing, you say. Minas<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Tirith will fall, if the Ring lasts. But why? Certainly, if the Ring were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with the Enemy. But why, if it were with us? '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Were you not at the Council? ' answered Frodo. 'Because we cannot use<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it, and what is done with it turns to evil.â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir got up and walked about impatiently. 'So you go on,' he cried.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Gandalf, Elrond â€” all these folk have taught you to say so. For themselves<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they may be right. These elves and half-elves and wizards, they would come<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to grief perhaps. Yet often I doubt if they are wise and not merely timid.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But each to his own kind. True-hearted Men, they will not be corrupted. We<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of Minas Tirith have been staunch through long years of trial. We do not<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">desire the power of wizard-lords, only strength to defend ourselves,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">strength in a just cause. And behold! in our need chance brings to light the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">-Ring of Power. It is a gift, I say; a gift to the foes of Mordor. It is mad<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not to use it, to use the power of the Enemy against him. The fearless, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ruthless, these alone will achieve victory. What could not a warrior do in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">this hour, a great leader? What could not Aragorn do? Or if he refuses, why<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not Boromir? The Ring would give me power of Command. How I would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">drive the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hosts of Mordor, and all men would flock to my banner!'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Boromir strode up and down, speaking ever more loudly: Almost he seemed<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">to have forgotten Frodo, while his talk dwelt on walls and weapons, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mustering of men; and he drew plans for great alliances and glorious<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">victories to be; and he cast down Mordor, and became himself a mighty king,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">benevolent and wise. Suddenly he stopped and waved his arms.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'And they tell us to throw it away!' he cried. 'I do not say destroy<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">it. That might be well, if reason could show any hope of doing so. It does<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not. The only plan that is proposed to us is that a halfling should walk<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blindly into Mordor and offer the Enemy every chance of recapturing it for<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself. Folly!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Surely you see it, my friend?' he said, turning now suddenly to Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">again. 'You say that you are afraid. If it is so, the boldest should pardon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">you. But is it not really your good sense that revolts?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No, I am afraid,' said Frodo. 'Simply afraid. But I am glad to have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">heard you speak so fully. My mind is clearer now.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Then you will come to Minas Tirith? ' cried Boromir. His eyes were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shining and his face eager.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You misunderstand me,â€™ said Frodo.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'But you will come, at least for a while? ' Boromir persisted. 'My city<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">is not far now; and it is little further from there to Mordor than from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here. We have been long in the wilderness, and you need news of what the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Enemy is doing before you make a move. Come with me, Frodo,' he said.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'You<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">need rest before your venture, if go you must.â€™ He laid his hand on the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hobbit's shoulder in friendly fashion; but Frodo felt the hand trembling<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with suppressed excitement. He stepped quickly away, and eyed with alarm the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">tall Man, nearly twice his height and many times his match in strength.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Why are you so unfriendly? â€™ said Boromir. 'I am a true man, neither<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">thief nor tracker. I need your Ring: that you know now; but I give you my<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">word that I do not desire to keep it. Will you not at least let me make<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">trial of my plan? Lend me the Ring! â€™<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'No! no! ' cried Frodo. 'The Council laid it upon me to bear it.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'It is by our own folly that the Enemy will defeat us,â€™ cried Boromir.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'How it angers me! Fool! Obstinate fool! Running wilfully to death and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mining our cause. If any mortals have claim to the Ring, it is the men of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">NÂ®menor, and not Halflings. It is not yours save by unhappy chance. It might<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">have been mine. It should be mine. Give it to me ! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo did not answer, but moved away till the great flat stone stood<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">between them. 'Come, come, my friend! ' said Boromir in a softer voice. 'Why<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">not get rid of it? Why not be free of your doubt and fear? You can lay the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">blame on me, if you will. You can say that I was too strong and took it by<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">force. For I am too strong for you, halfling,' he cried; and suddenly he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sprang over the stone and leaped at Frodo. His fair and pleasant face was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">hideously changed; a raging fire was in his eyes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo dodged aside and again put the stone between them. There was only<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">one thing he could do: trembling he pulled out the Ring upon its chain and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">quickly slipped it on his finger, even as Boromir sprang at him again. The<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Man gasped, stared for a moment amazed, and then ran wildly about, seeking<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">here and there among the rocks and trees.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Miserable trickster!' he shouted. 'Let me get my hands on you! Now I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">see your mind. You will take the Ring to Sauron and sell us all. You have<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">only waited your chance to leave us in the lurch. Curse you and all<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">halflings to death and darkness ! ' Then, catching his foot on a stone, he<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fell sprawling and lay upon his face. For a while he was as still as if his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">own curse had struck him down; then suddenly he wept.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He rose and passed his hand over his eyes, dashing away the tears.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'What have I said? ' he cried. 'What have I done? Frodo, Frodo! ' he called.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Come back! A madness took me, but it has passed. Come back! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">There was no answer. Frodo did not even hear his cries. He was already<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">far away, leaping blindly up the path to the hill-top. Terror and grief<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shook him, seeing in his thought the mad fierce face of Boromir, and his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Soon he came out alone on the summit of Amon Hen, and halted, gasping<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">for breath. He saw as through a mist a wide flat circle, paved with mighty<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">flags, and surrounded with a crumbling battlement; and in the middle, set<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
