<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Up he went and sat upon the ancient chair, feeling like a lost child that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had clambered upon the throne of mountain -kings.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At first he could see little. He seemed to be in a world of mist in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">which there were only shadows: the Ring was upon him. Then here and there<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the mist gave way and he saw many visions: small and clear as if they were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">under his eyes upon a table, and yet remote. There was no sound, only bright<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">living images. The world seemed to have shrunk and fallen silent. He was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sitting upon the Seat of Seeing, on Amon Hen, the Hill of the Eye of the Men<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">of NÂ®menor. Eastward he looked into wide uncharted lands, nameless plains,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and forests unexplored. Northward he looked, and the Great River lay like a<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">ribbon beneath him, and the Misty Mountains stood small and hard as broken<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">teeth. Westward he looked and saw the broad pastures of Rohan; and Orthanc,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the pinnacle of Isengard, like a black spike. Southward he looked, and below<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">his very feet the Great River curled like a toppling wave and plunged over<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the falls of Rauros into a foaming pit; a glimmering rainbow played upon the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fume. And Ethir Anduin he saw, the mighty delta of the River, and myriads of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">sea-birds whirling like a white dust in the sun, and beneath them a green<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and silver sea, rippling in endless lines.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">But everywhere he looked he saw the signs of war. The Misty Mountains<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">were crawling like anthills: ores were issuing out of a thousand holes.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Under the boughs of Mirkwood there was deadly strife of Elves and Men and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">fell beasts. The land of the Beornings was aflame; a cloud was over Moria;<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">smoke rose on the borders of Lurien.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Horsemen were galloping on the grass of Rohan; wolves poured from<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Isengard. From the havens of Harad ships of war put out to sea; and out of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the East Men were moving endlessly: swordsmen, spearmen, bowmen upon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">horses,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">chariots of chieftains and laden wains. All the power of the Dark Lord was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in motion. Then turning south again he beheld Minas Tirith. Far away it<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">seemed, and beautiful: white-walled, many -towered, proud and fair upon its<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">mountain- seat; its battlements glittered with steel, and its turrets were<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bright with many banners. Hope leaped in his heart. But against Minas Tirith<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">was set another fortress, greater and more strong. Thither, eastward,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">unwilling his eye was drawn. It passed the ruined bridges of Osgiliath, the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">grinning gates of Minas Morgul. and the haunted Mountains, and it looked<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">upon Gorgoroth, the valley of terror in the Land of Mordor. Darkness lay<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">there under the Sun. Fire glowed amid the smoke. Mount Doom was burning,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">a great reek rising. Then at last his gaze was held: wall upon wall,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">battlement upon battlement, black, immeasurably strong, mountain of iron,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">gate of steel, tower of adamant, he saw it: Barad-dyr, Fortress of Sauron.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">All hope left him.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">And suddenly he felt the Eye. There was an eye in the Dark Tower that<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">did not sleep. He knew that it had become aware of his gaze. A fierce eager<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">will was there. It leaped towards him; almost like a finger he felt it,<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">searching for him. Very soon it would nail him down, know just exactly where<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">he was. Amon Lhaw it touched. It glanced upon Tol Brandir he threw himself<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">from the seat, crouching, covering his head with his grey hood.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He heard himself crying out: Never, never! Or was it: Verily I come, I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">come to you ? He could not tell. Then as a flash from some other point of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">power there came to his mind another thought: Take it off! Take it off!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Fool, take it off! Take off the Ring!<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The two powers strove in him. For a moment, perfectly balanced between<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">their piercing points, he writhed, tormented. Suddenly he was aware of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">himself again. Frodo, neither the Voice nor the Eye: free to choose, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">with one remaining instant in which to do so. He took the Ring off his<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">finger. He was kneeling in clear sunlight before the high seat. A black<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">shadow seemed to pass like an arm above him; it missed Amon Hen and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">groped<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">out west, and faded. Then all the sky was clean and blue and birds sang in<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">every tree.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Frodo rose to his feet. A great weariness was on him, but his will was<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">firm and his heart lighter. He spoke aloud to himself. T will do now what I<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">must,' he said. This at least is plain: the evil of the Ring is already at<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">work even in the Company, and the Ring must leave them before it does more<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">harm. I will go alone. Some I cannot trust, and those I can trust are too<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">dear to me: poor old Sam, and Merry and Pippin. Strider, too: his heart<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">yearns for Minas Tirith, and he will be needed there, now Boromir has fallen<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">into evil. I will go alone. At once.'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">He went quickly down the path and came back to the lawn where Boromir<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">had found him. Then he halted, listening. He thought he could hear cries and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">calls from the woods near the shore below.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'They'll be hunting for me,' he said. T wonder how long I have been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">away. Hours, I should think.' He hesitated. 'What can I do? ' he muttered.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'I must go now or I shall never go. I shan't get a chance again. I hate<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">leaving them, and like this without any explanation. But surely they will<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">understand. Sam will. And what else can I do?'<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Slowly he drew out the Ring and put it on once more. He vanished and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">passed down the hill, less than a rustle of the wind.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The others remained long by the river -side. For some time they had been<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">silent, moving restlessly about; but now they were sitting in a circle, and<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">they were talking. Every now and again they made efforts to speak of other<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">can't jump waterfalls. He's got no gear. So he's got to get back to the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">boats. Back to the boats! Back to the boats, Sam, like lightning! '<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Sam turned and bolted back down the path. He fell and cut his knees. Up<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3">'Coming, Mr. Frodo! Coming! ' called Sam, and flung himself from the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">So Frodo and Sam set off on the last stage of the Quest together. Frodo<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">paddled away from the shore, and the River bore them swiftly away, down the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">western arm, and past the frowning cliffs of Tol Brandir. The roar of the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">great falls drew nearer. Even with such help as Sam could give, it was hard<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">work to pass across the current at the southward end of the island and drive<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the boat eastward towards the far shore.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">At length they came to land again upon the southern slopes of Amon<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Lhaw. There they found a shelving shore, and they drew the boat out, high<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Then shouldering their burdens, they set off, seeking a path that would<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">bring them over the grey hills of the Emyn Muil, and down into the Land of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Shadow.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>

<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">Here ends the first part of the history of the War of the Ring.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The second part is called THE TWO TOWERS, since the events recounted<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">in it are dominated by ORTHANC, the citadel of Saruman, and the fortress<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">o/MINAS MORGUL that guards the secret entrance to Mordor; it tells of<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the deeds and perils of all the members of the now sundered fellowship, until<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">the coming of the Great Darkness.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3"><br>
</span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">The third part tells of the last defence against the Shadow, and the<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
<p class="p4"><span class="s3">end of the mission of the Ring-bearer in THE RETURN OF THE KING.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></span></p>
